reviewText: There is a sweep and grandeur to "Pride and Prejudice," which gives the movie an instant appeal.  Based on the Jane Austin classic, the scenes move forward at a brisk pace to keep our interest, but it is the portrayals that make the movie continually engaging.The Bennet family is of small means.  The father, and, particularly, the mother, are interested in seeking suitors for each of their five daughters.  Focus is primarily on Elizabeth (Keira Knightly), or "Lizzie," the protagonist, who is treated like the ugly duckling of the five.  She is captivating for her wit and intelligence. We immediately have an affinity to her, for she never suffers fools gladly, and she has the brazenness to confront those of higher standing who may belittle her.  So, the situation is ripe when an aristocrat, Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyed) and his friend, Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods), pay a visit to the household.  After some social invitations and gatherings, Mr. Bingley takes a fancy to Jane, her favored elder sister, but it provides opportunities for Lizzie to mingle with the seemingly cold and aloof, Mr. Darcy.  There are many instances when the two meet and work out their desires and distastes for one another.  He regards her as saucy; she finds  him to be arrogant.  Many partial disclosures of his past help to make a portrait of him that she increasingly detests.  There is a diversion when a guest suitor, Mr. Collins, a respectable and scrupulous moral figure, visits the household and forces his affections upon her.  There is also a key crisis when the youngest daughter is taken by a suitor in a situation that may be described as compromising.  Once affections are fully realized, Lizzie is confronted by Mr. Darcy's aunt, the indomitable Lady Catherine de Bourg (Judi[th] Dench).The new production of "Pride and Prejudice" has many merits.  The scenes unfold with a grace and movement that is instantly appealing.  Especially the dancing and mingling scenes are choreographed with finesse.  Similar British movies with great acclaim are sometimes tedious affairs, but this one is winning.  The characters, including the nervous mother, the affectionate father, and the likable Mr. Bingley, are exemplary draws.  The portrayals, especially by Knightly, MacFadyed, and Dench are enthralling.  The novel, which I confess I've never read, is probably followed closely--it would be hard to imagine otherwise--but I don't wish to put up pretenses or consult other reviews.  However, it is easy to appreciate the skillfulness that Austin uses through her mouthpiece, Elizabeth, to confront the attitudes and mores of the upper classes.  Maintaining her charm and dignity, she is able to answer to the impossible standards suitors make upon their chosen mistresses for courtship.  Like "Lady Chatterly's Lover" and "Jude, the Obscure," which I have read, "Pride and Prejudice" overthrows the mores and conventions of aristocratic arrogance with style and skill.  The movie captures the spirit well.

reviewText: Once again, I have had the pleasure of finding one of Jane Austen's classic novels brought to the big screen -- and once more I couldn't fancy myself happier.  Ah- would that there were hundreds of such renderings!Jane Austen's PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is amongst all in the whole vast world of literature the dearest to my heart.  Therefore, even a version that deigns tamper with a decade-old perfection serves to excite my interest.  Indeed- for I was simply ecstatic when, in 1995, A&E; and the BBC collaborated to create a grand and brilliantly performed portrayal of that book.  At a length of nearly 6 hours, no aspect of this wonderful story had been neglected - and I knew that such a true commitment to the literature, combined with such passion for the tale, is a precious rarity in film. Now, years hence, that 1995 picture still resonates.  Comparisons are to be inevitable, no doubt.  I'd already been well reconciled to the fact that a two-hour version of the story, no matter how well done, could only suffer in the comparison to that A&E; production.  I therefore resolved to judge this movie by its own qualities -- And what fine qualities they turned out being!  Brilliantly directed by Joe Wright, this sensual and earthy interpretation just warms my soul.Keira Knightley takes on the role of our heroine: Elizabeth Bennet, the 2nd oldest of the five daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Bennet (Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn).  Matthew MacFadyen plays our hero: Mr. Darcy, the handsome and aloof owner of a great estate in the north of England.  The two go down the dance, waltzing through misunderstanding and mischance - wit and romance, dexterously stepping along fine lines of social propriety and distinction of class, through rejection and redemption, conjuring the many diversions of country life in Regency England. Yes, we Janeites all know the story.The casting herein is essentially very agreeable.  Knightly is lovely and makes for a fine Elizabeth, and the camera adores her- though when Darcy finds her appearance only "tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me," it strikes one as rather unbelievable.  She effortlessly captures Lizzy's wry spirit and spark of humor, though I must admit I found her a little bit wanting in that quiet depth or the brilliance of mind that role calls for.MacFadyen's take on Darcy is more dark and brooding than actors in the past have portrayed him.  And though I enjoyed watching him, I cannot say that he did very well in expressing the changes Mr. Darcy undergoes:  I did not see an aristocrat stuffed with pride, whose passion for Elizabeth blossoms as he becomes transformed by her spirited influence.  Rather, he just seems to convey the same brooding manner all along - and his only problem appears to be that he is misunderstood.As for the supporting players, I think Sutherland was excellent as the bemused Mr. Bennet - and his scene with Lizzy at the end was exquisitely drawn.  Blethyn played her part very well, too - her Mrs. Bennet was every bit as laughable and endearing as Austen wrote her.  Judi Dench was wonderfully formidable as Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  The roles of Mr. Collins, Jane Bennet, Mr. Bingley and Wickham were also excellently played.Visually, this film is just stunning.  I've rarely, if ever, seen more exquisite scenery in a movie. The camera work is mesmerizing.  The cinematography here is certainly Oscar-worthy.  I can even forgive the overly rusticated state (complete with chickens, pigs, & all manner of livestock traipsing throughout the house) of Longbourn, the Bennet family home.  This, in fact, only serves to give charm to this beautiful and totally unique rendition of a most beloved story.

reviewText: In this latest version of Pride and Prejudice, Director Joe Wright uses impressive visuals and sumptuous period locales to create an exquisite wide-screen spectacle, filling it with details that illustrate important sociological information about its central family, the Bennets. From the movie's mist-filled and dream-like opening moments to its marvelous ball sequence and the predictable but nonetheless glorious ending, Pride & Prejudice is an absolutely sumptuous evocation of Jane Austen's milieu, and is a captivatingly youthful spin without compromising the novel's late-eighteenth-century manners; it also deserves to be remembered as one of the very best screen adaptations of this book so far.Mrs. Bennet (Brenda Blethyn) is fraught with worry. The mother of five daughters has proved to be a little bit much for her and if they don't start marrying soon, the family will be ruined. The father (Donald Sutherland) stays out of the way, hoping his daughters somehow overcome societal prejudice against their gender and make something of their minds.  Headstrong Elizabeth (Kira Knightley) has done just that. Smart, feisty, and fiercely independent, Lizzie promises herself that she won't be one to settle.When Lizzie's older sister, Jane (Rosamund Pike), meets the wealthy Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods) at a dance, their future as a couple seems predetermined. But when Lizzie is introduced to the gloomy and standoffish Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen), an instant dislike is established. Lizzie and Mr. Darcy must overcome quite a few obstacles before they can transcend their dislike of each other, not the least of which is unsuitable suitor Mr. Collins (a wonderfully comic Tom Hollander) and Darcy's formidable aunt Lady Catherine (Dame Judi Dench) who tells Lizzie that she is of an "inferior class." Of course, Lizzie's frosty rejection of Darcy eventually thaws when he confesses his passion for her one evening on a misty moor.Pride and Prejudice really works because of the marvelously impassioned performances from its two sexy leads. As the strong-willed Elizabeth, Knightley is tantalizing and seductive, so perfectly fitting into her 19th century Austen surroundings; she catches Elizabeth's essential skittishness and youthful braggadocio, making her final conversion with Darcy all the more moving. Macfadyen as Darcy is a more conflicted, softer figure than Colin Firth's indelibly etched performance, but Macfadyen is much earthier and sexier, and his portrayal is one that fits the movie's more realistic mood.Pride and Prejudice benefits from Wright's intensely visual approach that manages to meld realism with romance in a canny balance. The movie has a youthful essence, as well as providing a richly detailed setting. Scenes barely sketched in Austen's dialogue-heavy, description-light prose leap fully detailed onto the screen, thanks to Sarah Greenwood's terrific production design and Jacqueline Durran's textured costumes. This is a unique, gorgeously evocative, and quite accomplished film, which should satisfy even the most rabid Austen-ophiles - just lovely. Mike Leonard March 06.
summary: "She is tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me."

reviewText: Pride and Prejudice is a great movie! Both Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen give great performances. Rosamund Pike as the elder sister, Jane, is a delight. Simon Woods as Bingley is wrongly portrayed as rather foolish, but he is absolutely cute and adorable about Jane, so it's all good. Claudie Blakely (Charlotte Lucas/Collins) gives a much more sympathetic performance than any other Charlotte before her. The friendship between Lizzy and Charlotte feels totally right and believable.I feel it is my duty to warn you that the ending scenes are very close to horrendous, at least to Janeites. The dialogue is cheesy, and the second proposal is in the early morning, with both Lizzy and Darcy in their nightclothes. Darcy especially made me cringe. When the movie all of a sudden jumps from Mr. Bennet's consent to Pemberley, you have to cringe again. And then grit your teeth when Darcy and Lizzy are again in their nightclothes, and saying lines that are so syrupy you want to laugh, but have to cry b/c it's P+P that this crew is messing up.There are many things wrong with the movie, but I love a lot of things in it too. For instance, when Lizzy sees Darcy at Rosings. The scene when Bingley and Darcy practice Bingley's proposal to Jane. The scene when, in church, Fitzwilliam tells Lizzy about Darcy's separation of Bingley and Jane.A must for die-hard Janeites, just ignore the ending.
summary: Loved it, but BEWARE of cheesy ending!! (spoilers)

reviewText: Of the four versions of "Pride and Prejudice" I have seen (1940, 1980, 1995, 2005), this one is definitely the nadir. To begin with, it's astonishingly ugly. It looks like the Middle Ages in Asia rather than like England of the early nineteenth century. Even after making the usual allowances for omissions and changes during the adaptation, the screenplay departs from Jane's original in a most deplorable way. It is this version, not the 1940 one, which is the real travesty, if not in terms of plot at all events in terms of characters.Whoever had the bright idea of casting Keira Knightley as Lizzy did a great disservice to the future generations. I shudder to think how many people will see this movie without any prior knowledge of the novel and will think, quite mistakenly, that Keira's portrayal has anything to do with Jane's; if they ever come to read the book later, they would probably be too full of pride and prejudice to really appreciate it. Keira's vapid performance, rife with hideous grins that apparently pass for smiles, is fully matched by the worst Darcy imaginable. The proud and conceited gentleman has been scaled down to a timid and tedious creature.The supporting cast, despite the presence of such illustrious names like Donald Sutherland (Mr Bennet who speaks his generally witty lines with a funereal air) and Judi Dench (Lady Catherine who sounds much more like Lady Macbeth), is no improvement over the weak principals. There is not a trace of Mr Collins' trademark pomposity or Mrs Bennet's equally typical (and fake) hysteria. Jane is supposed to be a placid creature, but is this one entirely devoid of life! The whole cast speak their lines in the most contrived and unnatural manner. All grace, charm and vivacity of the original have been lost.There is nothing redeeming about this movie (except, perhaps, Lydia and the interlude with the marble statues). In addition to the fabulous vapidity of the acting, this includes the mediocre production, the clumsy direction, the clipped and simplified dialogue. It's all matter of taste of course. But my idea of Pride and Prejudice has nothing to do with anorexic Lizzy, moronic Darcy and a bunch of talking mannequins who seem to have no idea what their lines mean. The praise lavished on this movie, by both critics and audience, is something I really don't understand.

reviewText: Oddly enough the BBC version features a more lavish production than this movie. Also, trying to condense the book into 2 hrs  cuts the characters into 2 dimesionals. This movie feels more like a stage production with the acting. Donald Sutherland and Judi Dench are the sole exceptions. Kiera Knightley does a good job but when compared to Jennifer Ehle - well no one compares to her acting. The Mr. Darcy in this movie looks incredible as does the handsome actor who plays Mr. Wickham yet even their acting is stiff though Darcy's gets better towards the middle half. This whole movie feels rushed - in a matter of 10 minutes we are introduced to Mr. Collins and then Mr. Wickham. We also only get one Bingley sister instead of 2.This could've been an incredible version but it was very disappointing. My sole gripe is not being as faithful to  the classic book as it should. I could overlook the acting and the sets if only this movie didn't cut and rearrange the book.
summary: Looks pretty but cuts out much of the book, Not enough Details

reviewText: Pride And Prejudice is an exuberant celebration of what movies do best.  In one meticulously constructed scene after another it showers viewers with eye candy and in so doing, transports them to a distant, fascinating place and time.  In a cynical age such as ours, where every image is suspect, this is more difficult than one might imagine; director Joe Wright's success is complete.Jane Austen's Pride And Prejudice has demonstrated Rocky-esque box office endurance.  Were she alive today, Austen might marvel at our attraction to this tale of marriage as business, crushing social stratification, and nuanced mannerisms - told with precision, wit, and irony - considering that our own society, though bloated with both pride and prejudice, possesses none of the refined subtleties she described.Apart from our Anglophile obsession, born of the indebtedness we feel for providing our culture, such as it is, this attraction is most easily traced to the character of Elizabeth (Keira Knightly), a smart, beautiful, and appealingly feisty young woman who holds out for love over financially-motivated marriage.  (Heresy!)  While older sister Jane (Rosamund Pike) may be lovelier, we root for Liz as she battles uphill. Her triumph does not seem facile, Liz is tested and must grow - indeed, we cheer her victory because we sense she will not abuse it.Superb performances abound, led by Judi Dench as Lady Catherine.  From her comfy chair on top of the food chain, Dench embodies the full force of social pressure as you've never seen it before - terrifying.  Matthew MacFadyen is compelling as Mr. Darcy, he has on-screen presence and commands attention with his quiet, thoughtful demeanor.  Keira Knightly carries the picture admirably, mischievous without being obnoxious, self-absorbed without being narcissistic, sharp-witted without being needlessly cynical.  Brenda Blethyn (Mrs. Bennet) is wonderfully nutty, ambitious, and calculating while Donald Sutherland (Mr. Bennet), workmanlike as ever, should have been told that a Canadian accent is not an English accent.  Tom Hollander, as Reverend Collins, isn't on camera much but is simply brilliant.Pride And Prejudice reveals a world where function follows form, not vice versa.  In one glorious scene the five Bennet sisters dance at a ball and Liz scrupulously avoids the advances of Reverend Collins while attempting to attract Darcy.  This is the carefully delineated atmosphere of Jane Austen; it's a wonderful place to visit.

reviewText: At first, you might be thinking, "Why do we need yet another remake of Pride & Prejudice?"  It's a valid question.  I mean, it hasn't been that long since the BBC remade the famous story; however, this version of the Jane Austen classic is, in my opinion, the best one yet.  From the casting, to the adaptation, to the beautiful cinematography this is a far superior film.  If you loved Austen's novel, then you will love this film.  It stays true to the book better than any version I've seen and the casting is nearly perfect.  I'm not a huge fan of Kiera Knightley, but she was wonderful as Elizabeth Bennett.  Equally as good is Rosamund Pike as the lovelorn older Bennett sister, Jane.  Whenever she is on screen she far outshines any of the other actors around her.  Of course, there's Mr. Darcy as played by Matthew Macfadyen.  Throughout the film he has to play the sourpuss and condescending Darcy who is unwilling and unable to show true emotion; however, if you really watch Macfadyen's performance you can see so much just by looking at his eyes, which convey so much that is left unsaid.  When Darcy finally does let his guard down it's almost alarming.  The entire cast of this film, which is mostly British, but with some Americans thrown in for good measure, is just wonderful.  Director Joe Wright assembled the perfect group of people to play these roles.

reviewText: I love-love-love the BBC miniseries P & P.  I could not wait for the new P & P to come out in theatres.  When it did, I was surprised to find that I love-love-love the new P & P as well.  I had people ask "Which do you like better?" and I could not answer because I loved both so much.  I recently ordered the new P & P on DVD and watched it back-to-back with the BBC miniseries to see if there was ANY way to determine if I had a preference.  In the end, I decided that I do like the BBC one a teeny-tiny bit more because I enjoy how much more exaggerated the characters are.  In the BBC version, Mrs. Bennett is more of an annoying drama queen and Mr. Collins is more repulsive (nearly impossible to imagine that "old maid" Charlotte would consent to marrying him - ugggh!).  In the new P & P, it seems more believable that Elizabeth would "come around" to Mr. Darcy because he is less "standoffish" than Colin Firth's character in the BBC version.  I enjoyed Keira Knightly in the new version but there was something about what I call Jennifer Ehle's "secret amused smile" in the BBC version that I feel really helps define Elizabeth's character.  All in all, if you're a P & P fan - you should own both.  If you are a person pressed for time - watch the shorter (new) version and if you have the time - watch the miniseries!  Above all - enjoy!

reviewText: The scenery in this version of Pride and Prejudice was absolutely gorgeous. That is the one positive comment I can give this film.But a coyly giggling Elizabeth? When did Jane Austen ever intend the strongest female character she's ever written to be reduced to a girlish and immature giggler? Elizabeth is supposed to stand out among all the other girls as clever and quick witted, not a vapid silly girl the way her sisters are depicted. After all, is Jane Austen's Elizabeth the prettiest? No. Is the the smartest? No. Is she even the most talented? No. But that was the point! She stil has so much confidence and gumption that she can tell Darcy and his aunt off with skill and articulation.And Darcy? He's supposed to be proud. Not bland and boring.The proposal scene was an utter sham. How could the makers of this movie change the articulate monologues Elizabeth and Darcy recite and cut them up into dialogues to suit the modern audience's short attention span. Couldn't they sit through the monologues and feel the full punch of the words instead of having to have them disected into a back and forth dialogue which Austen clearly did not intend for them to be.I felt like the movie was trying to shout the entire time "Look at this zoom in of the pig, look at this interesting angle of the Pemberly House from the ceiling! Look at me! There is a director for this movie! Forget about the timeless dialogue. There is a director in this movie and I won't be ignored!"

reviewText: Just for fun, I watched the Director's commentary with the film and now understand why watching this film is like looking through a broken kaleidoscope. It starts with birds chirping on a beautiful landscape, moves to an odd close up, over the shoulder, of a book Lizzie is reading, but you can't see the title of, then has her walking over a FILTHY duck pond into a working farm house, eavesdropping on her parents.The whole movie goes back and forth between modern use of cameras against a backdrop of regency styles. The family, the costumes, the houses, are all regency, while the camera work fractures the story-telling with its movement from harshly lit close ups to single hand held shots. In the commentary, even the director admits Dame Judy Dench looks awful in her close ups when she comes to visit Lizzie in the middle of the night to confront her about Darcy's proposal. He talks about getting ideas on the way to filming different scenes - like the sunlit close up of Lizzie when she travels to Derbyshire with her aunt and uncle came to him when he put his head out the car door in the sunlight when he was going to a film location.This story seems filmed a bit off the hip, or off the cuff - improvised!I still love it. The unspoiled landscapes are gorgeous. From the Longbourne house with its moat and surrounding wildlife and even the farm life to the gorgeous grecian temple in Wiltshire - I will try to go there now that I know where it is - where Darcy proposes makes me melt to the cadence of Matthew MacFadyen's voice. I want to go there just to listen to the echoes of the scene - in the rain, of course. He is a revelation as Darcy, although I can also picture him in modern terms as a spy in his series Spooks. But he is fun and sexy. The close up of his hand after he touches Elizabeth helping her into the carriage is glorious.I would recommend listening to the directors comments about ALL  his casting choices, what he feels about their performances, the design of the sets, and how he made his decisions in telling the story.  (the ribbon dyeing scene is wonderful).So I would recommend this film to anyone. But I would caution them that it is a clash of sensibilities - modern and regency.Thanks for making it.Emily Linden, RN, BA.

reviewText: I'm a serious fan of the 1995 BBC version. It's still the best P&P adaptation to date. That said, Joe Wright's updated version is the one that gets the most play in my house. The characters have been given a free run of the house. There's plenty of dancing, laughter, running about. It's Austen on hormones. The emotions are pumped up and the drama heightened. The cinematography is just gorgeous but the best element is the soundtrack, hauntingly beautiful and difficult to get out of your head. Whatever your preference, there's always room for more Jane Austen. And the sight of Darcy striding over the hill at sunrise .. a jaw-dropper.
summary: You can be a fan of both!

reviewText: For those of us who are rabid Jane Austen fans, like myself, who went in to watch this looking forward to it but not expecting much after watching the superb and nearly-flawless BBC miniseries with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth countless times, this movie was a joyous and exhilerating shock. I admit that after watching the preview and reading everything there was to read about it before it  came out, I wasn't expecting much.I was still crazy-wild to see it-it looked very romantic and come on, its Pride and Prejudice-but Matthew MacFadyen as Darcy looked plain and boring, and some of the changes to the handling of the atmostphere and everything sounded very dubious. Having said that, I went in and came out stunned. The new movie is gorgeous, tender, passionate, lovely, fun. But mostly it brought back to me a feeling of what love is really like-that understanding that we've lost so completely after hordes of mediocre and wishy-washy romantic comedies and soap operas. The only thing that has come close to re-creating that feeling is Titanic,and I thought that Pride and Prejudice did a better job. And Matthew MacFadyen was superb as Darcy. He is Darcy-he captures a different version, a different part of him than Colin Firth, but he is as utterly him as Firth was. The man was perfect-by the end of the movie you are utterly in love with him. He starts out, like the movie,a little bit of a nonentity-you're not sure whether you like him or not. Then both he and the movie pick up speed and from there it just gets better and better until the ending, which is as nearly perfect as a movie ending can be. Don't mistake me-the old Pride and Prejudice will always in the end be the quintessential one, and Colin Firth's Darcy remains at the peak-but this movie is very nearly as good and MacFadyen's Darcy is really just as good, in a very different way(I never thought I would say that). MacFadyen played him with shyness, intensity, subtlety, warmth, idiocy, humour, and charm by turns,and by doing so turns out a very human and completely-perfect man. And his chemistry with Keira Knightley is exquisite-a miracle. In the end that is what makes up the movie-they light up the screen together. I haven't seen anything like it since-well-Titanic, and this movie shows it up in that area as well. Like the producers said after it was released,when they got the two actors together on the set something happened and they became their characters-two characters madly in love with each other.(Keira Knightley is just as good as MacFadyen-another mild surprise-she plays her with a delicacy and warmth completely lacking in most of her other performances.The moment when she steps down from the carriage and looks up at Pemberley and releases a quick bubble of laughter made up of equal part irony, delicious laughter,regret, and a sense of the ridiculous, is a cinematic moment that won't come again, and only she could have produced it).After watching it,I came out of the theater poised between sheer joy and hysterical laughter, and feeling an intense desire to be in love with someone-that is what the movie did to me.It is flawed-Jane and Bingley are pretty much ruined and several very important plot points are brushed over or ignored-the producers seemed to feel about two-thirds of the way throught the movie that they'd better speed it up,and so they rush through several major events at breakneck speed-but other things make you forgive them for it.Lady Catherine and Mr. Collins, while very different versions than in the BBC one, are good once you get used to them, and this is pretty much the case for all the minor characters with the exception perhaps of Bingley and his sister. Watch it, not really expecting it to be as good as the old one and definitely not hoping for the book, because it's not that-but it stands on its own as shining movie masterpiece of romanctic dramas.

reviewText: First of all, no film adaptation can ever compare to the book itself. If you enjoyed whichever film version you've seen, including this one, read the book! You'll love it.I have read the book countless times. The 1980 BBC production starring Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul is the most accurate and thorough adaptation in my opinion. I don't care for the newer and more popular 1996 A&E; version because of the MANY liberties it takes, although the visuals are gorgeous. (You can read my comparison review of those two on their product listing pages:Pride and Prejudice (BBC, 1980)andPride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996)).When I saw the preview for this new version, it just looked very "Hollywood-ish" -- over-emotive, mangled dialogue, too sappy and dramatic. And it seemed that Darcy, who is supposed to be handsome on the Adonis level, looked way too plain for the role. But I knew I had to watch it anyway, and I was pleasantly surprised. Although a lot of the book's scenes were left out to fit into the 2-hour time frame, the dialogue and scenes were well-chosen and more faithful to the book than I expected. Despite the shorter length, this newest movie version still captured the spirit of the novel. Each actor did wonderfully in his or her role... including wonderful appearances from Donald Sutherland as the droll yet affectionate Mr. Bennett, and Dame Judi Dench as the odious Lady Catherine De Burgh.My husband who likes to avoid sappy `chick flicks' even walked in the room while I was watching it, and sat down and watched the rest of it with me and really enjoyed it. (He had also enjoyed the 1980 BBC version).My complaints about it are:1) Mr. Bingley's hair looks utterly ridiculous (it's like a furry red dog sitting on top of his head) and I had to laugh every time he appeared on the scene.2) Speaking of hair, many characters did seem undergroomed, with very messy hair, no jewelry and very plain, drab-looking outfits; especially Elizabeth. I hated that brown dress! I guess they had to find a way to make Kiera Knightley seem less pretty than the actress playing Jane, which is certainly difficult since Kiera is considered one of the most beautiful women in the world. Add to that the messy scenes of pigs and farming and laundry hanging out to dry at the Bennett home, the whole family seemed perhaps of a lower class than they actually were... as if the director wanted to 'gritty' them up a bit.3) Mr. Darcy does not acknowledge to Elizabeth how much she helped him change to be more humble and considerate of others. One of the best lines in the book is when he says to her: "... dearest, loveliest Elizabeth! What do I not owe you? You taught me a lesson... by you I was properly humbled." This is an important point, because one foundation of their love is their gratitude to each other for the changes each brought about in the other. In this version, the impression is given that it was only Elizabeth who was ever in the wrong and needing to change.4) Some liberties were of course taken with dialogue and the timing of events, and there were some contrived/invented scenes, including things that were not in the book at all, and things that would not have been appropriate for that time period. (Hollywood has never learned to leave well enough alone.) Examples include: family members hovering over every closed door to hear the conversations therein, and giggling and gawking at the people who had been conversing as they come out of the door; the 'rejected proposal' scene happening outside in the rain and them almost kissing (??!!??) during it; Lady Catherine visiting late at night; the `married' scene at the end; Mr. Bingley appearing in Jane's sickroom; a room of mostly naked statues in the Darcy home instead of the book's wall portraits (guess they had to get SOME sensuality in there somewhere); a sleepless Darcy and Elizabeth meeting up in the fog in the wee morning hours. Some of these were cool things in and of themselves; just not Austen. Bronte, maybe?But for some reason, those discrepancies did not bother me as much as they might have, and I think it is because they were so well offset by the positives of the film that had me really enjoying it and appreciating what I felt it DID pull out of the novel well. I had complaints of a similar nature about the 1995 A&E; version, but there wasn't enough `good' to offset my annoyance at what I considered `bad' in that version, whereas in this version the good outweighed the bad for me by more than enough. I think it's certainly a great introduction for anyone who is new to Austen.I did not think I would say this, but I will definitely buy this movie. It is an obviously romanticized version, but the added romanticism didn't bother me like I thought it would, and I found myself enjoying it.
summary: Greatly exceeded the expectations of this die-hard Austen book fan!

reviewText: I own the mini-series version of Pride and Prejudice with Colin Firth, which is more true to the book, but I think this is the more entertaining film. Other reviewers have discussed the difference in performances by actors who are closer to the actual ages of the characters in the book and the more realistic setting. One difference between book and movie that I appreciated was the director's take on the relationship between the Bennet parents and his expansion of the minor characters. Here, Mr. Bennet is both exasperated by and in love with Mrs. Bennet; Mr. Collins is as annoying as ever, but we also sympathize with his vulnerability and social awkwardness. Elizabeth's sister Mary is still a preachy bluestocking, but the film doesn't just make fun of her; we also her as the awkward teenage girl who sobs in her father's arms after being embarrassed at the ball. The five girls are very convincing as sisers and their embarassing mama loves them dearly. Bingley is as shy as Jane and here we see Darcy helping him rehearse his marriage proposal to her. Darcy and Elizabeth seem a little more raw and REAL here. The director has really gotten at the humanity of all of the characters here in a way that adds a lot to the film. That, and it's not six hours long, which should appeal to anyone who doesn't have the patience to sit through the mini-series.

reviewText: I don't know if I'll every truly know why, but I absolutely LOVE this movie.It's not as brilliant as `Sense and Sensibility' (mostly because it lacks the splendor that is Kate Winslet) but `Pride and Prejudice' is a perfect family film that builds off its subject to create a beautifully crafted masterpiece.  The performances match the surroundings and the direction by newcomer Joe Wright is astoundingly accurate and beautiful to look at.  Keira Knightley rightfully earned that Oscar nomination, for her portrayal of Elizabeth Bennet is the best by far of anyone attempting at the coveted role.  The fact remains that `Pride and Prejudice' has been done and redone and supposedly mastered by BBC (and Colin Firth) in 1995.  While that is the case this beautiful reimagining of the classic Austen novel is, in my humble opinion, the best film adaptation, by far.The film, aside from being splendidly acted, is above and beyond a beauty to look at.  Each frame is astounding in its visual flare.  The camera pans out over the surroundings with beautiful precision.  Just watch the fog scene with Darcy and know that a picture speaks a thousand words.  It's graceful and mesmerizing.The film follows the love affair (or lack there of) between Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy, a pair made in Hollywood heaven.  She's strong-willed and opinionated as is he and they seem to butt-heads more than steal hearts but in the end there is no denying they are perfect for one another.  What makes this movie so brilliant is that it is in affect the catalysts for almost every other love story out there for these two characters seem to pop up in almost every teen film produced as of late.  These are the originals though, and with splendid performances by Knightley and Macfadyen are so effortless and uplifting in their impish immaturity that they breathe a whole new life to the classic tale.The supporting cast all hold their weight as well, especially the likes of Donald Sutherland who is perfectly cast as Elizabeth's father and Brenda Blethyn who plays her mother, but it's Dame Judi Dench who stole the show for me with her few moments of screen time.  She plays Lady Catherine de Bourg with such ferocity that her confrontation with Elizabeth was the highlight of the film for me.In the end I can only say good things for this film for I cannot find a single flaw.  Watching Keira chew up the scenery is orgasmic for me, especially when you think that this is the same girl who fights pirates and hunts criminals.  Under that action hero exterior is a giggly teenage girl who becomes so real to her audience that you can't help but fall madly in love with her.  `Pride and Prejudice' is a wonder of a film, a beautifully magnificent cinematic experience that brings nothing but joy and warmth to my heart.So I guess I do know why I love this film after all...go figure.
summary: Beautiful, mesmerizing and, simply put, utter perfection...

reviewText: If you rent this movie for the car chases, you will be very disappointed...there are none.Besides that point, there were several things I didn't like. reviewText: I have only read the book one time, after getting completely hooked on the 1995 A&E; version of Pride and Prejudice and watching it about six times this year alone, so I am probably not the most qualified person to write my objections to the 2005 piece of filth, but after reading what everyone else had to say, I could not keep silent either. Here are my objections as follows:1. Kiera Knightley- Hollywood clearly cannot tell the difference between a great actress better suited to the role of the intelligent Elizabeth Bennett (as in, almost anybody but K.K.) and a walking, talking, beanpole who claims to have read the book, but I don't think she did because if she had she would not have fudged this role up so badly with all the excessive giggling, outspokenness to her parents that was more or less non-existant during that time period, and for goodness sakes, somebody tell her to please close her mouth. Sexiness is appropriate in modern-day romantic comedies, but NOT in period pieces such as this one, or at least not the kind K.K. displayed. A woman from that time certainly did not run around outside with her hair down, or in her nightgown, and they almost never went outside without a hat or bonnet of some sort, which, I can't recall seeing K.K. wearing one, even after forcing myself to watch this film three times. Also, somebody please tell that girl to eat once in a while! I find it hard to believe that somebody from that time period, who did no housework and clearly had time to kill by making the audience sick by spinning on a swing, could be that skinny, when a typical daily diet from back then included a great consumption of whole milk, cheese, butter, bread, and eggs. Fattening fare that would have made a person look at least healthy, not like somebody who had not even seen puberty. Kiera Knightley was totally wrong for that role, having too modern of a face, and too thin a figure. I'm sorry Kiera, but you should stick with modern flicks. As a final irritation on this subject, I might add that she rattled her lines off so fast in some scenes that I hardly knew what she said, which is pretty sad for a person like me who is more than familiar with the dialogue. I believe that in a film with language that is as old as this, the lines should be spoken more slowly, to give our modern minds time to translate and understand what was said.2. Fitzwilliam Darcy- I felt absolutely nothing for this film's portrayal of the character whatsoever. There was nothing in him that made him the least bit likeable or desireable, and that haunted look that was constantly plastered to his face just depressed me.3. Charlotte Lucas- '"Don't judge me, Lizzy!"' Pul-eeeze. The film portrayed Charlotte's acceptance of Mr. Collins as being that she was unhappy to be marrying him, like she was trapped. In the book, she was actually in persuit of a comfortable home, and wasted no time in securing Mr. Collins for herself, even though he was not necessarily her first choice. But being older than the typical marrying age back then, beggars cannot be choosers, as the saying goes, and she may have become one eventually had she remained a spinster.4. The Costumes- I thought they were completely inaccurate for the time period, and terribly boring and colorless, especially the one Knightley wore in her first scene. Yuck, and I don't know what was up with her hair, but it just did not go with her modern-looking face. Speaking of hair, I didn't know that Marie Antoinette was cast to play Lady Catherine de Burgh. And could anybody honestly tell Lydia and Kitty apart with their identical pigtail/ringlet combinations?I honestly do not know how in the world this movie received four stars from the critics, who quite obviously have never read this book. I am sorry for the hordes of disappointed fans out there who were expecting something great (as I did), only to get spoon-fed this '"barely tolerable"' adaptation, only to choke on it after the credits rolled. Congratulations Hollywood, on ruining yet another (what could have been a) great film (just like Eragon got ruined) by attempting to 'modernize' it and change it to what you think the audience would want. Well, if it isn't broken, don't fix it! This is one of those stories in which everything was perfectly fine just the way it was. But (surprise!) some idiot out there had to open their mouth and suggest 'changes.' Well, would it be too much of a 'change' to get it right? If you are watching Pride and Prejudice for the first time, watch the A&E; Firth and Ehle version. I haven't seen the one that was made in the 1980's yet, but I am willing to bet that it totally blows away the 2005 version.Anecdote: I eventually did view the 1980's version of Pride and Prejudice, and it WAS way better than the 2005 version! Still not as good as the 1995 one, but still worth seeing and better represented.
summary: It was UNtolerable, I suppose: not handsome enough to tempt me!

reviewText: I just watched this for the millionth time, and I loved it all over again. The cinematography is fantastic and artfully done. The classical music score is so soothing and perfectly suits the story. The whole movie gives you a sense of life with the Bennets that is so real. They are a family whose quirks and charms are immediately evident, and you fall in love with them all. I like that the Bennetts house is so well lived-in and even a little dirty looking. There is a lovely contrast between their poorer household to the richer settings of Mr. Bingley's temporary residence and especially Mr. Darcy's home at Pemberly.Keira Knightley is such a wonderful Elizabeth Bennett. She is natural and witty and somewhat angelic, but she's still a little rough around the egdes and down to earth. I like how she seems silly at times but still knows how to conduct herself properly without coming off as a snob. She's confident but still maintains an innocent quality.Matthew Macfadyen is the hottest Darcy to walk the planet, in my opinion. At first, I wasn't sure about him, because he looked so much like a sourpuss when he made his entrance to the film, but, as his character transforms, he becomes more handsome and eventually just completely sexy - this is where I can see why Jane Austen first titled the book First Impressions. If that title had stuck, it would certainly still work for this story. All the little nuances of Darcy's - the stolen glances, the tension in his hands, etc. - were all captured perfectly on camera and really brought his secret longing for Elizabeth into focus for the audience.I have to add that there were moments when I wanted to jump through the screen and bite Darcy's bottom lip. For example, the rainy day scene was so intense...if I were Elizabeth, I'd be tempted to just say screw pride, I'm yours! And she almost looks like she will. But seriously...Matthew Macfadyen is exactly how I would want my own Darcy to be. The scene where he walks through the dew-covered field at dawn in his flowing coat and his boots and high-waisted pants, YUM! I'm so glad they kept that shot in real time so the audience can watch every single sway of his hips. Wow. Oh, and this is my favorite line of his, "You have bewitched me, body and soul." Who talks like that anymore?! I love it!I like the BBC version...Colin Firth is such an awesome, sexy Darcy, too, and now we have this modern, more sexually tense P&P.; Wow, two great P&P; versions, Austen fans should rejoice about that!
summary: Amazing...and another hot Darcy! Yes, please!

reviewText: I was shocked at the 3.5 cumulative rating here, but realized even after a quick glance that there's a rather understandable division between the BBC watchers and those who loved this later film.  However, it's really not necessary.But why choose?  Sure, they took liberties with this adaptation, but to me that makes sense -- it was the only direction to go after the definitive "traditional" rendition with the gorgeous BBC miniseries.  They did it all beautifully in that one.The 2005 version, it's grittier, faster, a little more brutal and sad too. I personally loved it -- it's fresh and fast and a new and lovely view of the story.  It's surprisingly swift-moving, very energetic, and a gorgeously made movie.  The acting is superb and the writing is great. It is not paced at all the way you expect these things, and I love the fact that (thanks to a few liberties with the book's time period) it looks and feels somehow very vibrant and real and just a little grungy.  The homes, the clothes, everything looks so real and lived-in (not frilly and clean and perfect the way these things usually are).  Even the dashing hero, who is quite hot, has terrible hair. And Kiera Knightley, who is not always a favorite of mine, is lovely and wonderful here. In this role, it's believable that (as beautiful as she is) that she is not fashionably beautiful or even noticeable, that her smarts and vivacity would be off-putting.  She is absolutely wonderful here, as is the entire cast (and Donald Sutherland is smashing in a scene very late in the movie as well).And yes, I still love Colin Firth.  But newcomers will find this Darcy terrific as well, in spite of his bad hair. ;-)
summary: Superb (3.5 Cumulative Rating is Way too Low...), Even for Firth Lovers

reviewText: The first time I watched this movie I compared it to the BBC mini-series with Colin Firth, the ultimate Darcy. Firth is a  handsome man even without saying a word.  Matthew MacSpayden looks like a normal person who could use a haircut.  Then I started googling and reading interviews with the actors and directors and came to an appreciation of this work.  Matthew MacSpayden had not read P&P or seen the BBC version before he played the role.  His Darcy isn't as arrogant as Firth's although he is still proud and prejudiced!  Keira Knightley does a wonderful job.  Her Lizzy is full of energy and life!  The story is not followed EXACTLY as the book was written but I found the differences acceptable and reasonable.  The ending is a little weird---it was written for the American audience apparently.  The directing is fast-paced and dramatic (they had to squeeze the whole thing into 2 hours, unlike the 6 hour mini-series) and I love the music.  Several scenes weren't even planned, they just came about---the solo ballroom scene and the proposal-practicing scene with Darcy and Bingley.  And the sculpture gallery at Pemberley, especially the veiled woman, was amazing.
summary: Just as good as the Firth version but in a different way

reviewText: My husband and I love the Firth movie and just about every Austen film we've seen. Sadly, we found this remake a vulgar version of a truly gracious story.The earthy, lust-filled movie left no reason for the bland, distant, dull father to even own the dusty books in his hovel library. There was no reason for this Darcy to choose THIS Elizabeth - no reason at all.This movie was emptied - stripped - of all we love about Austen. Austen without the winsomeness of intellect; Austen without wisdom and compassion of good, ennobling character; Austen without highly refined interpersonal drama; Austen without the loveliness and intricacies we've grown to expect. Finally we laughed and laughed: this was Austen without Austen!We would not recommend this to anyone. Save your money. Use your time for better things.

reviewText: I found this adaptation to race along from beginning to end, and in the process I believe it sacraficed some much-needed build-up that we find in the BBC/A&E version. We don't get a sense of the time that has passed during which characters are ruminating on what is happening and their feelings about it. We just get scene by scene thrown at us and we are expected to be carried along and believe it. The cinematography is excellent in many parts. The acting is good, but Keira Knightly always has that smirk on her face and after awhile I wonder why it is there so much. Although she holds her own, I was not always drawn in to her performance...or I was drawn in but wasn't sure what I found there. This definitely had a more romantic and sensual feel that other versions have not. I do wish there had been more build-up of the relationship between Elizabeth and Darcy that would make their falling in love more believable. I always feel that on Darcy's part there is not enough conveyance of what he is attracted to when he is attracted to justify the passion in the end. I did find Mrs. Bennet to be far less shrill and irritating than in other adaptations which was a big plus. I also liked the character of Charlotte here very well. All of the laughing and giggling at the Bennet house was a bit over the top.
summary: Fast but still hits the spot

reviewText: I've watched this movie three times. I've read the novel twice and seen the A&E; version (which this film is unfairly compared with). Therefore I am fully aware of the story and characters and all that diddle-dee-do. So I guess I can be considered informed of the material and what it is about.Now I should mention to people who have this idea that movies based on books should remain faithful to the point of thinking the source as sacred text: the screenwriter did take liberties with the story. A leap in time here. A missing episode there. A sudden visit here. And a hussy fit there.But it is an "adaptation" and not a "translation" of the original novel by dear Miss Austen. The changes are not drastically uncalled for. They are actually refreshing. As is the mood that the director (Wright) set for the film. The film moves at a swift pace but the mood is always down-to-earth and emotionally focused. Normally when people do Austen adaptations they have this image of the whole movie being focused around drawing rooms with the etiquettes associated with the Regency period. They put so much emphasis into the details of the setting and situations that they neglect the characters humanity and hope that the actors are up to code. This version actually looked at the material in the opposite direction and focused more on the main characters (especially Elizabeth or "Lizzy" as she is well known).Oh well I must talk about the acting. It was good.For more info notice the academy award nomination Keira Knightley received for her portrayal of Lizzy. Even though the Academy Awards relativity to cinematic excellence has lessened, please be assured that the notice placed towards Ms. Knightley's performance was well deserved. The whole cast was pretty good with the other standout being Donald Sutherland. But if I must say something more about Ms. Knightley, it is that she fitted who Elizabeth was as a young opinionated woman. She plays Lizzy with the conviction that I felt was missing in other P&P; adaptations. It one thing to say the lines, it's another to say the lines like it's something you would actually say.This movie puts the "passion" aspect into the romance of Austen's creation. A true Romantic (of the literary kind) would think of this adaptation as a triumph. And if dear Miss Austen were alive she would probably giggle (of the hushed kind) with delight at the unabashed joy this movies gives in spades.Well RecommendedNote: For the strict Austen fans who believe that Austen would spin in her grave at the supposed blasphemy of the movie, I will say this. You forget that Miss Austen (the writer of gothic-satire Northanger Abbey) probably did not think so much of herself that she wouldn't have wanted other people to look at her work in different ways. Stop being narrow-minded. Miss Austen wasn't! Now enjoy the movie.(Off the soap box)

reviewText: English and pastoral... Countryside was captured with extreme authenticity and delicacy!I was stuned by this wonderful adaption of the Jane Austen novel. With a spontaneous direction from Joe Wright, Pride & Prejudice leaves you happy!Keira Knightley and Donald Sutherland are wonderfully casted for this brilliant romance. Also Brenda Blethyn and Judi Dench portrayed extremelly well their charachters. Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy and Jena Malone as Lydia, Elizabeth's younger sister, are also good. It evokes the England countryside easily.I have my DVD copy now and if you like a great romance please add this new one.With my eyes wide open I'm dreaming...

reviewText: When I first heard there was going to be another version, my first thoughts were that nothing could top the BBC version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle!  Especially since that one was 5 hrs., and followed the book to the tee!Well, of course the new one was cut down to a measly 2 hrs.!!  Because of the time constraint- they had to rush the story along, almost at a fast-forward pace (or as someone aptly put it: "didn't allow the story to breathe").  Surprisingly, I didn't find it that big of an issue.There were a few notable changes however... *SPOILER* First, the part where Mr. Darcy first proclaims his love to Elizabeth is a bit different than it was in the book (the setting that is).  Second, the confrontation between Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lizzy is customized (for the sake of time).  Also, (towards the end) the part where Elizabeth confesses her changed feelings towards Mr. Darcy is different than in the book; and the end was also tweaked a bit.Despite these changes, I think the original story was still able to shine through!For the most part I was pleased with their choice of actors.  Dame Judi Dench was a perfect Lady Catherine; and I really enjoyed Rosamond Pike (as Jane), possibly even more-so than the actress in the '95 version.  Mr. Bingly, a tad naive and silly at times is nonetheless endearing!However, Keira Knightley just isn't selling Elizabeth for me (as Jennifer Ehle did).  I don't sense much emotional depth, or connection in and to her character.  KK's roles- at least the ones I've seen her in- all seem to blend together.As for Matthew Macfadyen, my only experience of him prior to this, was a smaller role in the miniseries based on Anthony Trollope's "The Way We Live Now".Instead of coming off quite as cold and haughty as CF's Darcy; Matthew's portrayal gave a somewhat new dimension to this enigmatic character!  He really did a fine job in showcasing the more introverted/introspective side of Fitzwilliam (possibly an INTJ temperament). And truth be told, it was a little too easy to get lost in his "fine eyes"!  Needless to say, he is now my second favorite "Mr. Darcy"!  (If you haven't already, check him out in the latest BBC adaptation of Charles Dickens "Little Dorrit" - he's absolutely brilliant in his role as "Arthur Clennam"!)All in all it's a good movie- especially for those who don't have the patience to sit through the 5 hr. one.I'm also really pleased with the "special edition"!  While there's not a whole lot more DVD extras than on the original; the added book, and soundtrack make the purchase worthwhile!**Last edited 2013**

reviewText: I simply love this movie. I also like the BBC version with Colin Firth and J.Ehle but honestly this version is my favourite. Although the adaptation of the novel is not really faithful to the novel(unlike the BBC one) I think that Joe Wright, the director, still did an amazing job by making a two-hour movie with all the major passages of the book. The first thing I noticed about this movie is the unique, wonderful atmosphere that the director and his assistants managed to create, with a beautiful-yet-down-to-earth setting, the movement of the camera (I was impressed by the way the camera moves, turns or follows the characters through the ballroom at Netherfield) the long shots mingling with close-views of the actors. Even the sounds are perfect -you can hear birds singing in the morning, rain pattering down- and just for that, the movie is a pure joy for me because it feels somewhat real. The atmosphere in the Bennett's house is so familiar and pleasant that you feel almost immediately a connection with this family. I just love every moment of the movie, I love the dialogues even if they don't correspond to the ones in the book (the Darcy's proposal is a moment of anthology! as this `lovers' spat'- kind of argument between Darcy and Lizzie gets more and more intense) The pace of the movie is fast, the good thing is that you don't have time to get bored, there is always something going on in every scene, the bad thing is that there are not enough scenes with these wonderful characters and I don't want the movie to end!!!Right from the start, you feel so close to the characters that you don't want to leave them. They seem so alive (Lizzie Bennet has never been so flamboyant!)I couldn't help feeling as emotionally charged as them. All the actors are great, not only the leading ones but also the minor ones: the younger Bennet sisters -Jena Malone is so funny-and R. Pike is perfect as serene, beautiful Jane -.It is a pity though that we don't see some characters like Caroline Bingley or Charles Bingley or Wickham very often.And of course Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen are really perfect for me as Elizabeth Bennet and Mr Darcy. Keira Knightley gives energy and a mix of wit and mischievousness to the heroine. MacFadyen's Darcy is different from the book, I grant you, but this shy, love-struck and vulnerable is simply irresistible!! OK, maybe you don't have Colin Firth's wet shirt but you can still see MacFadyen drenched to the skin at one point while he is proposing to Lizzie and he is downright sexy too. Plus, his deep voice gives me the shivers! Knightley and Macfadyen have powerful chemistry, and when Darcy proposes to Lizzie in the rain, you can feel the heat, the passion growing more intense between them. The long stares between them, the way they passionately spar and their near-kisses are so sexually charged that they make me almost swoon with delight. One particular moment that I like too is when he helps her getting into a carriage and by doing so, he touches her hand. This is such a magical moment because it is not something you would do at the time especially when you've just met. And the climactic scene , oh boy, this scene in which Macfadyen appears in the misty dawn, desperately seeking Lizzie is so beautiful and rich with sensuality that it always makes me sigh just as it does Lizzie. At that point, I always feel the urge to tell Lizzie that she would be crazy to say 'no' to him now! I think that for once there is the perfect combination between Lizzie and Darcy: (They are both young), he is shy, reserved and socially ill-at-ease while she is free-spirited, flamboyant, lively, always speaking a mind of her own, and so they seem to complete each other very well.The DVD, the English version,is worth the money because the special features are very interesting and ...there is also THE ALTERNATE US ENDING with the balcony kiss. About this US ending, I still think that they could have made a better scene although it is downright sweet. I can feel that Wright wasn't a 100% behind this last conversation between Lizzie and Darcy. Not that I am really complaining, it is still very nice to see them together one last time. One regret, where are the cut-off scenes? I am probably asking too much since the DVD features are already excellent but I 'd love to see the deleted scenes. And I am sure that Joe Wright must have deleted some scenes... Let's hope that there will be one day a special edition with two DVDs. This 'Pride&Prejudice;'movie has become one of my favourites (I think that I must have seen it 4 times in the movie theater before buying the DVD.)I am definitely a big fan because not only I have the book and the music but I 've also been to England just to visit Chatsworth/Pemberley,the Peak District and Burgley House/Lady Catherine De Bourgh's house!!!
summary: This movie has bewitched me body& soul!

reviewText: I somehow didn't feel the magic and electricity that I got from the 1995 mini series and Sense and Sensibility; which is a shame because I was all ready to adore this one too.  The reason I loved the mini series is because there was no stone unturned; every nuance of emotion was true to Austen's book. Even the narrations as Elizabeth read the letters. Too much goes on to gloss over the things that make you fall in love with the story.  There is no possible way to get the complete feel of the novel unless you have the time to do so.  Much like the Lonesome Dove mini series.  Although totally different genres, the characters felt real and were full-bodied.  The book had a light air to it much like the novel and the movie/novel Sense and Sensibility although both had their sad moments but I can't say this movie did that for me.The only characters that I thought did complete justice to the novel and the mini series were that of Dame Dench's de Bourgh and Tom Hollander as Mr. Collins. I connected also from time to time with Knightly's rendition of  Elizabeth particularly when she overheard Darcy's opinion of her at the dance. Yet Blethens and Sutherland both of whose acting I adore just missed (more so Donald Sutherland) I don't blame the actors for this, mostly the director.  (I especially didn't care to Jena Malone's rendition of Lydia, which was slyer than it was totally oblivious, immature and childlike).  I just feel that this is such a beloved and full novel that leaving the small things that make it so wonderful isn't as satisfyingI'm far from a novel purist but you just miss so much if all of it isn't shown.  If only Hollywood was brave enough to gamble on making something that length, this may have worked better for me.  But we know that will never happen.  I found it somewhat lacking and far from the BBC mini series caliber.  Maybe the extraordinary classics should all be mini-series.  For those who think this is good.... take some time over a weekend to see the mini series with an open mind.  You'll be hooked!
summary: Not enough character development for me.

reviewText: This version has beautiful scenery, costumes, actors and has great film quality! The acting is marvelous. Mr. Dacy does such a wonderful job being tormented inside and portraying that torment without a word, only showing it in his guarded expressions. Lizzie and Jane are both beautiful and great actresses. Mr. Bingly is a bit overly enthusiastic and air headed, but pleasing. It had the potential to be a great version of Pride and Prejudice.....but it wasn't!I was confused most of the time and at the end felt like I was rushed through a beautiful love story. I have been a fan of Pride and Prejudice ever since watching the 1996 version starring Colin Firth and have since watched it so many times I have it memorized! Perhaps that is the problem. The 1996 version was a wonderful story. I always knew what each character was feeling and what was going on. There were no gaps in the story and I fell in love with it. I was excited to learn there was an updated version being released this year because I hoped for a better film quality than the 1996 one. It at least had that much going for it. It was a beautiful picture but with a hurried story. They should have lengthened the film so the viewer knew all the characters and details of the story. Instead the movie felt rushed, like a summary to the real thing. A good movie, perhaps if you haven't watched the 1996 version already, but I strongly suggest you only rent this one and then buy the other =-).
summary: It had the potential to be great....but what happened??!!!!

reviewText: I was looking forward to this version of my favorite novel because I wanted to see how they would slice it down to two hours runtime.  I was delighted with some of it.  Miss Knightley's performance is quite good and she seems to possess all the fire of Elizabeth Bennet.  Brenda Blethyn and Dame Judy Dench (perfection itself) were also standouts, although Miss Dench's important final scene with Miss Knightley was abridged.  And why does she mention a pretty sort of garden (taken from the novel), when they play this scene inside the house at night?I found quite a few more flaws in the production.  The best dialogue is taken directly from the book.  When Miss Austen speaks, the film and the actors are just fine.  When the dialogue is newly invented, it doesn't seem to fly along.  I found Matthew McFadyen rather wooden and not as attractive as the characters say Mr. Darcy is.  Also, the family relationships are not correctly delineated as Miss Austen wrote them.  In the novel, Mr. Bennet favors Elizabeth for her wit.  Of all his daughters, she is the only one, he confides in the book, that he can converse with on an intelligent level.  Also, Lydia (in the novel) is an exact replica of her mother -- which is not apparent in this film.  Also, Mrs. Bennet favors Lydia above her other daughters in the book.  This is nowhere apparent in the film.  It seems that the daughters are all lumped together as one by their parents.  Mr. Bennet's financial concerns are barely brought to light and Lydia's scandalous elopement with Wycham, which is so important to the denoument, is reduced to little more than a trifling matter and is over with in less than three to four minutes.  The ending is like a fast-forward (obviously they were running out of time), and we get a tacked on coda that has Darcy and Elizabeth at Pemberley in a love scene.  Miss Austen's "psychology" is missing nearly throughout this film.The DVD supplies us with the actors being interviewed as well as screenwriter and director, and here is where we find where they went wrong.  It seems that all of the information they are giving us is not at all what Miss Austen intended.  Donald Sutherland himself (Mr. Bennet), constantly speaks of how much his character loves his daughters.  Maybe he should try re-reading the book.  Mr. Bennet spent nearly all his time in his library wishing to be undisturbed by the noise of his wife and the household in general.I am forever grateful to the BBC for having taken the novel, one of the finest in the English language, and giving it the royal treatment in 1995 with superlative actors and a screenwriter who knew how to aptly recreate Miss Austen's world.  How fastidious they were with every detail and Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth seem to be the quintessential leading players in this beautiful production.  We have it for as long as DVDs and film last.This new production, even though it is sliced down, seems slow, oddly enough, and I could not wait for it to be over.  I look forward to sitting down with the 1995 version soon.
summary: When it's Austen talking, it comes alive.

reviewText: Firstly, if you have already seen the Pride and Prejudice miniseries with Colin Firth, don't expect too much from this movie or you will be disappointed, as I was.It seemed that the dialogue was "dumbed down" for the general audience.This film is one of the worst adaptations of Pride and Prejudice ever filmed and if Jane Austen were alive, she would demand that her name be removed from the film. Austen's novel is only superficially a story of the development of true love between Elizabeth Bennet and Fitzwilliam Darcy.  If one is making a period movie, one must be true to the period. The best thing that can be said about this film is that it contains many pretty scenes of the English countryside.I guess the main flaw of this new version is Darcy himself, a role played by Matthew MacFadyen. In the story he is rather dull and generally uninterested in what's going on. It must be difficult to replace Colin Firth as leading man and the Darcy of the miniseries of course had more screen time to show his inner struggle. But the new Darcy is so dull that frankly you don't care if he ends up winning Elizabeth's heart or not. There is absolutely no spark between Knightly and MacFadyen. At the end of the move they don't even kiss and as an audience you couldn't care less.I don't recommend this movie to anyone.  Go rent the miniseries with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle if you want a real Jane Austen story.

reviewText: The acting in this version is wonderful and spot on. To begin  Jane and Mr Bingley are a perfect fit for their characters and each other. Both actors show a goodness and quietness in their manners so that one has trouble imagining them together and the issues that this couple faces along the way. The biggest issue no doubt is sharing their heartfelt emotions and love for each other.Elizabeth and Mr Darcy are also a perfect match. Elizabeth is just the right amount of independence and vulnerability that her character comes alive. Elizabeth shows that she is sensitive to others opinions, as when Darcy comments on her appearance and behavior at village dance, after his cutting comments she seeks out her best friend to help confirm her beliefs that he is wrong and has a great prejudice. She assumes and exhibits an attitude that she has everything figured out and as a result judges things much to quickly - including Darcy. The development of the character throughout the movie is played so expertly! You really do see her character grow and her opinions rendered incorrect - she too has prejudices.To me this is the best acting of Mr Darcy's character that I have seen. I found it easy to see the shyness in Darcy hiding behind his pride. To me I found this portrayal so right on with what I imagined in from the book. He is quiet and aloof, yet you find yourself drawn to him, much like Elizabeth does as she gets to know him. Darcy does not seem as harshly played in this production as he is in others. It is not as hard to imagine Elizabeth falling for him as in other films. In other productions his change from "bad" guy to "good" guy seems too fast, here the character has time to grow and we see glimpses of his true self - small in the beginning and then revealed more throughout the film.The scenery of the English Countryside from the village to the residences is beautiful - with incredible scenic shots that will make you want to pick up and move directly to the English countryside.The costumes are simple for the country ladies - One of the greatest examples is the scene in which Elizabeth comes to check on her ailing sister Jane, at the Bingley residence. Elizabeth appears as if she has had a terrible journey to arrive there. Standing in front of the proper ladies and Darcy she is a sight to behold - and so believable.This is definitely worth purchasing and if you love Jane Austen's works or simply a good period piece you will no doubt return to this film again and again.In a word beautiful.

reviewText: Okay, I was VERY skeptical of this remaking of P&P.; First off, feature films rarely do a good job of interpreting a book into a 2 hour film (I thought Zefferelli's Jane Eyre was just dreadful!). I also questioned the casting of Keira Knightley as one of literature's most beloved heroines, Elizabeth Bennett. I really didn't think she could pull it off. But she really did.I'm one of those fans that hold up the BBC/A&E; mini-series with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle as the gold standard as adaptations go. It wasn't perfect, but it was the best I'd seen to-date and I treasure my DVD copy. And so, it was with fairly low expectations that I went to see this film. But I must say that I was pretty impressed. The setting, as others have pointed out, was of a much more rural world where people got dirty and farm animals wander about in the front yard. I thought the depictions of the Bennett sisters were well done particularly Jena Malone's silly Lydia, Rosamund Pike just luminescent as Jane and Ms Knightly's fine job as Elizabeth. Brenda Blethyn was a much less flighty Mrs Bennett from the BBC version which was welcome. But I was not that wild about Donald Sutherland's portrayal of Mr Bennett. He seemed more willfully neglectful of his daughters than the more benign neglect depicted in the BBC version.As for the men, I know that for many Colin Firth IS Fitzwilliam Darcy (he's played him twice after all) but I found Matthew MacFadyen's portrayal more nuanced and sensitive, almost vulnerable than the more cool and haughty Firth version. I loved him! MacFadyen interprets Darcy's reserve not as superior hauteur so much as a sort of shyness. MacFadyen's Darcy seems to be a shy man who is uncomfortable with strangers and, perhaps, in his own skin. He's attracted to Elizabeth because she is everything he's not. She's totally comfortable with who she is and her place in the world even if she is often stifled by the social strictures of her day. Charles Bingley was portrayed as a boyish innocent and one could see why Darcy felt he had to look out for him. I really felt that the Caroline Bingley character was pretty inconsequential seemingly only there to give Jane the excuse to visit. But one never got the impression that Caroline even liked Jane in this version so that part was not very well done. I must confess that the portrayal of Mr Collins had me smiling with serious bemusement! He wasn't the buffoonish comic relief so much as a bit of an oddity! But the biggest surprise was what a small part George Wickham played in this story.And that is my biggest issue with the film. Other than Mr MacFadyen, Ms Knightly is the star around which everyone else orbits and as a result, everyone else comes off as fairly minor secondary characters. As expected, some events are missing or time periods compressed to fit the time requirements of the film. I suppose it's as faithful as a feature film could be, but it does sort of boil the book down to just the romance between Lizzie and Darcy. Other issues I had were some of the costuming which would have been inappropriate at the time. The almost slip dress that Caroline Bingley wears to the Netherfield ball would have been positively scandalous in the day (a night gown would have shown less skin!). And gloves would have been worn by both ladies and gentlemen at any social occasion. And there was also a scene where Lizzie and her sister are shopping in the village and her hair is down around her shoulders. A young lady of the day would never appear in public without her hair being put up! And I was very disappointed in the lackluster Lady Catherine DeBurgh this version offered. Judi Dench is fine, but she lacks the amusingly pompous condescension Lady Catherine had in the book and in the BBC version. She plays her too regally as my sister pointed out!Ah well, nothing in life is perfect, but bottom line, I enjoyed this adaptation and have added the DVD to my shopping card.  Highly recommended!
summary: 4 1/2 stars - probably as good as a feature film could be

reviewText: "And how are you this evening, Mrs. Darcy?"One of the reasons I started this project of reading the original books from which these movies sprung is so that I can find out whether my favorite bits are in the original. The above line, the last in the movie, I sincerely hope is from the book. It's so perfect. But of course, you have to know how it came to be so perfect, don't you?Keira Knightley is a beautiful woman, a superb actress, and could probably make any role a fine thing. But this is only the beginning. I love period pieces with great costumes and sets, and the old-fashioned dignity of the King's English, and those lush landscapes. And I do love Jane Austen. This movie not only has all that, but some sweet special touches, like Donald Sutherland in a role unlike any he has ever played before, with gentle humor and just exactly what's wanted in the father of five girls.The humor is gentle all through this movie, such as when the two oldest sisters giggle together under the covers over their reactions to the gentlemen at the rustic country ball. The contrast when an elegant upper crust ball is later held so gently illustrates that only those two eldest girls have the kind of class required to be at home in both circles. Yes, their mother is ridiculous, but she loves her girls sincerely, and did not manage to ruin their chances by being rather too obvious in attempting to marry them off.There are difficulties, of course, but the only tragedy comes when the youngest sister proves too eager to be married and runs off with a soldier. Yet rich relations can smooth things over, and she returns to the family a smug married woman, if not exactly a lady.
summary: A Beautiful Movie About a Beautiful Book

reviewText: I've read Pride and Prejudice a couple of times, and loved the story, the characters (especially Elizabeth and Darcy), and Austen's humor. The miniseries from the mid 1990s with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle was fantastic too, with Firth as a perfect a Darcy as could be, and the whole thing capturing the spirit of the book. I heard a couple rave reviews of this adaptation, so I thought I'd check it out. Let's just say I want my two hours back. It's horrible. It's chopped way down so you just get a shell of the story, perhaps a cliff's notes version. You know what's going on, but you never get much of the wit and development. I didn't give a damn about any of the characters, like I did in the book and the miniseries. In those I was falling for Mr. Darcy right along with Elizabeth and wanting them together. In this version the characters just don't come to life. I didn't care what happened. And on top of that, despite the editing down of a classic to bare bones story, they still tossed in a lot of filler, lots of shots with some piano music tinkling away, and it's like, you couldn't have put a few more good lines of dialogue, explain more of the goings on? Anything? It just doesn't capture the spirit of the book; it's a lazy man's Austen. Bridget Jones' Diary (the movie, anyways, I didn't read the book), better caught the spirit of 'Pride and Prejudice,' with Firth as Darcy  (naturally) and Hugh Grant as Wickham, the crazy mom being the crazy mom with a bit of Lydia's drama thrown in. Rent that instead if you want a lighter version, or give the book and the miniseries a chance. It'll take longer to get through, but it's worth the time.
