reviewText: I never like to compare different versions of films, but I just couldn't help but do so after watching this adaptation. I have seen other P&P; films in the past, and the one that blew me away was the 1996 A&E; version. This new film doesn't measure up.1) Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle defined the story's characters beyond belief; in fact, the whole cast was superior (you felt as if Jane Austen's characters jumped off the pages). There was chemistry, subtlety, passion, etc. Here, the characters seemed undeveloped/undimensional and lacked all the qualities of the book's characters.2) The length of the 1996 movie gave a lot of detail and was well-developed; the story made much more sense in terms of why and how everything was happening. Here, they just took out all the main parts from the plot and pasted them together, leaving you to wonder if more was supposed to happen. Also, in the 1996 movie, Elizabeth and Darcy saw each other quite often, and each interaction contributed to the overall progression of their relationship; you can see why Elizabeth disliked Darcy and how she slowly started changing her mind. Here, one minute she hates him, and then, after hearing a couple of nice sentences from people, she, all of a sudden, "magically" loves him. The two characters barely saw each other and have not even held a real conversation, except for the scene where Darcy makes his first proposal, and is turned down, yet they somehow fell madly in love with each other...?3) 1996: Manners, etiquette, and traditions of the elite British class were captured quite well. You really saw how courtship was intended to be, and how marriage was looked upon. Here:too much Americanization going on ("Hollywood BS" I call it!). Certain parts were ridiculous (Lady Catherine's night visit, Mr.Bennett's dialogue, Charles Bingley's moron personality, Elizabeth's nightgown run, and the list goes on.......)Basically, a bunch of Americans (with exceptions, of course) pretending to know about British culture.I could go on forever with a list of complaints, but I don't want to bore the readers! If you're going to make a romantic film, make it about anything else, but don't take a classic novel and pretend that you can pull it off with good cinematography.Overall, if you have no idea what the book is about and have never read it (like this version's filmmakers), you might enjoy see this P&P; movie because it's a "romance". Just watch it as it is and don't give a second thought to what Jane Austen's story really stood for. Enjoy the costumes, music, etc, but don't pay attention to the plot. Just be glad that everyone lives happily ever after.
summary: Has difficulty in overcoming its predecessor....

reviewText: The Tagline of the Movie: "The one man she cannot stand, may be the one man she can't live without."The new version of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice is a must own for lovers at heart. Wonderfully casted by Jina Jay, she brings the story of the prideful Elizabeth Bennett and the prejudiced Mr. Darcy to life in this updated classic. Starring in the lead roles Keira Knightly,Matthew Macfadyen, and along with other well known actors Donald Sutherland, Brenda Blethyn and Judi Dench.This remake blends the unique acting of today with the glorius scenery of the past. Keira Knightly proudly shows that she is a very powerful Elizabeth Bennett, especially in a wonderful night scene shot with Judi Dench along with the scene's shot with the gentle Donald Sutherland. Matthew Macfadyen positively shines in his role as a tormented and shy man trying to overcome his prejudice to win the woman of his heart.Yet I will remark that for those that see this, try not to compare it with the wondefully done BBC miniseries version starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle done in 1995. Now while I enjoyed this film and found it exhilarating from beggining to end, it does go very fast at certain parts and slow it seems at others, but overall a wonderful remake of the famous book, and a version for any true lover at heart.

reviewText: While obviously abridged compared to the A&E; mini series, this P&P; is dead-on accurate.  Though I still appreciate the A&E; version, Wright captured the 'everyday-ness' of Austin's time: the dirt, the dress, the deportment, and Austin's well crafted satire.Compared to Wright's P&P;,  A&E;'s characters are wooden while Mrs. Bennett, Mr. Collins and, Mr. Wickham are nearly cartoonish.  On the other hand, Wright's Lady Catherine seems overblown though in the capable hands of Dame Dench, and Donald Sutherland's physicality doesn't quite fit Mr. Bennett though he does capture the character's charm & sense of humor.Wright's costuming & sets were well researched exemplified by older women wearing less fashionable gowns and younger women dressing more stylishly within their particularsocial rank.  In the A&E; P&P;, there is little variation in dress with so much pure white linen which could lead one to wonder if Longbourne was a suburb of Heaven.Wright's choreography and camera work really 'raised the bar' for historical dramas, too.  A&E;'s comes across as overly reheased & rigidely exacting while the camera remains static.  All of this results in scenes that are "not so much like a ball".With the luxury of time, the A&E; P&P; does include the entire Wickham subplot, one which Wrightwas required to  abridge but did so fairly elegantly.  Both versions exclude the novel's postscript-like conclusion.Enjoy both, and a read of Austen's novel.

reviewText: Of all the movies on my Top 10 list, this adaptation of Jane Austen's classic was the one I was the most reluctant to include because it's light and airy, it's a story that I've seen done before and because I knew a lot of Austen fans don't like it because it takes liberties with her apparently sacred text. But then I thought about the movie itself and how I felt swept up in it while it played in front of me. This new PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is a thoroughly engaging, lushly romantic time at the movies, presenting us with two brilliant, headstrong characters who are too stubborn to admit that they love each other. In this year of surprisingly strong performances that seem to come out-of-nowhere, Keira Knightley achieves the nearly impossible by making the role of Elizabeth Bennet entirely her own. By minimizing every part of the story that didn't deal directly with Elizabeth, director Joe Wright and screenwriter Deborah Moggach have created a swift, fun adaptation of the work that just keeps building momentum. It's thoroughly charming.

reviewText: On the one hand, the music, the costumes, the hair, and the scenery are all very well done; and the movie does have a good fast pace to it.  The designers showed great perception in having different levels of up-to-dateness and fashion among the various characters; the visuals are almost without fault, and the soundtrack is not bad at all.On the other hand, Jane Austen should never seem fast-paced, even within the limitations of cutting a novel down to fit within 2 hours or so (there's a reason why there's a mystery series where the detective is Jane Austen herself) and there is also lacking in the movie a sense of Jane Austen's ineffable good humor.  People are all to willing to tell their secrets, and constantly saying "Oh, didn't you know? . . ."  and, for example, when Charlotte announces that she is to marry Mr. Collins, she exclaims, "Don't you dare judge me, Lizzie!" when there was no question of Elizabeth judging Charlotte in the book at all, only questioning her future happiness.So you'll probably enjoy the movie more if you're not a Jane Austen fan to begin with than if you are.

reviewText: This is perhaps my favorite tale of society culture and men and young women finding love. It is also my favorite Jane Austin book and movie and series.  It is set at just about the turn of the century in around 1800.  It must have been a naughty kind of a read because Austin really does use the book to poke fun at the Aristocracy and the way they turn their noses down at everyone.  There is one slightly superior BBC version made up of several episodes where the young lady who played Elizabeth is just as pretty as Keira Knightly with long and beautiful black hair and an ivory complexion, but I so enjoyed this one too.  How indifference becomes irritation and then almost hate before we see an perfect partner as who he or she really is must be the most endearing story of romance.  They each see a reflection of each other in their stubborn pride and it's what each dislike about themselves.  Well, they have to get over that because there is a lot they share in common.  Darcy is very handsome, but shy.  Elizabeth is very beautiful and used to speaking her mind.  Her father encourages that a great deal.  Her mom is pushing all the girls to get married and Elizabeth will not be married just to obtain a better station in life for herself.  The poor and lower aristocracy is represented in the Bennetts with Elizabeth as one of many daughters.  They are intelligent and spirited and have a good opinion of themselves.  Mr Darcy and his friend Mr. Bingley come to stay in their own grand homes.  They are high aristocracy.  Can rich fall in love with poor? Does wealth matter very much when love is what matters.  We shall see and you will enjoy the whole funny, tender, and mishap filled road to romance.  Very, very enjoyable and really quite hopeful and upbeat overall.

reviewText: I may be the only person in the world to not like the 1995 BBC version of P&P.; I was cringing inside right before I started watching this one terrified they were going to butcher Austen's language like that adaptation. But I was pleasantly surprised to hear the good old words I know and love. The screenplay is wonderful. Thank you, thank you, thank you! They have chopped out a lot of scenes from the book and shortened a lot of speeches, but what they have retained is mostly verbatim and/or sounds just like Austen and will not offend.What else is there to say? Everything about it is fantastic. Music, acting, direction. As an art historian, I was especially enraptured with the cinematography, scenery and use of art. It was amazing. I love the genre scenes around her house with the hay bales, man with pipe, pigs.This is without a doubt the sexiest P&P; I've ever seen. Its all about the passions that are exploding beneath the surface. Matthew MacFadyen is especially good at conveying this.Notice what the director does with the theme of eyes and looking. Jane says, "One of these days someone is going to catch your eye and then you'll have to watch your tongue!" In the very next scene Darcy appears and when he's walking down the room at the first ball he does the smallest of double takes when he sees her. Its all about the glances towards and away from each other. Keira is wonderful with her eyes, especially in the last scene.Brenda Blethyn = hilarious. The best Mrs. Bennett I've seen. Rosamund Pike = perfect. Keira Knightly = brilliant. I liked Donald Sutherland, but please. That was not the Mr. Bennet. They've sweetened him to a ridiculous degree. Doesn't bother me, but its a flagrant departure from the book. I greatly missed Elizabeth and Darcy sparring at Netherfield. "Your defect is a propensity to hate everybody!" That was the only scene that I really did miss, though, and they cut out a lot. Otherwise I hardly noticed it. Best scene = the "car crash" proposal in the thunderstorm.This is a gorgeous, romantic film. Absolutely loved it.

reviewText: I own the BBC version of "Pride and Prejudice" and I must say that both films were good in their own rights.  I do believe that anyone viewing either of these two fine films must judge them as such instead of comparing the two.I will admit that this version has proven to be a favorite of mine between the two (I watch it at least once a week - gotta have my dose of Darcy *grin).  For one, this version was more "romantic" to me - Darcy helping Lizzie into the carriage, Darcy watching Lizzie on the ballroom floor, etc.  This really assisted in making Darcy's sudden proposal to Lizzie more believable whereas in the A & E version (not comparing, merely pointing out) - I was surprised by the declaration of love because I didn't see it coming.  There were no obvious signs that Darcy held any affections for Lizzie other than an occassional glance here and there.  In short, Firth and Eahle lacked the chemistry that Knightley and McFayden had in this version of the film.  Although I absolutely adore Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy - it took me a minute to warm up to him as he initially came off as a snob.  Matthew Macfayden portrays Darcy as more of a man who although he possesses great wealth, he lacks simple social skills.  I fell in love with the sweetness of his face and the scene with him walking across the field as his long coat blows in the breeze accompanied by that gorgeous music...*fanning self frantically  His walk, his voice, and his magnificent physique combined have made me stand up and unashamedly declare that MATTHEW MCFAYDEN IS "THE" MR. DARCY!!!Also, the fact that this film was slightly over 2 hours as opposed to the other, longer versions of the story was a definite plus to me.For those reviewers who wish to harp about the clothing being wrong for the time period or certain behaviors being unacceptable and unheard of for that era...give it a rest, please!  I am an avid reader of historical romances and an avid viewer of period pieces, most with romantic themes, and I'm here to tell you that when I'm in the mood for a good romance - I could care less if the heroe's cravat is knotted incorrectly for that time of the evening during that particular time period - I'm more concerned with a good romance!  And this version of "Pride and Prejudice" delivers just that!  A beautiful and romantic tale!  Now if Mr. Darcy had decided to deal with Lizzie's rejection by flopping in front of the t.v. to watch reruns of "The Golden Girls" I might have had issues.  *laugh  You get my point though - those details are minor.  In the end, it's the story that counts.I would DEFINITELY recommend to anyone looking for a sweet romance and a wonderful film.p.s. I mistakenly hit four stars when I meant to hit five!  Amazon doesn't allow you to change your rating for some odd reason.  *shrug  Trust me when I say - this film is all of 5 stars!!!

reviewText: Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice has been translated to film several times now - from Robert Leonard's 1940 "attempt" starring Laurence Olivier, to the 1980 and 1995 TV miniseries', and now on to a new theatrical release here. Having read the book and seen all of these adaptations, I feel I can comment objectively on what does and doesn't work with regards to director Joe Wright's newest version.Let's start with the positives. It's beautifully filmed (from gnarled old trees to stunning sunsets against old English mansions) and the cast performs well. I even liked Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods, FOYLE'S WAR TV series) and the rest of the actors. They seemed to be able to grasp the internal dynamics of their respective characters and pulled in fine performances. Keira Knightley (BEND IT LIKE BECKHAM, 2002) does a good job as Lizzie Bennett but appears upbeat far too often during a time when love and loss went hand in hand. Matthew Macfayden (WUTHERING HEIGHTS TV series) does an admirable Mr. Darcy but being up against a giant of the English acting world from a previous adaptation made his character representation a bit tougher when it came to comparisons.Now let's get into my main problem: the pacing. I usually don't mind fast-paced films, but Jane Austen's book is anything but quick (checking in at around 500 pages depending on which publisher you choose). Books of this size tend to be difficult to translate to the silver screen (or TV) because of their scope, and this was the big "ouch" for this film. Clocking in at 129 minutes, condensing the book in such a drastic manner meant clipping out chapters and causing a bit of confusion. The confusion comes from the lack of understanding a new viewer might have IF they've never seen any of the previous TV/movie versions or IF they've never read the novel. When Lydia runs off with "the wrong man" it is a vital portion of the story that is only touched on and could seem disorienting to the new Pride and Prejudice viewer. We never see what happens to Lydia in London, nor do we see the wedding and where Mr. Darcy's pressure exerts itself.Comparisons will obviously be made between this theatrical release and the 1995 miniseries (which many, including myself, feel is the penultimate adaptation of Mrs. Austen's book). Some might complain that it isn't fair to make such comparisons because one was designed for television while the other was meant for theater. I'll grant that. But with the lengthy films that've come out of Hollywood lately (Lord of the Rings, King Kong, etc.), I don't feel that this new version would've suffered in the slightest by lengthening its running time and thus adding a better sense of coherency to many of the side stories. The 1995 miniseries also had an incredible benefit in that Mr. Darcy was played by the estimable Colin Firth (SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE, 1998), and it is THIS Mr. Darcy that many hold as the high standard for such work. Try putting Matthew Macfayden up against Mr. Firth and you'll see what I mean; there's just no comparing them.I did give this film a positive review because a) I liked the cinematography, and b) the acting was generally well done. But for emotional impact and excellent character portrayals look to the 1995 miniseries.

reviewText: Someone next to you on an airplane says, "I'm studying filmmaking and cinematography."  I would say, "When are you going to get a real job?"This version of P&P; shows people like me what craftspeople can do who are at the height of the film making profession.  This is occasionally (not always - thus four stars) a visually stunning film, and I don't mean Keira's face (Austen must have rolled over in her grave with that casting.)The version I like to think Jane A. would have preferred is of course the fabulous BBC version with Colin Firth as Darcy, and the wonderful Jennifer Ehle, who was born to play Elizabeth.Anyway, the camera people and the screenplay people made certain moments of this P&P; as visually moving as any I've seen in a long time.  The scene with Liz on the swing as the seasons change; the early morning scene when Darcy and Liz meet in the ...fog; the camera movement at the second ball, the confrontation in the rain; etc., these I could watch a thousand times.  Offsetting these, are the terrible ending, the family scene at the beginning, and several other weak moments (the statue admiration scene at Darcy's mansion...is she staring at what I think she's staring at?!)  Had I directed, I would have added more "edge."  More humor, more angst, more terror.But I enjoyed this latest interpretation of this masterpiece. I think you will too.  But don't see it without also seeing the BBC production.  You'll enjoy comparing the two.

reviewText: Yet another Jane Austen movie?  You could say that this stinker is an Austen-INSPIRED movie.  But any inspiration was all on Miss Austen's side.  Any movie adaptation must take some artistic license even with a literary classic, but this dreadful production takes too many unforgiveable liberties.  This is for the crowd that reads Austen and thinks, "Great story, but where's the sex?"The movie goes off course in very basic ways--plot, theme, characters and setting.  The principal characters are prominent people of means.  Why do they all look as though they need a hairbrush and a bath?  Mr. Bennet is a solitary bookworm with an acerbic wit.  How did he become become a disheveled hick?  Miss Austen writes that Elizabeth had a lively air of sportive playfulness that made it difficult for her to offend anybody.  So why are we treated to so many views of Keira Knightley's bared, vampiric teeth as she bites off her sadly abridged lines?  Matthew Fayden is an equally unsatisfactory Darcy, so far removed from the handsome, elegant, arrogance of the original that we keep waiting for the hero to show up and get the story going.  Lady Catherine is all sweaty vitriol, too vituperative to be as ridiculous as she should be.The change of setting to the Georgian period is a poor fit, as is the barnyard the Bennets appear to occupy.  Mr. Bennet is a gentleman, not a gentleman farmer.  The Elizabeth-Darcy romance is better attuned to the early age of romanticism, particularly in the relationship of the characters to nature.  Austen heroines like to be outdoors, and many pivotal scenes take place in a garden.  This aspect was far better treated in the films "Sense and Sensibility" and "Persuasion," and the BBC's Austen productions, which are more appropriately set in the Regency period.Worst of all is that final scene!  Like so many dimwitted authors who spin off Austen's novels into hot steaming garbage, someone tacked a jarring final scene onto this film that feels all the more coarse for bringing such an elegant tale to a tasteless conclusion.  Not that all the scenes that precede it are much better; but they merely distort the story.  Its clumsy ending hammers it into a cynical, profit-seeking uber-anachronism.
summary: Mr. and Mrs. Bennet as Ma and Pa Kettle

reviewText: I was certain it was impossible to improve upon the BBC's stellar interpretation of P&P.;  I was sure that no one could improve upon Jennifer Ehle and I was certain that Colin Firth was the penultimate Darcy.  This movie proved me wrong.Firstly, I want to address Keira Knightley's interpretation of my all-time favorite literary heroine.  She had the spark and fire and quick wit that is so characteristic of Elizabeth.  I thought her performance was pitch perfect and I give her the edge of Ehle.  While I do really like Ehle's rather more sedate Elizabeth, I really liked Knightley's more impetuous version.  Her outbursts sprang from her with such passion and impatience that I felt she had really nailed the character.As for Darcy, I love Firth's arrogant but socially awkward portrayal.  Because of this, I was glad to see Matthew Macfadyen play Darcy as something of a nerd.  It was an interpretation of Darcy that I'd never pictured but I think it worked splendidly.  Rather than being overtly haughty as Firth's Darcy was, Macfadyen's Darcy was painfully socially awkward and who came across as arrogant because of it.  His Darcy was intensely private and unwilling to give up his family secrets and yet all the more pained for how he knew it made him seem to Elizabeth.The rest of the cast is stellar as well, though I won't go into great depth or I'll risk running on for pages.  I particularly liked Elizabeth's warm relationship with her father and the way his eyes teared over when he wished Elizabeth happiness in her betrothal.  I also liked the way Mrs. Bennett was made more complex and her motivations made more clear.  After all, what did a woman of that social standing have to do other than ensure her daughters made prosperous marriages?  Mrs. Bennett seems so silly until one considers just how stressful it must have been to have to worry about the welfare of so many girls and to be constantly conscious of how quickly they'd sink into poverty and oblivion if their father--the sole breadwinner--were to become ill or die.The film itself is wonderfully layered and I find that with each viewing I see subtle things I had not before noticed.  It certainly bears repeat viewings not just for the wonderful story, gorgeous scenery, and stellar acting but also for the subtle background touches that become apparent once one focuses on them rather than the action occurring in the foreground.  This version is rife with small gestures and looks that speak volumes about what is occurring in the story.  Simply put, I adore this film.

reviewText: This movie does just what a classic love story should.  It takes two headstrong people with (very) different backgrounds and throws them together against the backdrop of an over-polite society and social prejudice.Each and every actor in this film is perfect and thoroughly believable.Kiera Knightley, though playing a character with limited opportunity to show her evident quickness of tongue, managed to jut her chin and give back-handed insults just enough to flaunt the independent spirit of Elizabeth Bennet.Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy was an interesting casting choice.  What I particularly like about this man was that he isn't your average pretty boy.  Macfadyen gave the character (and audience) something more than just the gorgeous smile and perfectly placed hair so often seen on Hollywood screens.Rosamund Pike, playing Elizabeth's sister Jane, shone in a supporting role.  Her short scenes were beautiful, full of hope, tears-on-cue, and occasional self-doubt.And it's not just Rosamund either.  The other supporting characters, in all their glory, delivered just enough giggling or disdain or awkwardness as was required.I definitely enjoyed this movie.  It made me think.Just a warning: you may be initially caught off guard by a certain important protestation of love from one character to another, but, upon review, you will discover that significant looks and the like were evident throughout the earlier bits of the film.Rent or buy this ASAP - you won't regret it!

reviewText: ..I still was able to find the charm in this one. I dare say I enjoyed it very much!  I like both the Firth and the Knightley versions. Funny how when we think of the BBC we think more of Mr. Darcy (Firth) and when we think of this one we think more of Elizabeth (Knightley).There are many scenes from each of the P&Ps; that I can say I like over the other, so I can't pick a true favorite version. Even with significant script downsizing and tweaking in this version, overall you still get the many *SIGH* moments between Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth and the laugh out loud moments with Mr. Collins (I'm forever a fan of the Hollander actor who played him in this rendition!). You sympathize and adore Charlotte (who is very believable as the plain "spinster-in-the-making" than the other versions) and WHO can bring aristocracy to the screen like the dame Judi?  This role was made for her and out of all P&P; ladyships, she is by far my favorite portrayal. I was also happy with the Lydia casting - her portrayal was the perfect comedic silly and selfish.LOVED Donald Sutherland's Mr. Bennett!  You get an idea of why they aren't in the best financial shape with his laid back and resigned attitude - the go-getter he is not. The scene between he and Lizzie at the end is very touching.  Any daddy's little girl will be moved when they watch it.  I know I was and still am every time I see it.Matthew MacFayden did a fine job with his portrayal of the handsome and initially stoic and snobbish Mr. Darcy.  I think his emotions and tenderness really trasmitted itself well across the screen as his feelings grew for Elizabeth.  Truly FINE performances from all of the cast.Some have brought up the discrepancies in this P&P;, yet I do not remember Mr. Darcy swimming in a lake and coming out of it sexy and dripping wet in the book like he did in the Firth version - yet we do not complain about it. That's because it was a GREAT scene (for the ladies) and it didn't take away from the movie.  There are going to be changes in each one, as long as it doesn't take away from the romance of the two and the gist of the story (again many only have 2 hours), I think when given a chance, P&P; lovers will really enjoy this one.I would have loved to have seen more effort with the costume designs, but overall I really LOVED the movie and occasionally when I have 2 hours on a rainy day, I'll pop it in. It's one of my rainy day favorites!

reviewText: Another example of the contemporary inability to render a classic in anything like its original intent, sense or form. Here we have a parade of third millennium anachronisms almost as preposterous as those on display in the equally absurd current rendering of "Tristan and Isolde." Thus, our heroine Kiera Knightley sails through the whole film with a saucy, feminist tinged, "cat that swallowed the canary," facial expression and vocal delivery, that suggest that she has been watching a great deal of Katie Couric and Elizabeth Vargas, and is dying to drop the word "empowerment," somewhere into her dialogue.Then there's the "incomparable," Judi Dench--(as the publicity breathlessly assures us). For some incomprehensible reason, contemporary casting directors' are under the lamentable delusion that Miss Dench, (like Maggie Smith) is somehow suited to grande dame roles--when nothing could be further from the truth.Having seen Miss Dench on stage in a five hour production of "Cymbeline," at Stratford on Avon, I can personally attest to her range and power as an actress. However, whatever her qualifications for Shakespeare, there is nothing in her appearance or deportment that is remotely aristocratic in the 18th/19th century sense of the term.Indeed, if anything, her persona is pronouncedly proletariat.Add to that her coarse and rubicund complexion, (un-pancaked in the current naturalistic mode) and her Lady Catherine appears more like a refugee from a Hogarthian gin palace than the daunting and imperious creature Miss Austen intended.Martita Hunt where are you now that we need you?There is little to say about Donald Sutherland in the role of Mr. Bennet, inasmuch as he has built a successful career out of being miscast--a feat he continues with this role. And his wife in the picture, (far from the lavender, rose silk and cream Mary Boland of yore) looks like a blowsy, overage bawd from the cast of a backwoods dinner theater production of "Moll Flanders," who has somehow wandered onto the wrong movie set.But mercifully we at length arrive at the priceless (and now requisite) final clinch, where Miss Knightley and Mr. Macfadyen are depicted in the lotus position on a lake in front of their chteau, where they proceed to launch into a demonstration of mutual affection that looks like a TV promo for "The Bachelor," and makes one wonder if Brad Pitt and Julia Roberts are standing just outside of camera range whispering instructions.For now if you absolutely require a filmed alternative to the novel itself--stick with the 1940 Greer Garson or unfairly ignored 1979 British TV version.

reviewText: I like this newest film adaption of Jane Austen's classic "Pride and Prejudice."  I won't rehash the plot here or where the movie differs from the novel, as numerious other reviews have already done so.  I think the movie is loyal to the novel where it counts, and that is the courtship of Fitzwilliam Darcy and Elizabeth Bennett.  Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen breath new life into the characters of Elizabeth and Darcy and they truly inhabit their respective roles.  I particularly liked Macfadyen's Darcy, as he seems much more feeling and would be the kind of person who would inspire the loyalty of his close friends and family as in the novel.  The supporting cast is also excellent and has some of the most beautiful women from accross the pond, including Rosamund Pike and the underused Kelly Reilly.  I highly recommend this fresh remake of "Pride and Prejudice."

reviewText: This is even worse than the Mormon one!  If you want to have any idea of what the novel is actually like, DO NOT watch this film.  People did not act, dress, speak, or live like this. It is truly abhorrent to me that this film has such high ratings, because it is *nothing* like the book, and the book is excellent.  That it leeched on Austen's work to be made, that a studio exec thought that this was a good idea, it's almost as bad (and successful) as "Springtime for Hitler" in THE PRODUCERS.  Completely outrageous!  The Mormon P&P was better, the Bollywood P&P was better (actually very good, BRIDE & PREJUDICE), the A&E P&P was miles better, even the WISHBONE P&P is better!  Ugh. It might be better if Keira Knightly could act, but I don't deal in fantasy.
summary: The worst P&P adaptation I've ever seen

reviewText: Beautiful cinematography and an Academy Award-nominated performance from Keira Knightley make this newest film version of Jane Austen's PRIDE AND PREJUDICE one to savour.  Although there is a legion of dedicated fans for whom the 1995 BBC miniseries (with Colin Firth) is still the definitive screen treatment, director Joe Wright (with a screenplay by Deborah Moggach and Emma Thompson) invests this version with a youthful feel and a slightly earthy, grittier edge.  Most importantly, Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen (as Darcy) are very close in age to what Austen describes in the novel.Headstrong and opinionated Elizabeth Bennet's rocky road to romance with the "insufferably proud" Mr Darcy plays out it's course against Austen's web of family intrigue and social mores. The colourful gallery of supporting players includes Brenda Blethyn as the social-climbing Mrs Bennet, Rosamund Pike as Jane, Jena Malone as Lydia, Donald Sutherland as Mr Bennet, Kelly Reilly as Miss Bingley, Tom Hollander as Mr Collins and Dame Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourg (a role she was born to play).While the Austen novel, with all it's incidents and well-crafted story, is better suited to the luxurious running-time of a miniseries, this new version is, on the whole, very enjoyable and fans of the Austen works will surely love it.
summary: Austen's story given the grand treatment
Title: N/A

reviewText: The reviewers who gave this film low marks are entitled to their opinion as I am entitled to mine. The initial urge to criticize this film dissipated after glancing at a quick second showing. It is not required that a movie be perfect in order for it to be perfected within itself given the constraints of various limitations. Those who cry foul and point to inaccurate text mirroring or cite smidglings of literary discrepancies seem to have bones too stiff for enjoyment. Although it is possible (usually in most films it is not only possible, but probable, that different actors may have carried success to further extreme - or inversely, failure), it seems pointless to snivel about it. We have these actors - these particular combinations - no others. This film came into a life of its own and spoke well to the human condition. The acting, overall, was excellent and in several instances phenomenal. Quite a wonderful pleasure. We would certainly be the poorer without it.

reviewText: Purists may not like this version and I too am a lover of the classic version. But.....  Directed by Joe Wright and screenwritten by Deborah Moggach, this is the most visually arresting and artistic of the "Pride & Prejudice" films.  The strength of the other versions has always been the dialogue. This is the first version which trusts the camera and imagery and lets the luminosity of the story line shine through rather than talking straight through it. The actors in this version are also a who's who of British acting. There is the young and impudent incandesence of Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet. She is the prejudiced one against the wealth and position of the young man who initially finds her too inferior to even be his dance partner.  This is Mr. Darcy as played by Matthew Macfadyen.  I was used to him as the head spy on MI-5 so he is maybe the last actor I would have cast as Darcy. However, I didn't realize how versatile an actor he is.  He is fabulous as Darcy, the one who suffers from pride in his origins, his convictions, his family and his property.  Elizabeth is beneath him so how could he fall in love with her?  This is the best story for answering that question with "how indeed!" Brenda Blethyn and Judi Dench play Mrs. Bennett and Lady Catherine.  Acting doesn't get any better than this.  See it with an open mind.
summary: Excellent Adaptation of Classic--Most Visual & Artistic Version
Title: N/A

reviewText: Stunning photography and highly imaginative scripting and casting: Donald Sutherland (Mr. Bennet) is especially striking in his clear familial and sartorial resemblance to great-great-grandson Buddy Ebson (Jed Clampett), before the family left England (possibly due to some unspeakable behavior involving pigs) and moved to the New World where they acquired more polish and class, rising in American society to the beautiful mountains of Kentucky.The director has wisely smoothed out Austen's complex characters and overly involved plot to a level more suitable to modern sensibilities and tastes; for moderns challenged by the complexities of "The Beverly Hillbillies" or Harlequin novels, this tender tale provides all the depth, subtlety, and brilliant crafting of a Barbara Cartland Romance.Stars are subtracted from this otherwise lovely film as an issue of Truth In Labeling, with potential confusion to the consumer. It is common for artists producing a work "Based On" a classic work (but bearing little resemblance to the original) to give their work a fitting alternate name. For example, a stirring tale "based on" "Homer's Oddysey" might become "O, Brother Where Art Thou" or it might become "Cold Mountain." The novel "based on Jane Austin's "Emma" has become "Clueless" and her "Pride and Prejudice" has become "Bridget Jones' Diary." This production continues as "Pride and Prejudice" suggesting that credit belongs to Austin. Very gracious and modest of them, after putting so much of their own creativity (and so little of hers) into the movie, but really, they shouldn't have.
summary: A Tender, Beautifully-Filmed Prequel to "The Clampetts"

reviewText: This is a beautiful version of the classic Jane Austin novel Pride and Prejudice. the actors and actresses are beautiful and the English countryside glows golden at sun rise and sun set. There are three aspects of the film that I will point out tht make it wonderful entertainment.First, Elizabeth Bennett is one of the great characters in English literature. Here she is played as more impulsive than Jennifer Ehle plays the part in the great BBC version. For example, beautiful Kiera Knightley plays Elizabeth as young, playful, and inclined to romance, as evidenced by her reactions to Mr. Darnley at the country house dance at the beginning of the film. Jennifer Ehle pays Elizabeth Bennett as more reserved, more mature, and more sphnix-like. The strength of Elizabeth Bennett is that she is witty, intelligent, considerate, and willing to change her mind. It is this last quality, the willingness to changer her mind, on which much of the film revolves. Elizabeth's first impression of Mr. Darnley was that whereas he was rich and handsome, he was also arrogant and prideful an maybe even a little cruel. Eventually, through a series of mishaps and interactions, she begins to see him differently, seeing his strenghts and compassion and convictions and most of all, his love for her despite the tensions and misunderstandings they undergo.The scene where Darnley proposes to Elizabeth despite his low regard for her wild family and her poverty was wonderfully played in this film, with Kiera Knightley firing back at him that his poorly worded proposal of marriage was the height of insult to her and her family.Yet these two weather this upsetting event and go on to love each other greatly as they further discover each other's best qualities. Isn't this what love should really be about? Shouldn't we move from erotic first impressions to deeper appreciation and understanding of each other?Second, Darnley is well played here. Colin Firth does such an exceptional job in the BBC version that it was hard for me to warm up to another Mr. Darnley, but this actor gives us a version of Darnley that is more mysterious and less aristocratic than the Firth version.Third, Jane Austin creates a charming world full of odd, delighful, endearing, and yet realistic characters. Jane Bennett is the height of beauty and sweetness, no wonder Mr. Bingley falls madly in love. Mr. Bingley is as silly as he is rich, however he is sincere and is a perfect match for Jane. Mr. Bingley's sister is wonderfully played and I loved the line she speaks at the country dance where she wonders when the guests will stop dancing and chase pigs. Lydia Bennett is such an empty headed young women, not realizing how her elopement could ruin the reputations of her sisters. Mr. Collins is such a fool, basing his self worth on the whims of his wealthy benefactor, Lady de Bourge. Judi Dench plays a great angry scheming Lady de Bourge. Mr. Bennett says in the book: "God placed us here on earth to laugh at our neighbor's folly and for our neighbor in turn to laugh at ours." This line wonderfully represents Austin's philosophy which she brings to all her characters.The acting is super and truly romantic, the English countryside is beautifuland moody, and the novel actually can be revealed in a short two hours, which I could not believe until I saw it.
summary: Very good updated version of a wonderful classic

reviewText: I own both versions of this story and love both of them. However, if I had to choose between them, this would be the one I'd pick. The interplay between Elizabeth and Darcy is breathtakingly intense from their first glances and their inner struggles are shown clearly on their faces, unlike the greater restraint shown in the longer BBC version. The whole thing is much more cinematic than the latter, also, and the ballroom scene where everyone but Elizabeth and Darcy disappears for a moment is but one of many masterful touches throughout the movie. It does not follow the book as well as the BBC version does, but somehow it fleshes it out and redeems it for the 21st Century. Excellent in every respect except that I can't seem to get enough of watching it! :-)

reviewText: This is a wonderful ADAPTATION of the story of Darcy and Lizzy, very well made with beautiful music, scenery and artsy segues. I would recommend anyone unfamiliar with this story to NOT watch this movie first. It is a nice, bite size version that can best be appreciated when watched with a prior understanding of the characters and the story (as it hacks the actual story to pieces). First, of course, see the '95 version (and read the book!).My praise: Artsy, artsy, artsy! If you listen to the commentary, the director really knew the story and was NOT trying to blatantly follow the book (as we all know, that has been done with perfection, so why try?). He was trying to bring fresh thought and feeling to it and, though I don't agree with a lot of the re-writing of the lines, I applaud the way he alluded to the windows being a metaphor for perception, the way the sunrise opened and closed the story, the setting being 100 years prior to the actual setting of the book, the domestic abuse of Lydia by Wickham (which we all suspected), the little character nuances and sub-plots that took place in the background of every scene (you gotta be quick!), and the romance he could achieve with scenery and music, when no action was taking place. Oo! Simply beautiful! So much more than simply telling the same old tale! And the first-proposal scene! Nice!My rant: I felt this version blew thru the actual story perhaps a little too fast. Much of the wit for which Jane Austen is so well known is NOT done justice. Lines from the book which ARE left intact are spewed with little thought or acting, especially in the beginning. Sometimes so fast that, if I wasn't familiar with the dialogue, I would've had no idea what was going on. And character development? What's that?I was not infatuated with Knightley as Miss Lizzy. She lacked the playfulness and intrigue of her character. She had some of the best lines, yet constantly disappointed me in their delivery. Plus, she always looked disheveled and sticky to the touch. And the teeth on Mr. Bennet! Such pearly, straight choppers for a poor man in 1790! They are blinding amidst all the gloom. C'mon makeup guy, try a little harder!However, Macfadyen was wonderful as Darcy and I wish he had more scenes to better explain his character. I feel he could've done it justice. And Lady Catherine? Perfection!I really expected this to throw out ALL the wit and plot and turn this into some sickly, thin love story that would appeal to idiots everywhere (the 2 hours run time scared me). However, it did not. Some wit remained, all the high points were addressed and there was many a scene where Knightley and Macfadyen had fantastic chemistry. In the end, though, it just wasn't there for me. A little cheesy/sappy perhaps.My ideal P&P; would be somewhere between this and the '95 one. I LOVE the romantic artsy-ness this one brings to the table, yet the '95 version is faultless in it's story. Oh well, maybe the next version will be better.Should you buy this one? Of course! A new take on a great story is always appreciated! However, I would recommend the WS version, as the director has a lot of shots with characters on extreme R and L, and they are uncomfortably close to the edges of the screen on the FS version. Plus, WS will do the beautiful, sweeping wide-angle scenery better justice.

reviewText: Matthew McFadyen's portrayal of Darcy has yet to get the credit it deserves. He was the very living vision of Jane Austen's character. He brought to life the person she described as "not having the talent to converse with strangers easily". The people who masterfully created this movie understood Jane Austen. McFaydyen made Colin Firth ( Darcy in the BBC version) look two dimensional (not an easy task). Keira Knightley as Elizabeth was inspiring. Watching this movie made you feel as though you were eavesdropping not only on the poetic unfolding of the character's lives, but even their thoughts and emotions. An enjoyable experience.

reviewText: This is my favorite book of all time. I own the miniseries in both VCR and DVD format. While I realize it's hard to fairly compare the two, due to running time I found to be fair I'd look at a few different things.  After reading the book so many times one comes to know the dialogue and vernacular. I gave allowances for the running time on the former but the slipping in and out of period vernacular on the latter drove me a bit nuts.  Locations beautiful.  Most of the characters well cast. (Mary is the unnattractive sister and a Talulah Riley is very pretty)  Particularly liked Dame Judy Dench as Lady Catherine and Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett.  Also did not like completely deleting characters and changing the dialogue to suit.  Suddenly the Gardiners have no children?  Where was Maria Lucas?  Unmarried ladies of the time did not travel alone. The the turning-point is the trip to Pemberly. Ladies of the time would not be visiting a house touching things.  Yes I know this movie is adapted from the book, but I think I would have given it another star if it stayed truer to the book and the proper behavior of the period.  I'd watch it again, but like the title of my review states... The Colin Firth mini-series sets the bar and those are some very big shoes to fill, indeed.
summary: The Colin Firth Mini Series sets the bar

reviewText: The disc set is packaged in a box cleverly designed to look like a P&P; book.  Inside is the double disc set, the amazing soundtrack, and a terrific book with lots of commentary on the filming and photos.  The book in itself is a treat as I remember similar Oscar pressbooks going on ebay for upwards of a $100.  (I in fact was able to win a French one -- and am so delighted to have the English counterpart!)  The CD is fantastic -- as the Dario Marianelli music is one of the truly magical treasures of the film.  The 1st disc is exactly like the DVD I all ready have with  the director's commentary; conversations with the cast; Jane Austen, Ahead of Her Time; A Bennett Family Portrait; and HBO First Look.  The 2nd has the new features:  1)The Politics of Dating (with a funny comment by Matthew Macfadyen quipping something like, "I fancy you; here's my number"  and cutting away to a handwritten Fitwilliam Darcy calling card with a number on it. Too funny.Enjoyable.  2)Galleries of the 19th Century which has stills of various art, furniture and fashions.  Interesting.  3)The Stately Homes of P&P; that you can use the interactive map to look at stills of the homes of the movie as well as watch film with interviews and comments about the locations.  VERY good.  4) P&P; Family Tree was something lacking.  Interesting for those that may be new to the story but for me it was just "filler."All in all, I am pleased to have it.  Was excited to get anything new about the story and this film.  Yes, I would have loved to have seen more unseen interviews with the characters, bloopers, cut scenes, etc... If that is what you are hoping for with this new release, that is not in this gift set.  However, if you are a fan of the movie, would like the sountrack, a couple extras on the 2nd DVD, and that most excellent pressbook... then buy this.  I for one am happy to have it in my collection.  Besides, it's always good to have a back-up copy of the film... god forbid, if I cannot locate my Dvd when I am in need of my P&P2005; fix! And for an added bonus, my copy came with a free movie pass to Keira Knightley's ATONEMENT.
summary: This was a delightful gift,,, to myself!

reviewText: I finished reading Pride and Prejudice and immediately checked out the Colin Firth BBC series as well as this film from my local library.  I watched this film first since it was only slightly shorter than the BBC series from the mid 90s.The film stays pretty true to the nature of the book, with some few exceptions.  Mainly there are many moments from the book which could not possibly make it into a 2 hour film.  Several characters were cut entirely, such as Maria and Sir William Lucas.  The two visits to Catherine de Bourg's estate were condensed into one.  And there are a few added scenes where the film takes some liberty.  All in all though, the changes made were good for the pace and continuity of the film.  The only odd scene was when Lizzy confronted Darcy about Jane and Bingly and Wickham.  He actually gives half of his response there, then the other half is contained in a letter (like the book). But the half response kind of takes something away from that moment as described in the novel.The acting is very good.  I liked the casting for most of the main characters.  Donald Sutherland was an odd choice, but he worked as Mr Bennett.  Kiera Knightly is very good as Lizzy; she embodies the under appreciated attractiveness that is described in the novel, especially compared to her more obviously and classically attractive sister Jane.  Knightly embodies the fire and the tomboy style of Lizzy's character very well.I am most happy with the actor who played Darcy.  He is very good at the brooding, yet firm resolution of Darcy's character.  He has the tall, rugged handsomeness that Austen describes.The production quality is what I liked about this film over the drab and overly dark (just bad contrast, not anything with the lighting) BBC series.  Where the BBC series looks like a DVD made from one of those VHS dubbing to DVD devices, this film shines with dramatic settings, and quality film making.  Granted they had the budget to do so!  But with great cinematography, a quality soundtrack, and terrific casting, this is easily my favorite Pride and Prejudice adaptation (over the Laurence Olivier film and the BBC series).
summary: Review of the film as compared to the novel~

reviewText: I hate to review the movie in such a fashion but invariably as a fan of the TV version, I initially (and errantly) made comparisons to that version and this film version.Overall, I was rather pleased and surprised by my reaction to this film.  Granted with a listing of solid actors, I did not anticipate it being bad, but instead a bad interpretation of the book (which I have read a couple of times) especially given the time constraints that feature film provides.While the 1995 TV version is quintessential in its adaptation of the text, the 2005 film version in my humble opinion captures the spirit and the raw emotion that although not on public display must have been in the hearts and minds of the central characters.  I guess this is what many folks consider the "modern edge" given to this adaptation.  I personally found it refreshing, vibrant and alive.In terms of casting I must start by saying that I loved Keira Knightley's Lizzie - by far the best interpretation of the role.  And despite those who were blown away by the dashing Colin Firth, Matthew MacFadyen did the role of Darcy service.  His performance wonderfully gives perspective and insight into the perceived fastidiousness of the Darcy persona - I felt like in this version I understood where he is coming from.Beyond the two leads, all the supporting characters did a wonderful job.  I am almost tempted to go to the theater and see it again it was that good.  Highly recommended to all!

reviewText: Having watched the 1940 Pride and Prejudice (Greer Garson and Lawrence Olivier) and BBC's TV version (Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle), it is simply a must for me to see this remake and compare with its predecessors.In the first 30 minutes, I have to adjust to Keira Knightley's relatively modern face and giggles. She has given such an impressive performance in Bend it Like Beckham and Love Actually that it took time to envisage her in the classic role of Elizabeth. Fortunately, the last hour of the movie saw her adding greater depth to her character, making her and Mr. Darcy a charming couple to watch.While the 1940 version revealed a more comical side of the story (such as performances of Mr. Collins and Lady Catherine de Bourg) and the BBC version was graced by the beautiful landscape and the handesome Colin Firth, I would say this one is a well balanced remake. Maybe Elizabeth (Knightley)and Darcy(Matthew MacFaydyen) on their own do not steal the scenes. Yet together they look such an attractive couple. A 20-year-old Knightley has made Elizabeth come alive on screen, intelligent and beautiful. MacFaydyen has also portrayed a handsome and vulnerable Mr. Darcy. Jane was convincingly sweet and uncalculating whereas Donald Sutherland, as the father, gave her daughter away in tears of joy.The superb cinematography, a sense of tension and urgency when Elizabeth discovered how she had wronged Darcy, a quickening of pace made possible by rearranging and rewriting (Alas, a big risk!)of some scenes have all made the movie a delight to watch. Credits must also be given to a more realistic portrayal of the Bennet family. The Bennet sisters' costumes were conspicously plainer than the Bingley's and Darcy's. The extravagant interior design of the grand mansion (Chatsworth) at Pemberly is simply awesome.As a big fan of the previous versions, to be able to finish the movie and still feel good about it, I would say this movie is a successful remake. Even for fans mesmerized by the other remakes, this movie is worth watching for including new elements which complements nicely to its predecessors.

reviewText: Adaptations are always tricky since condensing a large 200-500+ page book can lead to liberties and many events taken out entirely. Another thing that can happen is filmmakers tend to be too nervous of altering anything that what worked in book format doesn't work as well on film. Hence we get Pride and Prejudice, which looks great, has respectable casting, but unfortunately has poor pacing and its 19th century-esque language.The film centers around the Bennet sisters, most specifically Elizabeth(Lizzy) and Jane. They're all trying to get married, hopefully with someone with a big wallet. Jane ends up meeting someone named Mr. Bingley which takes an awful long time to resolve while Lizzy is in a love/hate mode with Mr. Darcy, a friend of Mr Bingley. The entire rest of the film follows the 2 women trying to get their respective men to marry them while the mom gets frantic about marrying them off.One thing that tends to plague adaptations is trying to match the spirit of the novel a bit too closely without making it work in a film format. As such the book resembles the language from the book, incredibly long and dictionary-laden words are throughout the film, making me ask "isn't it better to just say 'I hate you' rather than that much words"? Same thing with the modern Romeo and Juliet film except this takes place in its proper time period and still seems odd hearing it.Many actors and actresses seem to only have that in title only, as if they don't actually "act" they just do their job without doing much else. Usually they're girls with pretty faces where you watch them in a film and they don't really do much else that makes them memorable, they just read their lines. Look at Al Pacino in Godfather or Peter O' Toole in Lawrence of Arabia, perfect acting but making them transcend just lines on the page. The actresses here do their parts well, with a special nod of course to Keira Knightley who still has some awkwardness but is still capable of making a character believable.It's a period piece so you're going to expect 2 things: beautifully shot and accurate costumes and of course we have both. Colorful sharp cinematography with 18th century style clothes make the film feel believable and accurate. The music also suits the film well, largely piano-based with some orchestration peppered throughout but not enough memorable themes to make me want to buy the soundtrack.If you don't really feel like reading the novel, it's always best to check out this film although it's not exactly need to buy DVD material, unless you're a Jane Austen fan.
summary: 3.5; I merely liked it, didn't find it great

reviewText: In my freshman literature seminar, I was put on the spot by my professor and asked how I liked Pride and Prejudice. After a few throat clearings, I admitted that I had not been a fan and in fact found the language so dry so as to make the novel boring. I certainly am not alone in thinking this, and most who do tend to be male. That being said, this movie was incredibly entertaining. I've heard marvelous things about the long BBC version (many people watched it instead of reading the book for my seminar), but it's hard to imagine it being better than this. Knightley reminded me of Winona Ryder in Little Women and played her character splendidly. I highly recommend this for girls and guys alike. You'll love the dry British humor and the wonderful scenery. Maybe even more than the book itself.

reviewText: Pride Ampersand Prejudice (or just plain Pride and Prejudice) is a pleasant movie with nice acting by all concerned. Keira Knightley does a fine job, but for me Jennifer Ehle remains the gold standard for Lizzies. The director and writer crammed a lot into the run time. If you like the more leisurely pace of the BBC Ehle/Firth version, you might find yourself longing for more than you're getting. But with either, or the much earlier BBC version from 1980, the story is such a strong, romantic fable of manners and misunderstandings that it's hard to go wrong. Even the half-hour TV program with Wishbone as Darcy was good. If you've never seen a version of Pride and Prejudice, however, please don't start out with the Olivier-Garson movie.The only criticism I have is that I thought the movie score was overblown and there were a few too many grand scenic shots. This version is entertaining and satisfying but, for me, not especially memorable.
summary: A Pleasant Way To Spend An Afternoon

reviewText: I am an avid fan of the 1995 A&E;/BBC version of Pride and Prejudice starring Colin Firth.  And so, I had my reservations about giving this one a whirl.  Most of Hollywood's literary adaptations are underdeveloped, underwhelming and downright superficial.  Emma starring Gwyneth Paltrow springs to mind.  However, this 2005 adaptation directed by Joe Wright and adapted by Deborah Moggach, while not better than the 1995 version, is definitely more enjoyable than the bunch.  (Warning: there will be more comparisons between this version and the 1995 version.  So, if you're tired of reading comparisons between those two, then I suggest you skip reading this review.)  The cinematography is gorgeous -- the scenery and sets are a major eyeful.  The film direction is one of the best I've seen.  Wright has done a splendid job.  The music score is one of the best I've heard.  I especially love "Dawn," the one played in the beginning of the movie.  It is absolutely beautiful. The wardrobe, however, is a disappointment.  The gowns (more Georgian than Regency) are not appropriate for the time.  Elizabeth Bennet would have never attended the Netherfield ball without wearing gloves and Caroline Bingley's sleeveless slip dress with a plunging neckline is downright anachronistic.  Not only does it look too modern, a noble lady would have never worn such a flimsy gown at a formal ball unless she was some sort of daring widow wanting to cause a scandal.  The gowns Mrs. Bennet and Lady Catherine de Bourgh wore were at least two decades or so out of style.  And I won't even comment on Judy Dench's hairstyle except for one expression: yikes!  That hairdo was fashionable in the 1750s -- at least sixty years before Austen wrote Pride and Prejudice.  The quality of the characterization varies from person to person. I do not like Keira Knightley's Elizabeth Bennet.  Knightley does not show the right amount of sharp wit, intelligence and conflicting emotions that makes Miss Bennet one of the most endearing heroines in literature.  The director concentrates more on Knightley's pretty face than on focusing on the character's complexities.  This Elizabeth is too petulant and giggly for my taste.  Jennifer Ehle had a better grasp of the character.  I did not like Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet.  He comes across more as a cynical, laid-back loner than the sarcastic and witty character in the book, qualities that were passed on to Elizabeth.  (By the way, I found it odd that in this film Mr. Bennet and Lizzy do not have the kind of closeness and affection that is required in their roles.)  Also, his imitation of an English accent is simply awful.  I wish Benjamin Whitrow had been cast in this version as well.  I also liked the actor who played Mr. Collins in the '95 version better than Tom Hollander.  Even though Hollander was wonderful in BBC's Wives and Daughters, I feel he was miscast as Mr. Collins.  The actors who played Mrs. Bennet, Jane, Mr. Bingley, Caroline Bingley, Lydia and Kitty do a good job, but somehow aren't as colorful as the ones in the 1995 miniseries.  And last, but definitely not least, is Matthew Macfadyen as the dark, handsome, proud and brooding Mr. Darcy.I don't think I'm being biased when I say that, while Macfadyen does some wonderful scenes in which Darcy shows his longing for Elizabeth, he in no way outshadows Colin Firth's performance.  Firth was able to transmit Mr. Darcy's complexities and conflicting emotions in almost a flawless way.  He also convinced me that Mr. Darcy was indeed rude and proud, or at least seemed that way from Elizabeth's perspective, and Macfadyen's Mr. Darcy comes across more as shy and awkward than anything else, which would have been fine, but then why would he be so against Elizabeth's poor connections and convince Mr. Bingley that Jane isn't the one for him?  The one thing Macfadyen was able to convey better than Firth was his love and desire for Elizabeth.  (Actually, I thought Firth's subtle approach to Darcy's feelings and sexual tension for Lizzy was more dead on.  Macfadyen's approach is more blatant and in-your-face.)  This film's Darcy appearing without a cravat in the last scenes has a nice, sensual touch, but it's nothing like Firth jumping on the lake and then walking back to Pemberley in wet clothes.  Anyway, as for the rest of the film, due to time constraints, many scenes are glossed over, including the whole Lydia and Mr. Wickham debacle.  In fact, Mr. Wickham, such an integral character in the story, appears only in two or three scenes! There are also some characters that are eliminated altogether, like Mr. Bingley's married sister (who was supposed to be Miss Bingley's chaperone.  Miss Bingley would have never stayed at a house alone with two single men, even if one of them was her brother).  And what can I say about this version's Miss Caroline Bingley except that all she does is scowl, purse her lips and look conceited?  Anna Chancellor of the 1995 version may not be as attractive as Kelly Reilly, but she was definitely better developed.  In fact, the characters and storyline were better developed in the 1995 version.  Then again, the miniseries had eight episodes, plenty of time to be true to the novel.  Also, this version is not as centered on humor as it should have been.  This version is more solemn and everything and everyone centers on Elizabeth.  Then there are the anachronisms.  Mr. Bingley would have never entered the private chambers of a female guest, Elizabeth would have never walked around the village with her hair undone, Mr. Darcy would have never entered Elizabeth's bedroom (without wearing a cravat) to hand her a letter, and Lady Catherine de Bourgh would never pay a visit in the middle of the night.  Perhaps these details are negligible to some, but not for me.  Period accuracy is very important to me.  All in all, despite all the flaws I mentioned regarding the cast and condensed plot due to the limited 129-minute format, this adaptation of Pride and Prejudice is still worth watching and owning, which is why I give it four stars.  The last scenes are wonderful and romantic (if a bit corny), perfect for fans of period pieces with modern-day sensitivities.  The DVD is also wonderful -- great audio and video with wonderful special features.  I highly recommend it.  And, if you haven't watched it, please get the A&E;/BBC production starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle if you long for a truer adaptation of Austen's literary classic.  That goes without saying, but I had to anyway. :-)
summary: Not perfect or quite as good as P&P '95, but still enjoyable and recommendable...

reviewText: Admittedly, I did not have high hopes for this moving knowing that it would be hard to do in 2 hours what A&E; did in 5+ hours.  But,  I had thought it would have been better--Emma and Sense and Sensibility were much better shortened Hollywood versions of Austen's books than this was.So what did I find wrong with this adaptation?1.  The Bennets looked sloppy and poor.  I immediately thought back to two lines from the book that made me think that this was not how the Bennet's should have appeared:  Jane tells Lizzy "We're not very poor." and Lizzy telling Lady Catherine "He is a gentleman and I am a gentleman's daughter, so far we are equal."  I felt that the Bennet's looked just a little better than the orphans in Oliver Twist.2.  Mr. Bennett was portrayed as a grumpy old man.  One thing I  loved about Pride and Predjudice was Austen's humor and Mr. Bennett had in my opinion some of her best lines.  These were totally lacking in this movie and didn't need to be--why change his character completely?  True, he did redeem himself a little in the end and I loved the line about sending in any beau's that may call for Kitty and Mary."3.  At the movie's beginning, Lizzy seemed to have a chip on her shoulder and hated Darcy from the moment he walked in the door.  I couldn't account for that.  She felt at liberty to make biting comments to him before she ever overheard his critical comment of her.  She really irritated me from the beginning and it was hard to get past that to enjoy the rest of the movie.4.  Mr.  Bingley appeared as a bumbling imbesole instead of a humble and likeable gentleman and I agree with one writer that the actress who played Jane would have made a better Elizabeth.  Jane seemed to have more wits about her than Lizzy.  Kitty and Lydia and sometimes Lizzy seemed to giggle for no reason.  I found them irritating as well. Georgiana Darcy's character was also altered.  The book describes her as being very shy as to appear a snob but that is not so.  This Georgiana was not a bit shy.Overall, I felt that the end of the film was better than the beginning, but I still would never buy or recommend this movie.  I wondered if I would have liked it better having known nothing of the book.  I would have preferred much more of the story cut out to develop the overall love story between Elizabeth and Darcy and give certain characters more presence.I know that my reviews will probably be unpopular, since others who have rated this movie poorly have recieved ratings to reflect that, but to be honest, I find it hard to find many things I liked about this version.I'll stick to the A&E; version.

reviewText: The review on the box says "Best Film of the Year" and I would agree that it's one of the best for sure.  It's beautifully done.....with fabulous acting and an outstanding screen play.  The costumes are lovely, too.  It's an in depth look into the restrictive, oppressed English life in the late 1800's. The thing i liked about it the best is that it ENDS HAPPY.  None of that "unspoken rule" from Hollywood that says if a movie doesn't end with everyone dying or suffering, it's not a good movie.  This movie fulfills all your fantasies about how injustices should be answered and reminds you that life and love really can be all you want it to be.  Rent or buy it FOR SURE.
summary: GREAT  classic drama/comedy/love story from Jane Austen

reviewText: I went to see this in the theater,and then refreshed my memory as to its sheer awfulness by watching it again on an airplane flight. The worst feature of the film is the script, with its utterly tin-eared adaptation of Austen's brilliant dialogue. The casting, acting, costumes and attempts to represent daily life in the Regency are also really, really bad. Austen's Eliza Bennett is a rather sharp-tongued young lady, but Keira Knightley plays her as an out and out boor. Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett has to be one of the most inappropriate pieces of casting I've ever seen. The filmmakers seem to think that Regency gentlemen lived like Albanian peasants of the same era -- e.g., see the scene in which Donald Sutherland is seen following a large pig into the pigsty which is actually attached to the Bennetts' house. Elizabeth and Darcy play the climactic love scene outside, in their jammies. If you want to watch an adaptation that is true to Austen, buy the DVD of the wonderful 1980 BBC "P&P" with Elizabeth Garvie as Eliza Bennett. Everything about it -- cast, acting, script -- is perfect.
summary: This is dreadful -- don't waste your money

reviewText: In reading other reviews of this movie, I felt I just had to be one to say something nice about it! Just like every other movie, this one had strengths and weakness, here is my take on it:Strengths-This movie looked amazing, it was truely beautiful to look at! The cinematography was beautiful and more artistic than a lot of flims that have come out. The colors were very rich, and the lighting was...perfect. Location shots were wide and encompassing; when Elizabeth first saw Mr. Darcy's home, you can "feel" and see how large and impressive it is. Another seen that stands out, was when Elizabeth was being shown around Mr. Darcy's home and is shown into a room full of light, and sculptures. The feeling of coolness in the room, being full of diffused light, and pale white marble figures, was lovely!I also enjoyed a more "down to earth feel" to the family, and their looks. They may have had a richer station in the book, but the fact that the family was not swimming in silks, furniture and little lap dogs, hardly detracts from the film. Not to mention the sisters acted, well...like girls! We are not all perfectly behaved all the time, nor are we little angels.Also, the ages for Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy in the actors, were closer to the book. And I think their youth and inexperience with love/relationships, was a nice refreshing way to act their parts.Finely, I loved the big ballroom, dance! The music, wall to wall people and activity was very realistic. I felt like I was there in the room, listening to the girls talking, dancing and laughing. In our modern age of elictric lights, CD players and deodorant I think we sometimes forget what a candle light party, with a bunch of sweaty people in it would look like.Weaknesses-Yes, the story is kind of choppy. If you haven't either read the book, or seen the four hour A&E; version you might be lost. Although strangely enough, I went to see this with four other women...all fairly "girly girls", and they all felt the story went "too slow" and was almost "too long for a movie".Another thing I have to agree with, is that the different relationships could have been given more time, or better development. But still, at the end of the movie you don't leave wondering what happend to anyone, or wondering why someone was left out. You know what happens!Conclusion-In the end I really liked this movie. The twist's and a different artistic take on a good story, is always a pleasant thing. Maybe it wasn't historiclly perfect, or exact to the book...but if that is what you really want; Stick to the book.

reviewText: I suppose it could be said it was my misfortune to be introduced to Pride and Prejudice by the 1983 BBC adaption by Fay Weldon directed by Cyril Coke and starring Elizabeth Garvey and David Rintoul. Not the 1940 Leonard version with Oliver and Greer Garson, nor the later BBC adaptation with Colin Firth, and not, alas, this 2005 version measure up in tone or historical accuracy. The beauty and faithfulness of Weldon's script, the spot-on casting and attention to historical detail more than make up for the lesser production values.Keira Kneightly fails completely to project the moral character of Jane, conveying little more than a sort of morose petulance with her vacant, glazed-over expressions, colossus of a jaw and toothy mouth. Spoiled and resentful instead of spirited and principled, her emotionally constipated delivery of lines seems forced and pugnacious rather than courageous. Nothing about her invites us in--she is too stiff and self-conscious, too virginal. Sentimental music by the yard and grand landscapes are no substitute for emotional resonance with the protagonist. The thread-bear script is in part to blame for the failure to convincingly embody the moral- and class-conflicts that drive the novel. Jane is never allowed to manifest as the outspoken, head-strong, shrewd yet empathic young woman that she is. Perhaps her character was dumbed-down out of a fear that a modern-day audience, with its egalitarian prejudices (the taboo against distinguishing oneself intellectually) and despite its enlightened feminism, might be put-off by such a characterization. Elizabeth Garvey, on the other hand, managed to be alluringly feminine (warm) and intriguingly articulate--the ideal balance of head and heart.The film fails to convey the mores or the class- and sex distinctions of the period with any conviction. The minds behind this adaptation seem younger (more beholden to youth-culture) and older (wan and worn-out) at once. Judi Dench does raise the octane level with her caricature of Lady Catherine De Bourg's demonic fury. But Brenda Blithyn as Mrs. Bennett is not irritating or shrewish enough by half, and Donald Sutherland, emasculated and mumbling his way through in one continuous aside, is completely wasted. Only in the 1983 BBC adaptation has the character of the father been allowed to assert his patriarchal prerogative and provide an effective check to the over-bearing and histrionic mother, who was meant to be insufferable. Matthew MacFaydean makes a sleepy, crestfallen and disengaged Darcy, where Rintoul is authentically haughty with hidden depths. A lot was sacrificed in the characterizations of both Darcy and Jane to make them `likable' to modern day hipsters. The result is a confection of a film, hollow and without integrity, content to be a historical spectacle.By the time Darcy and Jane come together in Cyril Coke's 1983 adaptation--without as much as a kiss, just a couple strolling through a park--it's quite overwhelming. I'm hard-pressed to think of another reconciliation in all of film that could compete for impact. And it's all done with spoken dialogue--the sublimely beautiful language of Jane Austen faithfully rendered by Fay Weldon--and silence. There is an element of cosmic tragedy as the camera sweeps up over the trees, even as they emerge at long last from all their pretenses and misunderstandings ("pride and prejudice!") to bear their souls, happily surrendering to one another. It is the archtypal situation of love supervening upon hatred (envy).Kneightly and MacFaydean, by contrast, seem more like teen-agers who suddenly stop playing hard to get and find they have the house to themselves. Had they consummated their passion before our very eyes to sweeping violins we could not have cared any less. So if you want to be transported to another time and mind-set, to a pre-modern world at once more rigid and more genteel, try the Coke adaptation. It is as close as you will get to reading the novel without actually reading it.
summary: Not the Spirit or the Letter

reviewText: I've seen every one of the versions of P&P; that are available: 1940, 1980 and 1995.  I've seen Bride & Prejudice and Pride & Prejudice, A Latter-Day Comedy.  Each one has something to offer, and this new version is no exception.I really liked how they cast actors who were very close in age to those in the book.  Keira Knightley's youthful exuberance was endearing, and I enjoyed watching her mature before our eyes. Matthew MacFadyen's performance as Darcy was more nuanced than any I have seen before. This version doesn't need made-up fencing, bathtub and wet t-shirt scenes to show us his intensity and his sensuality.  He and Knightley both have very expressive eyes and an understanding that less is more.  They have a chemistry that is almost palpable.It's not everyone's cup of tea (especially for the Firth fangirls), but it is mine, and I love it to death.  I saw it 9 times in the theater, and have seen it twice at home (so far) via the UK edition of the DVD.  I look forward to seeing the extras on the US disc.
