reviewerName: Damian Gunn "The Dark One is I"
reviewText: I'm not one for movies of this nature.  I was not a fan of Ang Lee's 'Sense and Sensibility' yet after watching this wonderful and delightful film I just might watch the latter again, you know, for a second opinion.  Based off of Jane Austins novel of the same name, Pride & Prejudice revolves around Elizabeth Bennet (Knightley) and her sisters as their mother (Brenda Blethyn) tries to marry them off.  The eldest daughter Jane (Rosamund Pike) is quickly taken fancy by a wealthy young man, yet it's his best friend Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen) who catches the eye of young Liz, but not in a good way.  While she can't deny her attraction for him, his arogance blinds her love and drives her away from him, but as events take place that uncover her eyes to the real man he is she puts her pride and pejudice aside to be with the man she loves.  The acting here is top notch, with Keira taking the top position here.  She was brilliant, lovable, likable, adorable and believable.  Donald Sutherland, who play's Liz's father, did amazing with his role and I can see why so many wanted him to recieve an oscar nomination.  I was also very impressed with the amount of power Dame Judi Dench brought to a role that recieved such little screen time.  The scene where she confronts Liz is one of the best in the film.  She truly is a star.  This film, from start to finish, was oscar worthy and theres no doubt in my mind that we'll see Keira at the awards again soon, hopfully this time she will be taking home her own little (yet heavy) man.
summary: "And how are you feeling today, Mrs. Darcy?"

reviewText: I must admit, when I first saw it, I was critcizing everything. I didn't like the actor they chose for Mr. Darcy, I didn't like Keira as Elizabeth. There were also some aspects of the play that irked me- technical things; things the character wouldn't do. Of course, I realize that it has been a few years since I thorougly read Pride and Prejudice but as the movie continued on I began to enjoy it.I found the actor who played Mr. Darcy very attractive. I loved the costumes, the music, I thought the acting was good and lo and behold, I loved the movie. I cannot stop watching it. I enjoy trying to catch the little mannerisms of the characters and the looks between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. The more I watch it the more I realized that I was wrong about Keira- she was really good in this.I can understand why many people may not like it. There are some movie adaptations based on some of my favorite books that I hated. Am I a purist? No! but sometimes you just want the movie to catch the magic of the book and I'm starting to realize that it can't happen. That's why you can always go back and read the book. It's more fulfilling when you can envision the characters yourself.This movie is not for everyone, Austen fans or not. I never seen the Colin Firth version but now I want to. I forgot how much I loved Jane Austen and I thank this movie for reminding me. I'm rereading the story now. All I have to say is, just rent it first or watch it on HBO since they're showing it now. It doesn't hurt to try it and then make the decision. I enjoyed it, i thought it was good. I have not seen all of the versions so I can't answer which one is better.Of course there were some differences between this and the book. But I think it's good enough to recommend to others. I had my misgivings at first but I took the chance and watched it and now I love it. Take a chance, it's not bad.

reviewText: Keira Knightley's fine performance cannot save this poor representation of the great book by Jane Austin. The visual presentation of the Bennet home was shocking. Rather than a gentleman of moderate means we see a household where the family walks through the chickens' habitat to enter the back door, the hog is led by the open kitchen door - it's a mess. Mrs. Bennet is represented as a sometimes drunken slob instead of the proper wife, light in intelligence, seeking to fulfill her primary duty - getting 5 daughters, with little dowry, married. There is no attempt to portray the close relationship of sisters, Elizabeth and Jane.  In fact, the relationship is cast as that between sisters Eleanor and Mary Ann in "Sense and Sensibility". It was a terrible disappointment in nearly every respect. Buy the version starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle - it's a treasure whose length gives hours of pleasure.
summary: A Great Performance - a Poor Film

reviewText: First things first, I have never seen the Colin Firth version of "Pride and Prejudice," which has gotten such rave reviews, and I have never read the book by Jane Austen.  With that said, I think I came into the movie unbiased and had nothing to compare it to.  I loved this movie and felt that it had several key aspects to make it a great movie.  First, Keira Knightley does an amazing job as Elizabeth and she has a face that is so captivating that you cannot keep your eyes off of her.  In every movie she is in, she steals the scene.  Matthew Macfayden does an excellent job as Mr. Darcy as he transforms himself in the movie from one type of character to another.  When you're supposed to dislike him, you do.  When you're supposed to like him, you do.  Simon Woods as Mr. Bingley also does an excellent job and is very likable throughout the movie.  "Pride and Prejudice" has great pacing, beautiful cinematography, and conflict which kept you involved in everyone's lives.  Plus, it has Donald Sutherland as the father who plays each line to perfection.  One suggestion I would make to somebody watching is to what I did. reviewText: Jane Austen's classic novel tells the story of the five Bennett girls and their misadventures on the way to marriage, centering, of course, on the second daughter, Elizabeth (Keira Knightley), and her great romance with Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen).  Joe Wright's fine direction and Deborah Moggach's capable adaptation are certainly indispensible elements of this excellent film, but Knightley's performance is really at the heart of it.  She brings an irresistable natural exuberance to her portrayal of a girl changing into a young woman who longs for romance.This film deserves a better rating than 3 1/2 stars, but it seems that many people compare it unfavorably to the miniseries that aired on A&E.;  I haven't seen that version yet, but I urge anyone to give this film a chance and judge it by its own merits.  The cast is uniformly excellent.

reviewText: Before it was released, Joe Wright's adaptation of Jane Austen's novel seemed destined for failure.  After all, a "definitive" BBC version starring Colin Firth already existed, with a stellar cast and a faithfulness to Austen that purists adored.  This newest entry, however, is every bit as compelling as its BBC relative.  Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet is brilliant; her Elizabeth is keenly intelligent, witty, spunky, and, above all, utterly charming.  While the BBC version may be known as the "Colin Firth version" for that actor's memorable performance as Darcy, this one will be known as the "Keira Knightley version," as the emphasis here is firmly on Elizabeth, exactly what Austen would have intended.  Of course, Knightley is surrounded by excellent actors such as Mathew Macfayden (Darcy), Judi Dench (Lady Catherine), and Donald Sutherland (Mr. Bennet), but her outstanding performance is responsible for this film's success.For those unfamiliar with the plot:  the Bennet family lives in a precarious situation.  With no male heirs and a household of five unmarried daughters, their future is uncertain, as the house will be inherited by the family toad, Mr. Collins, upon Mr. Bennet's death.  As in most Austen novels, the mother sets about frantically trying to match up her girls with men of social standing and wealth to ensure that they will all be cared for.  When repressed aristocrat Darcy and his foppish but eligible friend Bingley arrive in the country, Mrs. Bennet starts scheming.  In keeping with the theme, the truth of matters are often obscured by the "pride and prejudice" of the characters, lending complexity to the plot.Probably the most amazing accomplishment in this film is the transformation of Elizabeth and Darcy's relationship.  Macfayden is cold, judgmental, repressed, and glowering--and yet by the end of the film, without significant change in his countenance, his Darcy seems perfect for Knightley's radiant Elizabeth.  Likewise, Elizabeth's gradual appreciation of Darcy is completely believable, although unfortunately the film suggests that his wealth first turns her head.  Much of what transpires between these characters is expertly shown through the actors' eyes and small gestures, which then makes it equally believable that no one else suspects their growing affection for each other.This adaptation, while not entirely faithful to the novel, captures the spirit of Austen's masterpiece.  The cinematography is as accomplished as the performances, giving the film a vibrancy that puts aside any question of pretension.  The only sour note comes in the last moments of the film when Wright and screenwriter Moggach opt for sappiness over the unsentimental beauty of the rest.  This misstep can be forgiven, given the utter brilliance of everything that comes before it.  Highly recommended, even for those who would not ordinarily sit through a literary adaptation.

reviewText: This version has its merits.  The scenery is terrific, and the one scene in the morning mist with the sun rising is incomparably beautiful.  Mary and Anne de Bourgh are treated more sympathetically than in the BBC miniseries' version, and Jane and Wickham are very good-looking (as they're written in the novel).  Judi Dench as Lady Catherine is good.The two-hour time frame makes it difficult to develop the story very much, so basically everything that isn't Lizzy-Darcy is truncated (Lizzy-Jane, Lizzy-Mr. Bennet relationship, even Lydia and Wickham is shortened).  Some of the period stuff (another reviewer mentioned the bedroom visits, and the costuming) is a little off.  But these aren't major problems, at least for me.My main issue with it is that it feels like a twenty-first century version of the story.  It is more angsty, and it takes a very modern young person view of Lizzy and Darcy--that is, it has them behave emotionally more like us moderns would at their ages rather than the Lizzy and Darcy of the novel and of two centuries ago.  It's got a twinge of the WB teenage drama in it.The cleverness and the wit of Austen's work are minimal here, and it feels more somber.  Mr. Bennet's "sarcastic humor" is gone; his lines are delivered seriously.  Mr. Collins' servility and Mrs. Bennet's nerves and silliness are much toned down from their BBC versions, making the characters more personable, but it feels just a little less.  (Less amusing, for sure.)I had trouble caring for this movie's Lizzy and Darcy.  Austen's Elizabeth had an easy playfulness and a quickness about her.  This Elizabeth has lost most of her witty humor (albeit fitting of the more serious tone of the movie) and thus comes across a little shrill, without the lively charm to cover for her more "insolent" moments.She is emotional and flighty, swinging from smiling and giggly to crying hard, to yelling (raising her voice) at Darcy during the first proposal--which seems a little weird for the restrained manners of that time period.  This Elizabeth feels more like a modern, fiery teenager than the proper, confident but lively novel heroine.Darcy, here, instead of being proud, just comes across as sad.  He has sad puppy dog eyes the entire movie.  To me, it makes Lizzy's rejection seem a lot harsher.  Even the end scene (for American audiences?) didn't make me like them any more--it just felt hokey instead.The novel has Lizzy and Darcy as equals in intellect and in faults--Lizzy to drop her prejudice and Darcy to learn to change his pride.  In this movie version, Lizzy just comes around to where Darcy is; he doesn't change.As a movie taken by itself, not bad, and a fast way to acquaint onself with the basic storyline.  To see a much truer version of the novel, though, watch the 1995/1996 BBC/A&E; miniseries with Ehle and Firth.

reviewText: I haven't read Jane Austen's book or seen the BBC series.  Sorry...kill me!!I enjoy movies and don't feel the need all the time to read the novel beforehand.I did read "No country for Old men" before seen the movie. Definitely there's a big gap between some movies and their book.I also understand that movies have only 2 hours to comprise a book.  Many fans of the book may not share the inevitable editing choices, due to time and business constraints.  That is another constant inevitable.  But also, those editing choices made it possible for an excellent book to reach a mainstream audience, that otherwise may never have had the possibility to be exposed to some part of it and/or relate to it so closely.Since this a forum to review THE MOVIE, I'll do that.  I hope some readersappreciate my review it's not biased by the novel, which I don't doubt is great.First the cinematography and photography are outstanding.  The music is beautiful, it enhances greatly every piece.  The costumes are gorgeous, may or may not be appropriate for the period on some regard.The language is striking, rolls over the tongues of the characters easily and pleasantly.Sophisticated language used to provide a richer communication than we have with our contemporary butchery of it.Reminder of a time where people read and language was enjoyed and honed to increase it's effectiveness, on societies where statements were carefully worded, because what said meant what it meant, and people were not able to hide behind sarcasm and ignorance, when honor was beheld high.  And the consequences of disrespect and/or misunderstandings were significant.A time without TV:) -if you want to save your soul smash yours with a bat-Mr. Darcy is a proud, perfectionist man.  A pose he adopts to protect himself from his insecurities.  By this device, avoiding the risk of trying to attract and be rejected.  He places unrealistic qualities on his ideal woman to avoid having again to be attracted to the real one and be rejected.The essence of shyness, which everyone can relate to.  The flawed leading man, cornerstone of every good script."I don't have the talent of conversing easily with people I have not met before", Darcy confesses to Elizabeth, revealing his flaw, disarming himself and standing naked shy before the woman he loves, as his greatest gift.  Teased by Elizabeth, he finds himself as rules of seduction will point,even more captivated by her.And rising love as a catalyst of virtuosity in men, the only force so powerful as to bring a man out of this shell of pride, and risk utter embarrassment: his deepest fear.The fear of, as The great Lebanese poet/philosopher Kahlil Gibram says on  "The Prophet" in his essay about Love:"...To know the pain of too much tenderness.To be wounded by your own understanding of love;And to bleed willingly and joyfully..."Darcy Places too much importance and pride on his intellect.  Hence, protecting himself of the "foolishness" of emotions, and all spontaneous crazyness that comes with strong states of emotion as love, with all the revelations of your true self it entails.  All that could lead to unexpected acts,  and to uncharted territory.  That is dreaded, thus avoided by the one inclined to control out of fear of failure or rejection.The first time he touches Elizabeth's hand to help her into the carriage and feels that unequivocal heat of great chemistry, punishes himself for his warmth and the possibility of having disclosed his emotions.  You can witness that on the shot of the tensing of his hand afterward.  Those subtleties punctuate the movie, and the detail makes the story more intriguing.Elizabeth is as many other heroines, is ahead of her time.  With a strong character and habits considered exclusively masculine is more of a modern woman.  Witty and with an acid sardonic sense of humor punishes all that she spots easily as phony.Her wit and sarcasm her are her own shell, though, as hard as Darcy's.  And also the flaw that bonds them and along with their skill with words.  Language as a an armor becomes also a game for the two, to prove who's able to penetrate the other defenses, mascaraded attraction, finallyWounding them both, with the delicious bittersweet tenderness of sexual repression liberated.And yes, ever so trite: love.She's more open to love, and so able to taunt Darcy into following her into their final "jump" into the unknown depths and heights of love and their ultimate purification.  Below the pouring rain, yes, a trite a cliche as it can be cliche, but still powerful as powerful poetry can be."A woman difficult to alarm" as Mr Darcy qualifies her, Elizabeth is, as all heroines, a malcontent, a free soul not bounded by social conventions.  Moreover, a rebel and a outspoken critic of conventions.Again, traits contemporarily all can relate strongly, and make her so attractive as a modern character.It was a time and place where women are limited by social structuring to depend in a great deal on men's favors of their beauty primarily.  Relegating education to a lesser state,On the scale of traits needed for survival and social acceptance.For men also emblematic of power, pride, honor, masculinity, etc.Marriage then was a huge deal in  their lives.  These period conditions conjure more intense romantic games.  With more at stake, with more tension, pride and prejudice keep lovers apart, through the heart wrenching twists and turns, ebbs and flows that we love to watch until the expected happens.Demoting the less physically endowed to settle to a very restricted lifestyle.The men pursuing the attractive females and the woman the powerful men is another trait  that remains until our days.  Modified  in form but not essence.  A condition we can also relate and understand it's inception better, watching this period.Donald Sutherland's character is the icing on the cake.  He's just marvelous. As a father whose daughter's can confide for support, without the fear of a backlash of chauvinism.Smart enough to grasp the female soul is refreshing, specially on this context.I suggest this movie to all romantics at heart, who dare to be mocked and fooled.For the bravest of men, who dare or even indulge and see "chick flicks" proudly, beyond the purpose of scoring some points.And for anybody who likes beautiful photography, scenery and a well written piece.
summary: A blueprint for all romance movies

One can love it in it's own right :)

reviewText: I love movies and though I don't see a lot of first run films, I thought 2006 offered an unusual variety of interesting movies and made a special effort to see them in theaters.  Of all the films I saw last year, this is one of the few I felt I would want to see again and so I purchased it on DVD and have watched it a few times since my purchase.  In fact, now that it is being shown on HBO during the holiday season when I have more free time than usual, I have watched it several MORE times--which is very unusual for me.  But this has very quickly become one of my FAVORITE movies.I am a big Jane Austen fan and loved the Firth/Ehle 1995 production and also the earlier 1980 BBC production with David Rintoul which I used to introduce my daughter to Jane Austen several years ago.  I don't think it's all that relevant to this film to compare it to the TV productions since a TV miniseries can be so much more faithful to the novel itself given much longer playing time and less need for distinctive scenery and sets.In order to translate such a social novel successfully to the film screen, and in order to attract a more varied audience than those who faithfully appreciate Masterpiece Theater, dramatic visuals were needed and the sets and scenery took on much greater importance.  Also a much simpler story was imperative to fit in a two hour framework.  The choices made were admirable.  The scenery is so beautiful and so evocative of rural England, the acting is inspired, the dialogue is perfect and the drama moves quickly and holds the interest even of those highly unlikely to pick up and read a Jane Austen novel--even my husband, a comedy and adventure film fan, loves this movie.I think the relevant group to which this film should be compared are the other big award winners of 2006, and this is a FAR SUPERIOR film to many of the films which won big awards.  I was able to watch 'Walk the Line' a second time, and I HAD to watch 'Syriana' a second time to understand it all--they were both good films and I have to admit I even enjoyed Crash when I first saw it--but I would never bother to watch 'Crash' again, and I think this film gets better each time I see it.  Each time I watch it I see something new in the sets, in the performances, in the story, and in the direction.  I really cannot recommend the film more highly--it is tremendously enjoyable and can be watched by a wide variety of adults as well as older children.

reviewText: Wow. I love (LOVE) the BBC miniseries, and I adore Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy. I also detest Kiera Knightly. Consequently, I went to the theatre expecting to be disappointed. I stand (sit, actually) corrected in the most vehement manner. I never would have believed it possible, but this is better than the BBC version. Matthew Macfadyen is better (!!!) than Mr. Firth was, and I will be very disappointed if Ms. Knightly does not win the Best Actress Oscar. To think I would ever say that, especially after her insipid performance in "Pirates of the Caribbean!" But, quite frankly, she deserves all the praise she has garnered for her performance as Elizabeth.Donald Sutherland plays Mr. Bennet with a sympathy that was completely lacking in the BBC version, and he quickly became my favorite character. (I must stop comparing the two films. They really are apples and oranges, so to speak.) Rosamund Pike. Wow. I cannot imagine anyone else playing Jane. She will forever embody the roll for me. I know that every time I read the book from now on, I will see her in my mind's eye every time Jane speaks. But quite honestly, the real standout, the actor who completely made the film (for me, at least) was Mr. Macfadyen. I was disappointed the first time I saw him. The second time, I decided he was "not that bad." By the end of the film (actually, by the time he proposes so horribly), I was completely in love with him (as Darcy, not as an actor), and wondered why on earth Lizzie would have refused his first proposal. Seriously.The cinematography is also breathtaking, and the soundtrack is next on my CD purchasing list. After that, of course, I will be buying the DVD on February 28. I am so glad I don't have to wait for months!
summary: I wish I could give it six stars.

reviewText: I have been a longtime Jane Austen convert, for as long as I can remember.  "Pride and Prejudice," one of her most well-known and well-loved stories, has been brought to the screen a total of three times (prior to this new 2005 version).  The previous versions were made in 1940 (with Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier), 1985 (with Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul), and in 1996 (with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle).This new version, with Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfayden, is intelligent, witty and very sensuous in its adaptation.  Elizabeth Bennett (Keira Knightley) is one of five daughters of the "have not" Bennett family, and her mother (Brenda Blethyn) is anxious to marry them off.  Once Elizabeth encounters Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfayden), a man who comes from great material wealth, but who lacks a lust for life, it is clear that the unlikely pair has been brought together for a reason, bigger than the both of them.This is an excellent character study and social commentary, on the state of the British class system and the pursuit of true love.  What's more, the actors in this film shine brightly and have great onscreen chemistry.  The photography is luscious, the story is engaging, and this is definitely NOT a chick flick.  I saw several men in the audience, and heard them chuckling warmly in the darkness of the movie theater.  Check it out!!!

reviewText: 2005's "Pride and Prejudice" is a skillful adaptation of Jane Austen's classic romance novel to the big screen.  Only a bold production team would have taken on the task, given the continuing and justified popularity of the 1996 BBC television version starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.  Taken on its own merits as a theatrical release, the 2005 version is visually stunning, includes wonderful location shooting and period detail, and offers two attractive leading actors with genuine on-screen chemistry.The storyline is familiar to Jane Austen fans.  The middle-class Bennet family, including its five eligible daughters and a scheming mother anxious to marry them off, learns that the wealthy Mr. Bingley will visit their small English village.  They meet Mr. Bingley at a village dance, where he is attracted to the beautiful and kind but reserved Jane Bennet.  Jane's spirited and headstrong sister Elizabeth is less impressed with Mr. Bingley's seemingly haughty friend Mr. Darcy.  Her disdain for his manners and his prejudice against Jane and against a militia officer whom she favors, will cause Elizabeth to angrily reject his surprise offer of marriage.  However, Elizabeth learns she may have been wrong about Mr. Darcy.  His generous efforts on behalf of Jane and of Elizabeth's eloped youngest sister will earn him a second chance.Keira Knightley is perfectly cast as the young and impertinent Elizabeth.  Matthew MacFadyen is very effective as the painfully shy and reserved Mr. Darcy.  Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn are a sympathetic Mr. and Mrs. Bennet.  The interaction of the Bennet sisters, including Rosamund Pike as Jane and Jena Malone as youngest sister Lydia, is authentic and by turns touching and hilarious.  Judi Dench personifies the "dragon" Lady Catherine DeBurgh.Adapting Pride and Prejudice to a two hour movie format means seriously compressing a treasured storyline. Under Director Joe Wright's sure hand, the movie steps briskly through the plot, keeping a tight focus on Elizabeth Bennet and her developing relationship with Mr. Darcy.  Among the key scenes: Elizabeth's chance encounter with Mr. Darcy at Pemberly; Mr. Bingley's proposal to Jane, reworked to bring out the humor and to make explicit Mr. Darcy's role; and Mr. Darcy's second proposal to Elizabeth.  The latter features a long atmospheric tracking shot as Mr. Darcy crosses a field at dawn to meet a surprised Elizabeth.  The next-to-last scene, in which Elizabeth requests permission to marry from her father, brings out the best in two very good actors."Pride and Prejudice" is very highly recommended to fans of Jane Austen.  The Collectors Edition DVD Set includes a music score CD, production notes, some excellent background features, and Joe Wright's fascinating director's commentary.

reviewText: The notion of not comparing this version to the mostly sublime 1995 version with Jennifer Ehle, Colin Firth, et al is simply ridiculous.  Does one not constantly use comparison as a basis for all judgements in life?  If you deny it, you are deceiving yourself.That said, the music and lighting and colors (cinematography shall we say, minus some instances of jiggly camera movement and disturbing slight zooms in and out) are almost always wonderful throughout this film.  Music + Cinematography = 4.8 Stars.  Beyond that, I was alternately cringing and smiling and the sum which was null.  The Rest = -0.8 Stars.  Thus Average = 2 Stars.It is not necessary to make a movie of a book just because you can.  There are many books, and this is one of them, that require more time to have justice done to their tales.  It's impossible (at least for me) to watch this movie without becoming frustrated, and that's not entertainment.  The dialog is mostly useless, in some parts you may find yourself wondering if the actors are actually being paid for their performances (it can't all be the fault of the screenplay can it?).  I found almost nothing enlightening in this version except for the aforementioned music and cinematography.  I agree with the negative criticism in other reviews of this version of P&P; but will not take the space to repeat it here.I hardly ever write reviews, but I felt irrepressably compelled speak out and warn would-be buyers of this film (probably because I bought it because of the high average rating) - rent it first!!If you've never read Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice or seen any other film versions, I encourage you to at least read the book first, and if you must watch this film version first, then afterwards see the 1995 version.  If you're also a Jane Austen-phile and sort of liked this movie, listen to the commentary - some comments will really drive you up the wall, and perhaps cool your opinion of this rendition!  Since I now own it, I'll watch it again and see if I can find any other redeeming qualities...however I sincerely doubt that I'll increase my rating...p.s.1.  The 10th Anniversary Limited Edition Collector's Set of the 1995 A&E; Pride and Prejudice will be released in late September 2006 - pre-order it now!

reviewText: "Pride and Prejudice," directed by Joe Wright, is a beautifully mounted version of the beloved Jane Austen classic.  Gorgeously filmed on location in England, the movie stars Keira Knightley as the spirited Elizabeth Bennet.  Knightley has luminous eyes, a wickedly mischievous smile, and a saucy manner.  The director wisely zooms in on her captivating face in a number of tight close-ups.  Matthew MacFadyen plays Mr. Darcy as an aloof and sullen gentleman, who hides his smoldering sexuality beneath a stolid facade.  Brenda Blethyn is appropriately dithery as the nervous and silly Mrs. Bennet, a mother of five daughters who is desperate to marry her children off to men of means.  Mr. Bennet, played solidly by Donald Sutherland, frequently hides in his study in order to get a respite from his noisy and high-spirited brood.  Also noteworthy are Tom Hollander as the stuffy and pompous Mr. Collins; his pursuit of Elizabeth is met with undisguised disdain.  Dame Judi Dench is formidable in her cameo as the imperious and overbearing Lady Catherine de Bourg. Less successful are the miscast Simon Woods, who turns in a nerdy performance as the carrot-topped Mr. Bingley, and Rosamund Pike, as Jane Bennet, is lovely to look at but a bit too vapid.Roman Osin, the cinematographer, captures the lush beauty of the English countryside and the glamor of Darcy's and Bingley's estates.  The camera is always in motion, panning over the dancers in a ballroom, a breathtaking sunset, a rainy field, and the expressions on the characters' faces.  There is rarely a dull moment in this film. Unfortunately, the dialogue is sometimes difficult to follow because the Wright frequently directs his actors to speak over one another.  In addition, unlike Dench, whose diction is impeccable, some of the performers speak too quickly and fail to enunciate.Another quibble is that the screenwriter, Deborah Moggach, gives short shrift to  Austen's underlying themes of snobbery, social stratification, and the constraints of women in eighteenth century England.  These issues are certainly implied, but they are peripheral to Elizabeth and Darcy's romance, which takes center stage. Still, this movie is a treat for the mind and heart. "Pride and Prejudice" is an enchanting, wildly romantic, and entertaining love story that will please all but the most finicky Austen purists.

reviewText: I never thought I would understand Pride & Prejudice enough to critique the film adaptations but some unexpected leisure in the past couple of months has allowed me to see them all. The 1940 Greer Garson is good - indeed all 4 are good although widely different. The Keira Knightly is the best, however, both because of her portrayal of Elizabeth Bennet, and because of the warmth of the film maker's conception of the Bennet family.  Of course it is the portrayal of Lizzy that makes or breaks the film, and this is my favorite portrayal, and my pick of the best of the 4.  Keira Knightly is my favorite Elizabeth. She is younger than the other actresses who have played Elizabeth,  and plays a Elizabeth Bennet closer to the 20 year old we read about in the novel. I would not call her beautiful - indeed in this film Jane is the most beautiful of the 5 Bennet sisters, just as she is supposed to be. But Keira is unbelievably attractive because of her facial expressions. She has a marvelous smile and we see a lot of it, and, like Garson, her face can show her emotions and their changes so well that soon you are completely engrossed in her character and her story. As they used to say, "You'll laugh, you'll cry, but you'll never forget Keira Knightly as Elizabeth Bennet."This version also manages to allow Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland) to be his sarcastic and witty self without being unpleasant. He is played too harshly in some other versions, especially the 1979 BBC adaptation.  The Bennet family holds together quite well, even Mrs. Bennet is redeemed, although with some dialog that is definitely not in the novel.  Darcy is almost impossible to cast, I suspect. Certainly in this film he is no better than acceptable. Mr. Collins, on the other hand, is very good, although his part is much cut down in the interest of getting a 2 hour film. (We do get to hear a short sample of his preaching). The only unhappy casting is that of Wickham. Wickham is a sociopath, and should have a great deal of charm when he meets Lizzy. Here he is more whiner than charmer. All 3 of the other film makers were able to find someone to fit the bill, but here Keira's boyfriend, I believe, got the part, and he is simply wrong for it. Luckily his role is also quite reduced from that in the novel so we don't see him often enough to be disturbed greatly.So, for those characters that survived the scriptwriter, this is the best cast of the 4 adaptations, and the most sympathetic to the Bennet family. Who is missing? Aunt Phillips and "broad faced stuffy Uncle Phillips, breathing port wine." Mr. and Mrs. Hurst, Maria Lucas (well really, excepting Charlotte, Sir William and all the Lucases are missing), Mr. & Mrs. Gardiner's children are gone, although the Gardiners do get to take Lizzy to Pemberly, Mrs. Hill is gone, Mrs. Young is gone, and Mrs. Ainisley is gone,  as are all of the Officers from the ____Shire militia (we see anonymous officers dancing, but no Denny,  and no Col. Forster except by mention. We do not go to London with Jane, or Ramsgate with Georgiana, and never were going to the Lakes. We do get a milita parade, quite a bit of poultry, one Wuthering Heights like view of Lizzy standing in the wind atop a cliff which they would do well to edit out of the film, Darcy's proposal in a faux-temple during a rainstorm, and absolutely the best Assembly Ball ever filmed.  The director's commentary is quite interesting, too.Do you remember the Polanski film where our heroes are pretending to be the living dead, and at a zombie ball they dance down the room until suddenly they come upon a mirror and, being alive, they are reflected in it but none of the other dancers are?  Here when Mr. Darcy dances with Lizzy their conversation becomes so intense that the other dancers vanish for a couple of minutes and we just have our couple dancing alone in the ballroom. I don't know that the scenes connect in any other way but one scene calls forth the other to me.So aside from Wickham, what problems? Everyone compresses the sequence of events at the end, but here someone piled them up and stomped on them. Bingley returns to Netherfield, proposes in the afternoon, Lady Catherine arrives around midnight, and at the next dawn Lizzy and Darcy meet in a foggy field and become engaged. Poor Mr. Collins' letter never arrives, as you can imagine. Where could it have fit in? In about 16 hours of one day, we see what took weeks in the novel. Most bothersome is the visit to Pemberly. Lizzy becomes detached from the Gardiners, wanders off alone in the house, and hearing piano playing,  peeks through a door and sees Georgiana playing, then she sees Darcy enter and his sister and he embrace, till he looks up and sees Elizabeth peeping in at them. That's bad enough, (and quite out of character)  but then she walks back to Lambton without the Gardiners and without looking for them. Is it possible that they did not realize that she was no longer with them as they went through the house?  Still, one can excuse these little things. If we put up with Caroline Bingley's "fat suit" costume in the Garson version, we can put up with almost anything.My advice? Buy all 4 versions, book a transatlantic cruise, and give each version one full sea-day to watch and consider. I think you'll find yourself agreeing with me that the Keira Knightly film is the best, and you'll be happy you watched the others.
summary: Probably the Best Film Adaptation of the 4

reviewText: You would think that Jane Austen's most famous novel is not in need of another cinematic treatment given the definitive BBC version of a decade ago and the classic 1940 MGM version starring Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier, not to mention a contemporary 2004 Bollywood-style musical and according to IMDB, at least six other versions. However, first-time feature director Joe Wright and first-time screenwriter Deborah Moggach (with uncredited assistance from Austen adaptation veteran Emma Thompson) have brought youthful vigor and a wild, Thomas Hardy-like element to the movie, and as a whole, it works very well. It almost makes the overly familiar novel feel revitalized.For those who have forgotten their required high school reading, the story focuses on the downscale Bennet family - a passive father and a domineering mother, the latter intent on marrying off their five daughters to wealthy families. Eldest daughter Jane becomes smitten with rich but somewhat weak-willed Mr. Bingley and the bookish Mary keeps to her piano, while the two youngest daughters, Kitty and Lydia, are giggly and boy-crazy. On the other hand, the headstrong Elizabeth wants marriage on her terms with an intellectual equal, and she becomes alternately repelled and drawn to the brooding Mr. Darcy. There are several plotlines that interweave precariously toward the inevitable conclusion, but Austen's witty, often insightful dialogue holds the story together organically with grace and humor.Twenty-year old Keira Knightley is the youthful embodiment of Elizabeth, as her predecessors, Garson in particular, always strike me as too mature for the role. With her beauty subdued in casual period fashion, she manages to convey all the necessary facets of her personality with a natural élan. As Darcy, Matthew Macfayden captures the moody character's insolence and growing romanticism with little affectation. Most all of the supporting players shine with Brenda Blethyn as the exasperating Mrs. Bennet, Donald Sutherland as her introspective husband, Tom Hollander as the priggish Mr. Collins, Rosamund Pike as beautiful and likable Jane, Jena Malone convincingly British as the impulsive Lydia, and of course, in all her scene stealing glory, Judi Dench lends acidic vinegar as Lady Catherine, Darcy's disapproving aunt.Parts of the film have a subtly stylized quality, such as the way the camera seems to track uninterrupted during the Assembly Hall ball sequence or when Elizabeth's head spins symbolically as she sits on a swing. There are also many well-turned tableaux-style shots that imbue the spirit of the period with vivid but unobtrusive detail. Credit should go to Roman Osin's textured and sumptuous cinematography, Jacqueline Durran's authentic-feeling costumes and Dario Marianelli's flavorful music, all of which capture a decidedly realistic though ultimately romanticized 16th-century England.The DVD package has several too-short features that provide some background into the production and Austen's characters but hardly enough to provide meaningful insight. Wright provides sometimes interesting commentary on an alternate track that borders a bit on the effusive, and there is an alternative and thankfully excised ending which spells out the plot resolutions unnecessarily. This movie is a joyous celebration of Austen's artistry as a writer whose story themes resonate today.
summary: Robust Adaptation of Familiar Austen Novel Is One First-Class Production

reviewText: This film is worth watching for its beautiful picture more than for anything else. Each shot looks like it has been taken from a painting of a period. Congratulations to the director and cameraman. The acting was good, the casting was good too, with some minor exceptions.It was the interpretation of the story which made me cringe from time to time. Was it really necessary to insert quite a lot of the awkward modern dialogue and the ways of expression into the story to show that it's topical? The director could express himself and convey the social message of the story without distorting the ways and customs of the past and adapting the story to modern ways.For one, could you ever imagine a grand lady of the society bursting into somebody's house in the middle of the night even if the matter was urgent?? Is it really necessary to take such radical measures to emphasize the character's personality? Sometimes I thought there was too much explained and too vividly expressed what could have been left to understand.On the other hand, the story was not very well developed, concentrating on Lizzy alone and leaving behind some important characters. We do not fully comprehend the drama of Lydia's escape with a man as we do not see in the full the wickedness of Mr. Whickam. Concequently, untouched is the theme of the goodness and just appearance of it as well as some other important messages. The story was quckly flowing from scene to scene without allowing the spectator to be involved.Moreover, almost all of the book characters appeared in the film; some, for a second only, after disappearing forever. This only crowded the film and left the residue of unsatisfaction, for you expect the story line to develop somehow in connection with the newly introduced character. True, the director didn't have much time at his disposal, well then... I know some big volumes transferred into the film media without losing their impact. If the director wanted to introduce a new, different interpretation of the story, he succeded only in modernizing dialogue and changing visual style, but his message is quite weaker than the original.On the whole, it is a pleasant production and does deserve an apprisal (for its picture mostly). However, the impeccable version of the book has been already made - 1995 BBC miniseries, and... what's the point in remaking the perfect?!

reviewText: This film takes place in rural England during the 18th century. My favorite actress Keira Knightley plays the witty and head-strong Elizabeth Bennett, the second eldest of five daughters who come from a modest family. The daughters have reached marriagable age, and when the handsome, wealthy Mr. Bingley comes to town, of course the whole household flies into an uproar. Elizabeth's older and stunningly beautiful sister Jane (who is played by Audrey Tautou look-alike Rosamund Pike) is established as the inteded for Mr. Bingley. Elizabeth meets her match in Mr. Bingley's best friend, Mr. Darcy, whose dark wit and forlorn manner somehow spark her interest, but when a series of misunderstandings arise that involve her beloved family, Elizabeth must learn to put aside her pride or else risk losing the man who completes her.This movie was exquisite and beautifully directed. The sweeping, epic shots and stunning cinematography served as the perfect backdrop for the delicate love story between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. Keira Knightley's performance as Elizabeth was so amazing that it should serve as the standard for all romantic heroines. The chemistry created by lingering glances and touches is electrifying, and conveys the love arising bewteen Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy more fully than covert displays of affection that afflict many movies made today.So utterly romantic and heart-felt. One of the best films I've seen in a very long time.
summary: One of the most romantic movies I've ever seen

reviewText: Over the years, there have been different film versions of Jane Austen's novel "Pride and Prejudice." I enjoy the diverging portrayals of the House of Bennet, where the Salic Law prevails, for new insights into the array of characters can always be gleaned. It is like visiting the same family in different seasons. I must admit that to me the 1995 BBC version was so excellent that I thought nothing else could compare, which is why the viewing of the 2005 rendition was postponed until a couple of days ago. With stunning cinematography and meticulously detailed sets, it is a highly entertaining production. Keira Knightley, although she is too thin for period roles when women were more fleshy, played the part of Elizabeth quite well. The other sisters and Mrs. Bennet were very well-cast. Donald Sutherland utterly stole the show. Sutherland's Mr Bennet seems to be in his own world yet he is really more in tune with everything that is going on than poor distracted Mrs. Bennet. That is especially evident from the way he goes over and comforts poor Mary at the Netherfield ball.The musical score is quite romantic, capturing the desperation of young love obstructed by such obstacles as money and status. The attraction between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy is more palpable than ever, although they hardly ever touch except when dancing. Those days of strict boundaries and protocols certainly make for some great love stories.In the 2005 version, the Bennets seem more like yeomen farmers than landed gentry, with pigs running through the house, and shabby dresses. Were the Bennets really that poor? Maybe they were. On the other hand, Mr. Darcy is raised to the peerage, living at Chatsworth like the Duke of Devonshire. The Darcys were a distinguished and wealthy family but I doubt that they had the Elgin marbles in the parlor. This was only a minor distraction (along with the few weak attempts at vulgar humor) in a wonderful film which brings the viewer into the world of the late 1700's, the world of Jane Austen, when young men knelt to ladies when proposing marriage, and being a penniless old maid was the fate worse than death.

reviewText: A charming, wonderful movie in its own right.  Brilliantly cast, and well acted.  I loved it.  It captures the essence of Pride and Prejudice.  I didn't want it to end when it was over.  It was filmed beautifully.  And if it wasn't my favorite book, if I didn't know the story so well, I probably wouldn't have noticed the `rushing' through the storyline.  Feelings aren't developed, can't be developed, within this kind of a short format.  Circumstances and emotions that took days, weeks, or months to develop in the book seem to transpire instantaneously in this movie.  The passage of time is not well represented.  Some characters that definitely add depth are cut out of the plot completely.  Where is Mr. Hurst, for example, eating, drinking, and sleeping to excess?  Mrs. Hurst?  Charlotte's sister Maria?  Aunt Phillips?  Mr. Collins doesn't get to develop his idiosyncracies appropriately.  And my favorite narcissist of all time, Lady Catherine De Bourgh, played by a phenomenal actress this time out (Dame Judi Dench), doesn't get to fuss, brag, and command as she ought.  If you want the nuance, the humor, and the character development, you have to read the original book or watch either the BBC or the A&E production.  However, this was a delightful movie taken alone, without comparison.  This adaption would be an especially good introduction to Pride and Prejudice.  Austen lovers, like me, will love it, too, even though it is slightly truncated.  I recommend it.  And the extras were also very interesting.

reviewText: Someone on another website (I regret that I cannot give the reference) commented aptly that in this movie, Longbourne looks  like Stella Gibbons'Cold Comfort Farm (Penguin Classics Deluxe Edition).  This was an amusing enough costume flick, but a pretty poor interpretation ofPride and Prejudice (Bantam Classics)so I recommend that Jane Austen fans tell themselves that they are not watching the Bennets, they are watching the Georgian-era Starkadders.  (I strongly recommend the offbeat Cold Comfort Farm as both a novel and a movie:Cold Comfort Farm).The problem with this movie is not so much that it is short, but that what is retained is frequently rendered inane.  Instead of handing his letter to Lizzie while she is out walking, the half-dressed Darcy breaks into the Collins' house in the middle of the night and surprises nightgown-clad Lizzie in her dark bedroom (and she doesn't even scream.)  One of the pivotal scenes in the book is Lizzie Bennet's hearing praise of Darcy from his housekeeper.  This is eliminated in favor of a dopy scene of her wandering around a collection of marble nudes, as if perhaps, the problem was with her libido and this fixed it.  The corny last scene made me glad the movie was ending.  I have read that this is not in the British edition; perhaps they are still trying to punish Americans for the revolution.  In addition, someone apparently decided that it would be hysterically funny if people were constantly interrupting the Bennets.  So instead of Mr. Collins proposing after breakfast, he starts his proposal during breakfast and Mrs. Bennet makes everyone but Lizzie leave the table.  Darcy wakes everyone up before dawn to ask for Lizzie's hand - I don't recommend this as a way to endear yourself to prospective in-laws.  Lady Catherine shows up in the middle of the night, wakes up all the Bennets, and then has it out with Lizzie in front of her family - really smooth and discreet.  People in this era avoided driving at night when they could - they didn't have halogen street lights all over the place, it was very dark at night and travelling could be very dangerous.The depiction of the period is very uneven.  I had a bad feeling about this movie when I saw the tie-in book featuring Darcy walking around half-dressed, looking a lot more like Heathcliff in Wuthering Heights.  I cannot understand the argument that this is a modern retelling when it is still set in the Regency.  Or that it is somehow more suited to a present-day audience than the A&E; (Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996)) and BBC (Pride and Prejudice (BBC, 1980)) productions.  There are a number of novels that have rewritten Pride and Prejudice as a contemporary story - why not do one of those if modern is what one is after?CluelessandBride and Prejudicewere certainly fresh, modern retellings of Austen's work, and I loved both of them, but I don't see how those adjectives apply to this film.  I don't understand why filmmakers use material for which they obviously have little sympathy.  Something by the Brontes would probably have been more compatible.There were some things that I thought were well done.  I am not an expert, but I believe that, in this era when most clothes were custom made and relatively expensive, it was common for older people to wear the fashions of their youth, so I actually found that an interesting part of the representation.  I understand that this is supposed to be 1800, or earlier, and the typical Regency dress was originally considered to be quite shocking. As to the status of the Bennets, on the one hand, the greater sophistication of Caroline Bingley's clothing (except for that anachronistic slip dress) vice the clothing of the Bennets' and their neighbors is a realistic representation of the difference in their lifestyles.  The Bingley's are wealthier and spend more time in London; the Bennets probably rely on local seamstresses, and are just a touch behind in fashion.  Some of the Bennets' clothing was a bit grubby, but perhaps that was how country people dressed for solitary walks.  The moviemakers do seem to be a little confused as to what qualified as suitable dress for public appearances.  One can imagine that the difference in decoration at Longbourne and Netherfield partly represents the difference between landed gentry with generations of occupancy and heirlooms that no-one wants to throw out, and the nouveau riche who, starting from scratch, use the very latest fashion.  Everything about the Bennets and their neighbors ought to seem a trifle rustic and old-fashioned, just not lower class.On the other hand, the Bennets have a very good income for a "gentleman", and I sincerely doubt that the barnyard was up against the house or that the Bennets spent much time tending the livestock.  There's not much point to having pigs (which are notoriously smelly) right by the house unless one is personally slopping the hogs, and the Bennets had farmworkers.  I suppose that the filmmakers used this to indicate the precarious position of the sisters rather than explaining that in addition to the entail, their parents were too irresponsible to save money out of their income for dowries.  Earthier is not necessarily more realistic.Given the amount of material that had to be omitted, I cannot imagine why we spent so much time gazing at bushes.  If I were editting the movie, the scene of Lizzie walking across the field to the house would be the first to go.  It's cliched, a waste of time, and I've seen much better photography of the English landscape.So, I recommend this to lovers of costume drama who can keep the original novel out of their heads, or people who have never read the novel in the first place.On the entry for the movie showtimes, there is a review: "A Tender, Beautifully-Filmed Prequel to "The Clampetts"', January 1, 2006, by Carol M. Shifflett which I thought was hysterically funny and which I recommend to anyone not entirely happy with the film.

reviewText: One of the greatest love stories of all time.  I love the book.  I love the BBC version with Colin Firth, and I absolutely love this version!!!  The cast is amazing. reviewText: **** 3.5 Stars ****How to begin?I bought this movie because I truly enjoyed the novel, and then had the opportunity to purchase the BBC Production, which was beautifully told, and I thought, I have to see how they handle this in a very short (comparatively speaking) 2+ hour movie....As I watched the movie, I began to contemplate it in comparison with the great piece of literature that it is based upon, and found many discrepancies, and liberties taken....  And as I progressed through the movie, I had to keep reminding myself that it is not the retelling from the book, but rather an adaptation.However, even with that in mind, there were things I had a hard time looking past - most importantly, almost every characater, with the possible exception of Elizabeth and Darcy, were caricatures of their literary selves, everything they said and did appeared so (at times) over the top....As others have mentioned, there was definitely a more modern approach to propriety (i.e. Bingley entering the sick room, Lizzy and Darcy speaking in the morning hours in their bedclothes, Lady Catherine's night time visit, the various members of the Bennet family constantly eavesdropping whenever they can in such an uncircumspect manner, characters addressing each other by their Christian names, sleeveless dresses, etc.)With the costuming, and some of the locations, there were times where I felt like I was in Colonial America and not Regency England, and the actors definitely appeared less genteel than they were intended to appear in the book....The movie can be at times very melodramatic (think of the carriage ride back to Longbourn with Aunt and Uncle Gardiner and how dark and depressing it is outside - amazing how it suits her feelings... but is it really necessary?). And, can ANYBODY tell me what was up with that tree that Lizzy, her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner stopped at to rest while the carriage was being worked on prior to going to Pemberly?Having thus laid out some of my obstacles with this movie, I have to say that as an ADAPTATION from the novel, it does have its own merit...  The acting is great for the way the screenplay was written, and some of the creative things that were done, like the scene of Bingley interacting with Darcy to 'rehearse' his proposal to Jane, were fun to watch, even if it didn't 'agree' with the book.I encourage all to watch this with the full knowledge that it is MERELY AN ADAPTATION of the novel, not a retelling.... It is much easier to appreciate this as its own story, separate from the book and the BBC production of 1995.  Indeed, once I got past trying to compare it with either the book or the aforementioned BBC production, it was fun and enjoyable to watch!

reviewText: I love Matthew Mcfadyen's work, all of it, and I think that Keira Knightly is a fabulous actress thus I was prepared to rank this version of Pride and Prejudice with the outstanding and pitch perfect Sense and Sensibility with Emma Thomas.I was sorely let down.  I did not like 1995's version of Pride and Prejudice with Ehle and Firth because I felt it too shrill, and after a while Ehle's exaggerated facial expressions became annoying. I felt that the actors whom she was laughing at or thinking about had to be in a coma not to notice them.Having said that I watched this version twice and still I could not get past the lack of chemistry between the two leads, and the camera movements which were dizzying.  The first dance sequence, the swing sequence in the farm yard, the soldiers marching through town, I felt that something was always moving in front of the actors obscuring them, and that the eye was constantly trying to find them in the picture.When Tom Hollander showed up at the front door here was yet another scene where half an actor's face was cut off until he moves to the left.  A camera angle stolen right from Polanski's Rosemary's Baby.  Finally I felt it all too forced - especially the endless giggling and laughter.I did love Dame Judy Dench who was severe and the cinematography and locations were outstanding which makes this purchase worth while at the current price.  The Blu Ray picture is beautiful.  The Blacks are rich and showing good detail even in Dench's dark estate.  The special features about the homes and locations are very intersting.

reviewText: Over the years Hollywood has produced innumerable romantic comedies in which two people, obviously attracted to (and perfect for) one another, are kept apart by circumstances for a couple of hours until the artificial barriers between them are torn down and they wind up in each other's arms. Most of them have been terrible, but British director Joe Wright's new version of the Jane Austen tale which is the granddaddy of them all proves that if you only return to the source, and treat it if not with absolute fidelity at least with respect, the experience can be delightful. This is a lively, colorful, intelligent retelling of the template for all the later books and movies about two people obviously destined to be together who remain apart all too long due to misunderstandings and the machinations of others. Its sensibility is more modern than Austen's, of course, but that doesn't mean it's any less enjoyable on its own.At just a bit over two hours, this "Pride and Prejudice" can't include as much of the detail of Austen's original as the well-regarded five-hour BBC mini-series of 1995, which starred Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth. But in Deborah Moggach's skillful adaptation it contains enough to convey the flavor of the book, as well as the basic plot, very successfully, though the tone is more overtly romantic; in this respect it's certainly the equal of the famous 1940 film with Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier. And Wright proves remarkably adept at infusing the action not only with the serenity and charm it needs, but with lightness and vivacity as well, an effect achieved especially by his penchant for fast-moving tracking shots, beautifully managed by cinematographer Roman Osin. Osin's luscious widescreen images have the benefit of focusing on lovely locations and utterly convincing period accouterments; the production design by Sarah Greenwood, art direction by Ian Baille, Mark Swain and Nick Gottschalk, set decoration by Katie Spencer and costumes by Jacqueline Durran are all superb. One could spend one's time just luxuriating in the visual splendor on the screen, made even happier by Dario Marianelli's pleasantly evocative score.But the meat of the story is in the characters, of course, and here too the film proves outstanding. Keira Knightley makes ample amends for her dreadful performance in "Domino" by portraying the strong-willed, level-headed Elizabeth Bennet as a young woman of both (dare one say it) spunk and an undercurrent of melancholy. Matthew Macfadyen, happily not a conventionally handsome sort, matches her by capturing Darcy's aristocratic demeanor and his inner conflict nicely. Together they make a couple that emphasizes the youthfulness and relative inexperience of Austen's creations far more than was the case in any of the previous filmizations--which makes the tale not only more credible but somehow more poignant. Their excellence doesn't stand alone; the supporting cast is superb, too, with Donald Sutherland wonderfully unruffled and sardonic as the put-upon Mr. Bennet and Brenda Blethyn keeping his wife--an unsophisticated woman obsessed with finding husbands for her many daughters, and a character that can easily become an irritation--within bounds. Rosamund Pike and Simon Woods make an appealing pair as the secondary couple in the mix, Elizabeth's easily-hurt elder sister Jane and Darcy's more ebullient friend Bingley, and Jena Malone is suitably flighty as the immature Lydia, whose infatuation with the handsome but unreliable Wickham (an appropriately smooth Rupert Friend) causes not only a Bennet family crisis but an opportunity that in time will lead to the resolution of the Elizabeth-Darcy impasse. If one can raise any qualifications about the casting, they'd have to concern Tom Hollander, who gives the stiff, obsequious Collins more of a conventionally comic tone than some might wish, and Judi Dench, whose Lady de Bourgh might seem too much the usual intrusive cameo (and whose final scene isn't ideally staged). But you easily become acclimated to them, and in the end they fit Wright's conception.In fact, when looked at as a whole, there's something just a bit miraculous about how enjoyable Wright's film is. "Pride and Prejudice" may be the same old story about finding Mr. Right, but this movie shows that if your take on the familiar tale is sufficiently deft, it can be as fresh and enchanting as Austen's book itself must have been in 1813.
summary: "Sometimes the last person on earth you want to be with is the one person you can't be without."

reviewText: How would the teens of Dawson's Creek or the recent Juno speak like if they were English in the year 1797?  Look no further than Pride and Prejudice, one of the greatest love stories ever told and the original template for essentially every modern chick-flick or romantic comedy to come henceforth.At first I thought the movie was rather talky and somewhat boring, but the more i watched and the more I paid attention, I started to realize that this is one of the most engaging and accurately lavish English period pieces I have ever seen before.But it is not for everyone.  Certainly notsomuch as Atonement is for more general audiences or more easily digestible.  This film requires a more expert level of movie watching/comprehension and a certain degree of literary aptitude.  It begs for, nay demands the viewers active participation, involvement, and a certain commitment of attention more novice pieces would dare not request.  And by literary aptitude I don't necessarily mean the source novel as much as I mean Shakespeare.  The characters relate and converse in a pseudo-Shakespearean manner minus the iambic pentameter.  If you cannot keep up with all of the double entendras, doublespeak, subliminal messages and the like you will likely have a difficult time appreciating the genius of this screenplay written by Deborah Moggach.The complicated relationships and plot are also like a Shakespearan comedy (all though at times feels like a tragedy) and it is very easy to get left behind if you are not of to task.  This is why I enjoyed the movie so much.  You need to pay full attention to fully appreciate this work of art.  Visually there were many hidden cues like actors' not-always-so-obvious facial expressions as well as unspoken hints from the brilliant, however also purposeful wardrobe and costume design.  It's very difficult to explain in a simple way, but I simply love this director's work; Joe Wright is stupid genius!What a guilty pleasure for a moviephille for me to watch.And let us not even mention the name Keira Knightley.  This is the film that finally put her on the map as a serious actress to be reckoned with and not just another pretty face.  She thoroughly shines throughout as the star and primary protagonist of the movie.Director Joe Wright's second motion picture 'Atonement' was extrmely good, a modern classic in its own right, but it was not exactly a happy story.  It did not make me smile inside as the subtle and not-so-subtle humor like P&P; did.  This one was more a romp that leaves one giddy so giddyup!note:  This was my first treatment of P&P.;  I never saw any other version or read the book, but now I have decided to gobble up all of Jane Austen's other famous works and find myself feverishly awaiting Joe Wright's forthcoming film 'The Soloist'My Addendum:I have been perusing the 1 star reviews that are speckeled among the many praising and applauding reviews of this movie and I just wanted to say something to address those naysayers.  First of all, I think you all have lost much prospective and are waging your 1 star rating for hyperbolic effect.  And second, if all of you who loathed this adaptation were in charge of all other adaptations in Hollywood, movies would just plain suck and not really be viable or marketable at all.  Thank goodness this is not the state of things.  It is more palatable movies such as this that satisfy the masses that draw in new viewers to your precious A&E;/BBC version or bring in new readers to the original novel.  Is that such a horrible thing?  I swear so many rabid Austen fans think P&P; was written only for them and belongs to them and if it isn't the approved 1995 edition of the miniseries, well then thee be damned.  Chill out already and stop trying to ruin it for the rest of us.  You should all be thanking the director Joe Wright because thanks to him (eventually) more people in the world will get to know who the heck Colin Firth even is!

reviewText: Superb casting, outstanding scenery, well designed period settings and a brilliantly written novel by Jane Austen comes to life making this a block buster winner and one of the hottest films this season. The film is likely to garner several well deserved Academy Awards ... I love the realistic country scenes and the opulent wealth of the era as depicted in this film. Keira Knightly is charming and dazzling as the intelligent and articulate Lizzie who is transformed within this film, becoming the butterfly that arises from her unique chrysallis. Matthew MacFadyen is the perfect Mr. Darcy, a darkly handsome introspective, intelligent gentleman ... who is easily misunderstood.Keira Knightly is an outstandng Elizabeth (Lizzie) Bennett, with her well chiseled lovely porcelain facial features, beautiful large brown expressive eyes, lovely swan-like neck and gorgeous brown hair, often worn pulled up and back, with tendrils framing her face. Her clever articulate observations and quips are very memorable throughout the film as she challenges the quietly brooding and handsome Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen). One memorable scene is when the guests of honor, Mr. Bingley, his sister and Mr. Darcy arrive in the ballroom, the dancing and music stop as the people part to each side, like a zipper being unzipped. Mr. Bingley happily joins in the dancing and socializing but both Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy remain aloof, quietly commenting on the differences between living in the city and country. It is quite obvious they feel  superior compared to the locals. Mr. Bingley laughs and smiles as he dances with Miss Jane Bennett (Rosamund Pike). Her mother, Mrs. Bennett (Brenda Blethyn,) is delighted by this good fortune. She is actively seeking a husband for Jane who is of marriagable age and the eldest daughter of five.During an intermission Lizzie over hears Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy discussing Jane and herself. Mr Darcy describes Lizzie as "tolerable" but essentially not his type. This phrase will eventually come to haunt him, as Lizzie repeats it to him  later during an encounter. Based on this event, she develops preconceived notions about Mr. Darcy's character and manners. She makes no secret of her feelings about him to her family.Jane pays a social visit to the Bingley's country mansion and becomes ill, requiring her to stay as an overnight guest for several days until she recovers. Mr. Bingley can not hide his joy at having such a pretty and desirable house guest. Lizzie visits her sister during the illness and encounters Mr. Darcy and Miss Bingley. She engages Mr. Darcy in several verbal duels and cleverly exchanges challenging words, demonstrating superior skill and prowess in the intellectual game of quoting poetry and verse. Both Keira Knightly and Matthew MacFadyen perfom their roles superbly ...While Mr. Bingley was falling in love with Jane and quietly making his feelings known, his sister suddenly closed the manor house and persuaded him and her entourage to return to London. It is obvious she wanted to sever the budding relationship between her brother and Jane, before it became serious. Essentially, Miss Jane Bennett was viewed as a social inferior. About this time, the Reverend Mr. Collins came calling on the Bennetts, with the intention of marrying one of the daughters. He lived on an estate owned by Lady Catherine, who required him to find a wife before she would finance a parsonage and church for him. Lizzie captured his attention but she outright rejected his proposal. Following this refusal, Mr. Collins offered marriage to Charlotte their young housekeeper, who accepted him. Lizzie could not understand why Charlotte would marry Mr. Collins until the realities of Charlotte's situation sunk in. Charlotte explained he had a stable profession and provided her a home which was a major improvement from her current situation. Lizzie slowly awakened into adulthood, recognizing many unpleasant facts of life. The scenes went from comedy to almost tragedy as different events unfolded in the lives of the Bennett family. The importance of social position and wealth in selecting a life partner was clear and evident.It never dawned on the Bennett's that the sudden departure of the Bingley's was meant as a snub, a refusal of Miss Jane Bennett as a fiance. The Bennetts had high hopes of relighting the match and sent Jane to visit an Aunt in London in hopes of meeting Mr. Bingley. About this time, Lizzie was visiting Brighton with her relatives when she took a tour of Mr. Darcy's residence which was open for public viewing. She met him unexpectedly in the garden and received a declaration of love which took her completely by surprise. She immediately dismissed it and rejected him ...Jane returned from London without having established any social connection with Mr. Bingley. Lizzie returned from Brighton, in an unusual emotional state, a totally confused frame of mind. Unknown to herself, she was battling unresolved feelings for Mr. Darcy. A family crisis arose when Lydia, the middle daughter, had run away with a soldier. This scandal would ruin the Bennett's chances for marrying off Jane and Lizzie to good families. Help came from an unexpected source: Mr. Darcy had known this soldier in the past. Mr. Darcy's father had treated the soldier nearly like a son. Due to nearly similar circumstances involving Mr. Darcy's sister Georgiana, he rescued Lydia from her shameful situation by setting them up finanacially and ensuring Lydia married her soldier. When Lizzie heard of this matter, she remained in a deep quagmire for having rejected his overtures of love, she was awakening to the true nature of his character and discovered herself attracted to him. The resolution to Lizzie's emotional conflict and the rematch between Jane and Mr. Bingley is what makes the book and this film so popular. Jane Austen's classical writing via this new film adaptation provides a creative twist to the eternal conundrum which young ladies and young gentlemen of every era and generation must face and resolve anew for themselves.Erika Borsos (erikab93)

reviewText: I've watched the 1995 A&E; version of Pride and Prejudice many times, and I never get tired of it, mainly because of Colin Firth, whom I adored in the part. Because of that, I put off for a very long time until just recently watching this version. First, I did not think the actors could possibly measure up and second, it is an abridged version, so a great deal of the story would inevitably be sacrificed. I had also heard about the infamous kiss at the end of this version.I am happy to report that I enjoyed this film for its own sake. Relatively short though it is, Macfadyen and Knightley offer a lovely take on the romance. They are both very attractive people who are young enough to be very near the actual ages of the characters, and their chemistry is wonderful. Macfadyen especially does a wonderful job with soulful, smouldering looks that suit Darcy perfectly.I highly recommend this wonderful version of P&P; to all Austen fans.
summary: It's not Colin Firth, but I loved it anyway

reviewText: Although I do not consider myself a "finnicky" Austen purist, there is only so much irreverence I can take. If you want a good laugh - go see this. Although it's more likely you'll laugh AT it than with it. I realize they were extremely pressed for time, and in light of that I do give them some credit for what they tried to do. However.......My main quarrel is with Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy, who is wooden and awkward (and I don't compare him with Colin Firth - this is how he truly is without comparison)I read in a review that Mcfadyen did not read the book before they began shooting. What a mistake! Maybe if he had, he should have done more justice to the character and the movie.Secondly: Keira Knightly, who i'm afraid is just another pretty face. She cannot play Elizabeth, most of the movie she walks around with an artificial smile, and when in doubt, tries to play up Lizzy's vivacity by laughing, when nothing is really amusing. True, she was not so gratingly bad as Mr. Mcfadyen, but I think she too, missed the essence of the character.As for the rest of the Bennet clan, I think a former reviewer caught it very well: they are barnyard rustics living in a shabby house, where the daughters are seen baking - then later Mrs. bennet denies that her girls have anything to do in the kitchen! as for the other girls: Jane is lovely, but too shy. Lydia looks more like she should be playing Mary, and vice versa. Mr. Bennet is seen in the book as a sort of indolent country gentleman who is fond of books, in this version we see him taking an active role in the farm, and when he is in the house, trying vainly to be witty. Donald Sutherland was a bad choice.What is most disturbing to me though, is the closing scene, all fans of the book and the A&E; version will agree - this is weird, awkward, and completely uncalled for. What would Jane Austen think? I wonder.
summary: Tell me - is this for real?

reviewText: Absolutely NO humor. I can't be Jane Austen without her wit. This film lacked any chemistry at all between the family and that is the foundation upon which an Austen novel is built. Lizzie & Jane barely spoke, the father (played by Sutherland) was dull and lackluster. Keira Knightly's hair was absolutely ugly with those always wet-looking bangs. It was a ghastly take on Pride & Prejudice. The scenery was gratuitous, there were contrived silences that only interrupted the cadence of the plot, and there was just nothing to write home about in this film.Keira Knightly's portrayel of Lizzie Bennet was too strong, that jutting chin and too-fighting glance was all wrong for the character. Lizzie has more grace, tact, class, and love for her family. YUCK!

reviewText: I read somewhere recently that the directors/producers of this version made some intentional decisions to do unnecessary things like lowering the financial status of the Bennets to near-poverty, changing some of the dialog to sound more modern and reflective of (their own shallow experience with) teenaged girls, and changing the timeframe entirely because the director "didn't like" the fashions of the time in which Austen set her original novel. They apparently wanted this version to appeal more to a younger audience. Thus, along with the issues mentioned above, you will also find faster cuts and dialog, scenes in which the characters do things that would be completely unacceptable for the time (Lizzie with her hair completely down, or Darcy walking across fields with his shirt flapping open), and some very strange behavior from the family (Jane allowing a man in her room while she is in her nightdress). Not to mention the blatant attempt to infer sexual innuendo where there simply isn't any. (Seriously? That shot of the pig's...um...boy parts? Lizzie making a very vulgar check of Wickham's rear? ...Was the director influenced by a 13 year old boy?)Knightly's portrayal bugged me more than a little. I couldn't figure out what she was giggling at half the time, and the other half, the character was doing things blatantly out of character for Austen's heroine. I did, however, appreciate the fact that Mrs. Bennet is slightly more lovable in this version. The 1995 portrayal grates on the "nerves" and is way over done, but I thought this actress did a much more appropriate job of it.It is worth a look every once in a while, but if you want to see an adaptation that actually attempts to remain true to the story and the customs of the day (and not our narcissistic modern teenaged audience) then I, too, would recommend the Ehle/Firth BBC production.
summary: Meant to be a "teen" movie, and it succeeds
