reviewText: I bought this widescreen DVD for my wife, who absolutely loves this movie. She has watched it on VHS many, many times, and knows almost every scene by heart. I looked forward to watching it with her on our home theater system consisting of a hi-def front projector displaying on a 96" diagonal screen, and a Dolby Digital 5.1 surround system using a Denon receiver and Definitive Tech speakers (BP2002 towers, CLR2002 center, BP2X surrounds and PF15 sub). Anyway, the audio quality is outstanding, as was expected. The music is a highlight of this film and I enjoy it immensely. However, my wife commented that the top and bottom of the image was cut off. I told her that this widescreen image was simply wider and she was mistaken, but she insisted that she was right, so she popped in her VHS tape and we compared identical scenes, and surprisingly, she was right. In one scene, the father is sitting in a chair and you could see his hands folded in his lap. In the DVD version, you can not see his hands at all. A minor detail for sure, but my wife says that she likes her version better. Oh well, I'm hoping that the hi-def version scheduled to be released in November will have the entire picture without any cropping. Other than that, I can recommend this movie as a lush, well told love story.
summary: Great "chick flick", but video is cropped

reviewText: The high quality of this films production values and the stellar cast, help make this version of the beloved "Pride and Prejudice" a certified masterpiece.  The 1939 version, starring Greer Garson and Lawrence Olivier, is still charming and holds that nostalgic class that practically all of the films of that period in time seem to hold.  However, Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfayden have taken this material to new heights.  I was glad for Reese Witherspoon's win at the Academy awards, for her portrayal of June Carter Cash  in "Walk The Line," was very well done.  But after having seen Keira Knightley's performance here in this enduring tale, I couldn't believe such an injustice could have been done.  This movie would not have flowed so beautifully without her.  I highly recommend "Pride & Prejudice," for it is one of those rare films that can both lift the spirits and challenge them to respond to life's ups and downs.  It is the `best winner" of 2006 in my book and holds a special place of honor in my dvd library.

reviewText: Beautiful production values enhance the entertainment value of this latest adaptation of Jane Austen's classic novel. The storyline itself will win over any moviegoer, even those who usually balk at period pieces and classic literature. The characters are likeable and the sets are exquisite.Elizabeth and her sisters, from an impoverished family, are even more eager to make the "great marriage" that all young laides of the time were expected to find. Elizabeth, however, just can't bring herself to marry a man she doesn't respect no matter how much it helps her needy family. She surprises herself when she finds love and fortune with the man she least likes.Fine performances as well as a great story make this movie one not to be missed for those unfamiliar with the novels, and fans of Ms. Austen won't be disappointed with this newest remake.

reviewText: To think a story like Pride and Prejudice can be improved on, that one can write its dialogue better than Jane Austen, and that a story such as this needs help before it can become accessible is a case of hubris.  The appeal of Pride and Prejudice is universal and its characters are timeless.  The creators of this movie, however, took major liberties in their translation of this classic onto the big screen.I had high hopes for this movie, and I anxiously awaited for its release, but it fell completely short of my expectations.  Most of its characters were poorly cast, and the scriptwriters blundered many parts of the plot, re-writing it into nonsense that wouldn't have fit the sentiments and protocols of the era.Mr. Bingley was portrayed like a goofy boy rather than a respectable, good natured gentleman; Caroline Bingley looked more like a runway model on a perpetual high as opposed to a keen, manipulative social climber; Georgiana Darcy was bubbly and extrovert instead of being painfully shy; Mr. Collins was wooden and dull as opposed to being an obsequiously wily toadie (he was funny, though, I'll give him that); Darcy was portrayed as utterly misunderstood without pride, when we know that Darcy was definitely proud; and, though Keira Knightley is definitely spirited, she played Lizzie with liveliness and fire, but without the undeniable charm that tempered her faults and compelled us to forgive her trespasses.  Knightley's performance is also a little too forward and she is unable to subdue herself when necessary--basically, it's too modern a portrayal.Other reviewers have already poured over the script blunders, and I agree with most of them, but the ones that really stood out to me were:- Georgiana's wild hair, which was loose and looked absolutely unbrushed, along with her being portrayed as an extrovert.- Lady Catherine's late-night visit, with the entire Bennett clan standing around in their nightwear.- The rainstorm scene where Darcy proposes in clothes that are utterly drenched.- The inconsistencies with the costumes, particularly Lady Catherine's throwbacks and Caroline Bingley's modern, sleeveless numbers.- The inconsistencies with Longbourn.  It was rustic, dingy, and dirty--no doubt to make the Bennett's surroundings look more 'raw'--but they had servants at the ready in nearly every Longbourn scene.This isn't Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice; it's entirely someone else's vision of Pride and Prejudice.  Often times, I would wonder if the creators of the movie and I had even read the same book.  The scriptwriters thought that they had to help the story, that the story the way it is wouldn't work with audiences.  In the end, what was preserved of the original story was the only saving grace, with all the changes made with the plot done in poor taste.I understand that films and books are two entirely different creatures, and that there would be tremendous challenges for any movie seeking to portray a book's worth of material into a 2-hour film.  That, however, still does not excuse the dumbing down of the plot and dialogue.  One reviewer said that the film was too "obvious," and I'm apt to agree.  Even my husband says that the movie was "P&P; for Dummies."  The movie was more of a typical romance novel featuring P&P; characters rather than a movie version of our beloved novel.In the end, the A&E; version is still vastly superior.
summary: Hit and miss, but misses more often than hits

reviewText: The movie for last night was "Pride & Prejudice." I found the DVD in our shelves and apparently it was something that my wife picked up and we failed to watch. Well, its a "best-film-of-the-year" type of movie no matter what year it might occur in. Without question. What can I possibly say? This movie already has over 1300 Amazon reviews and about 60% of them are five stars. And a lot of the reviews are exceptionally good. Well, it's a quite touching love story, actually two love stories, but I'm not going to dwell upon it. I'm just going to make a few remarks about things that especially impressed me.One was the setting. Magnificent! Where do they ever find such places in this modern world? The buildings and grounds were just immaculate! It was like being in the best park you could ever imagine. Everything was done to perfection and the photography was amazing. How do they ever manage to get big sweeping panoramic views with out a single power line, roadway or cars showing? Amazing! It really felt as if they had taken you way back to that pre-modern time. Does England have "preserves" like this just for the purpose of making classic movies?Secondly, the costumes were excellent! And so elaborate! And no doubt correct for the time. This movie paid attention to the details, believe me. And the interiors of some of the living quarters were just magnificent. Do the Brits really live like this? Well, I guess these were all upper-crust Brits, so I'll let this one pass by. However, any fancier of interior decorations and antiques is just going to be awe-struck by this movie. No expense was spared, and it's not some computer animation trick.Finally, the acting is just first rate. It always takes me a while to adjust to the stiff British methods, but it wasn't long before I felt like a part of the set and I laughed and suffered right along with the members of the cast. Well done! Also, the movie had an exceptionally good musical score. I thought the sound was a little too intrusive and interfered with the dialog here and there, but that's probably because it was set in surround sound and I watched it using a stereo sound system. In any case, this is just an exceptional movie. Five Stars!Gary Peterson

reviewText: Loved the movie and I don't even like Jane Austen's stories.This interpretation was completely honest and surprisingly contemporary while still using Austen's words to effectively portray the emotions of the characters.  Keira, for such a tiny thing, is surpringly forceful and powerful in her prideful portrayal of Elizabeth Bennett.  Her acting style is so natural that you wonder if she was acting at all.  If Reese Witherspoon hadn't won the Oscar, it clearly would have gone to Keira Knightly.  I haven't seen the Colin Firth version of Pride and Prejudice, but this was well done, straighforward yet still cinematically beautiful and pleasant.I'd love to see more of Keira in strong roles which is what she's clearly suited for.  English Rose she may be, but dainty dame she is not.  Clearly a lovely tomboy who can hang with the boys...which acocunts for her solid performance in Bend it Like Beckham. Her off screen persona is not too far off.  When interviewed on the Red Carpet by Isaac Mizrahi, she told him with quick frankness she didn't think she would win.  Mizrahi responded that she needed a plan when her name was called.Keira:  Whether or not I win, I'm going to party afterwards.Mizrahi:  Great!  Who are you going with to the party?Keira: I don't know...I'm just going to...follow people.Now that's how a 20 year old talks.  You could tell she was clearly there to have fun and wasn't taking herself too seriously.Star in the making.  She's got plenty of time for Oscars.  Might as well enjoy herself.

reviewText: PRIDE & PREJUDICE is a handsomely mounted production, moodily filmed with a pervasive dark texture of visual expression about it. It is quite a visual presentation of the story where dialogue is left unspoken and the power of the images both animate and inanimate speak for themselves. That is not to say that the film goes on without dialogue, but rather quite the opposite. The many exchanges of dialogue are witty, brilliantly structured, eloquently spoken and presented with an economy of style that is concisely intelligent. This film with its intricately mounted visuals and words does an admirable job of bringing this literary work to the screen with all the constraints inherent in the medium of the cinema. Director Joe Wright also did a more than commendable job of representing the two main characters. Keira Knightley gives an awe-inspiring performance as Lizzie giving her great insight of the human condition. Lizzie though impetuous at times has a gift of rationalizing human behavior with a certain sense of reality offsetting loftier romantic ideals thus making her a young woman of keen intelligence. I truly enjoyed Matthew MacFadyen's performance as Darcy. He seems a young man tired and perplexed by convention but knows no other way to conduct himself and is trapped by his by his social status but more importantly by his own upbringing. Matthew MacFadyen's does an exceptional job conveying this. Awkwardly trying to emote his inner feelings he does more to alienate Lizzie than win her affections. MacFadyen's Darcy is truly a man misunderstood. Only through good and anonymous deeds can the true nature of the man prevail. I think this is a very good film rich with artistic fervor yet embracing all that is good of the human spirit. The DVD extras are very good.
summary: Concise and Exquisitely Beautiful Production and DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: Some will ask "how many versions of Jane Austen's read-to-the-point-of-fraying 'Pride and Prejudice' do we need?"  The current film archives show no fewer than ten versions and growing.  But for this viewer the current P & P du jour is as satisfying as any, edited and distilled to its main story lines without diminishing the main message from the author. Deborah Moggach can be thanked for the screenplay (with some subtle revisions by Emma Thompson) and Joe Wright  for his sensitive and forward momentum directing approach.So what make this version different and successful?  First, the placement of the Bennet family in the pig and mud friendly country home that sets the scene properly for the driver of the film - finding proper husbands for the five daughters whose well placed marriages will assure the lower class Bennet family a future stability.  Yes, it is a bit untidy, this household, but that makes it a family more dependent on the land and more prone to dreams of 'marrying up' in a country ruled by class system. Second, the casting of the Bennnet family with five truly young actresses (Keira Knightly, Rosamund Pike, Talulah Riley, Jena Malone, Carey Mulligan) instead of older types trying to appear like teenagers; a mother (Brenda Blethyn) who indeed shows her desperation of class; and a father (Donald Sutherland) who epitomizes Austen's father figure mold.  Add to the Bennets the credible men characters of Simon Woods, Matthew Macfadyen, Tom Hollander, and  Cornelius Booth and top it all off with a pivotal Lady Catherine de Bourg of Judi Dench and all players are in place for a fine cast.  The dialogue is crisp and sharp and the usual diversions into lineage names and sidebars are eliminated, bringing this long story down to just over two hours.The scenery and costumes are superb as is the cinematography by Roman Oshin and the musical score by Dario Marianelli  with a lot of help from Henry Purcell.  Is it one of the best movies of the year?  Perhaps, perhaps not, depending on taste. But it is nice to see Keira Knightly shine in a role more challenging than any she has had to date.  She inhabits Elizabeth Bennet luminously.  Grady Harp, March 06
summary: Distilled Austen Makes for a Fine Brew

reviewText: I am not British, I haven't seen the BBC version and have no idea of the minutiae of aristocratic surroundings in the UK to be too distressed about the Bennett house. I read the book, but not recently, so I cannot offer a detailed comparison of what was altered. Perhaps because of these factors I was surprised about the mixed reviews this film has gotten.I really liked this film for its emotional intensity, social commentary and beautiful cinematography. Love is unique enough today, when most people's choices are far less circumscribed than in the 19th century. At the time, it was the exception many dreamed about and few experienced, at least in their marriage. Pride and Prejudice is about women's lives, where compromise rules and the rational decision of Charlotte is the order of the day. The necessity of marrying for financial security gives even the most unsuitable men the pick of quite adequate women.The social hierarchy is clear and oppressive and all of us romantics watching it :) root for love to upset it. The pacing of the film allows us to understand the way Lizzy's and Darcy's feelings develop (by contrast, we are told of Jane's and Bingley's feelings, but do not experience them) and although we may know what comes next, we can still hold our breath. When at the end of the film, for example, Darcy comes to visit early in the morning, we watch him approach, rather than cut to him appearing and then talking to Lizzy. An important conversation is given weight by editing. These are the details that give the film its intensity. The actors are wonderful, a complex mixture of well-bred manners and uncontrollable emotion.Finally, the images of the countryside are striking in their beauty and rich detail rules even the indoor scenes. I actually regret that I haven't seen this film in the theater and I am seriously considering buying it. As this rarely happens to me, I can strongly recommend this movie :)
summary: I am thinking of buying this

reviewText: Yes, it's true.  A two-hour movie can't cover as much ground as a five-hour mini-series, and it may be unfair to expect it to.  What is a reasonable demand, however, would be expect the filmmakers to make judicious cuts in the narrative and not to rush, rush, rush through a fairly complex storyline and to run roughshod over the elegant dialogue that the story's original author provided her flawed, but self-aware and articulate characters.This film's failings--when compared to the artistic success of the 1995 BBC series--begs the question as to whether or not a novel this rich and this subtle doesn't deserve a full five or more hours to unfold on film.  Maybe that's the only real way to translate Austen's literary genius successfully to a visual medium.For the first half hour or so, I thought the problem may have just been me.  But when we got to the "Mr. Collins" scenes, I knew something internal to the film had gone awry.  The equivalent passages in the book--as well as the equivalent scenes in the 1995 production--make for masterful comic moments.  In this film, it's BING (Collins arrives) BANG (he proposes to Elizabeth, who rejects him completely) and BOOM (he marries Charlotte).  The acting is fine--especially Tom Hollander, who has some fine comic moments as Collins.  But the timing is way off.I will give director Joe Wright and his collaborators credit for coming up with a top flight ensemble cast overall.  There has been considerable attention payed to the casting of Keira Knightley, who is somewhat closer in age to her character than previous Elizabeths had been, and there is something to be said for that kind of "age appropriateness."  All well and good.  She's a fine young actress.  But her dialogue--like so much else in the movie--is too rushed and therefore almost awkward.  Elizabeth should speak with a kind of regal self-confidence.  That she doesn't quite manage that may not be Knightley's fault.  It's hard to be a witty and spirited conversationalist when you're obliged to dash through your lines.Matthew McFadyen as the more taciturn Darcy has it somewhat easier.  Like most educated young men of his class and of his era--and like any proper Austen hero--he is supremely well-spoken when he chooses to speak. McFadyen is an appealing actor, and certainly not a bad Darcy (he will have his camp followers, just as Colin Firth has his), but just about all he has time for is a furrowed brow here, a wounded look there.Probably the only really bad casting is that of Judi Dench as the Queen of the Night--I mean, Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  In British cinema, Dench is, of course, an institution.  Here unfortunately, she's more of a mental institution.  Her moments onscreen are almost painful to watch.  Someone on this site (perhaps the Amazon critic?) has kindly described her performanceas "full throttle."  That's polite for "overkill."Well, she does liven things up a bit.  But what we really need and what we really expect from any production of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is a certain esprit,  a sense of narrative driven by intelligent, incisive dialogue.  That's where the subtle social satire comes in.  Do away with that and you have a romantic 19th Century love story.  Not bad, but not all it could be.  And not really what it's supposed to be either.PS--I notice I received a number of "non-helpful" votes within less than 24 hours of posting this qualified (not actually NEGATIVE) review.  Well, people are certainly entitled to their opinions (just as I am entitled to mine).  However, I do wish readers of these reviews would learn to make the distinction between "non-helpful" and  "I disagree with this."  If a negative (or mixed) review gets you to THINK about why you liked the work in question, then, kids, it is HELPFUL.  You just happen to disagree with it.  I sometimes get the impression that some readers out there want nothing more than to see their own biases confirmed.  Which begs the question: why even BOTHER to read what anybody else thinks.

reviewText: Yes, loved it, as I didn't really know it and only read the book and watched other earlier versions as a result. Knightley is perfect in the part, and the rest are well placed as well, though the girls should've looked a little different in age to be precise. The only problem, once you know the book and Austin's life/material is that the director, which did such an excellent job in the first half, only did an average job in the second. That mirror scene failed, and should have been cut in the editting room if not later before release. The feel of the book was changed too much in the second half from the man's sister to the lack of walking scenes, so that the sense of history is lost in an attempt to 'modernize' the storyline, forgetting that the essence can be lost in the same process.All that said, I feel it is the best version I've seen. Others have had a better sense of historical accuracy but the female leads just weren't 'right' for the part in my opinion. Knightley seemed to be made up as Austin at times and the feel of the characters seemed more true, even if so many changes were made by the end. She is the only actress that 'was' the character in all the version's I've seen, the others either didn't have the look or the feel or age to play the part... again, in my opinion, as today's 'taste' has changed over the past few decades. I just wish the second half of the script could've been rewritten and reshot, a couple of great 'walking' scenes would have made better adaptations to film drama/comedy than what the director/writer choose for whatever reason they had at the time, but again, if I had to point to one, I'd take this shortened version over the other longer ones, that seemed so dull by comparison, some of which is a statement of British tv production values or lack of, at the time. The quality has improved to 'Hollywood' standards of production and presentation, for better and for worse, that's life here in Purgatory.

reviewText: Keira Knightley is one of the most beautiful women of this generation, as well as a terrific actress ("STAR WARS Episode I," the wildly successful"Pirates Of The Caribbean" films) and is a natural choice for the role of Elizabeth Bennet in what seems to be the 200th film version of Jane Austen's classic romantic comedy. Trust me, they are so worth it.The all-star cast is simply amazing.My only complaint is the casting of Donald Sutherland. His American accent was distracting, as the story is set in England, during the 19th century, and all the other actors had British accents. Fortunately, his screen time is limited.

reviewText: I am completely "prejudiced" because I LOVE the A&E; version.  I did at least hope to find Mr. Darcy handsome. Unfortunately this movie was a very big disappointment.Elizabeth Bennet: Played by Keira Knightly, she lacked... spirit. When talking with Mr. Darcy at the ball, she's supposed to be enjoying this clever and witty word play, but she just talks like anyone else would. And why does it seem like she's attracted to Darcy before he even proposes? She's supposed to find him insufferable. While many reviewers said they felt they could relate to Knightly better than Jennifer Ehle of the A&E; version, I didn't feel any connection at all. She showed very little emotion at all when she wasn't ranting angrily, and I simply didn't find her performance entrancing.Mr. Darcy: Someone told me that they thought Matthew Macfadyen cuter than Colin Firth, so I may have had my expectations too high, but... I thought Macfadyen rather ugly! I'm sorry, and I think he's very nice-looking in real life. But as Mr. Darcy... ugh! Also, he didn't make a convincing "insufferable" Mr. Darcy. Darcy is supposed to be rather rude, cold, and arrogant. Macfadyen simply looked either bored or sleepy.Mr. Collins: Oh, what a travesty! He's hardly even in the movie, and he didn't really seem to care a twopence about Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  This Mr. Collins was incredibly dull, his only advantage being his shortness.Mr. Bennet: Donald Sutherland lacks Mr. Bennet's dry wit and sarcasm, much too quiet and beaten down to be interesting. Also, it looked like he hardly ever shaved. With his long hair and scruffy chin, I kept thinking he looked like a cross between Benjamin Franklin and a pirate.Dialogue: Choppy, rushed, and SO watered down from Austen's original. They talked so fast that it was like they were afraid of running out of time and had to spit out every line as fast as they could.Costuming: Although a bit more attractive to our 21st century eyes than that of A&E;, it does not feel as authentic. Miss Bingley's dress in particular is ridiculous, having no sleeves and only very thin straps.Music: The one area in which this movie shines, although the music is not as authentic to the time period as that in A&E.;I had fairly low expectations when I started this movie, but I really tried to like it. Unfortunately, I found the events rushed and chopped, the characters cast quite poorly, and the over-all movie pretty lame. I was more bored in two hours than I've ever been in the five hour-long version. If you're looking for a good one, I would recommend the 1995 A&E; TV serial.

Jane was the beautiful one, of course. And Elizabeth's confidante and best friend.

reviewText: I love Pride and Prejudice the book. I've read it a dozen times, so like most true fans, I would like movies about to stick true to the real story. But I appreciate this movie a lot. I've seen four different Pride and Prejudice movies and in all of them, I think Keira Knightley is just the perfect Elizabeth. She's the right age, the right look and seems to have the right spunk. I enjoyed the unraveling of Matthew MacFadyen's Darcy. I felt he did all he could with the character, given the time constraints. I did like Colin Firth's version but I felt Jennifer Ehle was way too old to be Elizabeth. Did I love Colin Firth's Darcy? Sure but he had the luxury of a mini-series to make women understand him better.Anyway, this movie is a quick P&P; fix, using some creative liberties to meet the challenge of a movie. But the cinematography is breathtaking, the music excellent and the cast is brilliant. I loved it.

reviewText: There is no denying that turning a book as rich in characterisation and plot as "Pride and Prejudice" into a film is a dicey proposition. It's no potboiler with forgettable dialogue. Its characters are not two-dimensional. The story threads interweave and there is delicious wit and rather wicked social commentary from the pen of Jane Austen. How can a film adaptation hope to capture all of that?Of course, it cannot.But need a film adaptation transgress as heinously and thoroughly as this one does against the intentions of the author?There were some inexplicable blunders that don't make sense at all: Darcy actually CAME INTO ELIZABETH BENNET'S BEDROOM to give her the letter he wrote (inexcusable blunder - this is simply inconceivable); the Bennet dining room had servants serving the food in far too small a room (English country houses do not have dining rooms of such miniature dimensions, and certainly a normal meal rather than a grand occasion for a family of the straitened circumstances the film attempts to portray would not include servants standing at the ready to serve. It seems as though the director has melded the serving practises of larger country houses with the idea of a poorer yet still genteel family, but that is entirely historically inaccurate); Darcy was wandering about with his shirt undone and no cravat (as sexy-looking as that is, it's so inauthentic as to constitute an unforgivable faux pas); the ball held by Bingley had far too many people to constitute a country ball held to get to know his neighbours (again, it seems the director is going by vaguely and inaccurately held ideas of English country habits - could some real research not have been done?); the entire embarrassing and ridiculous scene with Elizabeth Bennet lasciviously viewing and caressing naked statues could only strike a 20th or 21st century American audience as appropriate; and Darcy proposing in the rain... (as anachronistic as a watch on the wrist of Michelangel's David); and an utterly bewildering moment occurs when Lady Catherine de Bourgh arrives at the Bennet's house in the middle of the night. Unless she came with urgent news, she would have been neither heard nor admitted at such an hour, nor would a gentleman have dreamed of appearing in front of a lady in his nightclothes. Those are only some of the ill-conceived and inappropriate moments.Let us pass over the strange family dynamics - clearly neither the director nor the actors bothered to read the novel in order to discover the complex relationships involved. For one thing, Mr and Mrs Bennet's marital relationship was clearly written by Jane Austen to be the worst mismatch in history; Mr Bennet is intended to be so disgusted and bored by most of his family (wife and daughters, except for Elizabeth and Jane) that he can find refuge only in perceiving them as amusing, and hiding in his study to avoid having to deal with them.Let us pass then to the casting. Keira Knightley is a lovely-looking young actress, but the character of Elizabeth Bennet is beyond her. She does not have the complexity to understand such a character, and her acting skills are not at present sufficient to convey the depth of such a richly drawn character. However, for the purpose of this film, the characters are completely altered anyway. In terms, then, of this film, within its confines (and not in respect of Jane Austen's Elizabeth Bennet), Ms Knightley was perfectly adequate, although she looked odd at times. Partly this is because her thinness was highlighted rather than flattered, and partly it's because her hair was so very strangely arranged. I could not understand the "washerwoman" hairdo, I confess - it is historically inappropriate for the period. If the purpose was to make Elizabeth Bennet look less beautiful than Jane Bennet, a very strange idea has occurred. Elizabeth is certainly not plain in the novel. She has a loveliness that is characterised more by her liveliness than feature-by-feature, but she is considered by all who know her to be one of the prettiest girls in the county. Jane is considered by the regularity of her features to be the most beautiful, but the whole Bennet family is known for their beauty (save for Mary). How has this been translated to mean that Elizabeth is not lovely-looking? Why the insistence in this film on downplaying Keira Knightley's looks? Simply because Mr Darcy does not instantly find Elizabeth Bennet beautiful...? And because Miss Caroline Bingley and her sister will not do justice to her looks? The difference between Elizabeth and Jane is one of kind, not of quantity. Both the director and some of the viewers seem not to have realised that.The Darcy looked beautiful, and it's not really the actor's fault that he was not conveying Jane Austen's Darcy. Again, really I blame the scriptwriter who did such an appalling hatchet job, and the director who seems to have thought of this film in terms of making the cinematography look beautiful but eschewed any care with regard to historical detail or the requirements of the story itself.The dialogue flip-flops from modern "I'm writing an historical novel" style to authentic Jane Austen - and the difference between the two styles is embarrassing. Unless a scriptwriter is prepared to enmesh him/herself into the writing style of the period, complete with an understanding of the grammar of the English language as spoken at the time, and specifically the style employed by Jane Austen, such an obvious clash is bound to occur. And furthermore, a modern idea of dialogue can only create further flaws in the style of the dialogue. It simply doesn't work unless the scriptwriter is prepared to let go of a 21st century idea of how the characters OUGHT to be. If he/she isn't prepared to do that, the scriptwriter had better stick to modern dramas.What a pity that the scriptwriter felt it necessary to make Darcy "misunderstood" rather than truly "proud". This reduces the title of the book (and thus the title of the film) to meaningless drivel. In the novel, Darcy really WAS a proud man - he acknowledges it, and through his love for Elizabeth and the travails in their relationship, he found within himself a more proper understanding of how he could maintain his sense of self yet become more approachable. Elizabeth, too, acknowleged in the novel that her prejudices led her astray, and she, through knowing Darcy and through the troubles of her own family, comes to learn herself more thoroughly. "Until this moment I never knew myself", she says - but she does not say it in the film. Indeed, she could not - for in the film, she too is just "misunderstood". The characters do not grow and develop in this film - because, like a Mills & Boon romance novel, they don't need to. The characters are two-dimensional - but most viewers don't seem to notice that.To compare this film to the splendid 6-part adaptation with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth is to compare a somewhat battered meringue with a superb full-sized gateau. The BBC series had everything right; this film sadly does not.I suppose the main flaw of this film was its obviousness. Moments such as "sexy open-shirted man strides through the mist, his cloak flapping in the wind behind him" abound. Oh dear. Very, very Mills-and-Boonish. The lack of subtlety is everywhere... and the same holds true for the character dynamics. Instead of the subtle 18th century character interplay, the audience is served with lashings of modernised ideas of love sans any of the biting social judgements that add spice to Jane Austen's excellent writing.By the end of this film (indeed, fifteen minutes into the film), I no longer cared whether Darcy and Elizabeth ever married. I could not consider them real. They had no claim upon my sympathy. What a contrast to my emotional involvement in the BBC series!I recommend this only for viewers who enjoy soap operas, or for people who don't care about historical accuracy or subtle performances. Oh, and it may also please those who find Jane Austen's actual novel too difficult to read.
summary: The Harlequin Mills & Boon version of Pride And Prejudice

reviewText: Would Jane Austen approve of this use of her book?  Ask a silly question.  In the protracted pre-dawn of the audio-visual age that we call the nineteenth century, literature, as in our day, could be conceived as a means of making people think, but never could it guarantee where thoughts might wander.  The whole idea was to set thoughts in motion, to stir the imagination into creating self-styled images that reflected the author's words as readers experienced them.  A do-it-yourself motion picture.I think that Jane Austen would find our reflections every bit as entertaining as her own.  As ever, the character of human nature is timeless, much as we delightin exploring the nature of her characters, and have done for generations, beyond anything that she could have anticipated.I am impressed with this film at all levels.  The cinematography is outstanding, and beautifully understated, as is the acting.  Historically, it is as true to the period as anything I've seen.  It's also a product of its own time, and the pace runs accordingly.  Parts of the original book are suggested more than played outon screen.  Still, there is something to be said for brevity in telling a story, especially if it's a good one.

reviewText: Is it possible for a film to get better and better with repeated viewings? I originially caught Pride and Prejudice in the theaters when released, and was surprisingly delighted at the adaptation presented before me. Then, I promptly forgot it with the Caoptes and Brokeback Mountains of the world. Upon it's release on DVD, I absolutely fell in love with this movie, and again and again, and now regard it as a mere masterpiece; a cinematic feast.I'm not an Austen purest. In fact, I shudder to admit on Amazon.com that I have not even read her. So any comparison of the book to the movie would be lost on me. I also have not witnessed the BBC comprehensive version of Pride, to which many compare this movie. So the disruptive ending of the movie, which sometimes seems to upset the Austen purests, and the wonderful performance of Colin Firth, which dominates the BBC version, are unknown to me. I watch this with virgin eyes.And of course, I delight in what I see. A story of a young woman, one of four girls, destined in early 1800's England to marry, but with strong will and mind of her own. She bristles against the bristle-y Mr. Darcy, hard edged, unsocial (much like me, minus the money), and like flint and steel, tremendously spark and start a fire which burns through the film, brightly, intensely, passionately. The moments of confrontation, and lack thereof, between Elizabeth and Darcy are juicy, palpable, and true, and thus drive this plot honestly.The performances astound. I've caught all of the leading actress roles this year, and I must say, Kiera Knightly's performance ranks as superior. She is the film; simply put. Should another actress play Elizabeth, the film would have lost its soulforce. By all rights, she should have marched up to the stage to claim her reward (possibly only surpassed by the comparable Felicity Huffman's role in Transamerica). In turn, Matthew Macfadyen's harsh Mr. Darcy melts before our eyes and on the screen before Elizabeth, and the glacial melt is amazing. Where was his nomination? Supporting actors Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn were born to play Elizabeth's honest, supportive parents. And Tom Hollander as the bumbling, ill-fated suitor Mr. Collins almost steals the movie with his comic pathos. Fine performances from all.Adding to this mix, Joe Wright's amazing, amazing, amazing direction. Most of the film's enjoyment comes from his camera placement and work. Just watch the scene at the second party, where the camera moves throughout the party, and manages to tell several parts of the story seemlessly at once. Wright tells on the commentary how it took hours to set up the shot; the results impress and delight. He shaped this movie, which could have been another bland period piece, into something rich, delightful, multi-layered, and dare I say.... modern?Pride and Prejudice is a film that in many years, people will be popping into their video players of the future; to study fine filmmaking, to learn from solid performances, to watch young love, and to enjoy the exploits of Elizabeth and Darcy, their machinations of love, and the persistance of desire.Bravo!

reviewText: 1. This movie is much better than my wife and I expected.  To be sure, there are big departures from Jane Austen's book and the tale seems tailored to a modern audience.  Nevertheless, we're giving this production five stars, because of its overall impact and flow.  The acting and location shots are first-rate and key scenes are so beautifully done.  We particularly liked the scene near the end where Elizabeth entreats her father so she might marry Mr. Darcy.  She reveals how Darcy is the one who bailed out the Bennett family from Mr. Wickham's debts and also arranged for sister Lydia's marriage. This ending seems more convincing than other versions we've seen because it registers with Mr. Bennett that Darcy is the one who saved the family.  If you look it up, the bail-out revelation is in the book.2. Viewers may want to turn on English subtitles in places so as to get all the dialogue.  This is a British production making it hard for we Americans to follow at times.  An idea raised by another reviewer is also a good one, namely, to turn on the director's commentary when you have time to re-view the movie.  A lot of things come out you would not know otherwise, making this a deeper film than what you first saw.  Not all the director's comments are profound but when he tells you he devoted 2 years of his life to the film (morning, noon, and night) you need to pay attention.  Also, we're told why Elizabeth and her aunt and uncle are given a tour of sculptures at Pemberley rather than seeing portraits of the Darcy family.  Sure, the scene departs from the book, as so many other things do, but it's awfully well done.3. This movie runs only 2 hours, so its character development pales in comparison with miniseries that were done by the BBC in 1979 and by A&E; in 1995.  On DVD, these productions run 4 and 5 hours, respectively.  To really understand the story line most viewers should see one or both of these and even read the book.  Key characters like Wickham and Mr. & Mrs. Collins barely have cameo roles in the 2005 movie which is a pity.  Also, time constraints may have precluded showing more on the special relationship between Mr. Bennett and his second daughter, Elizabeth, who may really be his alter ego.4. In other respects, it's apparent that the producer and director wanted to stage this movie a lot differently than previous versions.  The Bennett family is seen living a very rustic life with pigs, geese, and dogs underfoot.  This is a major departure from life discussed in the book and depicted in other film and TV versions.  This movie is set in the year, 1797, not 1813, as previously understood.  In another departure, the opening ballroom scene is far more informal and earthy than what we've seen before. But it has an infectious energy that prepares you for the rest of the show.  Yes, this version is going to be different from other ones!5. For most of the movie, Elizabeth runs around in very casual attire with her hair wild and unkempt.  All the while she states her opinions freely and is not bashful about offending others, including her poor mother.  In many ways, Lizzy seems like a wild animal that may appeal to Darcy's basic instincts. This is another big departure from the book and from past productions where the eldest Bennett girls are seen as well-dressed and presentable, desperate as they are to find good husbands.  The "car wreck" scene where Elizabeth rejects Darcy and his first marriage proposal may be the most powerful moment in the movie.  Darcy, despite his imposing size and presence, appears lucky Elizabeth didn't have a club nearby when she rejected him.  What a contrast to the second proposal where Darcy stammers out his love for her and Elizabeth accepts him while gently taking his hand.  Brilliantly done!6. Music has been an important element in past productions of Pride and Prejudice and it is here, as well.  The Baroque-era music played at the balls is our favorite kind.  Also, the haunting piano theme heard throughout the show is extremely well done and played.  Bravo!7. Although the casting of Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett may have raised some eyebrows we thought he did quite well, especially at the end where he talks to Elizabeth about Darcy's second proposal.  Keira Knightley is marvelous as the untamed Elizabeth, Mr. Bennett's favorite daughter.  Matthew MacFadyen is a revelation as Darcy.  In truth, Matthew looks like such a physical specimen he might have playing linebacker for the Green Bay Packers.  What's just as amazing is that when he speaks he sounds like an educated, British gentleman.  Actors portraying Mrs. Bennett, Jane Bennett, Mr. & Mrs. Collins, Lady Catherine DeBourgh, Mr. & Miss Bingley, and the other Bennett sisters were fine, too.  Mr. Bingley did seem a bit foppish at times, but in contrast to MacFadyen's Darcy, it's not surprising.8. At the end, Elizabeth seems to blame herself completely for misjudging Darcy.  He comes off then as pride-free and irresistible.  Some might feel this is taking one too many liberties with Jane Austen's message.  Actually, Darcy has been changed and humbled by Elizabeth's rejection of his first proposal.  It takes several months for a transformation to be completed and for Darcy to do heroic deeds.  He then becomes acceptable to her and us.  The movie's producer and director may have been aware of this fact but with only 2 hours to work with simply couldn't show it.  Or, maybe they just wanted to stress that rich people have their problems, too?9. Comparisons to the other versions of Pride and Prejudice are difficult.  For us, the wit and elegance of the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle version from 1995, may never be surpassed.  Also, the 1979 miniseries with Elizabeth Garvie, David Rintoul, and Judy Parfitt has special moments.  The 1940 version with Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier deserves attention as well, even though it takes even more liberties with Jane Austen's story than the others.  In style and substance, the 2005 version is quite different from earlier ones but it is effective and entertaining.  Our sense is to get and study them all.  The timeless story and characters make for a masterpiece in English literature and a study of human nature.  If nothing else, the happy ending of the 2005 version is classic.10. Special features on the 2005, DVD include interviews with the producer, the director, and the main characters.  There is some repetition, but their comments offer more insights into why this story is so appealing. Too bad other productions haven't offered interviews of the leading stars in this way.  Maybe we'll see them some day in a super-gold, Nth anniversary, collectors' edition?
summary: Not the 1995 version, but still very well done

reviewText: I first read P&P in college and some years later was thrilled to see the wonderful adaptation starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth.  It was so good and followed the book so well that I wondered what was the purpose of remaking this story and in such an inferior way. I do not believe that I am being nitpicking when I say that at the time of the story, women would never have been seen with such messy hair and clothing.  Even the poorer class ones (which the Bennets most certainly were NOT) would never have lived and dressed the way they are depicted in this ridiculous film.  Pigs in the yard and such dirty surroundings!  Really!  It looked more like Tobacco Road than the home of British gentry!  The characters also were badly interpreted especially Mr. Bingley who was a real wuss and one wonders what did Jane see in him besides his money.  Did screen writers or director even crack the book? They certainly did not study the history and social customs of the time. I thought this movie might at least be passable, but I found it abysmal and stupid!
summary: Why was this movie even made?

reviewText: Okay, I'm a total Janeite who adores Austen and all her work. I probably re-read each of her novels at least once a year, and I'm a high school English teacher. So I find the 1995 BBC mini-series to be the Holy Grail of Austen movies. But this one has its charms. I am not a big Keira Knightley fan, and I found her Lizzy to be less spunky and more moody than in the novel. (The director keeps showing Lizzy alone, staring into space. I suppose that should make us think she's deep.She's much more cheerful and sociable in the book.) Also the director went for a "grubby" look in this movie. Everybody has greasy hair and appears to need a shower. I guess he figures nobody bathed much in those days. The story is a bare bones version of the book that hits the high points quickly, but the movie is clearly more interested in being beautiful and poetic, and there it succeeds. The piano music in this film is lyrical and moving, and the movie has lots of interesting visual images. The director does a nifty thing with the characters' hands that I really liked. And this Darcy (while no Colin Firth) is not too shabby. Matthew Macfadyen seems to be portraying a "kinder, gentler" Darcy who seems more shy that gruff, but he's such a handsome guy and has such a gorgeous, deep voice, that I enjoyed looking at him and listening to him. So my overall impression is that I liked it for what it was, a quicker more stylized version of a wonderful story. As a footnote, I'll add that my students fall into two camps when I show them this movie: girls who fall in love with Darcy and adore the film, and kids of both genders who say they hated it because the story moved so fast they couldn't tell what was happening.
summary: Lovely but not that true to the novel

reviewText: I really detest Knightley. I've never liked her even though I've desperately wanted to. Her quirks and mannerism's all seem to scream "Look at me! Look at me!" in almost a Lydia like fashion, pardon the pun. The Darcy in this one was good, loved his eyes, but I just couldn't get past Knightley. There were redeeming qualities about this though. Donald Sutherland as her father was excellent and I especially enjoyed the final scene between he and his daughter when he's asking her if she really likes Darcy. He tears up and it's entirely believable. I did not like the scene at the end when Darcy and Lizzie finally declare their love for each other. Instead of answering, in this version, Knightly takes his hand and kisses it. I'm very much convinced, after reading several Jane Austen's and books during this era, that this would not have happened. There is just too much propriety here during this age for that. Took me out of the story, and because of it, can't recommend it.[...]
summary: This Movie is Only for Knightly Fans...

reviewText: We swore not to compare it to the BBC miniseries. You can't improve on perfection. So, after hearing the rave reviews, we decided to throw caution to the wind and watch it, after swearing never, not once, to compare between the two.All in all, it wasn't a bad movie. The main problem lies in the confusing storyline which simply cannot be covered in such a short time. If I hadn't such an intimate knowledge of P&P; before the movie, I would have been quite lost. This affects character developement and relationships. There are moments of quiet and pretty music but very little interaction between Elizabeth and Darcy.The feel of old-England society was lost, which leads to a lot of confusion. Why is it so terrible that Darcy won't dance with Elizabeth? Why are her sisters such an embarrasment when the parties they are in are as raucus as themselves? Being familiar with the book, I already knew, but the impact of the embarassing and moving moments were lost because the society that made them embarassing and moving were gone. Also, Elizabeth going out into the rain to get herself a towel off the line? *shakes head* The Bennets are not poor; they happen to be quite well-to-do, the only thing they don't have is dowries for the girls. You can have a huge income and not any money saved up. And admiring nude statues in Darcy's home? Uhh.. that's not right.The society portrayed in this movie was not the stuffy, prissy life of the upper-middle class, but more suited to the lower. Perhaps they meant to liven it up a bit by showing us the nitty-gritty side to life, but instead they spoiled the feeling of the whole society. Elizabeth and Jane giggling in bed? I don't know.. that's just not.. English.Keira Knightly is not a bad Elizabeth Bennet. She did justice to the role. Darcy talked to fast and was more quiet and laid back than arrogant and imposing. Also, he wasn't good-looking at all. Part of his personna is his hot animal attraction! Wickham was not only very likeable but gorgeous! That's not right! Darcy should be more cute! (Ok, enough juvenile complaints) Mr.Collins was.. not stupid. He was almost.. conniving. And handsome, too, if short. I really couldn't understand why Elizabeth could object so strongly to marry him especially considering her family's condition. It seemed.. selfish of her. Again, this is only looking at the movie as though I had never read the book before.THe movie was pretty, with beautiful music and nice acting. It had its good parts and carried the essence of the story pretty well. However, it left much to be desired and the characters weren't Jane Austen's own. I would have to recommend the BBC version.. the book there is played to perfection. But this is a good movie for your weekends as well.
summary: Meh.. nothing spectacular.. beautiful music, though..

reviewText: I still consider the 1995 miniseries to be THE definitive version of Pride & Prejudice.Still, this new version does have things about it I prefer to any other version. Donald Sutherland in this version I find to be the best Mr. Bennet of all versions.No matter what version you watch, you hear Mrs. Bennet repeatedly comment on how much prettier Jane is than Lizzy. In the '95 version Lizzy is 10 times prettier than Jane and therefore Mrs. Bennet's comments just make you scratch your head and say "what!?". The Jane in the new version is such a beauty that you can accept these comments even though you may not agree with them. The Jane in this version is also more fitting in age. The Jane in the '95 version seems to old for the part, even though Susannah Harker acted the part with perfection.I like the new Wickham a bit better too since in the new one he is much more handsome. Someone could indeed picture Lizzy choosing him over Darcy for looks alone and therefore could indeed be considered a threat. The Wickham in the '95 version isn't nearly as good-looking as Mr. Darcy and therefore less of a threat.As far as Mr. Bingley goes, I loved both the new and old '95 versions of him. Unlike most people I like the new Mr. Bingley better. He is more shy and timid in the new version and this to me makes him more endearingAs far as comparing the 2 Lizzies, I think that Keira Knightley is every bit as a talented actress as Jennifer Ehle is in the '95 version. With that said every now and then an actor or actress comes along who was born to play a part. As much as Keanu Reeves isn't the best actor out there , he was born to play the part of Neo in The Matrix. Nobody could have done it better. I feel the same way about Jennifer Ehle in the mini series. While Miss Knightley is just as talented and did a great job in the remake, Jennifer Ehle was simply born for this part and truly embodies Lizzy. I don't think anyone could have done a better job than her.The same goes for Colin Firth as Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy. While Matthew Macfadyen did a WONDERFUL job in the remake, Colin Firth was simply born the part. He IS Darcy.All-in-all as a whole there is no version that can compare to the '95 mini series, which is truly a masterpiece. Still, the new version is well worth buying and offers a refreshing take on this story. I would even go as far as saying that the new version is my favorite movie of the year !I rate the '95 version 10 stars out of 10 , and this new version 9 stars out of 10. Buy them both!

reviewText: This is a very attractive film.  Attractive stars, attractive sets, attractive story.  As a period romance it is a fine and entertaining film.  But it is not Jane Austen.  In fact, if you weren't already well versed in the plot of Pride and Prejudice, I don't know that you'd get it from this film.  Austen wrote with an 18th century sensibility, not a Romantic Age one.  And although the film has an 18th c. setting feel - a bit of the country raunch of Tom Jones - it is not the setting Austen wrote. Her characters did not wallow in pig slop.  Most of her wit is swamped by misty morning ramblings of the young stars, caught in glowing close-ups - time better spent on the plot and dialogue.  Classic comic characters are given short shrift and played with far too much seriousness or sympathy.  The all important sub-plot, which explains the sisters dilemma, flashes by so fast that many may miss its significance, particularly in light of today's mores. But then adequate development might detract from the time needed for all those misty close-ups.  Knightley is attractive but this is NOT her Academy Award star turn - or rather, shouldn't have been.  If Austen doesn't matter to you, you'll enjoy the film.  If Austen does, stick with the BBC mini-series.

reviewText: First off, let me say that I'm not a huge Jane Austin fan, nor am I a fan of most 'romantic' movies (because they suck!).  But I absolutely adore this movie.  For all you purists out there who complain it leaves too much of the details out, it's a movie not a mini-series.  I also have the 4 disc BBC production, which is lovely, but who has time to watch 8 hrs. of movie on a regular basis?  Visually this movie is stunning, and so is Kierra.  It looked awesome in DVD and is even better in Blu-ray.  It's a much 'fresher' version of the original, the actors are just as good (Mathew MacFayden is just as good a Mr. Darcy as Colin Firth, just different)and the photography will simply blow you away.  Just a beautiful, beautiful film.

reviewText: This a terrible adaptation of an excellent book. I'm not denying that the movie is entertaining to watch, since it is. But it does no justice to the actual book. Granted, I'm comparing with A&E;'s brilliant adaptation, so it would be hard for any movie to stand up to that. Obviously, this is a shorter movie and necessarily cannot follow the book as closely, which I don't necessarily have a problem with. The real issue that I have with this movie is the incorrect portrayal of the characters, particularly that of Mr. Darcy and Mr. Bingley. Mr. Darcy looks like scruffy slob in much of the movie, which is ridiculous. The worst though is Mr. Bingley. His character is portrayed as stupid throughout the whole movie. While Mr. Bingley is certainly a bit goofy in the book, he is anything but stupid. Here though, the directors or whoever else have made him seem like a bumbling idiot. This is such a shallow interpretation of his character, as if he serves no other purpose in the story besides comedic value, which is preposterous.Realistically though, this movie was created purely for entertainment and they did do that. I guess I just love A&E;'s version too much to be satisfied with anything else :) But if you don't have 6+ hours to devote to watching all of that and just want to curl up on the couch and watch a good love story, this one works well :)

reviewText: Though beautifully shot and ably acted, there is too much story in "Pride and Prejudice" to fit into 2 hours. The film skimps on the relationship between Elizabeth and her father, and flattens the differences between the sisters until they are nearly indistinguishable. Mister Collins, the fusty pastor, is only marginally dull; fiendish Mr. Wickham seems incapable of guile; Lydia Bennet insufficiently silly. The movie gives us little background to appreciate the country-vs-city issues, such as why Darcy and Miss Bingley considered walking so bizarre a mode of transport. And not for a moment did I consider Keira Knightley as someone who could be taken as plain-looking.The sets are quite splendid, however. Even the Bennet's "poor" country manor, for all its faded and peeling glory, is rendered with great detail. The sountrack however, was so loud and lush and hardworking that it bordered on cliché -- when it wasn't actually masking important dialog. So much of the film is hurried, with machine-gun dialog that I could not understand. And compensatory touches -- like providing the characters with different outfits or outsized personalities -- were ignored for some reason, perhaps to focus more on the main characters. If so, this was a huge mistake. The charm of P&P; is the interplay between the book's many characters and the norms that governed them. To streamline the characters and plot is to take away the story's soul.And no amount of loud music can make up for that.I highly recommend the 1995 miniseries, starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth. It's more than twice as long as this movie, but has to be.

reviewText: The challenge of adapting any previous standing work is cited by screenwriters as notoriously difficult, perhaps the most so. It's especially encouraging, then, to see such a well-made, engaging translation to the big screen. It's no small feat, as for many Austenites (including my wife), the 1995 BBC-TV miniseries is the definitive one.While that version has six hours to gently unfold the romance of the quick-witted, independent Elizabeth Bennett (Keira Knightley) and the imperious, remote Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen), this new film only has two. It's a fine telescoping and shuffling of locales and events, nicely paced without feeling rushed. Both performers warm to each other in increments well-suited for the story's shape. It's believable, tender and touching.The casting choices are strong, but purists may find themselves longing for the BBC cast at times. Especially missed are Benjamin Whitrow's Mr. Bennett, and David Bamber's Mr. Collins. Mr. Whitrow's Bennett is a flinty delight, but Mr. Sutherland's final scene is so warm and emotional that it rescues his far softer interpretation. Tom Hollander's Mr. Collins suffers the most in comparison with his predecessor, whose hilarious take on the character bordered on the reptilian. Of course, Colin Firth's Mr. Darcy is in no danger of being eclipsed, but Mr. MacFadyen more than holds his own with a subtly rendered performance. Ms. Knightley defies the "pretty girl" casting with very strong acting as well, proving herself to be convincing in a period drama.This is a great stand-alone version of the story, drawing viewers in and engaging their hearts and minds. While the miniseries is ultimately superior, this new film also preserves the story's charms through a new lens.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've never seen the BBC mini-series version, so I can only compare this to the book.  Naturally, large parts were cut or reduced (such as Wickham and Collins' parts).  All that information cannot be faithfully reproduced in the short time span of a movie, as it can in a miniseries.  However, the filmakers hit all the right notes in what they chose to include and how well it was rendered.  The movie focused on Lizzie and Darcy, which is of course the heart of the novel.The acting was top notch, especially Keira Knightly.  She deserved the Best Actress nomination as she fully embodied Lizzie.  I disagree with the reviewer below about Darcy's "deadpan eyes."  They lit up like the sun in the closing of the movie when his love was embraced by Lizzie--he was a misunderstood person and Matthew Macfadyen conveyed that.  Additionally, it was nice that for once Darcy didn't have to be a "pretty boy."  Rugged good looks can be just as dashing!  Donald Sutherland was a delight as Mr. Bennett, conveying his love and exasperation for a family of women with charm and dry wit.  He is a superb actor, and you could see that he truly cared about these women (and the actresses who played them).While the movie was spectacular, the DVD leaves a lot to be desired.  There are four main featurettes, but there is a lot of repetition between them.  The viewer need only watch "Behind the Scenes at the Ball."  The interviews with the cast in it are repeated for "HBO First Look" and "A Bennet Family Portrait."  The small biopic on Jane Austen was nice, but not very informative--focusing mainly on her home and where she wrote her novel.  Why not a complete biography?  And where are the deleted scenes?  Filmakers are notorious for filming more than they could ever include.  During the commentary, the filmakers mention that the dancing scene at the Ball between Darcy and Lizzie was completely recut and edited.  Why not show the original cut vis a vis the theatrical cut?  This film deserved the two-disk treatment--no doubt we'll get that in a year or two after we've all bought this version.  Hollywood sure knows how to treat the fans.
summary: 5 stars for the film, 2 for the DVD.

reviewText: Keira Knightly is just an appallingly bad actress nowhere near up to this role.  She is hauled along through this along with Matthew Macfadyen (Mr. Darcy) and Kelly Reilly (Caroline Bingley), slightly better actors but weak overall.  Actually, part of what disappoints one in Kelly is simply bad costuming - she dresses and gives the impression she's walking out of a rather elegant party sometime in the 20th century versus the 19th - her hair's wrong, too.  The rest of the cast is somewhat amazing in establishing a sense of authenticity and picking up their roles - the costuming and photography, the settings will suck you in and make you watch!  A heavy Hollywood thumbprint is unfortunately highly visible in a few scenes: the `Titanic' ending someone thought was a good idea! (Bull!) - and the Church `joke' that dared to take a perfectly respectable 19th century word and serve it up on a platter for modern sensibilities so that a hip-hop audience could giggle at it.  Sorry - you've just walked past the proscenium, it doesn't work - it murders the historical authenticity you've invested so much to establish!  Excellent performances: Donald Sutherland (Mr. Bennett - so perfect but unexpected for this role), Tom Hollander! (Mr. Collins), Simon Woods (he glows), Brenda Blethyn (Mrs. Bennett - this is such an easy role to steal!).  Amazing scenery.

reviewText: I was excited to see this condensed version of P&P; and relied on friend reviews. Previous to receiving reviews, I had planned not to see this version, because to me the BBC version was definitive. I was extremely sorry to find that this version is noisy, busy, and much less good than the BBC version. The lines of dialogue are chipped out, barely said, you can hardly tell who anyone is, except for Bingley's huge head of hair, and all of the participants seem to be born in a barn. The slamped-t0-the-head hairstyle is old now and particularly unwelcome in the Georgian period. Further, Donald Sutherland fails to convince as Mr. Bennett. The whole thing struck me initially as horrid and a waste of time, upon viewing it again, scene by scene, I still think it lesser than the BBC version, but liked it better. However, if you are interested in Pride and Prejudice, watch the full BBC version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle first.Further, this version has none of the beauty or satisfaction of the original BBC version, plus, the screenplay takes huge advantage and abuses the story. So enjoy the barnyard version of P&P.; There are beauties in this version, but not it's not quite as  satisfying as the A&E; version.
summary: sadly much worse than the BBC version

reviewText: When I first saw the movie (probably in a theatre when it first came out) I was entranced.  I had never seen the TV miniseries, so I had nothing to compare it to, and I'd only read the book once, years before. So I came at it fresh, and based my opinion only on what was onscreen. I thought that Knightley was brilliant, and captured the lighthearted but also serious sides of Lizzy, and that MacFadyen was, I have to say it, a dreamboat. The filming - the amazing tracking shots, the way it moves in and out of window, the character actors playing all the other roles (Blethyn, Hollander and Dench are all FANTASTIC), the incredible scenery and lively earthy settings - I loved it all. I even set some of the music as my phone ringtone!  I watched it occasionally on TV over the years, and have always loved it.I just bought the DVD (June 2012, 7 years later) and watched it all the way through in one sitting.  In the last few years, I've read all of Austen several times through, and watched many film and TV adaptations, including the Firth/Ehle P&P;, and the 2009 Emma with Jonny Lee Miller and Romola Garai. Both of those, as 4 part mini-series, can be much truer to the plot and pace of the book than a 2 hour movie can - this P&P; has to speed through the plot, especially the second half.  And I notice it more now - we miss a lot of the character development and the true friendship that develops between Darcy and Elizabeth.I still love a lot about it - it is gorgeous, the acting is mostly wonderful. But with Austen's language more fresh in my mind and ear, the departures from her words, and the made up dialogue and scenes (some of which are necessary - she never writes much dialogue for proposal scenes - and some of which are extremely unnecessary) were more jarring.  There were some cringeworthy changes - making Mr. Bennett weepy in the scene where he gives Lizzy's marriage his blessing; "Yes, a thousand times yes" spoken by Jane when she accepts Bingley's proposal, and most sadly, one of my favorite lines: "you have bewitched me, body and soul, and I never want to be parted from you again." It's just too pulpy for Austen - she would absolutely have made fun of such language.Despite these criticisms, it stands the test of time - it's one of my favorite Austen adaptations, alongside Emma (2009) and Mansfield Park (1999) by Patricia Rozema - another that's absolutely beautiful to watch but departs enough from the book to make a lot of fans angry.

reviewText: I've lost count of how many films have been made of Jane Austen's best-loved book, but this latest release is far from the worst. That dubious honor in my view goes to the 1942 movie that had the characters parading around in what looked like wardrobe rejects from "Gone With the Wind" and Greer Garson at age 36 trying to convincingly play a 20 year old ingenue. Give me a break.The latest film, directed by Joe Wright, is a fairly faithful retelling of Austen's plot, which almost everybody and his mother is familiar with by now, with gorgeous visuals to hook us squarely into the time and place. The visuals, in fact, are so beautiful to look at that at times they tend to overwhelm the story.For anyone out there -- if there is anyone out there -- who doesn't know the plot, "Pride and Prejudice" introduces us to the Bennet family who belong to the upper-middle-class landed gentry in late 18th century England. The second daughter, Elizabeth, sharp as a marble and pretty to boot, meets Mr. Darcy, a tall, dark, handsome and single young man with money out the wazoo. It's loathing at first sight. He despises her middle-class connections; she thinks he's a stuck-up snob with an attitude. The rest of the story has them finding out how wrong they are about each other; there are a lot of interesting plot twists and turns, but in the end, of course, almost everybody ends up living happily ever after.Jane Austen told her sister Cassandra that she thought the book was "rather too light and bright and sparkling" but that is exactly what has endeared it to generations of readers in print and on film. Who doesn't love a good love story? But there is a problem with this version; perhaps, in trying to tell the whole story in two hours, it's told too much and not enough both at once. The second and third versions of "Pride and Prejudice", on BBC in 1980 and A&E; in 1995, were serialized over four to five hours and told the story pretty much as Austen wrote it, especially the BBC version, my personal favorite. Joe Wright's film tries to tell the whole story also but there's too much story for two hours to do it justice. As a result, the film feels compressed in spots. It feels truncated. We don't see nearly enough of Elizabeth's Aunt and Uncle Gardiner, two characters who are central to the book; Bingley's married sister and her husband are left out altogether, and the whole movie has a kind of rushed quality. You won't notice it if you haven't read the book and/or seen the BBC or A&E; movies, but you'll notice it a lot if you have.Joe Wright also took some positively unsettling liberties with the Bennets. In Austen's book they are an upper-middle-class family who are the "principal inhabitants" of the neighborhood. In Wright's film, they look like they've gone to seed. The cows are mooing in the back yard, the pigs are ambling into the premises through the back door, a harried-looking Mrs. Bennet and her daughters are toiling in the kitchen (although in the book Mrs. Bennet indignantly tells the Reverend Mr. Collins that her daughters have nothing to do in the kitchen as the family is perfectly well able to afford a good cook), and a bleary-eyed Mr. Bennet sits in his library looking unwashed, uncombed and unkempt. The whole establishment looks drab and dingy, in need of a good paint job. In the earlier movies Longbourn looks like a fairly prosperous estate; this movie conjures up images of Tobacco Road.Keira Knightley is a delight to watch as Elizabeth Bennet; she's smart, sassy and easy on the eyes. She's as good as Elizabeth Garvie was in the role in the BBC version and she's an improvement over Jennifer Ehle. Belinda Blethlyn is funny and ditzy as Mrs. Bennet, an insufferable airhead whose one goal in life is to marry off her brood. Dame Judi Dench is suitably Gorgon-like as Lady Catherine DeBourgh; it's a shame we don't see enough of her in the film either.The big problem for this reviewer was Matthew McFayden's interpretation of Darcy. For a lot of people who saw the other films, the gold standard for Darcy was Colin Firth, although not for this reviewer; I thought Firth was miscast as Darcy (ducking brickbats from Firth groupies as I type this). Firth was trying to be a very 90's Darcy, sensitive and vulnerable; but his Darcy wasn't Austen's Darcy by a long shot. McFayden plays Darcy as if he were racked with inner torment over his wealth and status; he comes off almost as insecure. If there is one thing Austen's Darcy isn't, it's insecure; he's almost too full of himself to be real until Elizabeth knocks him down a few pegs. McFayden was trying to bring out Darcy's soft side -- he has one, underneath all that starched armor -- but in doing so he underplays Darcy's haughty exterior to the point that we wonder what Elizabeth found so revolting about him in the first place. Something doesn't add up.Taken as a whole, the movie delivers in the time it has to do it in. There is no way to faithfully put "Pride and Prejudice" on film in only two hours. But the essence of the story is there. It's lovely to watch and nice to listen to. Wright does a creditable job of bring Austen's best-loved book to the screen. I just wish he'd made it into a longer film.Judy Lind

reviewText: This is a review of the Blu ray release only not the film as such which has been covered elsewhere. The main problem is with the sound track. As has been pointed out by another reviewer everyone speaks so fast it is hard to catch what is being said. The subtitles which would normally help are an absolute disaster: The speaker location system is used which results in the subtitles frequently running to three lines but they also hop about - left, centre or right, even top and bottom - depending where the speaker appears on the screen. To make it more difficult, like the speech, they are displayed only fleetingly and it is too often impossible to read them before they are gone. A further issue is the balance: speech is generally overpowered by the music and one is constantly fiddling with the volume control.The picture quality is acceptable but I did not find it as sharp or as well color balanced as I had hoped. The BBC Blu ray is of course a different version of the story but it is technically very good, especially considering its age and original format, and vastly superior to this most disappointing transfer.
summary: The Blu ray is an irritating disappointment
