reviewText: Certainly this is one of the two most intriguing versions of this movie I have seen.If Jane Austen herself were alive today, I suspect whe would love this version.In the Laurence Olivier version, I thought his Darcy came across as somewhat affected and foppish.  I have not seen the Colin Firth version yet, however I did see his depiction of Darcy in the modern Bridget Jones Diary movies, and he did seem off in his attitude towards Renee Zelwegger's character.  He seemed too snooty, and as if he genuinely disliked her at times for no reason.My other favorite version is the Bollywood version, Bride and Prejudice, a must see totally enjoyable version with the beautiful Aishwarya Rai, and replete with Bollywood conventions including musical numbers.The Keira Knightley version I have seen several times, and even made copious notes about it, because whether you know it or not, many love stories follow the template of this story, and it has become an enduring classic for good reason.The dialogue is simply beautiful, the scenes excellently executed, the lead actor Matthew MacFadyen interplays brilliantly with Keira, offering excellently nuanced scenes.  Finally, a lead actor who truly does justice to the role.Like many love stories it starts out on the wrong foot, when Darcy disses her to a friend.  He does not know she has overheard.  She responds with some later banter putting him in his place, and like the flick of a switch he becomes intrigued with her. Yet as you get deeper into the story, misunderstandings arise, new perceptions, a whole welter of emotions.I especially loved the scene where he proposes the first time and totally screws it up. She is hurt and angry, and turns on him, and yet beneath that anger stirs a passion.  Beautifully done.Mr. Darcy: ...Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your circumstances?Elizabeth Bennet: And those are the words of a gentleman. From the first moment I met you, your arrogance and conceit, your selfish disdain for the feelings of others made me realize that you were the last man in the world I could ever be prevailed upon to marry. [they look at each other for a long time as though about to kiss]I also enjoyed the performance of Collins played by Tom Hollander, the repressed smutty preacher whose small estate adjoins her ladyship's rather large abutment. Love it, the language that is, not the..I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.
summary: It starts with a diss, and ends with a kiss

reviewText: Joe Wright was cast to direct the latest version of "Pride and Prejudice". Hmmmm. Joe Wright, directed a couple of forgettable movies, followed by 3 mini-series (the little knowns "Nature Boy" from 2000, "Bodily Harm" from 2002 and a lavish, and well-made version of the life of Charles 2,"Charles II: The Power and the Passion, 2003) for A&E;/BBC. What made the powers behind the newest attempt to film Austen for the big screen choose Joe Wright?Well, Joe got it, right, that is, in many ways. He's made a more contemporary telling of this, my favorite of Austen's tales, and he's done it well. In a run time of less than 2.5 hours, his version will be more easier to digest than the two mini-series of this same work (the stand alone BBC version from 1980 with Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul and the 1993 A&E;/BBC version that most people know the best; with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth). But, as well done as it is, you'll find it wanting vs. either of these fine mini-series, and the film also pales in comparison to the Emma Thompson/Ang Lee run at "Sense and Sensibility" in 1995.If you are an Austen fan, the amount of characterization that has to be cut from the story to fit it in to a 2.5 hour run time, will simply horrify you. In particular, both Mr. Wickam and Mr. Collins, potential suitors for the Bennett bevy, are given very small amounts of screen time. Catherine de Bourg, the patroness whose money flows all over a variety of characters in the film (Darcy, for one, is her nephew) was played by Judi Dench with a particularly elegant stiff upper lip, but was given little to do.Director Wright has given us marvelous cinematography and beautiful settings (notably Darcy's estate at Pemberley). He has the same passion I do for Austen's work, and tried to keep the themes."Pride and Prejudice" is a love story between a young woman in a family stretched with 5 daughters and literally no dowries in 19th century England. In the book, the Bennetts are an upper middle class lot; in this film, in which Wright instilled a sense of real "living on the farm", they are shabby versions of Austen's intent.Mr. Bennett (Donald Sutherland) is a country gentleman beloved by his daughters and befuddled by the antics of his wife. Said wife's main passion in life is making sure the girls are all married off so that they are not penniless when the parents die. Mrs. Bennett (Brenda Blethyn in a comedic performance that is perhaps a little over the top) makes no pretense of her intentions, and they are embraced with different degrees of exhuberance by her daughters. Elizabeth (Keira Knightley) and Jane (Rosamund Pike), the eldest, are a bit embarrassed by their mother's antics and manage to try and ignore her histrionics while building their anxieties over marriage.It is Jane, the loveliest, whose heart is broken by Mr. Bingley from London, and Elizabeth who runs afoul of his dour friend, Mr. Darcy.Before the film is finished, the viewer is as surprised as Elizabeth to learn that Mr. Darcy has fallen in love with her, and having been rejected, Darcy sets out to change Elizabeth's first impression and win her heart by helping her family and by showing how much he cares for his own young sister.Keira Knightley was a good choice for Jane, although the lesser known actresses in both the British mini-series were better in the role than she was. Knightley looks the part as Austen described it, and has a quicksilver screen persona that fits Elizabeth well. If there is not the romance, the chemistry that should have grown on screen between Elizabeth and Darcy, it is not for wont of Knightley's efforts to portray it.Instead, in portraying the difficult Darcy, who, after all, is supposed to be wooden, actor Matthew Macfayden (with an impressive list of British television credentials including the MI5 drama, Spooks) was entirely too successful. He is wooden to a painful degree, and has difficulty turning his cold arrogance into foolishness when he first becomes infatuated with Elizabeth. And he's equally not credible as a "do gooder". The growth of that Austen staple, the love between two people who society has not meant to be together, the growing awareness, the yearning, well, it is missing from this film. It was not missing in the mini-series. Generally speaking, it usually means the director does not know how to capture the essence of love and longing on film, does not know how to invoke it from his characters and bleed it through to the audience. Despite this, I must say, that I did not walk away wishing to see Matthew Macfayden on the big screen again.And thus, we get an interesting movie, with some fine touches, some believable characters, a solid script and beautiful filming, music and costumes. But contrary to the print ads and the trailers, this is not the film of the year, just a pleasing version of an Austen tale that has been done better in the past.Definitely worth a trip to the theater!
summary: Not the movie of the year....

reviewText: I found this version of my favorite novel to be very touching and romantic, though lacking much of the gently ironic tone that makes Jane Austen unique.  Mrs. Bennet, for example, was beautifully played by Brenda Blethyn, but she was rather more sweetly dithering than the constantly plotting, embarassingly outspoken character in the book. I did like the Bennet sisters' portrayals, though, and I found Darcy quite believable in his reserve and his almost painful discomfort in the rambunctious social milieu of Meryton.  The cinematography is superb, however, and the sets and costumes are flawless.  All told, the film fulfills the director's vision and gives the viewer a wonderfully intimate look at life in early nineteenth-century England.
summary: Lovely film, less Austen than Merchant/Ivory

reviewText: I am a fan of the book and the BBC version of this movie, yet I found this Hollywood version to be quite entertaining.  I thought that Matthew Macfadyen did an excellent job portraying Mr. Darcy.  I wish I could say the same for Keira Knightley but I just didn't buy it. The relationship between Rosamund Pike (Jane) and Lizzie was just not convincingly close as depicted in the book and although this has nothing to do with the movie, . .  Keira always does this weird thing with her lips (trying to make them look fuller while pouting) that really bugs me. I like the way the set design, costumes, and the lack of to much makeup made the movie a little more "authentic", but what I truly loved was the music.  I felt like the music really transported me into that time. I felt like this movie tried desperately to make this movie authentic (much like the 1995 production of Persuasion) but due to time restraints failed to develop the depth of the characters of the book.  The result a slightly enjoyable, entertaining piece of Hollywood film that is entertaining to watch.

reviewText: Sorry to say but was disappointed in the film. It was very very rushed, as I suppose you can understand a movie length version of Pride & Prejudice would be and I felt that a lot of the major scenes were glossed over just to get through the story.As the movie is so rushed, unfortunately you don't get to really know about and feel for each of the characters much at all.Not only that, this movie is Boring. 1/3 of the way through I started yawning and couldn't wait for the movie to be over. When they finally met in the field at the end, couldn't care less if they got together or not. As I have read the book and watch the BBC version, I knew how many scenes had to go, before I could finally leave the cinema. Mr Darcy whoever he is in this movie, definitely can't act. He looks also too young to play Mr Darcy. Every word that comes out of his mouth is rushed like he needs to get through the script or something. Where is the build up? At first, he seems confused with everything. He is just bizarre! It all looks put on.Was trying not to compare to the Colin Firth version but if you love that version, you will most likely be disappointed anyway.The costumes are absolutely shocking. Where are the corsets? I know Elizabeth is poor, but I think she still knows how to dress as some sort of ladylike fashion, and hasn't been brought up in a squaller. Her dresses indicates she might be the poorest peasant in all of England walking around in nothing more than brown rags. Is that what Jane Austen had in mind?I didn't agree with a couple of scenes in the movie in the fact, that I don't think it would be considered proper in that society for men to do such things, i.e for Darcy to walk in (without knocking on the front door - I might add) - in the middle of the night to see Elizabeth and give her a letter??? If he was a gentleman, very unlikely. Secondly, Mr Bingley just walking into Jane's room while she is sick to see if she is okay? Doesn't he have any sense of propriety? Mr Bingley who has wealth and hopefully sense should know better.There is some things that are said that sound too modern for the period this movie is set in, and not at all like Jane Austen. Bingley's character is shockingly done, to me he behaves like a simpleton, not a character to like and respect. Mr Bingley to me was always suppose to be likeable. To me, he is on the same lineage that we would view Mr Collins. What about that laugh of his!!! Wickham hardly has a presence so you don't get to feel at all for the lead up to Lydia taking off with him and Mr & Mrs Hurst and a couple of other characters have no presence at all. Everything feels in sequence but not a smooth flow - feels very jumpy.Didn't see or feel the chemistry between Lizzie and Darcy.Okay I am a fan of the other but was willing to give this a go and knew there would be differences. I guess my biggest disappointment is the portrayal of Darcy and Bingley. Bingley and Jane seemed like a bizarre couple to be getting attached. I didn't think the way they portrayed Bingley would be the type of person that the Jane they portrayed would go for. Again - chemistry?? Questionable.The ending - where is it?? What a bizarre way to end it.

reviewText: Okay, I admit to being a Pride and Prejudice snob.  I've read the book 14 times in the last three and a half decades.  When I've found the right superlatives, I'll write a review!  And yes, I am probably prejudiced against anything that is not the 6 hour A&E; mini-series (with Firth--I have to say it too!).  But I tried to like this movie.  I even enjoy the books that have been similar to Austen's (like Pride, Prejudice and Jasmine Field).But there were just too many things that I didn't like.  For example, there was very little character development.  Keira Knightley does a well enough job as Elizabeth Bennet but Matthew Macfadyen (whom I loved in MI-5) did nothing but sneer in this film.  I don't know how anyone could form an attachment to someone who did not have any redeeming qualities.  I know that they cast the Americans for the American audience but I also didn't like the casting of Sutherland.  His 5-day stubble annoyed me, as did his American accent during part of the film.  The worst character portrayal though was Bingley.  He was definitely not a buffoon in the book....  In the movie, he acted like a simpleton!I do give kudos to the makers of this movie; trying to recreate the greatest novel ever written (my opinion) is certainly an ambitious undertaking.  The scenery was lovely and the people unfamiliar with the story will probably love this movie.
summary: Because of my Pride and Prejudices!

reviewText: Maybe every generation needs to re-invent Jane Austen for themselves. This  film interpretation of "Pride and Prejudice" stresses the youthfulness of the characters. Elizabeth and Darcy look younger here than they were in the most recent dramatization that featured Colin Firth. I loved the rough and tumble look of the Bennett's home. It's a non-prissy look at life in the early 19th century. The film's expansive outdoor scenes were like a series of Bruegel paintings--the characters' romances became part of larger ongoing drama of rural life. McFayden's Darcy is refreshingly nerdy. He's a nice change from the usual drop-dead handsome Darcys (like Laurence Olivier and Firth). Knightly is equally refreshing as a tomboyish Elizabeth.This is the story of two intelligent young people cursed with embarrassing relatives. Elizabeth has an emotionally disengaged father, a vulgar mother who continuously puts her foot in her mouth and three out-of-control sisters. Darcy's aunt, Lady Catherine, is an ill-behaved snob whose rude behavior is worse than the whole Bennett family put together.This film really conveys the precariousness of the Bennett's financial and social situation more than other dramatizations. We can see why Mrs. Bennett's desperation to get her daughters married off isn't so crazy after all. As in all of Austen, there's a dark undertone to the story--the vulnerability of women who have no money or powerful social connections. Lydia's elopement with Wickham shows how swiftly a young woman can fall from respectability and the double-standard that lets the men involved go scot-free. Elizabeth's assertiveness and integrity stand out all the more given the limited choices she has in her life.

reviewerName: Mall of America Gift Card Customer
reviewText: I've heard it said that it's just not possible to condense Pride and Prejudice into a 2 hour format. This absolutely proves that wrong. It takes the one thing that's essential to Pride and Prejudice, the story of Elizabeth and Darcy, and sticks to that. Certain creative liberties are taken, deviating from some of the expansive scenes in the novel, but in doing so the spirit of the novel is preserved. What takes chapters of text can be condensed into a few minutes of screen time. I wouldn't suggest watching this if you're trying to dodge reading the book for English class, but as a portrait of the spirit of the book it's a first-rate piece.
summary: Simply amazing, the best rendition yet

reviewText: If you are looking for Jane Austen's beautiful book translated faithfully to film, this is not the movie for you. But this adaptation `Pride & Prejudice' is wonderfully done. This movie has great casting, good writing and good direction. I did enjoy watching this shorten version of the film even though some subplots do not even exits in this movie. It would be impossible to place all that Jane Austen has going on in her novel into two-hour movie.One thing the director did do is film everything from the view of Elizabeth Bennet, played by Keira Knightly. And the dance hall scenes and social etiquette were accurate for the time period chosen, 1797. You could see what a middle-upper class family had to go through if they had daughters. I also thought that Matthew Macfadyen played a captivating Mr. Darcy and Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet, though looking soft spoken and soft on Elizabeth, and it showed he did marry for love.The scenery and music are highlights of the movie. This is a movie many will see more then once. Though Elizabeth Bennet in this movie seems to have more modern sensibilities then the book gives her, Keira knightly still does well. Especially considering every woman that has ever read this books has her own view on the character. But the chemistry you feel from the screen form Elizabeth and Darcy jumps out at you, there string love suppressed by misunderstandings and preconceived notions.... if I might be so bold as to say, their Pride & Prejudice.This book is a masterpiece and sets the standard for all romantic novels, so no movie could ever stand up to its standard. But for a two-hour entertaining movie, it was very good.

reviewText: The sceneries were beautiful, breathtaking, but the romance was a marathon. One day they didn't like each other well, the next they were in love without all the shenaningas. But the fact that the hero and heroin were so young, in their teens, made this love in a hurry seems believable. It is a good version but the masterpiece in my opinion is still the BBC one with Colin Firth. In that old version Darcy and Lizzie had their slow cooking romance and their chemistry was so palpable that really made me believe them to be in love for real off-screen, the way Collin Firth's eyes shone whenever he was looking at Lizzie, it was so real (especially when she was helping Georgiana at the piano) and the sweet face of Lizzie when staring him back. That scene is unforgettable. Oh my, if I could exchange places with Lizzie, be her...The actors in this version made the most in 2 hours and the wonderful settings made this movie a 2nd best, in my opinion. I love it, though I still prefer the emotional and romantic details of the BBC version.In this version they kept only the basics, even mr. Wickham and Miss Bingley didn't have enough time to show all their conniving dark sides in total splendor.

reviewText: Plenty of reviews here already address the Movie vs BBC Mini-Series angle (personally, I love both), so I'll just comment on the Blu-Ray itself.As a happy owner of the DVD, I wanted the Blu-Ray for the boost in image, and this release does not disappoint. The picture looks absolutely gorgeous: crisp and clear, with subtle yet rich colors. Pause at any point during the movie and you have a beautiful still on your screen. I don't currently have a set-up that takes advantage of the 5.1 audio mix, but it sounds just fine coming out of my tv speakers.Alas, to get to the movie, one must first navigate the horrendous BD Live system. Not content to stack trailer upon trailer onto a disc, the movie studios now force download a "fresh" trailer every time the movie plays. Skipping it is not an option. The disc allows no interaction until the trailer is downloaded, and even then, exiting the trailer is a nightmare: FF, SCAN, and NEXT are all disabled. If you don't give up easily you can eventually kill it (continuous pressing of "POP UP MENU" is one way), but that's two minutes of your life gone EVERY TIME you start the disc.Once you make it to the menu, prepare to be horrified. Thanks to BD Live there is a movie ticker along the upper right of the screen. Mercifully, this steady stream of marketing can be turned off, but the studios' desire to turn a simple menu into a perpetual commercial is enough to make me abandon Blu-Ray for DVD. The horror doesn't end there. Despite the Jane Austen pedigree, the menu designer opted instead to go with a slick, futuristic interface that looks better suited toFast & Furious, not Ms. Bennet & Mr. Darcy. The DVD release - actually, even the movie website from 2005 - did a better job with the menu.There's a lot to be annoyed at, but at the end of the day, the Blu-Ray treatment of the movie itself is absolutely marvelous, so if you're a fan and you find it on sale, it's worth picking up. Just go pop some popcorn or pour a drink while BD Live force-feeds commercials.
summary: BD Live starts this off on the wrong foot

reviewText: Okay, putting aside the gross inaccuracies in historical detail, my main problem with this movie is the complete lack of satire and wit that Austen is famous for. Hollywood made this a chick flick for the masses rather than a deep and hilarious jab at the ridiculous happenings in a society bound by precise codes of conduct. In addition, Austen, in Pride and Prejudice, was making gentle fun of the unbelievable amount of time people spent on making matches, thinking of marriage, and what people look for in a marriage partner. All of that is lost in this silly version.I don't think any of the cast is true to form--no one captures their character and so we are left with yet another flat romance that is meant to coo at you rather than shake you up with its pointed statement. In many respects, I think Hollywood believes audiences are  mindless and unable to tell the difference between a good adaptation of a classic and a travesty.If I had to make an analogy of pride and Prejudice I would say thisJane Austen's original novel = Lobster with butterBBC version = A prime cut steak, perfectly grilled and seasonedThis trite production = Spam in a can

reviewText: *** REVIEW FOR THE 2010 BLU RAY VERSION ***In order to have this movie in High Definition, I've had the HD-DVD format of it for a few years now - but it's an America issue and has the controversially modern US ending. Now at last it arrives on BLU RAY in the USA (January 2010) and in the UK (May 2010) and it's just as gorgeous a transfer. It uses exactly the same elements that the HD-DVD did - even the same menus - and the extras from the DVD are all intact also (with the US ending tagged on as an Alternate).The improvement in picture quality is immense over the rather blurred DVD experience. As it opens with a misty dawn and the twitter of birds, we see the young and feisty Elizabeth Bennet (played with a magical touch and staggering assurance by Kiera Knightly) walking with a book. But it's not until she crosses the courtyard of her home that the real quality kicks in - and it's a wow. The picture takes you aback - it wasn't this good in the cinema I can tell you...It isn't perfect throughout by any means though. Because they were going for authenticity, a lot of the early evening and dark night sequences are shot in candlelit rooms (as they would have lived), so you get fuzziness in the definition... But once you get out into the countryside or inside one of the great halls of stately homes - where proper lighting prevailed - the picture quality is beautiful. There is one famous dream sequence where only Kiera's closed eyes fill the screen - she is dreaming of standing on the cliff edge - the clarity is gobsmacking. You also notice the weave of the clothing, the dirt on the hemlines, the ever so slightly unkempt hair - the attention to detail is great.Directed by Joe Wright and released in late 2005, the film version was living in the shadow of the legendary 6-part BBC production from 1995 - so the movie had a lot on its shoulders and admirably rose to the task. Another trump card was Dario Marianelli's lush piano score (Oscar nominated) swirling around the scenes like a graceful swan.In the cinema, it was a delight to look and experience - but sitting at home and watching it in real definition is a far more rewarding and illuminating experience. The acting chops on display is right across the board and apart from a slightly jarring ending, it had the hallmarks of a shoot that was fun and supremely confident in its delivery. I know others will cite the BBC production as definitive - but I think there's more than enough room on my shelf for both.Matthew MacFadyen, Brenda Blethyn, Rosamund Pike, Carey Mulligan, Judy Dench, Tom Hollander - they were a cleverly chosen cast - and Rupert Friend won the heart of the lovely Kiera (which might explain the ethereal beauty of her performance). But it's the stunning adaptation of Jane Austen's novel by DEBORAH MOGGACH that is the real hero of the day. There is a sequence when Elizabeth and Darcy finally face off against each other in the rain - the dialogue is to die for - and should have been Oscar rewarded. As a dabbler in screenplays myself, I can't stress enough just how good the work here is - dazzling stuff.It's under a tenner, the DVD extras are all intact, the picture quality is much improved and in some cases unbelievably so - and its eminently re-watchable.To sum up - if you're a fan of the film, Jane Austen or both - then you must own "Pride & Prejudice" on this format. A Blu Ray gem and highly recommended.
summary: "...So This Is Your Opinion Of Me..."

reviewText: This is a wonderful adaptation of the Jane Austen classic.  It really does a nice job of not going too far over two hours, because with certain movies that don't move as quickly as others, it is very difficult to sit through them when they are too long.  The acting is very wonderful in this, but I am disappointed that the Academy did not consider Donald Sutherland for the supporting actor category instead of maybe Paul Giamatti.  I like Paul Giamatti, but I have a feeling that the Academy wanted to make up for not nominating him for his better role last year in Sideways.  Sutherland does not have many fiery scenes, but his mild manners and his modesty in this film just made me very excited to watch him in this role.  The rest of the acting is pretty good for this remake.  Kiera Knightley does not extremely impress me in this, at least as much as in Domino, but her acting suffices for this.  I shouldn't expect to see her accepting the Academy Award for Best Actress, but we should see her cheer Reese Witherspoon on.  The story is fantastic, and if you enjoy Jane Austen, then you will no doubt love this remake of one of the most popular novels in English Literature.  Very well done. (4 1/2 stars)

reviewText: After watching this movie, I'll have to admit that it was pretty good: the acting was done well, the camera quality and shooting were quite good, the character's dress and the sets really matched into there respective time period nicely. These qualities would have made it an excellent movie if it weren't for a few problems. I know that it may seem a little nick-picky, but I think that these are real problems that [most of them] could have been dealt with.The first problem is the actors. I think that the acting itself was done perfectly, great enough to make any director proud; but the main problems are with the actors themselves. Some of them look a little too "modern": for example, I though that Keira Knightley looked a little too modern-aged for that time. She has a slight hint of a model look that fits perfectly into movies about our day an age. But that really doesn't work in a movie set in the late 18th century. Sure, Keira played her character well, but she didn't really have the look for that time period. Some of the other actors look a little "goofy", like Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland), Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods), Lydia Bennet (Jena Malone), and Colonel Fitzwilliam (Cornelius Booth),  kind of look out-of-place in the movie setting. In the A&A; production, they had gotten actors that fit the roles and looks of the characters. And here, they get allot of them right, but some of them really aren't looking too good.Another problem is that sometimes, especially when the characters are in the streets of a town of inside a busy room, the dialogue and the background sound of the surrounding activity seem to clash a little bit. Sometimes, when the characters are having a quitter discussion in a more active place, the sounds of the hustle and bustle around them are allot louder than the characters, making it hard to hear them at several points. There will be several times were you will have to keep on adjusting your TV's volume so that you can hear the dialogue clearly. I think that this is a problem that could easily have been fixed before release via a small sound adjustment.And perhaps the biggest problem with the film is this: it's too short. I know that it is two hours long, but I'm not talking about the running length itself. Allow me to explain:Pride and Prejudice is a long book: even with the A&E; production, which was six hours long, several scenes from the book had to be cut out. But they still had enough time to have several smaller events that didn't have much to do with the main plot but didn't take away from the story at all: in fact, I think that those smaller scenes really benefited the whole production immensely. It was easier to connect and care for the characters if you saw more involved with there personal lives that just what you see in the main plot. I know that the makers of this film didn't have six hours to include that many side-scenes from the book, but it still feels a little "tight": pretty much just the main plot from the original story is included here, and even on that they really had to trim it. It just sort of feels in this movie like were zipping from one event to another: one moment the Netherfield Ball is just ending, then before you know it Mr. Collins comes in. There really isn't much time to contemplate on any one event: just as soon as one important even happens, another important one pops up. For example: I didn't think that they gave enough time to the whole Lydia running off with Wickham. That is a very important event in the story. But it seems like, almost as soon as they run off, they're found and brought back. There's no time to realize the seriousness of the situation if it all happens in ten minutes. There are other stuff like this in the movie that didn't get enough time: there wasn't enough time given to the character development of Mr. Darcy's younger sister, Elizabeth's visit to her Aunt and Uncle was too short, and perhaps the biggest hurtle of them all, several memorable characters, like Mrs. Hurst and Sir William Lucas  have been ultimately cut from the film for the sake of time. I know that you can't really blame the makers for these things: they didn't have six-hours to make a theatrical movie like A&E; did. But this still raises a question: does Pride and Prejudice really work out as a two-hour movie? This is still a really good film, I'll have to say; but this problem really prevents it from becoming a brilliant, plain-out really great film. But I know that this is a problem that couldn't really been helped, so I can't really hold it againsed the movie that much.Despite these problems, this still a good film that is really worth watching: even though it may have a few "casting errors" and some sound problems, and that it may feel a little rushed, but it's still a great film that deserves attention. It may not benefit your film collection as much as the A&E; production will, but it's still a film that is sure to be enjoyed.
summary: Good movie, but it could have been better

reviewText: Adaptations of this masterpiece have always seemed to me to idealize the period, as if everyone is always perfectly coiffed and nothing is ever out of place or even dusty. This film has filled in the story's background with great depth and color, taking us into a real English country dance, with all of its raucous energy. We see into people's homes with their daily activities, tasks, and yes, even the messes. The dialog feels like conversations that are face to face, not speeches posed across a giant stage. The overall result is a greater feeling of intimacy between you and the movie, almost as if it's not seen on screen but through a window... or even a mirror. I must have seen a dozen or more adaptations of this immortal story, but this time I felt like I was there, and a part of it all.As for the acting, I thought Matthew Macfadyen was the best Darcy I have ever seen. All of the actors were excellent, but I want to make special mention of Talulah Riley's performance as the bookish sister, Mary.  Most adaptations seem to disregard or even ridicule Mary for her social cluelessness. But this movie is brave enough to let us see her in greater depth and compassion, as a girl whose cluelessness is really just an extreme awkwardness, and therefore something we can all relate to. We even see her beauty and vulnerability as I have never seen on screen. In a master stroke of screenwriting, we see her suffer great pain and shame after her embarrassing attempt to be socially adept by performing at the pianoforte, albeit badly, to be publicly humiliated by her mother's loud declaration that "You have delighted us long enough" and her crumbling defeat from it. It is then that we see Mr. Bennet in a rare moment of warmth, comforting his disconsolate little girl, not aloof and sarcastic as usual, but holding her in his arms.  In this way, too, it breathed more life into the story in all of its fullness.That, for me, made this movie feel like the story was finally a part of myself, not just a tale about others.
summary: Not just the story but the age

reviewerName: M. B. Alcat "Curiosity killed the cat, but sa...
reviewText: I read "Pride and prejudice" (1813) more than 15 years ago, and I loved it immediately. I didn't know who Jane Austen was, but I risked disappointment and tried a "new" author. Truth to be told, I found a book that became one of my favourites, due to the fact that it is well-written, but also thoroughly entertaining.I must say that I was a little afraid to watch this movie, due to the undeniable fact that literary adaptations can sometimes go sour. Thankfully, that isn't the case in this occasion, because the director, Joe Wright, somehow managed to capture the essence of the book. I suppose the excellent cast must have helped him in that endeavour. All the actors are remarkably good, but some are specially noteworthy. I think I should at least mention Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet, Matthew Macfadyen as the handsome Mr. Darcy, and Brenda Blethyn as the kind of mother you are thankful not to have :)The plot is not overly complicated, and it tackles wonderfully themes such as relationships, love, class distinctions, and of course pride and prejudice, all from the point of view of what happened in 18th century England. The story begins in the small town where the Bennets live. Mrs. Bennet (Brenda Blethyn) has five daughters, and her mission in life is marrying them off. Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland) is an intellectual, who often escapes to his library in search of silence and to avoid Mrs. Bennet's nonsense. The two more important daughters, from the point of view of the story, are probably the eldest, the beautiful Jane (Rosamund Pike) and the second, Elizabeth (Keira Knightley) who is very witty but perhaps too proud.The dynamics of the town are changed when a single man of large fortune, Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods), arrives to Netherfield Park, an estate not far from town. Mr. Bingley comes with a friend, Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen), and the Bennets meet both at a ball. While Mr. Bingley immediately caughts Jane's eye, and is considered nice by Elizabeth, Mr. Darcy has not such luck. By sheer chance, Elizabeth overhears him making a negative comment on her, something that hurts her pride and spurs her to consider him a hateful man. But will that change? And if so, how?Discovering that is likely to be fun for the spectator, unless he is a perfectionist looking for inconsistencies between the film and the book. There are quite a few, it is true, but I firmly believe that is not important if the essence of what makes "Pride and Prejudice" a classic is present in the movie. And in my opinion, it is... Highly recommended :)Belen AlcatPS: Of course, if you want to enjoy this film even more, read the book too. Even though the director and the cast successfully captured the essence of "Pride and Prejudice", there is still a lot you will be missing if you don`t do that.
summary: Excellent, but please read the book too...

reviewText: I've never read anything by Jane Austen, and I suspect I never will. Thus I have no idea whether Joe Wright's version of Pride and Prejudice is an accurate translation of the novel to film. But I do know that it's one of the best films my wife and I have watched together in a long time. The film was like a breath of fresh air to me; I found something almost shocking about the culture of love and marriage the film depicts. As I watched the movie, I couldn't refrain from contrasting the drama of Victorian courtship with the oversexed, hypersensual culture of "courtship" (so-called) that characterizes today's young people.As for the merits of the film itself, Wright does a fantastic job of whittling down Austen's apparently complicated plot into a coherent narrative. The cinematography is striking as well. When the movie opened up with a slow, Malick-esque reveal of a sunrise over a stand of trees, I immediately knew there was something special going on. There is one shot at a ball where the camera goes from room to room, picking up conversations and characters as they move about, backtracking and picking them up again as they socialize and dramatize. I didn't count, but I think the shot was at least six to eight minutes long. This is a very difficult shot to accomplish, as multiple actors have to hit their lines and their positions in a very crowded area right on time, and if someone flubs their part, that's an eight-minute take that just went down the drain. This kind of shot is the mark of a patient and creative filmmaker.The largely British cast is also phenomenal. I usually consider Keira Knightley to be the queen of overacting, but here her personality is perfect for Lizzie Bennett. I've never heard of the actor playing Mr. Darcy, but I instantly knew I wanted to see him in other films. He has a weighty screen presence about him that's a joy to watch. My wife immediately declared Pride and Prejudice to be one of her favorite movies of all time, and as for love stories, I'd have to agree. It's not only good entertainment, it showcases a picture of love and romance that all young people would benefit from seeing, especially girls. We'll be showing it to our daughter when she enters the dating world as a counterbalance to the false messages about love and romance the world gives her.

reviewText: I must admit I was stunned to read the various scathing reviews of this movie, since I absolutely do not agree with them.  I thoroughly enjoyed the film and strongly feel it stood up quite well to the much-lauded 1995 BBC mini-series, even though it seems patently unfair to use another film version (which contained its own fair share of casting mistakes and flaws) as the benchmark to judge another.First, Keira Knightley gives a remarkably convincing performance (reflected by the fact that she received well-deserved Oscar and Golden Globe nominations for this role) as the "not yet 21 [years old]" Elizabeth Bennet.  Knightley was not only physically suited to play the part of Elizabeth, but she absolutely managed to capture some the spirit/petulance that is as much a part of the personality of the Austen heroine as the sharp intelligence and wit that traditionally characterizes Lizzie.  Knightley particularly shines in the well-directed rainy scene in which she lambastes Mr. Darcy, following his reluctant marriage proposal to her; Knightley is articulate and passionate in the scene and clearly demonstrates she is not only a photogenic presence on-screen, but has the chops for acting, as well.I was initially ambivalent about Matthew Macfayden's portrayal of Mr. Darcy, but after watching the movie a second time, I found Macfayden's interpretation of the character to be fresh and compelling. Macfayden's distant, slightly awkward Darcy works well opposite Knightley's fiery Lizzie.  The mutual attraction between the two characters is palpable, but clearly hampered by their strong personalities and the proper decorum dictated by the period.I particularly enjoyed the glimpse into early 19th Century life in rural England that this movie provided.  In other film interpretations of Austen's classic novel, the Bennets lived on a lavish (and hence somewhat unlikely), extremely formal and upscale style, which quite frankly, did not seem consistent with the family's alleged circumstances and situation.  In this particular film version, all of the Bennet girls looked lovely (for instance) when turned out in style (with curled hair and fresh frocks) to attend the ball at Netherfield; however, when the viewer is permitted a peek into everyday life in the Bennet household, the house itself is not only rather topsy-turvy, the Bennet sisters themselves are slightly disheveled--their clothes are suited for doing light housework and their hairstyles are mussed and flyaway as would be suited to the quiet and unpretentious lives they lead in the country.The supporting cast is excellent; standouts would include: Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennet; Dame Judi Dench as the formidable Lady Catherine de Bourg; and Rosamund Pike who plays, as well as looks the part of Jane Bennet.  This movie version of the much-loved Austen classic stands well on it own merits and does not disappoint; it is beautifully filmed on location in various parts of England and is definitely well worth seeing.

reviewText: I have not read the book.I have not seen any of the previous versions, including the infamous Colin Firth version.I bought this because it was on my wishlist, and we had (and still do have) a special promotion at work, which meant we were uncutting the price of nearly every other shop. So why the hell not?Firstly I was pleasantly surprised. After my disastrous attempts at watching some 'period' movies recently (Emma, Vanity Fair), I was preparing myself not to like this. A girl I work with, who also watched and detested Vanity Fair, also didn't enjoy this. But then I was being told by every customer buying it that they liked it.It took me a while, but I did eventually get around to watching it, although was disappointed to discover there was no trailer on the DVD. Plenty of other extras however.For some reason, Keira Knightley got an Oscar nomination for this (but lost out to Reese Witherspoon), which, upon watching the film, I didn't get, considering she mumbles most of her lines. I had to actually have the subtitles switched on to understand not only her, but the fancy olde English that was used. I had the sound turned right up, but still couldn't make much sense of it.But overall, the film was very good, even Keira! Jenna Malone doesn't get much of a look in, her 'big' part being that she elopes. (Not the done thing in those days.) It's good to see Keira actually smiling for a change, she rarely does. There's plenty of great scenery to detract your attention from the not-so-cute guys appearing on screen. I was really disappointed with the lack of good looking guys in this film. Why? You have Keira, Rosamund Pike, Jenna Malone & Brenda Blethyn, don't the girls need some eye candy?I can't really comment much on this, as it was average, perhaps reading the book, and seeing the previous versions might enlighten me a bit. It's understandable that for Keira and Matthew MacFadyen, it must have been difficult for them to step into their predecessors shoes, particularly the much-loved shoes of Colin Firth.There's an alternate ending, where Mr Darcy and Lizzie kiss, but it brings nothing to the film, except it was aimed at the US audiences. I feel us shivering in the UK got a better deal. The rest of the extras are alright, but not that outstanding.I've got my eye on the old version of Pride & Prejudice now, with Colin Firth. Should be interesting.

reviewText: When I heard that there was a new version of "Pride and Prejudice" to be made, I was far from pleased. In fact, I was fairly annoyed: A&E;'s version with Colin Firth has been a staple of my DVD collection for an incredibly long time, and I couldn't imagine anyone tampering with perfection. Why mess with genius?Happily, I was wrong in my estimation of the movie. Perhaps it's only appropriate, given the subject matter: the whole story of "Pride and Prejudice" is wrapped up in wrong estimations of character, miscommunications, and partial understandings. The Focus Features version of "Pride and Prejudice" is more of a classic Romance, set earlier in period and filmed against more stunning backdrops than the A&E; version: there were no grand cliffs or windswept heaths in that one, but they work here.The performances are universally excellent: I was appropriately annoyed by Brenda Blethyn's ludicrously inappropriate Mrs. Bennet, and Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourgh is one of the most delicious strokes of casting genius...ever. Donald Sutherland as the bemused patriarch Mr. Bennet holds his own in a largely British cast, and was suitably affectionately distracted in his fatherly role. Simon Woods is amiable and open-faced as Mr. Bingley, and properly deserves Rosamund Pike's delicate Jane.The movie belongs, however, to Matthew McFadyen and Keira Knightley, as it rightly should. The book, however involved its subplots, focused mainly on their sparring, and the film wisely excises a lot of the extraneous matter, tightening its focus and condensing some scenes. Matthew McFadyen is, possibly, an even better Mr. Darcy than Colin Firth (though that pains me to say): his Darcy is sensitive, prone to moodiness and shows of the Stiff Upper Lip, but his eyes don't always manage to keep up the mask, and it is this that makes him amazing. When his eyes do light up, it is stunning, because we have learned not to expect it. He positively smolders with passion, even soaking wet with pleading in his eyes. Or perhaps especially soaking wet. In any case, he smolders. Bosoms will heave, corsets or not, when he's onscreen.Watching Keira Knightley as Lizzie Bennet I was irresistibly reminded of another fiercely intelligent, wide-eyed brunette bookworm: Winona Ryder's Jo March, in 1994's exquisite "Little Women." Knightley conveys the same compelling blend of delicacy and strength as Ryder managed, no easy feat in this world of one-note romance, and one I wasn't sure she could manage, as I've never been a fan. Knightley does a good job, however: her Lizzie is a "fearsome creature," to quote herself, both fiercely loyal and heartily passionate for life, yet always with just a trace of vulnerability; one wonders, at times, if her passionate demeanour isn't as much a disguise as Darcy's cool mask. Perhaps that is what makes their inevitable but much-delayed romance so alluring: here are two people who absolutely should be in love with each other, but manage to think themselves out of it for a very long time.The world of the film is more realistically rural than other adaptations: the ladies' hems are dirty, their dresses are frequently wrinkled, and pigs traipse through the Bennet house as often as visitors do. There are some lovely little touches to the filmmaking as well, such as one scene featuring a distracted Mr. Darcy being circled, predator-like, by Lizzie and the coolly condescending Caroline Bingley; one absolutely feels sorry for the man. I particularly liked the dancing scenes: there is always something going on with someone familiar in the corner of the frame, lending the scenes a pleasant intimacy that suits the material nicely.Ultimately, I love this story so much because its romantic heroes deserve one another, even though they do not always realize it. Theirs is a relationship built not only on passion - although in this version, even more so than the seminal A&E; version, it is decidedly present, particularly in a post-wedding scene at Pemberley featuring (sigh!) a barefoot Mr. Darcy - but on mutual interests and a hearty respect for one another. When Lizzie and Darcy finally marry (as we know they must, long before they do) it is, to steal from Shakespeare (and another Jane Austen movie) a "marriage of true minds." And after all, what could be more romantic than a smart, handsome man in a cravat and a long, windblown coat?

reviewText: I liked this movie well enough. It's a good version to watch if you're not looking for something terribly deep and like the book, but I would much sooner recommend the '95 BBC/A&E; version, with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. There is too much Hollywood in this version; too much is changed from Jane Austen's original wonderful book. For one thing, the scene in which Mr. Darcy first proposes takes place outside in the rain. That is much too cliched for my taste. And it is just an example of the many rather sickening modernizations in this version.It is not wholly unenjoyable. But it pales in comparison with the previously mentioned '95 version. Compared to the portrayal of the characters in that version, Elizabeth and Darcy and all the rest in this one are a bit shallow, and the original story has been rather disfigured and twisted in an attempt to make it more appealing to the masses (it doesn't work). And the chemistry in this one is not bad, but nothing to that between Firth and Ehle's Darcy and Elizabeth. I say, rent this, watch it, and then go out and buy the '95 version for real enjoyment.

reviewText: I really feel it is unfair that so many people are comparing this movie to the excellent miniseries starring Collin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. You simply cannot fit the same amout of character development and plot detail in a 2+ hour movie that you can in a 5+ hour miniseries. And I think (shock) there are some things that this movie does better than the Firth version. One is (some of) the casting. For example I liked Mr. Collins, Charlotte Lucas, and Mrs. Bennett better in this version, because I think the actors were able to bring empathy for previously one-dimensional characters. Now I won't pretend to compare the lead actors between versions, but I don't think anyone disgraced themselves.Yes there were some things about this movie that were historically inaccurate or not faithful to the book, but again, you cannot fit all the content of a book into a film. Come on, people!! The one thing that really bugs me about this version is the final scene, with its chessy and un-Austen-like dialogue. But other than that, I think watching this film is a most enjoyable way to spend the afternoon. And it might even introduce more readers to Jane Austen who have been intimidated by previous versions. And that would be all to the good, certainly.

reviewText: I saw an advanced screening of this film in Boston and was very pleased, it is intelligent in its handle of the material and its fluency in cinematic crafting. Goodbye to dusty, "precious" interpretations of Jane Austen. This cheeky, poetic, even dark new film makes the story youthful with down-to-earth vibrancy and worship of emotion. Here are young people making the mistakes and dreaming the dreams of the young (when it was written it wasn't antiquity, it was life). Lizzie is not a smirking omniscient but a quick witted independent; hotheaded and fiercely loyal to her sister. She is wary of an unfair world and uses her wits to survive. Darcy is not an impenetrable stoic but a shy sensitive soul with high unwieldy social pretensions fending off the outside world. And they are both lonely and have big yearning hearts, so the filmmakers made one great decision -- they let them fall in love the first moment they lock eyes. In a shot we see hearts behind fortified personalities and an instant chemistry that takes a movie's worth of battling with each other and themselves to right itself. It's an earthy move that sets the tone for a film about the people and world behind the antiquated manners, a world not so different from ours.Now set in 1797, when Austen wrote the first draft of the book, the filmmakers committed to main plot points and themes, and astutely represent the Romantic Age and Austen's characters.  The love between Jane and Lizzie is supreme and fuels a desire in Lizzie to tear at Darcy when he separates Jane from Mr. Bingley. She's hurt, she reciprocates the pain, and it is bitter.  Pride and prejudices are drawn clearly: Lizzie searches hard to find fault with Darcy, and Darcy cannot bring himself to let down his guard. Both have their reasons justified, but they foil their own chances at love constantly until they see how wrong they are and are too heartsick to keep going. Class conflict is suddenly personally injurious and vicious. When Charlotte Lucas marries for security, it's a grave matter and she must bitingly sober up a disdainful Lizzie on the realities of their world. The Bennets are too eccentric and improper for their own good. Lady Catherine (Dame Judi Dench, who is downright fearsome) is not just a cold figure for Lizzie to spar with, but someone capable of deeply hurting others. The filmmakers are savvy in their understanding of history. Setting it back 20 years is a remarkable move, because we accept more diversions and variation with the 18th century than the 19th and it presents Austen as a Romantic, which automatically requires the story to be interpreted from a different, very legitimate, perspective. The ideals of the Romantic Age are ingeniously, subtly played here: human equality, gritty realism married with beauty for the sake of beauty, but a beauty which is never elitist or decadent, always grounded, simple, and universal: nature, the human being, emotion.The ensemble and mis-en-scene are electric. The camera spryly edges in and out of rooms and conversations instead of sitting arthritically in a corner. The dance scenes are less about ballet, now rollicking and spirited as characters send signals, flirt, deflect and analyze one another. In true Romantic form (worthy of filling Wordsworth with pride) the aesthetic unabashedly revels in beauty, but always the simple joys of our world: sunrises, dewy landscapes in wide shots, colors everywhere. It has a lovely score, period inspired and without any pomp and circumastance. Simple blocking is caffeinated and given substance, something is always going on in the background. Lively, layered interactions between characters make rich scenes, neither wasting space nor time. Consider a scene with Mr. Collins, played by the magnificent Tom Hollander (a standout here, so delightfully weird. When he jaggedly squirms his way up to someone you want to shriek). He wants to speak to Lizzie, alone, and a bolt of fear strikes through her as she pleads in vain not to be abandoned. The sisters are merciless, Mrs. Bennet delighted, Mr. Bennet at a loss, and Collins prepares. It's all silent and it's hysterical.Suggesting variation to revered characters is a frightful task, but here it's a revelation. The entire cast is brilliant, but the two leads are transcendent in their roles. Keira Knightley is charismatic, random, wonderfully young, intuitive to the bone -- she inhabits Lizzie. Matt MacFadyen is deep, remarkably subtle, but mostly he is soulful. I've long held him as a sympathetic actor, but he shines in this.  The two instill an unexpected exuberance of feeling in their performances.  Neither ever acknowledge the camera exists and make the most of every second they have on screen to project their characters. When you throw them together you get a love story full of emotional subtext, double meaning, and gloriously heavy moments.Because so much dialogue was cut, simple lines have impact and much of the exposition is visual. Epic little moments linger and rain, revealing souls. The thoughts and intentions behind the actors' eyes and words are visible at all times.  This movie understands the power of a shot or glance. Lizzie comes to understand Darcy in how he embraces his sister or smiles (a momentous occasion, indeed). When she talks about love it's stirring because it's finally spilled into the open after we've seen it near the edge many times with half said sentiments and stifled tears. Usually "I love you" comes with extra explanatory prose, but here sincerity kills cliché: parties are fun, a misty field is breathtaking, the dawning of love a revelation, the heartbreak is throbbing.It's a brilliant film. There is something breathless and luminous about it, from its youth and the break from propriety, to the beauty and spontaneity of life and romance, pain and joy, which provide the color.
summary: Oft told tale made soulful, young

reviewText: Like so many other people, I approached this film with trepidation because I dearly love the 1995 version and not just because of Colin Firth. Over the course of the months since this film's release, I'd heard vastly different reviews of the film and not inconsequential problems that Austen fans had with the movie. As I sat down to watch, I tried to forget what I'd heard, the 1995 version and tried to be as impartial as possible. However, it was very, very hard to forget the 1995 version.The good (the things that exceed the 1995 version):Rosamund Pike makes an excellent Jane. She's beautiful enough to fit the description of Jane being the most beautiful girl in Hertfordshire, something that Susannah Harker had been unable to do. She also gives some steel to a character that is frequently characterized as soft.The music is absolutely beautiful. It fits in so beautifully with the story. It rivals with Patrick Doyle's "Sense and Sensibility" soundtrack.The O.K. (things on par with the 1995 version)Brenda Blethyn gives a very different performance of Mrs. Bennett from the 1995 version. While wholly different, it is just as good and the character remains just as silly and endearing as ever.Simon Woods is a very good Mr. Bingley. He has the bumbling part down and clearly conveys his feelings for Jane. I particularly enjoy his work when his character says something rather off a nd must put it to rights.Judy Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourgh is wonderful casting. Dame Dench has played this role before and brings the same wonderful imperiousness.Tom Hollander, like Brenda Blethyn, was very different from his 1995 counterpart, but played the role of Mr. Collins admirably. I couldn't help but smile every time he came onto the screen  and laugh every time he mentioned Lady Catherine de Bourgh, Rosings, or made one of his funny little speeches.The Bad (the things that aren't as good as the 1995 version)The setting and costuming looked incredibly off. It seemed as if the people making this movie didn't realize that the Bennetts were pretty well off, as long as they had the estate, with 2,000 pounds a year. The overall appearance of everyone who was not a Bingley, Darcy, or de Bourgh left much to be desired.Keira Knightley is just not Elizabeth Bennett. Most of the movie she acted as if she knew she was remarkably clever, which didn't sit all that well.Matthew Macfadyen definitely does not fill Colin Firth's shoes. He lacks the ability to act with his eyes that helped Firth so much in the earlier version. He is too silent and dour for most of the movie and when he finally does perk up it is far too late.There is a lack of chemistry between the two leads which makes certain scenes like the first proposal scene seem entirely out of place. Any thoughts to attachment beforehand was created by the camera and not the 2 actors. Keira Knightley had more chemistry with Darcy's bust than Darcy himself.Jena Malone, Donald Sutherland, and Rupert Friend try admirably in their roles, but don't suceed. Jena Malone does act silly like Lydia, but with too much calculation. Donald Sutherland makes Mr. Bennett seem a very unfeeling man about anyone, including Elizabeth. Rupert Friend is far too young to be a contemporary of Matthew Macfadyen, plus far too young and eager looking for someone who had led a rake's life.After watching the film I came to the conclusion that I'd rather watch 2 hours of the 1995 adaptation than this film. With that said, the film does succeed as a period piece and as a film is certainly better than most film fare. I recommend it to the anyone excepting the most ardent admirers of Austen and the 1995 adaptation.
summary: Good as a movie, ok as a period piece, not all that great as an adaptation of Austen

reviewText: Elizabeth Bennett (Knightley) and Mr. Darcy (MacFadyen) do not impress each other in their first meeting.  In fact, they seem alltogether unimpressed with each other.  Circumstances continually force their paths to cross, and soon their opinions of each other begin to change.  Things are not happily ever after though, as marriage proposals interfere with their possible relationship, but if you know the story, you know how it ends.Yet another adaptation of Jane Austen's "Pride & Prejudice", and I am told that this is a pretty good one.  The story, however, did not hold my interest.  I am not a Jane Austen fan, and was probably doomed from the start to be disappointed.  Keira Knightley does a good job as Lizzie though, being both playful and vulnerable.  MacFayden, as Mr. Darcy, is uninspiring, but Darcy himself is kind of a jerk at times and I found him unlikeable.  This is a movie I would recommend for Jane Austen fans only.  I think they will enjoy the film, but others will not.

reviewText: I know, where have I been since I've never read a book by Jane Austen? I have watched a ton of movies based on her books, though, and this is probably my favorite, though I really enjoyed Sense and Sensibility also. The most impressive character was probably the hero, though. He was so stuffy and stoical at first, but as he felt more compelled to get to know the heroine and was drawn to her, he softened up quite a bit. It was aggravating how she doubted him so much, but I was delighted when she started to see that out of love he had helped her family numerous times to save their reputations, etc. Kiera did a great job once again, but I really love the guy who played Mr. Darcy. He was excellent!
summary: Really enjoyed the acting in this movie, but I've never read the book.

reviewerName: Mike J. Rice "'Mike Rice, Cultural Historian"
reviewText: Pride and Prejudice has a fantasticallyfast-moving opening at an Upper MiddleClass social gathering and dance.  We'reintroduced to Mr. and Mrs. Bennett and theirfive daughters in the middle of things.The Bennet Daughters are there to capturehusbands like every sensible woman inlate 18th century England.  Thespirited dancing seems to ape theemotions of the Bennet girls asthey wander about.The dance features not the usualsnobbish Brits but rather a free-wheeling group of normal socialites reflectingthe carefree, not posh and not snobbishBennets, their five daughtersand assorted friends.Keira Knightley plays Elizabeth Bennet,Donald Sutherland her besieged, drollrather appalled father.  Mr. Bennet,as in the book, is called Mister evenby his daughters.  Every man is Mister.It makes the movie funnier  contrastingthe formality of  the Misters with theconvivial and fun-loving play of theBennet girls.Mrs. Bennet is a  shimmering pile ofunspent emotional fiery. The girls at anymoment, mother included, are likely tolose their heads at the sight ofa man with 5,000 a year.  That isif they're not having a joke at hisexpense at the time.At those moments, Mr. Bennent retreatsto his study, where he has a new plantto look at.Only Mrs. Bennet is a straight fortune-hunter.  The Bennet girls somehow have foundtime to understand genuine love, thoughMr. Bennet seems as unaware of this asMrs. Bennet.  Mr. Bennet seems to havesense you see.  How the girls learnedof true love is a mystery.Jane Austen's novel is set in apredatory England.  A man with 1,000pounds will stir interest.  A manwith 5,000 creates sheer excitement.Austen predates Dickens and the BronteSisters, but the Director has managedto include visuals lifted right fromthe heather of Wuthering Heights andhas placed Elizabeth in settings that justdo not exist in the somewhat hardscrabbleback yard of the lower middle class Bennets.There is an instance or two of an enormousboar in the house for instance.Elizabeth escapes home with a flock ofducks fluttering about, seeming toimitate her. The image is stolenfrom the thirties David Copperfield andcopied again with great effect inTom Jones.The only true snob in the film is MisterDarcy.  Poor Mister Darcy,he cannot bring himself to speak to mostwomen, considering them trivial.  Heboorishly connives to torpedo Elizabeth'ssister Mary's budding romance with thehandsome though high-haired Mr. Bingley.At the dance opening of the film, Elizabethfinds Darcy odd at first, then turns squarelyagainst him after encountering  hismore offensive traits. The audience knowsthat both are intrigued and Darcy may evenbe smitten.There is Mr. Collins, who, spotting Elizabethat the dance, immediately cocks his hat forher.  Only Lizzy is taller than he, his designson her seem more about money than love, andbesides, he and the film are moving too fast.There's room for one bounder in the shape ofMr. Wickham, who, it develops, knows and dislikesMr. Darcy as much as Elizabeth and tells herso.  A frame or two later he has run off withone of Elizabeth's sisters.  Mr. Collins toohas found matrimonial bliss in Elizabeth's friendwho confides to Elizabeth that she hasn'tattributes enough to wait for love to arriveat her door as Elizabeth has.The new Pride and Prejudice is certain to becompared with the 1995 BBC miniseries starring ColinFirth as Mr. Darcy and Jennifer Ehle as Elizabeth.Keira Knightley, who ran away with the movieKing Arthur two years ago, owns this film too.  Un-like the miniseries, she doesn't really have toshare with this Mr. Darcy (Matt McFadyen).Knightley seems to be at once Audrey Hepburnand Winona Ryder.  Judy Dench, almost a necessitynow in every British period film, plays Darcy'shigh-handed and very rich aunt with her usual bombast.Some screen notes say actress Emma Thompson gavethis fast-paced screenplay a touchup that is  un-credited except in end credits.  I laughed moreat this film than I did at the '95 miniseries.I could hear all of Darcy's, Mr. Bennet's, and Elizabeth'slines, but the rest was sometimes too British to understand.Still, one could read body language just as well in manyscenes.  Director Joe Wright pushed the movie along ata torrid pace.  At times his camera moves in and out ofdoors and windows peering at the bewildering contrastsin attitudes of the many lovers and players in justseconds.I recommend that everyone see it.  Its very funny.When Mr. Bennett learns Elizabeth finally wants to wedMr. Darcy after all, he becomes teary when telling hisdaughter why, totally stealing the scene from Miss Knightley.Score one for Mister Bennet.Laurence Olivier and Greer Garson were Darcy and Elizabethin the first 1940 version. An Indian Directress who refilmedVanity Fair in 2004 put out a Bollywood version of Prideand Prejudice early this year.The present version, more than the miniseries, remindsthat Louisa May Alcott borrowed heavily from Austen's Prideand Prejudice to produce Little Women in 1869.  The two novelshave nearly the same structure.  Pride and Prejudiceis a first instance of Chick Lit written in English.Its a story of girls for girls and any male who wantsto learn a few things about them they hadn't known.
summary: Mr. Bennet's Daughters in Hot Pursuit,  their Father, Reserved

reviewText: The English literature gives us a new adaptation of Jane Austen's novel Pride and Prejudice, starring Keira Knightley and Matthew McFadyen.In the 18th century, the importance to achieve a good marriage was a fundamental pillar for the English society. For women, in particular, it was more than understandable that to live under that kind of pressure and social restrictions was a frustration, especially for the impetuous Elizabeth Bennet.Second among five sisters, Lizzie could be considered the rebel of the family, the Jo March of England, without a neurotic desire to be married for money or to be exposed to the agonizing rituals of traditional courting that was characteristic in that era.But when her matchmaker mother is aware that exists a remote but weak possibility to marry her older daughter Jane (Rosamund Pike) with a quite eligible bachelor (Simon Woods), Elizabeth trips accidentally with her match, the very observer, quiet, shy and taciturn Mr. Darcy (McFadyen).Darcy obviously sees Mrs. Bennet's intentions and driven by a sincere desire of protection keeps his friend from comitting to the lovely and shy Jane, while he and Elizabeth begin a turbulent relation of attraction and rejection, marked for his prejudice and her pride.One of the sharpest observations of Austen's novels is that the rich were used to judge the less prosperous for trying to assure a advantageous marriage, without realizing that they did exactly the same thing. Nowadays, this history of social acceptance, values, misundertandings and prejudices is as valid as it was in past times.The film had the joyous luck of counting with a terrific cast: from the childish sisters of Elizabeth, her shameless mother (a glorious Brenda Blethyn), the prepotent Lady Catherine (a magnificent Judi Dench) and Donald Sutherland as the absent minded and easy-going patriarch Bennet . Clearly, the stars of the history -Knightley and McFadyen- shine above this group. As Lizzie, Knightley is a bubbly mixture of passion, intelligence, defiance and vulnerability. Mr. Darcy, in turn, finds in McFadyen the perfect mixture of modesty, enigm, volatility, tenderness and dettachment, but simply with one look is capable of lettiing us see that his attitude is only a mask.Who is more proud or prejudiced? It's difficult to decide, since Lizzie and Darcy are so alike, and this is why the romance of these two is so provocative. Is clear that Elizabeth and Darcy are made for each other, and even thought neither of them will recognize it at first, theirs' is a soulmates encounter, and their relation is based on mutual respect, admiration, attraction and above all, a clear vision that love is a lot more than what some pretty words can express.

reviewText: from the comments that the Director  makes on the DVD it feels like he misunderstands the relationship between Jane and Elizabeth. I think he also fails to use the letters in the movie to their full extent.  In Jane Austens time as I understand it letters were a very important form of communication, especially when it came to intimacy and I think they have been waved aside in this movie.  The movie could have used the letters to emphasize intimacy between characters and I think that the Director completely misses out on this opportunity. The bonnets were also very important in Jane Austens time especially in terms of a lady's "natural and unblemished [freckle free] complexion" and  eligibility for marriage and yet the director dismisses the Bonnet as a cliché and uses it far less than needed. The Bennet sisters for example have already got strikes against them in terms of marriability why give them another one by refusing them a bonnet? The book also says that by the time that it was written any real affection that Mr. Bennet may have felt for Mrs. Bennet has long since died out.  The movie contradicts this. I also feel as though the Movie version of Mrs. Bennet cares more for her eldest daughters than is indicated in the book, and that she is a far more understanding and sensible woman in the movie than she is in the book and Darcy's objections to marrying Elizabeth therefore carry less weight than they do in the book because she is not as lacking in sense as she is in the book.  The last scene ended a bit abruptly for me.  This movie is based on a love story and I think that the kiss needs to have lasted longer and not been cut off so abruptly and waved away like it was. I am also a bit confused about the commentary about there being no make up available to ladies at this time as some websites indicate that something resembling make up did exist at this point in time. I did like the person who acted out Mr. Collins - very well done, most of the other actors too although I'm not sure about Mr. Bingley's "silly scene" (when Jane is sick) seems a bit out of character. I like Keirra Knightly, and the person who played Darcy. I think the movie could have done without some of the nature scenes.  A bit disappointing really.
summary: Good acting, but misinterpreted. lacks a little in understanding of Jane Austens world.

reviewText: I must confess to being one of the many doubters, who wondered aloud when the trailers for this P & P came out, Do we need another one? At the time my answer was: We Don't.  After finally viewing it, my opinion remains unchanged.  And it isn't just that the BBC version got it so right that we can't get over it.  It's a lot more: No doubt, there are moments of beautiful film captured here.  But the screenplay, which squeezes the book into just over two hours -- is botched, terribly so.  We know from other Jane Austen films that it is NOT impossible to capture the essence of the novel in a short time frame (when in doubt, please consult Emma Thompson!); nothing close to coherence happens in this film, as anyone who has read the novel and watched it can attest.  Those familiar with the novel will see immediately where scenes have been combined, re-arranged, or re-imagined entirely, often to bizarre effect.  Those who haven't read the novel will be utterly confused.  One explanation will suffice: Wickham's character is not sufficiently developed to make it clear why he departs, and why Elizabeth is so upset when Lydia elopes with him.  All of the important context for this storyline is dropped.  The random modernizing of language serves no purpose that I can find -- either leave Austen's beautiful language alone, or modernize entirely, and update the time as well, whereby Emma becomes "Clueless."  As to characterization, I find no evidence of Lizzy's and Mr Bennet's wonderful relationship (in fact, Donald Sutherland looks bored), I don't see much chemistry between Elizabeth and Darcy, or much chemistry between anyone for that matter.  Costumes are not period appropriate, which again would be fine, if there was some coherence to the choices that were made.  And why is everyone's hair wild and ukepmt?  Finally, I am told that the Bennet's "status reduction" -- whereby Longborn is made to look poorer than the novel suggests -- was done to draw a clearer distinction between Elizabeth's and Darcy's status.  This was hardly necessary, and random flights of geese, chickens and pigs all over the place is completely annoying.  The entire film feels rushed and perfunctory, like the cast is haunted by the ghosts of prior versions, even before the camera starts rolling, and says "Let's just get on with it."  Jane Austen -- and her fans -- deserve better.

reviewText: Jane Austen wrote six of the most sparkling novels ever penned and adapting them to the movies is hard because fans of Austen are passionate, literate and critical and can recite whole chunks of dialog from the novels the same way fans of Monty Python can do the lumberjack song.  And Pride and Prejudice is probably her best loved and most frequently dramatized work.This is the best adaption I have seen.  It is true in spirit and in sense to the original. The visual adaption of the novel is done with lyric beauty, gritty attention to detail and an eye for symbolic clues to the properly restrained feelings of the protagonists.  The scene where Elizabeth wanders through the nearly naked statuary of Pemberly is pure genius as if the artwork is showing us her secret attraction for Darcy.  So much fun--such chic chick-lit!
Title: N/A

reviewText: My favorite version of my favorite novel remains the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle version because it follows the book, for the most part, in spirit, manners et al.  The acting, in my mind, could not have been better in that version, especially in the casting of those who played the Bennetts senior - Mr and Mrs., Mr. Collins, Lady Catherine De Bourgh and others.  While I very much like Keira Knightley in other things she's done and I think she does well enough capturing the spirit of Lizzie here (and I very much like the actress here who plays her friend, Charlotte Lucas), I think the way the director and screenwriter strove for naturalism in this version made the Bennetts and their house and grounds in particular, as one other reviewer here has described it, too frumpy and dumpy for what one would expect from what Lizzie describes herself as being a 'gentlemen's daughter.'  There is almost a total LACK of gentility and manners in this Bennett clan - forget impropriety - we've gone way overboard.  Keira Knightley's hair, while more 'sexy' looking as modern standards of beauty go, would have been considered quite unkempt and wild when she goes to Bingley's to visit Jane in this version.  Her skirt is '6 inches deep in mud' but otherwise we can assume Lizzie had some idea of the proprieties, otherwise Darcy would not have exempted her and Jane from his condemnation of the rest of the family for not always following social mores/conduct/propriety.  While the scene with Darcy walking across the field with his shirt open is romantic, it's not in the book and seemingly out of character with the Darcy Austen wrote.  I loved Colin Firth's Darcy, and I also loved Greer Garson and Lawrence Olivier's portrayals.  Knightley and MacFayden do ok - I just term this version the Fabio version of the book.
summary: a different take on the Austen classic
