reviewText: I dared watch this movie on DVD with my wife, because my brother assured me it is awesome, despite being a girly movie.  Lo! and behold!  It is not a girly movie, but a work of literature accessible to everyone transferred to the screen with emotion and beauty!!  Wow!!The next day after viewing it, I logged onto my email, and was about to delete all the advertisement emails I regularly get from amazon and other companies without looking at them as usual, when my finger halted, and I then unchecked the box next to an amazon ad saying "new blu-ray releases," thinking to myself, "just in case Pride and Prejudice came out on blu-ray."  I opened that message, and there it was - a sign from heaven.  I purchased it as fast as my finger could click, and watched it again as soon as it arrived two days later!Very convincing acting, beautiful set design and very entertaining story!  Fantastic!Only negative aspect of the blu-ray compared to DVD: title screen is ridiculous mechanized console with ludicrous sound effects -- very opposite the atmosphere of the movie.  Hurry and push play to see as little of the menu as possible.

reviewText: For Devotees of the 1995 miniseries who have disected, and can recite the entire thing ... this movie will annoy you slightly, but at the same time it will be a breath of fresh air.  I f you just can't get enough P&P, you will enjoy the new scenery and different take on several of the scenes.  What will annoy you is the much weaker, and more bland actors.  With the exception of Kiera Knightly, who in my opinion carries the entire movie, the actors are altogether less outrageous and entertaining than those in the 95 version.  Being that the novel is a study of human folly, the 95 cast brings humor and outlandish behavior to life, as they were meant to.  In this new film, they are just dull by comparison.  Aside from that, this latest version of the classic novel, has a much more lush and interesting setting, and Kiera Knightly is outstanding as Elizabeth, bringing her own witty and fresh flavor to a heroin that everybody knows and loves. All in all I found the movie to be worth my while, as a new way to experience one of my favorites.
summary: A new perspective for 1995 P&P adicts

reviewText: I think I watched it ten times in a row; it's that kind of movie. What a fantastic job done by the director and stunning cinematography. The music is some of the best I've ever heard. The acting was incredible! The scenery was amazing! You get sucked right in and never want to leave. I didn't think they could pull off a two hour version but it was so wonderful. I do wish it had been 30 minuets longer so we could see more interaction between Elizabeth and Darcy. But this version gets the point across with such passion it makes you want to melt. I think the casting was great, I especially liked Rosamund Pike and Mathew Macfadyen. I'm not a big fan of Knightley, but it was great casting she did well and I liked her in it. I think Brenda Blethyn cast as the mother was a bit annoying but maybe that was their point. I don't understand why all the book nuts say it has to sick by the book word for word. This is such an entertaining film and I think Jane Austen her self would have really enjoyed it.

reviewText: First of all, I should say that I am an avid Jane Austen fan. I think she is one of the greatest authors in the English language. Making a film of this story is a privilege because of the material in the book. I loved the previous two adaptations made in Britain by the BBC, the last one from 1995 being exceptionally good. Colin Firth and Ms. Ehle were outstanding in these roles and apparently lived and breathed Darcy and Elizabeth for a whole summer. This latest adaptation doesn't even come close to the standards in the BBC version. It seemed as though this version tried to be different from the 1995 version, and failed as a result because this required a departure from the book.I found the acting surprisingly awful. Mr. Darcy in the 2005 adaptation lacked conviction, and seemed to be bored with the role he was supposed to be playing, when he wasn't trying to stay awake. Colin Firth was far more convincing. The other characters were almost as bad, including Ms. Knightley. The silly 20th Century smirks and childish behaviour, just didn't translate to the period of time that the book deals with. Jane Austen's great lines and dialogue were replaced with many 21st Century lines which although at times funny, didn't fit with the period. I do not understand why the Bennet family was made to appear very rural and poor. They were not poor in the book, but quite well to do. Like Shakespeare such modern adaptations can work, but this one was difficult to fathom. I look forward to seeing another Pride & Prejudice adaptation, but the 1995 version is the gold standard to which they will need to be compared, and not this version.Some positive points:Great CD with wonderful music. I loved it.Great packaging and extra materials.
summary: Disappointing Adaptation of Pride and Prejudice

reviewText: I too have been predisposed to dislike this hack-job of a story, and it did feel a bit uncomfortable to swallow.  Having watched the BBC version of P&P, I felt as though I were being chased through an enormous theme park, with colors and music (a bit too orchestrated IMO) and what felt like scenes being changed quickly just to give us a scent of what it felt like to live in that time.  All that said, the last minutes of the film more than made up for the condensed montage preceding it. Darcy's delivery of the note was, IMO, more romantic that the BBC version, the following early morning's meeting , along with the concent scenes made it truly worth the while.  If you watch the BBC version, you'll know what I mean.  BBC = two dimensions, New version = three dimensions (in feeling).  And sure, read the book.  I just got done watching Bleak House and have begun trying to read the Charles Dickens book (over 800 pages, no less)...and that might take me all year to get motivated to finish it.
summary: The latter part of the film made it worth watching

reviewText: After I borrowed this movie from my mom's house I dreaded putting it in. I thought it was going to be a long, drawn out & boring old-time flick about snobby people gossiping about each other. I was PLEASANTLY surprised. It caught my attention from beginning to end. The characters were SO likable. Yes, even the two-faced snobby rich sister, annoying mother & giddy younger sisters! They bugged me but made the movie that much more enjoyable. It was very nice how the script was able to portray the way of life back then. Although the Bennets lived in what we consider a huge house they were considered penniless. 5,000 pounds a year was considered rich. Trying to marry off your daughters to the wealthiest man possible was a goal a mother must bear (at least THIS one).I try to avoid watching Donald Sutherland movies as much as possible. He does so much better with villain roles than good-guy ones. Other than the failed attempt to an English accent, I really couldn't help liking his character in this movie very much. In fact, he was one of my favorites throughout the movie. Especially after he contradicted his wife when choosing sides w/Elizabeth in rejecting Mr. Collins' proposal of marriage.Personally, I don't think Knightley is the hottest fox out there but it fits her role of "nearly tolerable". Yeah, the lips have always bugged me but I looked past that because she's been great in all the roles I've seen her in. What I found most surprising was when Mr. Darcy first appeared, I had wished they'd picked a more handsome actor. His presentation of the role made him out to be SO irresistible and handsome. I loved the rain-scene the best. You were able to see his big blue eyes & he looked sexiest there.All in all, this was a very passionate & romantic movie. It was innocent enough to let young girls watch. Elizabeth Bennet was an intelligent character & a rather good role model for younger audiences. I put this movie up next to the Anne of Green Gables mini-series. Definitely not as wonderful but comparable in values & good storyline.
summary: GREAT!  I watched it twice in a row!

reviewText: Ok, so it's not Colin Firth in the BBC miniseries, but it's still a great movie, I enjoyed every minute of it.It's a beautiful movie in every aspect.  The scenery is absolutely amazing, and when it is put together with the music like it is, the result is breathtaking.  Keira Knightley and MacFadyen are great, and there's great chemistry between the two, and it's all very innocent and pure, which is a nice change.The supporting cast is also amazing, making the movie even better.It's not a slow movie, as in you won't be bored out of your mind at any time, it has a nice pace to it.  But it is slow in the way that it takes its time and it's not hectic in any way, which is exactly how it should be. I think the word to describe the pace would be "relaxing".You'll laugh, cry, smile, it's a beautiful emotional ride, with beautiful music to accompany you through the journey.It might truly be the greatest love story of all time.This movie is a pure gem, and one of the best I've seen.
summary: It truly is the greatest love story of all time.

reviewText: What a classy movie! This is the successor to the Merchant Ivory movies... Joe Wright does an impeccable job of getting a dense and wordy novel down to the essentials of the story, and still leave time to savour the beauty of England and the cast.The story involves Lizzy and her 4 sisters, following their path to marriage through the minefield of Georgian conventions of 1797 (when the movie was set)and English social mores. The pride and the prejudices come from every angle in this classic and timeless story.There are several ingredients here that simply make this work to perfection. The cast is for the most part spot on, with Keira Knightley in top form as the headstrong Lizzy, looking, sounding and emoting every inch the part. She is surrounded by Brenda Blethyn and Donald Sutherland as her father and mother, Judi Dench as a Lady Catherine to make you wither in your boots (unless you are Lizzy of course), ravishing Rosamund Pike as her older sister and Tom Hollander as the wimpy cleric, amongst others. The only slight let down, and only because the others are so good, is Matthew MacFadyen, who is perfectly adequately brooding as Darcy, but compared to Colin Firth lacks the charisma to make such a character attractive to Lizzy.Therein lies the problem, if any, with this adaptation - it cannot help but be compared to the impeccable casting and pedigree of the BBC version, which is still the definitive version because of its length, which allows it to stick more rigidly and fully to the book. But this movie must be taken on its own merits, and succeeds where the BBC version could not, in the scale and beauty of the photography - England looks absolutely beautiful here. The mud and dirt are all there - this is no stagey drama - but the beauty of the photography illuminates fantastic interiors of houses rich to poor, and most especially the exteriors of Georgian facades, and natures rich greens and majestic moors.I should also mention the music by Dario Marianelli which is a perfect contributor to the movie, beautifully classic while never dull, somewhat like the ivory tinklings of Michael Nyman (The Piano), but not nearly so minimalist, with lush orchestra where appropriate, and lively jigs for the ball scenes making them seem genuinely like something that would have been fun to attend.Overall, I suggest avoiding comparison with the BBC version, and take this movie as the definitive cinema version, at least.- a p.s. there are plenty of extras on the desk fleshing out history and Jane Austen as well as the usual 'making of' stuff, but most interesting is the alternative ending for the US market - this adds a scene of Lizzy and Darcy together cuddling and expressing their love, which seems much more like a Hollywood add on than the original ending, and adds nothing other than some saccharine for those who cannot find the romance in the story but require it spelt out.
summary: Fantastic entertainment for both fans and newcomers to Austen

reviewText: While I will admit this is an adequate adaptation of Austen's beloved Pride and Prejudice, I'm afraid that I can praise it no more than that.  Yet again, this is an instance of Hollywood production and direction and the overtness of both overriding the subtle nuances of this keenly written novel and its themes of love and possession.I won't comment on the actors' performances here because, again, the only word I can use to describe the ensemble cast is adequate.  I will note, however, that Kiera Knightely shines as Lizzie Bennett, albeit a little too giddy for my taste, and that Matthew McFayden's Darcy is more somber bordering on depressed than haughty or proud.In attempting to amplify the unsuitability of Lizzie as a match for Darcy, the producer of the film opts to place her family in relative squalor and, by doing so, completely subverts the delicate relationship and definition between the classes in Regency England.Although the film follows Austen's narrative quite closely, it departs from it often in terms of dialogue and action.  How inappropriate would it have been for Darcy to come bursting in the door of Lizzie's bedroom!  Lizzie says things like "I have no idea."  "I haven't the smallest idea" or "I haven't the slightest idea" would have been more correct.  "I have no idea" is a more contemporary phrase, and should not be made to feel at home in any movie which claims to be based on Austen's work.Those scenes in particular which veer from the manners and mannerisms of Austen's England just make the film a little too pedestrian for my taste.  "You have bewitched me body and soul"?  Hardly.  Although it may have been said of Darcy, it is not something that Austen's Darcy would have uttered.  What utter tripe and nonsense!  Even Charlotte Bronte, author of "Jane Eyre", was not a fan of Austen's because of what she believed to be a definitive lack of passion in Austen's writing.  It's not so much that passion is lacking, more that it is restrained, so for Darcy to exhibit that sort of passion would be completely inconsisent with the character Austen created.  I actually cringed my way through the last fifteen minutes.  "'Godess Divine' on Sundays'"?  Don't make me laugh.  There is such a thing as leaving some things to the imagination.  It is a pity that some movie producers just haven't mastered that fine art.All in all, if you view the film as simply a movie NOT based on the book, then it's enjoyable.  If you're a purist, as I am, take my advice and rent this one, don't buy it, and take it for what it is.  If you want to see Austenian adaptations at their finest, RUN AND BUY the A&E; production of Pride and Prejudice instead, or Persuasion, starring Ciaran Hinds and Amanda Root.
summary: Best movie of the year?  Hardly

reviewText: Aside from that, this is a lovely adaptation. As to the complaints about cuts and re-working of scenes, the film makers didn't have the luxury of five hours to tell the tale verbatum. I took my two nephews (age 16 & 14) to see this, and they both liked it. The older one is an avid reader who had been told by an older brother that Austen was dry and boring, so he expected to hate the movie going in and didn't. Now he's reading Austen and enjoying it. So where is the harm in knowing this is an adaptation and won't be completely faithful to the book? If you want a completely faithful version of the book, read the book.As to the particulars about my choice of rating: Keira Knightly is lovely as Elizabeth without outshining Rosamund Pike in beauty as Jane. Matthew Macfadyen does an outstanding job of showing us what Mr. Darcy is feeling and thinking. There's no other way to portray it in a movie; in the book, Austen puts us into his head so he doesn't have to show it. Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn shine as Mr. and Mrs. Bennet, presenting them as warm, real human beings rather than charactures. And Tom Hollander gives an amazing and completely different read on Mr. Collins. Usually played as a complete buffoon, here he is an ackward misanthrope who seems aware of the fact that there's something not quite right with how he comes across. It would have been nice if Judi Dench's scenes as Lady Catherine hadn't been cut so much, but there's that time restraint coming into play. Plus, you can't have everything.As to this DVD: Nice rendering. Good picture. Lovely sound. I only wish that the extras were a little more beefed up. I was sad to find no deleted scenes. However, the behind-the-scenes and interviews with the cast and crew are extensive and well done.Also recommended DVDs: BBC version, North & South (Elizabeth Gaskell), Wives & Daughters (also Gaskell), Sense and Sensibility (Emma Thompson version)
summary: If it gets people reading Austen, what's to complain about?

reviewText: I bought this DVD when it just came out.  I watched it and did not like it.  I just finished reading the book - again - and watching all the DVD's I own.  I give top rank to the 1995 BBC version with the 1980 BBC version a close second.  I have to say that the Hollywood version with Olivier was not that good and had several big flaws- I would not even rank it.  Unfortunately,  I watched this 2006 version  from beginning to end and, again, I did not find much to like.  The scenery and music were wonderful; however, the characters are not developed well with Lizzie being  a big disappointment - she did not behave ladylike, she seemed to just giggle and had no wit.  Mr Bingley  appears as a foolish young man without much going for him - can he be Mr Darcy's closest friend?  Can Jane fall madly in love with him?  Mr Bennet does not strike me as gentleman like - he was a landed gentleman with an adequate income, but a spendthrift wife.  I like Mr. Darcy, but he is still in third place.  I would have liked to see more of Mr Wickham - but we don't get to know him, and consequently cannot dislike him as we should.How improper to have Mr. Bingley go into the room where Jane is in bed with a cold - they seem to have copied the scene from the Hollywood version.  Did Mr. Darcy sneak into the Collinses house to give Lizzie the letter or I got that wrong?  If so, it would have been unthinkable behavior for Mr. Darcy.If this movie would have been presented with a different title and in a modern setting, I may have given it at least four stars.  I will keep the DVD and maybe I will watch it again in a few years - I may change my mind, but I doubt it.

reviewText: What a great film! I loved the score, I loved the cinematography, and I loved the casting.Kiera Knightley made a wonderful Elizabeth Bennet, and Matthew Macfadyen was a superb Darcy. Both of their performances were great. Macfadyen seemed to understand that, at first, Darcy had to be quite an unlikable character. However, as the movie progresses, the viewer (as well as Lizzie) learns more about him and grows to like him. It seems that, sometimes, actors are afraid to fully embody those unlikable characters unless they know they are playing the villain. But there are plenty of unlikable people in everyday life who are not villains. They are just cold, or boorish, or rude, or whatever. There are LOTS of folks with no bad intentions who are just plain draggy to be with.I really enjoyed how the movie stayed true to the spirit novel we've all known and loved, without become a slave to the book. (After all, movies and books are quite different mediums, and audiences change drastically over time.) I haven't seen much else that Joe Wright, the director, has done, but you can bet I'll be keeping an eye on him for the future.Near the end of the film, Darcy comes walking out of the morning mist, long coattails flapping in the breeze, to tell Lizzie that she has bewitched him, body and soul. Now, why on earth hasn't anyone said that to me lately? ~sigh.~

reviewText: Being a huge fan of period dramas, literary adaptations and Keira Knightley, I was delighted by the latest adaptation of Jane Austen'sPride and Prejudice. It is everything a movie should be, and then some. Great storytelling, an amazing soundtrack, an innovative director and a splendid soundtrack, it is definitely a movie you should own.It tells a classic story of Elizabeth Bennet, a smart, boyish heroine who meets the handsome Mr. Darcy, and judging solely on first impressions, believes he is "the last man on Earth she could ever possibly be prevailed upon to marry". Of course, it wouldn't be a Jane Austen adaptation if it wasn't for numerous plot twists, complicated character connections and humorous plays on words.Keira Knightley is perfect as Elizabeth, the role which not only propelled her to stardom, but also earned her an Oscar nomination in 2005. She is everything a classic heroine should be - sensual, expressive and beautiful, maybe even a little more than she should have been. On the other hand, there is Matthew Macfadyen, who makes a great, darker Mr. Darcy. Also in the all-star cast are veterans Donald Sutherland and Dame Judy Dench.Director Joe Wright did an incredible job. Not only did he play with the source in a very respectful, yet creative way, he used many tricks to make us care for these characters and believe their plights are just as well possible today. He also uses the stunning British countryside a number of times, and it is one of the film's best props - it is able to, accompanied by a great soundtrack, reflect the characters' emotions and send chills up and down one's spine."Pride & Prejudice" is definitely one of the best romantic movies and literary adaptations of the century, and one you should have on your shelf for sure.

reviewText: Okay, let's start with the positive when discussing the film: the cinematography really was quite nice, and the film has a lovely musical score. And... wait a moment, I've just run out compliments. In general, I thought this was a terrible adaptation of the Jane Austen novel. There were so many things wrong with it that I hardly know where to begin, and it would make tiresome reading if I were to list all of the film's faults. However, in brief...The film is hampered at the get-go by its very abbreviated running time of just over two hours. This is far too short to do the book any kind of justice, my opinion being that the best way to adapt classic novels on film is in the form of a television mini-series, where the producers can spend three, or four, or six hours to tell the story properly. Far too much material was condensed or cut entirely in this film, for it to be a satisfactory adaptation in any way.But that's just the beginning... another major problem is that nearly every character is portrayed in a way that is absolutely contrary to their personalities as depicted in the novel. Some examples... Mr Bingley, with his moronic grin, complete inability to carry on a simple conversation, and bizarrely wild hair-style, seems primed to take up the office of village idiot (that, or he may be slightly insane; either way, it's difficult to see why Jane admires him). Elizabeth comes across as rude and shrewish in several scenes, and Mrs Bennet (while dead common) appears to be a rather sensible and practical woman, instead of a featherbrain. Mr Darcy is melancholy and brooding, instead of proud and arrogant, and Mr Collins is dull and studious instead of obsequious and ridiculous. Miss Darcy is outgoing and vivacious instead of shy and retiring---etc., etc...Scenes containing important bits of dialogue have been transposed to incongruous locations that are ill-suited for the purpose, and there are many period details that are utterly incorrect. (Let's not even discuss the unattractive costuming; Keira Knightley goes through much of the film looking like she's wearing an assortment of ill-fitting sacks.)Okay, I guess you may have guessed by now that I really disliked this film! I'm frankly astounded by the fact that it has gotten a fairly positive response in general, with many people saying that it's a fine adaptation of the novel. I don't know how to respond to that attitude, other than to wonder if these people have actually read the book, or seen the film in question. I don't even recommend this one as a rental, unless one is determined to see every film adaptation of Pride and Prejudice that they can.

reviewText: This movie really had it tough. When you go up against one of the favorite movies ever, you have to be brave. Imagine making a new version of Gone with the Wind, or if someone decided to do Titanic Two. I remember when I saw this in theaters, everyone was whispering comparisons between this and the Colin Firth version. So, how is it?On it's own, it's great, actually. I've never been a fan of Kiera Knightley, but she does well here. I do think she played the part a little more teenage and a little less snarky than it was meant to be, but I'm sure the director was behind that 100%. This is, after all, aimed at the young audience. It's screaming, "I'm new, I'm fresh, I'm just like you!". Matthew MacFaden seems a little bored, to be honest. When he proposes the first time, it sounds like he's reading a phone book. Of course, I may be just comparing him to Firth because actually he and Knightley are good together. The real star here, though, is Tom Hollander. He play Mr. Collins in an entirely new way, a way nobody else had thought of. He is pitch perfect in his part and if you watch it for no other reason, watch it for him.[...]
summary: Had a Hard Battle to Fight

reviewText: It is my sincere wish that Jane Austen readers and non-readers  not miss a big screen viewing of Joe Wright's "Pride & Prejudice" because they let themselves be influenced by negative comments from the Ellen Jamesian sect of the Jane Austen society.  Particularly odious are those presumptuous enough to declare that Austen herself would consider the film a disservice.  Attempting to discourage potential viewers in this manner reveals not just a staggering conceit, but an utter cluelessness about how to read a film and about the power of a visual medium.This film adaptation of Austen's classic is the first one to fully capture its essence within the economical and efficient package of a two-hour feature film.  And it does so in a technically proficient way (cinematography-production design-editing); with perfect physical casting, excellent directing and scene staging, and fine performances from the entire ensemble.  In isolation it is simply the best film ever made, but because it is not an original screenplay the critics have downgraded it a bit from A plus to A minus (their acknowledgement of the debt it owns to Austen).Jane Austen once said,  "an artist cannot do anything slovenly".  Joe Wright's film is not perfect but it is the least slovenly in cinema history.  I was reminded of this by the film's treatment of Georgiana, Darcy's sister.  Georgiana was a minor but extremely important character in the book.  Elizabeth's point of view observations of Darcy's tender treatment of his shy little sister is how Austen shows Elizabeth's first realization that Darcy is worthy of her love.  Initially I was disappointed that Georgiana only has two brief appearances in the film, but on reflection I realized that the scenes had been staged and scripted so well that they said everything  needed about the relationship dynamics of the three characters.The film successfully brings Austen's ironic (insert comic here) observations of character and manners to the screen.  As the title proclaims, this story has a double theme, the pride of the aristocrat prejudicing the middle class heroine against him.  But as Elizabeth explains to her father in my favorite scene, she and Darcy are the flip sides of each other as her pride has long blinded her to Darcy's efforts to overcome the prejudice of his class to hers.The film also captures the more critical macro element of Austen's novel, the idea of a generous humanness that can transcend the motivations of social class.  Society is imperfect and while the social order encourages foolish prides and mean prejudices, it also enables kindness, affection, and courage.  In the film's movement of events there is a modulation between vices and virtues in which the latter more than mitigates the former.  This was Jane Austen's primary "value" which I think  would have formed the basis of her judgment and ultimate approval of the film.Then again, what do I know?  I'm only a child.
summary: Why I Think Jane Would Have Approved

reviewText: I thought that this version/adaptation of Austen's novel was excellent overall and would strongly recommend viewing to anyone (rent or purchase).I've seen most of the previous versions and agree that the BBC Ehle/Firth outing is indeed still much loved, however, I found this simply more realistic - from the grittier, grubbier lives of our heroines, played more girlish and younger than previously - to a much more 'real' portrayal of Darcy. Shy, vulnerable and as such, aloof.The real strength for me though was the true family that Sutherland and Blethyn create. The girls feel like real sisters, not literary ones, led by the extraordinary Knightley and Pike. Both quite luminous on screen and both embodying the spirit of the age.Special kudos must be given to Knightley though, who here just radiates a feisty lovability and who's capture of Darcy seems completely natural, as if any man who met her Lizzie would fall madly in love.And as such, McFayden embodies a Darcy that I can actually imagine falling in love with a girl, well below what he and his own family expects, and his struggle with his feelings and responsibilities.All in all, a great film.

reviewText: This film seems created by people familiar with the storyline of "Pride and Prejudice" but with little sense of Jane Austen's times or, indeed, her characters. The plot is essentially correct but the tone is frequently and incomprehensibly off.The general excellence of the actors, the dreamy cinematography and music, and the obvious care lavished on this movie make its flaws even more apparent and confusing. The Elizabeth and Jane Bennett described by Jane Austen would never listen at keyholes or shout at their mother or giggle at a feeble marriage proposal.  Mr. Collins was written as a comically pompous character; here he is so meek and awkward his romantic attempts are more pathetic than amusing and make the sisters' reactions seem cruel.The costumes and hair are inexplicable--Kitty and Lydia are dressed as if they are from a generation past, when they are the ones most concerned with fashion and are always buying new bonnets and gowns, and Elizabeth walks about with her hair down and in bare feet.  In reality, this would have been considered absolutely vulgar--akin to spitting tobacco--and never something a well-bred girl would do, no matter how high-spirited or independent.The Bennetts live in a place so ill-kept the animals wading across the yard look in danger of drowning in mud.  The Bennetts don't have the wealth of Bingley or Darcy, but they are supposed to be respectable, established gentry; Jed Clampett wouldn't own a place this slovenly.Despite all these missteps, this version of "Pride and Prejudice" is worth seeing for Keira Knightley's lively, if over-giggly, portrayal of Elizabeth and Matthew Macfadyen's interesting take on Darcy: he's more shy and subdued than actively arrogant (though his stuttering proposal at the end seems all wrong.  Love makes Darcy MORE eloquent, not less). The proposal scene in the rain is a highlight, and the plot stays true enough to the original for viewers to enjoy a cinematic vacation to Jane Austen's world.For the truest version of P and P, on all levels, definitely check out the BBC Jennifer Ehle/Colin Firth version.  It's wonderful!

reviewText: I debated whether I should give the picture 3 or 4 stars.  I obviously chose 3.  The problem with the production is simply it is too short to give full credit to Jane Austin's book.  That said, it is well executed, which is why debated between the two ratings.The first problem is for those who have no prior familiarity with either the book or at minimum the two relatively recent much more lenghty mini series (the BBC-A&E; version with Colin Firth of 1995 and--in my view, the better--BBC-Australian version with Elizabeth Garvie of 1990).  So much is cut from this version that the nuances of what Austin was trying to convey are simply missing.  The three younger Bennet daughters are hardly differentiated, mostly they giggle and it is even hard to figure out which one is which.  I have just seen Carey Mulligan as a wonderful Ada in Bleak House, and it took me most of the movie to recognize her as Kitty, the second youngest daughter.  Eventually Lydia becomes recognizeable but only because she gets married to Wickam.Wickham appears only briefly at the beginning and though he tells Lizzie of Darcy's alleged mistreatment of him, one never realizes from this movie that Lizzie is unduly intrigued by him and is in danger of succumbing to his false charms.  We do hear of his falsity from Darcy's famous letter, but nothing more is provided to flesh out Wickham's perfidy until he "elopes" with Lydia.  (In particular, the wise words of the housekeeper at Pemberley, a neutral source, on the perfidy of Wickham, an important fact for Lizzie, are simply missing.)Although Charlotte appears early in the film, her significance is almost unnoted  Thus, it is unclear why it is of significance (to those who don't already know the book) that Mr. Collins marries her.  In general the repellant nature of Mr. Collins is seriously underplayed. He is almost a minor character.Mr. Bingley's married sister and her shiftless husband are entirely missing.  The Bennet manse is presented almost as farm, not a gentleman's small estate.  On the other hand, Chatsworth one of the grandest estates in England, the seat of the Duke of Devonshire, is presented as Pemberley.  This is much grander than Fitzwilliam Darcy would likely to have.  Darcy is not a Duke, and not even a lord.  (The movie script suggests that Darcy owns half of Derbyshire, and nothing in the book remotely suggest this, and if he has "only" 10,000 [pounds] a year--the only sum mentioned in the movie or book--it is highly unlikely that he owns more than a few thousand acres of Derbyshire.  Even the extremely wealthy Duke of Devonshire doesn't own more than a small fraction of Derbyshire.I won't go on with the faults.  Why do I give it 3 stars and even consider 4 stars?  Mainly because the most central points, the evolution of Elizabeth Bennet, full of prejudice and Fitzwilliam Darcy, full of pride, are reasonably well developed and are extremely well acted--particularly well developed for Elizabeth Bennet.  A number (though not all) of the key scenes of this relationship are well presented (though in somewhat truncated form which was necessary for fitting the whole movie into an approximate two hour length required for commercial movies).  Lady Catherine de Bourgh's ill-fated attempt to derail the budding romance between Lizzie and Darcy is well done (though also a bit truncated).  Mrs. Bennet's hysteria was dealt with sympathetically.I have read the book a half dozen times, seen the 1995 (Colin Firth) mini-series version a couple of times and the earlier Elizabeth Garvie mini-series version a dozen times, and so I know the story well enough to fill in for all of the important missing details.  With this prior knowledge, the plusses made it worthwhile for me to watch.  For someone is not particularly acquainted with Jane Austin's book (or last read it in high school many years ago) the movie provides a pleasant love story, even if it is seriously lacking in the subtlety of the original.  Knightley as Lizzie is a delight to look at and Macfayden may be the best Darcy on film--at least as far as the script allowed.But, at best, it is the "highlights" of Pride and Prejudice and is no substitute for the book, or at minimum, one of the mini-series.  As I indicated above the Elizabeth Garvie version of 1990 is, in my view, the best.  Elizabeth Garvie is incredible, she simply "is" Elizabeth Bennet.  This version also adheres closest to the text of the book, and is now available on an inexpensive DVD--which, incidentally, is more complete than the earlier VHS version.  (However, the Lawrence Olivier movie of the 1940s is, in my mind, a complete travesty to be avoided like the plague.)

reviewText: This is a great adaptation.  The acting is great and is the directing.  This story is the classic " Pride and Prejudice" story as told by Jane Austen once you've cut out all the exasperating and inconsequential details.  This movie gets right to the point without diminishing the theme or plot of the story.It is the classic tale of Elizabeth.  Elizabeth is smart, but loyal to her sisters.  Jane, Elizabeth's older sister, falls in love with Mr. Bingley.  Mr. Darcy is Mr. Bingley's best friend and insults Elizabeth, but is unaware that she can hear him.  Elizabeth is enchanted by Mr. Wickham.  Elizabeth meets Mr. Darcy and through a series of misunderstandings on both their parts they end up misjudging both each and others.  Elizabeth finds out that Mr. Darcy encouraged Mr. Bingley not marry Jane because he believed that Jane didn't love Mr. Bingley.  Mr. Darcy tells Elizabeth that he loves despite himself.  Elizabeth clears up the misunderstanding that Mr. Darcy had about Jane and she also tells him off.  Mr. Darcy writes a letter and explains the truth about Mr. Wickham and what a leech he is.  Elizabeth's feelings towards Mr. Darcy start to change.  Then Elzabeth's youngest and most foolish sister, Lydia runs off with Mr. Wickham.  Mr. Darcy uses his vast fortune to make certain that Mr. Wickham marries Lydia.  He also gets Mr. Bingley and Jane back together.  Elizabeth finds out about both of these things.  Both she and Mr. Darcy start telling each the truth about how they really feel about one another.  It is not hard to deduce what happens next.All in all this is a great romantic film.  Jane Austen, tends to beat around the bush too much.  This film takes out all unneccessary running around and it gets right to the point without changing the plot.  However if films where the primary focus is romance are not your thing I would advise against you watching this film.  If a person loves a good romance then I would highly recommend this film.

reviewText: P&P; is one of the jewels of English literature. It's very robust in that it is so open to different slants on it. This movie is a new slant and adds beautifully to the Ehle/Firth BBC interpretation. It's the more moving. Jennifer Ehle was my own perfect embodiment of Lizzie but Keira Knightley adds a dimension of extraordinary unfolding of the internal turmoil of Lizzie and her kindness -- the scenes with Jane are so subtle in their deep love for each other. Matthew Mcfadyen is a completely different Darcy from Colin Firth's but far more resonant. It is interesting to see Judi Dench in the film as the dreadful Lady Catherine. I am an old Brit who saw her in many performances on stage -- I think Keira K signals in this film that she is in the same league and on the same growth path.Critics of the film point out that it plays around somewhat with the tone and storyline of the novel. True, but it also enhances one's perspective on this great work. The movie is too kind to Mrs. Bennet but does articulate the truly desperate issue of marriage as the only career chance for young women. Donald Sutherland is a little underplayed especially in not showing his contempt for his wife but brings out so well his love for Lizzie. This is also the best portrayal of Jane I know of.And so on. Yes, this is not the literal adaptation of P&P; but it really is a superb accompaniment to and enhancement of it. Jsne Austen was in no way a romantic but a shrewd and cool observer. She is Mozartian in that the cool and controlled surface is moving in that the depth of feeling their work hides but dignifies is so intense. Only in her last and apparently semi-autbiographical novel, Persuasion, does one get a sense of the depth of her regrets and the pathos of her short life. I think that the main contribution of the Keira/Matthew combination is to bring P&P; closer to Persuasion and unpeel Austen's deep insights into and regrets about love in an age where feelings were so rarely expressed.This is a lovely and loving film. It is almost Chekovian in its style. I hope Knightley doesn't get nominated for an Oscar for her portrayal. It's far too good for that. I also hope she will pick scripts that help her grow beyond the Oscar-ready stuff.

reviewText: Several years ago, I was involved with a lady who told me that I needed to see this movie, as she thought I reminded her a lot of Darcy. (We both HATE to dance, among other things) I was, shall we say, reluctant to believe her, but curiosity got the better of me. After all, I had to see what she was talking about.Now keep in mind that I was supposed to read this book in high school and as a seventeen year old male, I refused on sheer principle. What did I care about some romance book about a bunch of girls who want to marry rich. Who cared?All that said, this movie is a GREAT adaptation of the book (which I have since read, again out of curiosity) It makes the characters both modern and classic without diminishing either quality. The supporting cast is understated, but outstanding. Both Sutherland and Dench deliver superlatively without taking the limelight from Knightly or Macfadyn, to whom the film truly belongs.Even if the thought of having anything to do with Jane Austin makes your skin crawl (as it did with me), give this a try. Guys, if nothing else, this is two hours of the always watchable Kiera Knightly. You could find worse uses for your time.
summary: A period piece romance that even a guy can enjoy

reviewText: Jane Austin's Pride and Prejudice is a comedy. A romantic comedy. This was not.1. The BBC version was probably the best version of Pride and Prejudice. It remains true to the characters and to the tone of the book. It would remain the flagship and reference point for all other P&P; based movies.  I am certain that Jane Austin would have loved it. *****2. I also saw Bride and Prejudice (An adaptation). Although, it was far removed from the BBC Classic, It actually remained true to Jane Austin for the most part. A Comedy. A romantic comedy and very delightful. The Jane Austen Society was so enthused and ecstatic after sitting through a screening, they offered Chadha a lifetime membership. . On my first watch, I was expecting a serious classic and hence was disappointed. But on subsequent viewing, I thoroughly enjoyed the light humorous take on P&P.I; would wager that Jane would approve of Bride and Prejudice. ****3. This version? Well.. It is a romantic movie...but it is not a romantic comedy. It was way too serious more like Bront. Many of the characters were downright loathsome (Lizy's mom and Collins).  In that sense it was not Jane Austin,  But nevertheless it was not too bad. If you are not familiar with the book or the BBC version, this movie stands on its own as a serious romantic movie and very very enjoyable ***I enjoyed all three, in the order I mentioned them,Greatest love stories ever told on film:http://www.amazon.com/gp/richpub/listmania/fullview/R2KA5HYKSJ862R/ref=cm_pdp_lm_title_1
summary: Not sure if Jane Austin would approve!

reviewText: I knew that I wasn't going to like it, and still I watched it. I tried! They got it all wrong on so many accounts that I am trying to figure out where to begin. I really didn't care for this portrayal of the characters, they made the mother look like a sweet little lamb just trying to get her daughters married, Mr.Bingley like a bumbling idiot,and the three youngest girls act like children! Keira Knightley is beautiful, but a woman with that kind of flat chest would have been considerd deathly skinny, and not a man would have wanted her because she has no figure. They also portrayed the Bennets as being poor. Which is incorrect because the man didn't expect to have five daughters and therefore didn't make provision for there dowries.They were actually supposed to be upper middle class people. Lydia Bennet bothers me as does the relationship between Lizzie and Her father. They are supposed to be close, but through out the whole movie there relationship seems strained until towards the end where her father says that he will miss her.Boom! Right out of no where. And Lidia Bennet is supposed to be tall and good looking for her age, that's why she can attract the officers like flies. She flirts and looks cute. But no! The actress that plays her looks like she is a tall twelve year old. And speaking of looks, were they trying to go ugly when they cast Darcey? I thought he was supposed to be rich AND handsome. And if the guy that played Mr.Wickham would have wanted me to run away with him, I would have cried from insault! But, on a lighter note, they did cast Mr.Collins well. He is about as creepy as a little man can get. And this movie has some great cinematography. But the cons definantly weigh out the pros. I almost winced whenever Lizzie or Darcey spoke their lines, their delivery was awful. If you want to see THE BEST adaptation of a truely great story, stick to the unmolested version. Stick with Colin Firth and the BBC version.
summary: Oh! Is Hollywood Really This Bad?

reviewText: Pride & Prejudice is one of my favorite books, I've read it at least a dozen times.  This film version is very faithful to the main storyline and the important side stories as well.  Brenda Blethin (sp?) does a fantastic job as silly, vapid Mrs. Bennett and Donald Sutherland is spot-on as snarky Mr. Bennett. Keira Knightley is not a favorite actress of mine but she does a fine job as heroine Elizabeth Bennett.  Matthew McFadyen is a smoldering, tense, and prideful Darcy.  When he finally relaxes and smiles, your heart melts!  Simon Woods and Rosamund Pike do a beautiful job portraying sweet and affable Mr. Bingley and Jane, respectively.  Caroline Bingley is snotty, proud, and gorgeous.  Dame Judi Dench as Lady Catherine is superb.  She is derisive and arrogant in full measure.  When she confronts Elizabeth...watch out!I ordered the digital copy of this as well as the dvd copy.  The scenery, settings, and music are just lovely.  You will want to watch this film again and again.  And then probably once more.  =)

reviewText: I like this version of Pride and Prejudice because it is so unlike the BBC version and also the book.In a word, it's wilder.Also earthier.Lizzie is much more interesting as a fey gamin who loves to tease people--and this is exactly what Kiera Knightley supplies.  Her shock at Mr. Collins's proposal is palpable.But the real revelation is Darcy.  Instead of the prig he usually seems, here he seems a smoldering, volcanic presence more like Mr. Rochester.Also the setting is smashing--Romantic lush outdoor scenes, very untypical of Austen.Also the earthiness is sublime.  Pigs cavort in the Bennets' house--reminding us WHY Mrs. B. is trying to marry her daughters off: the rigid class system that prevents them from owning land, and prevents them from working.

reviewText: Where is the Austen in this Austen "adaptation"? Little from the original, beyond the names of the characters, remains in this sorry attempt; characters are altered, society is turned on its head, and custom is thrown to the wind - in short, everything that made Pride and Prejudice the masterpiece that it is is discarded in favor of dramatic flare and overblown romantic nonsense. Which is all too bad - Knightley is a capable actress, and, with a script that was worthy of the name, would likely have made a very interesting Elizabeth Bennett. Alas, but this version is to Austen's novel (and previous film interpretations) what a preschooler's scribble is to the Mona Lisa.One of the beauties of Jane Austen's works was her depiction of social reality - the austere social boundaries, the condescension with which those who crossed them were met, the petty grievances and wiles of social climbers, etc., etc. The decision makers behind this film, however, apparently found that all far too tedious, and, in their wisdom, opted instead to introduce a host of classic elements of refined society, such as pigs in the house and a family full of eavesdroppers congregated about every door. While her family was mingling with the swine and fixing their ears to the nearest entryway, this Lizzy, unlike the intelligent but flawed Elizabeth of the book, preferred to simper and smirk more than anything else. Poor Mr. Darcy, however, fares no better, and wanders about aimlessly in this film, seeming at times as if he suffers more from bowel discomfort than symptoms of the heart. The rest of the characters fall into this pattern, seeming little more than absurd caricatures or parodies of the original.The scenarios are no less appalling than the characters. Gone are the societal strictures that governed life, and, in their favor, the annoying banalities of the ludicrously dramatized romance novel. The tedium of proposing in a parlor is traded for the excitement of proposing in the rain; the monotony of social calls made according to the custom of the day abandoned in favor of dramatic confrontations. In short, the authors of this script attempted to apply the formula of the trite, forgettable modern romance novel, with all of its absurd scenarios and fanciful gestures, to a masterpiece of historical social commentary, and a love story worthy of the name. In doing so, they failed to make either a compelling Austen adaptation, or even a tolerable romance.1/5 stars...try to understand the source if you're going to make a film about it...
summary: A cheap, overly dramatized romance masquerading as Austen

reviewText: That being the case. I will always love the 1995 BBC mini series. I could not wait until Keira Knightley's version came to America. However, I do agree that it was shorter and left you wanting.  It was over too quickly and you felt sort of cheated.  I must say I thought the actor that played Mr. Wickam was much better looking than the Mr. Wickam of the mini series.Also, Judi Dench's Lady Catherine lacked character and was not a very good role for her so I was very disappointed. I'm a fan of Judi Dench's. And I really missed Colin Firth. Oh no one plays Mr. Darcy like Colin!  NO ONE.  So, Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth as far as I'm concerned still rein as the only true Lizzie and Mr. Darcy.I might add my sister is a great fan of the BBC version of Pride and Prejudice. She also was just getting over a treatment of chemotherapy for breast cancer and my niece and I decided to have a Pride and Prejudice Birthday party for her.  It was wonderful.  We all dressed in long skirts or dresses, white gloves, hats and we each brought a beautiful tea cup and saucer to the party.  At the end we drew numbers and whatever number was on the bottom of the saucer that matched ours we got to take home.  My sister was overwhelmed and very happy that we did that for her.  We also blew up a photograph of Colin Firth (whom she loves) signed it and framed it for her.  We put that beside her place of honor at the table which was ladened with scones and tea cakes, muffins and teas.  It was great and we plan to do it again this year!  It doesn't have to be anyone's birthday to have a Pride and Prejudice Party!  Step out of this world and into Lizzie's!
summary: Pride and Prejudice-No Other Love Story Matches It.

reviewText: Colin Firth's Darcy versus Matthew MacFayden's Darcy is a matter of taste and endurance.  Colin, Jennifer Ehle, and A&E; articulate all the nuance possible for Jane Austen's text.  Matthew, Kiera Knightly, and director, Joe Wright cut through the fat and get to the meat, which is a good thing.  I have seen both versions (mini series and movie) and like them both.  It's a good thing that there are so many versions of this story available; this is a testament to the value of the basic story.Some may have problems with Joe Wright's 2005 movie version, but it is refreshing to see this interpretation/adaptation of the story.  The Bennets are brilliant cast as very rural gentry, which is what they were.  Moreover, Darcy and Bingley are not overly fastidious, as urbane gentlemen.  Judy Dench, of course, nails aristocratic Lady Catherine.  These are three levels of English society.  Social caste was critical during that time, so it is important that Wright emphasize levels such as aristocracy, urbane gentility, and rural landed gentry.  It is very credible in either version that these city boys (Darcy and Bingley) would prefer country girls rather than too polished city girls, as sometimes the artifice must stop.If pigs in the country offend, or museum-quality mansions on the other side of the country seem cold and unlivable, then stick with the A&E; version, which sticks very close to Jane Austen's book.  This 2-hour movie is refreshing, brief, and "artistic."

reviewText: First off, the casting: Keira Knightley was a good choice for Elizabeth Bennet. She would not have been my first choice after the lovely job by Jennifer Ehle in A&E;/BBC's 1995 version, but Keira played the part very well and I believed in her Elizabeth from start to finish! Matthew MacFadyen as Darcy: all I can say is WOW! MacFadyen is a relative unknown (I know him only as the gambling loser Felix Carbury in Trollope's "The Way We Live Now"): his portrayal was passionate, gritty, determined, loveable, heartfelt and moving: I was completely convinced and fell in love (as other Colin Firth fans will likely do so shortly). Added to these two top-notch choices is some other great talent: Rosamund Pike (Lady Harriet Cumnor in "Wives & Daughters") as Jane Bennet, Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet, Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennet, Tom Hollander (Osborne Hamley in "Wives & Daughters") as Mr. Collins, and Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourg: the only somewhat puzzling choices were Rupert Friend as Mr. Wickham and Simon Woods as Mr. Bingley...they seemed to make Mr. Bingley's character incredibly nave and almost silly in this film (which I must admit, did add some nice comic relief), whereas the 1995 P&P; chooses to make him only too apt to believe the best in everyone too easily influenced by others. Mr Wickham was only slightly likeable to me, and was not given enough screen time for us to truly believe why Elizabeth defended him so much to Darcy. The cast was rounded out with Jena Malone as Lydia Bennet, Talulah Riley as Mary Bennet, and Carey Mulligan as Kitty Bennet, as well as a few others.The overall storyline and feel: I thought they did an excellent job condensing the storyline into a theatrical movie-length version. I was mighty impressed with the screenwriter, and was not surprised to find out that Emma Thompson (who wrote the screenplay for 1995's "Sense & Sensibility", as well as giving an Oscar-winning performance as Elinor Dashwood) did an un-credited and unpaid rewrite of the new "Pride & Prejudice" script: she is given a special thanks in the end credits. The cinematography of the film was well done, with gorgeous scenes and imagery created: the soundtrack score is excellent, soft and unassuming, but seems to blend perfectly with the film: highly recommended. There is little that I would like to change overall: a few content issues (as described below), and otherwise, my changes would be: 1) the final scene: it is a bit too modern-feeling, and not true to Jane Austen as it should be 2) one scene where Lizzie reads a letter: she is upset & crying, only I thought it felt a bit stilted and not quite credible 3) Lady Catherine's speech to Elizabeth: I felt it could have been stronger, and have more "umph" behind it. Set design and costumes: the costumes work perfectly with the mood and feel of the film: at first I was a bit disappointed that they put Elizabeth in so much brown, but it works very well with the grit and feel of the film (and makes it seem much more real), and there are times (like at the Netherfield Ball), when you get some gorgeous white & light-colored costumes on the characters (including a beautiful snow-white dress on Elizabeth, with a lovely upswept hairdo). I thought the set design was very well done, and loved the very realistic feel of the film: the comparison between the Bennet house and Pemberly is quite drastic and added to the credibility of Darcy's wealth.For those of you interested in "family-friendly" remarks, read this paragraph, otherwise you can skip to the next one. Content: There is one scene with a character walking through a room full of white, marble statues, mostly nude, and admiring them: mostly the shots show behinds, though some naked breasts are shown as well in a ceiling painting. There is one use of a*s, and little else in the way of language. There is some dialogue that alludes to the fact that an unmarried man & woman ran off together, not necessarily with any plans to get married, but it is eventually resolved; there is some cleavage shown, but nothing too drastic. All in all, the content is kept to a minimum.This beautifully-filmed and well-acted movie is well worth the time & effort of going to the movie theatre, in a day and age when there is often little that does such. The romance they created in a few scenes was, I felt, beyond compare. For those of you who loved & enjoyed A&E; and BBC's 1995 version of "Pride & Prejudice" with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, you are in for a treat: there are enough differences in the movies to make them both loveable, but enough similarities in dialogue that you don't feel you are missing anything. This new film & soundtrack is highly recommended (I bought the soundtrack from Amazon UK a month ago, as it is being released Nov 15th in the USA): this movie will also end up being a must-add to any woman's DVD collection!!

reviewText: I've read Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, Emma, and Sense and Sensibility.  She rivals Shakespeare as the greatest artist of English literature.  Both writers were concerned with basic human motivation, but Austen limited her observation to what she knew best, the courtship of 18th Century men and women of all classes.  She particularly enjoyed matching rather struggling middle class girls with the Bill Gates of their day, the local nobility.Keira Knightley makes a lovely Elizabeth Bennet.  She's has every virtue and flaw that her love match, Mr. Darcy possesses, and there is the problem.  They are so alike, they are blind to each other's virtues initially, obsessing upon their human foibles instead, mostly their unmitigated pride.  But what smitten couple of any century is any different.  Ah, Austen is universally appreciated since she spotlights what most Earthly inhabitants will encounter one or more times in a lifetime, love.I think I may prefer the Laurence Olivier version made in the 1930's.  After all, his Darcy is superb, never to be duplicated, but this newer version uses modern color cinematography to advantage.  Jane Austen is always worthwhile.  This is an excellent rendition.

reviewText: How can you not love a movie when it starts off with a woman reading a book, completely distracted by her intellectual pursuits? Then imagine this woman walking with vibrant piano playing in the background and her dress flowing in the breeze. Put her in an idyllic country setting and then set up an impossible romance. Then surround her with four lively sisters who love to dance and live for the faintest moment of romance. There are so many scenes in which these women amusingly listen at doors or giggle while discussing men. It is simply made even more intoxicating when these women engage men in witty banter. Truly, Elizabeth is a radiant delight. There is one scene where she expresses her utter disdain for Mr. Darcy and they almost kiss. The tension is unbearable but I completely adored every minute of it. To top it all off, this movie is so superbly filmed it makes other movies pale in comparison. The timing in every scene is impeccable and the precision is an absolute wonder to behold. This is now my all-time favorite movie. It is just indescribably beautiful. This is truly a movie I will enjoy again and again. Thank you to the friend who sent this to me for my birthday! What a lovely surprise. If I could give this movie 100 stars I would!~The Rebecca Review

reviewText: The only thing between Elizabeth and Darcy is their tender egos (pride) and misconceptions of each other (prejudice). A simple story based on the timeless theme that you truly come to know yourself through the eyes of the one you were destined for. Lizzie has her eyes on everyone around her, noting their flaws, and has a very small circle of people she believes in. Through Darcy she is able to see that she doesn't know everything, that she has faults and makes mistakes, but that she is still a person of integrity and worthy of love.
summary: I Love, I Love, I Love You

reviewText: Anytime I want to feel better, I watch this movie. I could watch this movie a million times (Really!) and not get bored. When I was in high school, I read Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice". It was honestly one of the few books I've read in my entire life (and I've read many books in my life) that literally had my heart beat and race at a fast rate. I couldn't put the book down. Jane Austen was one of the best writers of all time. You truly feel, sense, and live through her writing when you flip each page of her books. Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfayden do an excellent job in this film. The whole cast is great, but it is Keira and Matthew's acting that make this film so beautiful and emotional. If I had a fantasy romance, I would want it to be like this film's version of "Pride and Prejudice". I've seen all the movie versions of "Pride and Prejudice", and this is absolutely my favorite version. I highly recommend this movie to add to your movie library. It's a true classic!

reviewText: After hearing sterling reviews, I decided to find out what all the fuss was about. I am SO glad I did. The music lets you know right from the beginning that this is a love story/epic, and uses period-style melodies that draw you into the narrative. The attention to period detail hasn't been so impressive since Polanski's "Tess". And the acting couldn't be more pitch-perfect. Indeed, Keira Knightly was the headstrong yet vulnerable Lizzie, and Matt MacFadyen managed to get better looking as the film went on, to the point that it was almost a distraction. We are seeing Darcy through Lizzie's eyes. Wonderful supporting performances from Brenda Blethyn, Donald Sutherland, and a particularly bitchy Dame Judi Dench, as well as everyone else, certainly add to this most pleasurable film experience. I'm hoping the Academy won't write this off as just another adaptation of a classic. This film can stand on its own as entertainment right alongside any of 'em. The DVD is terrific.

reviewText: I quote Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice. Last month my fiancee and I went to see the film, starring Keira Knightley and company.Any period piece film adaptation draws an inevitable comparison against its novel roots. I have to say that, for the most part, the film does well with its translation. I had been concerned with the casting of KK in the lead heroine role here, but she does a good job with the material, and the emotional range she conveys with her facial expressions rather caught my attention. The rest of the main cast are solid choices as well, and it is nice to see a fellow Canadian, Donald Sutherland, continuing to find work at his age! I was left wondering if Dame Judi's character was supposed to be so one-dimensional, as it has been a long time since I've read the book, but it's only a little nit, nothing more. Matthew MacFadyen, does an excellent job with Darcy, leading us to see a complex character from a distance, literally, as the characters' pride keeps the two main characters apart so often.My main complaint is with the ending. If the movie had ended with the novel's ending, it would have been perfect. The "Hollywood ending", with "the big kiss", sticks a dagger into the spirit of the times, and of the writing--romantic love was supposed to be implied, not shown. Not sure what the movie makers were thinking--did they think this would be a big box office draw? Ah well.I do recommend the movie though. It's well acted, and well produced, and shot in spectacular scenery. It's, uh, safe for kids, but they'd better be able to keep up with "fancy talking"!
summary: "For what do we live, but to make sport for our neighbours, and laugh at them in our turn?"

reviewText: I must first confess that I am the typical man. True to my kind, my favorite movies heretofore tended to be triumphant accounts of victory such as “Miracle”, “Invictus”, “Secretariat” and of course “Gladiator”, coldly avoiding romantic movies as a waste of time!I only watched this film because Mrs. Douglas, my high school English teacher, required my class to read the book.  However, either I didn’t read it well or as a result of my failing memory I couldn’t recall what it was about.  I did, however, recognize the title as I clicked through the cable guide.  So, on a whim, I began watching it and shortly after the beginning I found myself captivated, frantically hitting the record button!I adore this 2005 interpretation of Jane Austen’s novel.  Keira Knightly is divine and Mathew MacFadyen as Mr. Darcy compliments her charming yet feisty portrayal of Miss Lizzie Bennet perfectly.Though previous renditions of Jane’s novel may be more faithful to the story line, the 2005 film boldly strays, offering a story deliciously saturated with laughter, riotous gaiety, humor and, of course, seething emotion.  I feel Jane herself would not have objected.  This version skillfully contrasts the grandeur and spectacle of Georgian England society through its display of the fictional estates of Netherfield, Rosings Park, and Pemberly to the earthy likes of Longbourn.  I know many criticize how Longbourn was represented in the  movie, but I felt it deepened the theme of the story.  So get over it!As for my avoidance of romantic stories, I’ve been so blind.  This movie has bewitched me, body and soul.  It’s an entrancing film, most completely and perfectly and incandescently wonderful.  As for the number of times I’ve watched it, guilt ridden, I can hardly be expected to own to it.It rises to the very top of my list!

reviewText: The acting is decent, though the leads are not at all in the league of Ehle and Firth, from the BBC miniseries. The real problem, however, is that it is an adaptation that tries to shoehorn Pride and Prejudice into a two-hour film. The "set up" for  many situations is weakened or virtually eliminated, so many scenes lack the punch they should have. I think somone coming to Pride and Prejudice for the first time would be bewildered as to what the 200+ years of fuss have been about. Another serious problem is that this drastic condensing eliminates a lot of the comedy in Austen's novel (that the BBC miniseries preserved) -- the character of Mr. Collins is one example, as is the visit of Lydia and Wickham after their marriage. And the close relationship between Elizabeth and her father just doesn't exist in this one. I'm afraid the BBC miniseries still rules, hands down!
summary: Two hours can't do it justice

reviewText: In the past week I have seen a movie that I thought I was going to love but ended up disliking and a movie that I thought I was going to dislike but found myself loving.  The former was BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN, which I found physically beautiful to look at, but whose characters I found to be uninteresting and bland.  The latter was PRIDE AND PREJUDICE.  The reason I thought that I was going to dislike it was the existence of an absolutely superb BBC mini-series, which seemed to me to be the last word on what could be done with Jane Austen's masterpiece.  I was wrong.  Not only is there room for a truly great six-hour television version but also for an excellent two-hour cinematic version.I still prefer the BBC version.  There are two reasons.  First, there probably will never be a better Mr. Darcy than Colin Firth.  Laurence Olivier might have had a shot in the 1940 Hollywood version, but that film was destroyed by an almost inconceivable rewriting of many of the key elements (the worst being making Lady Catherine de Bourgh into a matchmaker between Darcy and Elizabeth).  Matthew Macfadyen is an extremely capable Darcy, but it was as if Colin Firth were born to play the part.  The other advantage of the BBC production is time:  there is simply no way that a two-hour movie can do as good a job of adapting the novel as a six-hour production.  In watching the BBC version, one gets the sense that almost nothing of importance gets left out, whereas with the movie I found myself constantly regretting parts of the story that had of necessity to be left out.Nonetheless, there is no questioning the excellence of this new movie version.  Simply because the series does a fuller job of telling the story does not mean that this movie cannot excel in a shorter time span.  The film definitely feels abridged, yet one also feels that most (though certainly not all) of the most important bits have been retained.  With most adaptations of a novel this might not have been such a problem, but PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is one of the best known and beloved novels in the English language (I have read it five times, see the Garson-Olivier version twice, and the BBC version three times).  Given the time restrictions, I believe the movie did as good a job as is possible.The film does have some advantages over the television version.  First, it is remarkably gorgeous to look at.  Whether we are beholding household interiors or shots of the countryside, this film was a delight to behold.  Also, with the exception of Jena Malone as Lydia and the aforementioned Colin Firth, most of the performances in the film version are a bit stronger.  I wouldn't say Keira Knightly is better than Jennifer Ehle, but she is definitely a different Elizabeth.  Let's just acknowledge that both are superb.  I recently saw Kelly Reilly (actually, all of Kelly Reilly) in the wonderful MRS. HENDERSON PRESENTS.  Here is plays Miss Bingley and does a fine job.  Rosamund Pike is excellent as Elizabeth's slightly more beautiful sister Jane.  Well, she isn't noticeably more attractive than Keira Knightly, but she'll do.  Two supporting performances stand out.  First, Tom Hollander was superb as a completely different kind of Mr. Collins.  In all other versions, Collins is presented as an utter buffoon.  In defense of previous versions, Mr. Collins is a buffoon in Austen's novel.  But it is nice to see him as slightly less absurd.  And Brenda Blethyn, one of the great actresses of her generation, manages to make Mrs. Bennett into more than merely a silly cartoon.  In his book ASPECTS OF THE NOVEL, E. M. Forster makes a distinction between flat and round characters and argues that Jane Austen loves to mix the two types.  His example of a flat character is Mrs. Bennett.  And while it remains true that Ms. Blethyn isn't able to transform her into a deep character, she does keep her from being the silly twit seen in previous versions.  The one other character that did not appreciably improve upon the BBC production was, surprisingly, Judi Dench's Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  Part of the problem is that most of her scenes were shot in a somewhat subdued manner; partly she obviously decided not to play the role as a broad character.Finally, the movie works in very large part because of the chemistry between Keira Knightly's Elizabeth and Matthew Macfadyen's Darcy.  Though one genuinely misses the many big scenes early in the story in the BBC production where Darcy's pride is made manifest and Elizabeth forms her prejudices, in the romantic portions they are great together.  Also, Knightly is one of the few actresses to play the part and be the age that Elizabeth is actually supposed to be.  All in all, they click onscreen.So, I guess this should be a lesson that you shouldn't prejudge a film.  You actually can be surprised.  In fact, in the past couple of months, the two films that I most enjoyed in the theater were two that I didn't expect to like, the other being KING KONG.  So I suppose this is a lesson previously learned that has now been reinforced.
summary: A movie I loved that I truly expected to dislike

reviewText: I have now seen every filmed version of this, the Jane Austin masterpiece, and have loved almost every version, because no matter the actors, the love story, as it overcomes pride and replaces prejudice is eternal. The original film was the only big disappointment--but my father, who was an English teacher, loved it.  The "insufferably noble Greer Garson" as Pauline Kael called her looked more like Mrs. Bennet than Lizzie, but Sir Laurence Olivier certainly made a handsome if somewhat earnest Mr. Darcy.  In one BBC version, Judy Parfitt played the most imperious Lady Catherine and in the last BBC performance Colin Firth made men's and women's hearts beat as the truly inscrutible and mysterious Darcy.  However, this film has its own blessings.To begin with the Bennet household looks more like the eighteenth century truth of country living than the prettier versions.  Jane is truly vapid in appearance while sweet and trusting on an intimate basis and deserves the incredibly rich and awkward Bingley.  The other Bennet daughters are irritatingly silly and Brenda Blethyn is good--although I have seen more harried and neurotic performances.  But the Lizzie of Keira Knightley and the Darcy of Macfadyen are such that there can not be a dry seat in the house at the film's conclusion.  The impish nature of Knightley and the incredibly haughty disdain of Macfadyen make the final pairing something to long for, since it seems so unattainable.  Their youthful sexuality and the characters' cast iron personalities are lusty and appealing and their "climax" scene, in the pouring rain, in a verdant English garden is charged with emotion and longing--especially on the part of the viewer.  It should be pointed out that they are standing in a palladian "folly" in the garden which makes a delightful subtitle to their recognition scene.  Judy Dench chews up everything and everyone except Keira and is unfortunately denied some of her best lines when she has her final confrontation with Lizzie.  She would have delivered them in full throat throttle.  But these are insignificant notes to a beautiful production.  Lizzie and Darcy meeting on a foggy meadow is the stuff of romance and with these two actors the sexuality crackles like lightning.If you have seen the other versions of this film, please see this one to make the experience complete.  If you have never seen a version of this film, this is a great film to begin with--and then work your way backwards.  As for me and Jane Austin, Lizzie says it best when speaking of her obsequious cousin who is living on Lady Catherine's gifts: "I am sure that her blessings could not have been bestowed on a more grateful subject."
summary: Never is there enough pride and prejudice

reviewText: ***1/2It seems like every time we turn around these days some filmmaker has been hard at work producing yet another adaptation of Jane Austen's most beloved novel "Pride and Prejudice."  And even though some of the versions have been quite good actually, one can still wonder if this glut is really all that necessary.  The book's two most recent incarnations came in the form of miniseries produced by the BBC, the first in 1980 and the second in 1995.  However, since 1940, there has not been a "straight" (i.e. set in the proper time period) version of "Pride and Prejudice" designed specifically for the big screen.  Well, now we have one, written by Deborah Moggach, directed by  Joe Wright and starring Keira Knightley in the lead role.This latest version is distinguished from the earlier efforts primarily by its grittier, grimier and grungier depiction of life in early 19th Century rural England.  With its peeling paint and dusty furnishings, the film certainly has a less prettified and more lived-in look than we are accustomed to seeing in movies based on Austen works.  Yet, perhaps because we have been spoiled by the marathon lengths of those earlier miniseries, this film, at a mere two hours and seven minutes, feels hurried and rushed as it attempts to cope with Austen's complex tale of the five Bennett sisters and their mother's frantic efforts to marry them off.  We are moved so quickly through the story that some of the more subtle details of character and theme get lost along the way.  Still, it's quite remarkable just how much of the plot Moggach is able to cram into a little over two hours, so that even the staunchest of Austen purists will have little to complain about on that score.What they may have reason to complain about is the fact that the film fails to capture much of the unique humor that distinguishes the novel.  For the most part, the scenes are played much too seriously and "straight," particularly those involving the odious Mr. Collins and the insufferably condescending Lady Catherine de Bourg, who together supply some of Austen's most bitingly witty commentary on the superficiality of England's class-conscious society.  Tom Hollander gives a spiritless, leaden performance as the sycophantic minister, and Judi Dench plays Lady Catherine as if she were taking a stab at Lady MacBeth instead.  The same goes for Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett, whose pivotal role as the droll, dry commentator on the absurd Mrs. Bennett's matrimonial obsessions seems to have been lost on the actor.  Matthew Macfadyen fails to make an impact as the haute Mr. Darcy, although Brenda Blethyn hits the right notes as the grating mother driven to despair at the prospect of her daughters ending up old maids.In the coveted role of the high-minded, strong willed and extremely judgmental Elizabeth Bennett - certainly the most brilliant and fully realized of all Austen's creations - Knightley clearly means well but doesn`t seem quite up to the task.  Her annoying giggle and epicene expression make her far too silly and modern to successfully portray the rational but often misguided 19th Century heroine Austen intended Elizabeth to be.Yet, despite all these weaknesses, "Pride and Prejudice" makes for a reasonably entertaining film, thanks, primarily, to the strength of the original source material and the liveliness of Wright's direction (the ball scenes are exceptionally well done).  The film moves quickly and does a decent job telling its story.  Perhaps if we didn't have better versions to compare it to, this "Pride and Prejudice" would stand up better on its own.  It's far from a failure, but watching this condensed version instead of the two BBC miniseries is a bit like reading the Cliff's Notes instead of the actual novel.  You may be able to get the general gist of the thing, but not that wonderful flavoring that makes the original so special.
summary: gets the plot details right but misses much of the humor
