reviewText: Reflections upon First Viewing:*very beautiful film, wonderful color*satisfying melding of the common and the great: landscapes, housing, costumes, etc., allows for the disheveled as well as the pristine*satisfying cast*distracted somewhat by previous knowledge of both the book and the earlier BBC version; so difficult to avoid comparison*extraordinarily quick pacing in dialogue, gestures, behaviors and changes of scenery*Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet a fiery personality*Sound Track understated, even sparse; a decision most agreeable*assumption that we know the story*presents as good abstract or condensed version of book (despite artistically based alterations)Reflections upon Second Viewing:*Elizabeth deliciously sultry at times*Jane Bennet (Rosamund Pike) quite the `babe'*crowd scenes so densely populated*Caroline Bingley (Kelly Reilly) - "weaned on a lemon"*Chapt 6 - removal of the crowd for a few moments at the dance a telling moment*Mr Collins (Tom Hollander) so satisfyingly smarmy*Chapt 9 - if ever eyes were incongruent with words . . .*Sisters delightful whether bonding or squabbling*Charlotte Lucas character (Claudie Blakley) nicely done*Dame Judi as Lady Catherine her usual delightful pedantic and dour self*Donald Sutherland as Mr Bennet not the usual immaculate stuffed shirt/neither his bookroom*a wondrous study in facial features (what if film in B & W?)*Chapt 11 - ArtWorks at Pemberley most revealing, as are Lizzy's reactions*Chapt 14 - Lizzy and Jane's bedtime conversation telling*Chapt 14 - Lizzy and Lady Catherine's heated dialogue some of the best writing and acting in this film*Chapt 15 - Lizzy's final conversation with Father most satisfactory*Chapt 16 - not bothered by the `kissing' scene/the Americanized romantic closure we crave*lack of printed DVD chapter list, cast list, etc., a shortcoming*Trailer on DVD Extras?*well considered, well produced and legitimate addition to the Austen VideographyReflections upon Third Viewing:*appreciative of why Lizzy would seek out and enjoy solitude and silence*adjustments being made, pacing more agreeable*development of secondary characters?*so much revealed to us without words!The film is worth your time, perhaps even in multiple viewings. I think you'll pick up far more that way, if you're willing.Four Stars, I think.Russell de Ville14 March 2006

reviewText: Even as abbreviated as it is, this version of Austen's classic story is a revelation -- for once, we have a real sense of the Bennets as a middle-class country family, with pigs and chickens in the garden and crowded, energetic rustic dances for amusement.  The Bennet girls' hair is disheveled, their clothes are plain and unadorned -- in short, they're real.  I had my doubts that both Knightley and MacFadyen would be suitable in their roles, but in the end they are the most purely romantic, emotional Elizabeth and Darcy ever (and yes, I'm a great fan of the Ehle/Firth version).  This is the only version that has ever made me cry!  I just love it.

reviewText: When a coworker told me that a new version of Pride & Prejudice was in the works, I took interest.  She then said that Keira Knightley would be in it.  I innocently asked, "Who will she play?"  "Elizabeth, of course."  "But," I protested, "she's too pretty to play Elizabeth." I was thinking that unless the screenwriter excises Darcy's offensive comments about Lizzie's looks, this casting choice would be unconvincing.  In the 1940 version (with Aldous Huxley as screenwriter), Darcy (Lawrence Olivier) says that he has no time to humor the middle classes, sparing Greer Garson the evaluation of being "tolerable, but not handsome enough..."This movie has many great qualities. It is far "earthier" than the A&E;/BBC 1996 production, as swine roam both outside and inside the Bennet's house, and the characters look like they've worked up a good sweat at the country dances. I also like how much more tender Mr. Bennet's character is than in the book and other productions.  Granted this is an apocryphal character interpretation, but I really liked it just the same. Donald Sutherland's take on Mr. Bennet is one of his finest performances of my awareness. Instead of continuing to chide Mary that the other ladies need a chance to exhibit their musical talents, he comforts his sobbing daughter.  Another point that I liked is that the characters really look their age.  Though I love and still prefer the A&E;/BBC production, all of the Bennet girls were played by grown-up women well into their twenties and beyond.  In this production, Lydia does look like a 15-year-old girl and Lizzie like a girl who's not yet one and twenty (with four younger sisters out, your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own my age).Due to time constraints, this movie didn't get the opportunity to really fine-tune character development and relationships. The A&E; Adrain Lukis' Wickham was so dastardly charming, yet Lizzie's initial attraction to (Rupert Friend's) Wickham and later repulsion towards him was put on fast forward and barely developed due to the movie's two hour time frame. And the man who played Mr. Collins in the A&E; production was brilliant--he apparently was cast because he was the only actor who could keep a straight face while saying some of "the most fatuous" lines Jane Austen ever penned. Also, Colin Firth is the hottest Darcy yet on film. Not to disparage Matthew Macfadyen, but Firth's Darcy is an impossible act to follow (though in his own right, Macfadyen did a good rendition).I enjoyed this movie and enthusiastically recommend it.  However, I still prefer all five hours of the 1996 version.
summary: Even w/o Colin Firth, still an enjoyable adaptation

reviewText: The current version of "Pride and Prejudice" starring Keira Knightley is a travesty. Do not see it in a theater, buy it, rent it, or watch it on television. It was a waste of time and electricity to make, and will be a waste of your time to see.There was a full-length version of "Pride and Prejudice" filmed in 1995, starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth, that remains not only unsurpassed but unequaled. It is perfectly adapted, cast, directed, acted, costumed, filmed, and scored. It preserves not only Jane Austen's intent, but the dialogue she wrote. Buy it and watch it instead.When she starred in the 1995 film, Miss Ehle did not have the blandly "beautiful" features or skeletal body of a model. She was, nevertheless, captivating as Elizabeth Bennet. The beauty--spiritual, intellectual, and physical--of the character she portrays increases in our esteem as we get to know her, just as it does in Darcy's. Elizabeth, as written by Austen and portrayed by Jennifer Ehle, was a mature and fascinating young woman, not a giggly,  petulant teenager with an eating disorder.Keira Knightley looks desperately in need of nourishment, and the "lollipop-head" figure does not work for the character she is playing. It's hard to believe that a girl of Elizabeth Bennet's time, place, and social class could have grown up so emaciated, unless she had a tapeworm.And, finally, there are many, including prominent professional critics, who commend this adaptation of "Pride and Prejudice" for its "realistic" portrayal of dirt, unkempt clothes and hair, farm animals wallowing in the living room, etc. In fact, it is not only historically unauthentic, it is false to Jane Austen. There were no such scenes of squalor included in the novel. To the contrary, Austen wrote a passage in which Elizabeth Bennet sets out on a long walk after a rain storm to visit her ailing sister, during which she soils the hem of her skirt with mud. This slight soiling results in a small amount of embarrassment for Elizabeth, who tries to let down her outer garment to hide it, and a great amount of derision behind her back by two nasty female residents of the house she is visiting. Had dirt and shabbiness been the norm in households like Elizabeth's at the time depicted, it is unlikely a little mud on the edge of a skirt would have attracted anyone's notice or rude commentary, and these events in the book would have made no sense. The fact that Austen wrote such a scene and had the characters behave as they do indicates that cleanliness and neatness of dress were normal and expected at that place and time, among that class of people.

reviewText: How does one steal a movie that sees both Donald Sutherland and Judi Dench hit high notes as supporting characters?  Keira Knightley does it by (a) playing one of the best roles in Western literature in Elizabeth Bennett and (b) nailing it.This adaptation of Jane Austen's beloved "Pride and Prejudice" is a bit more scruffy (and therefore realistic) than its natural complement, Emma Thompson's adaptation of Austen's "Sense and Sensibility."  Everyone looks gorgeous, or course, but they also don't look like they had Hollywood hair stylists, either.  This helps the movie, as it underscores Austen's theme - England was a dangerous place for young ladies unable to get married.Indeed, just as with "S&S;," marriage is the peril and promise for all the characters in the story.  Does a woman grab what she can and hope to make the best of it?  Or does she hold out for true love?  And what do two lovely parents (Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn) do when they are relatively poor and (gasp!) unconventional but have five daughters they need to send into wedlock?One is to be delighted when a rich young man rents the nearby manor and brings along his dark friend, Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen of "MI-5" fame).  Lizzie and Darcy fall for each other immediately, but are compelled by circumstance as well as Lizzie's pride and prejudice (you knew they'd turn up somewhere) to go through one of the greatest love stories of all time.This is a gorgeous, funny movie with several thrilling ball and dance scenes, and the camera quietly does yeoman's work as it wanders through chambers and down hallways to keep the large cast in play and the viewer well-grounded in the story.  Of course the camera also knew to linger often on Ms. Knightley's beauty just often enough!  But she is no mere adornment - this is an excellent acting performance worthy of watching on its own merits.  Watching Lizzie how head-to-head with the rich society dame who hates her (Dench) is worth the price of admission.I have not read "P&P;," so I cannot respond in detail to those who complain that the filmmakers have rewritten the story somewhat.  All I would say is that there are plenty of other "purist" adaptations of this story as well as the book itself, and that judged on its own merits, this is one heck of a film.
summary: Keira Knightley steals the show in wonderful adaptation

reviewText: When version first came out, I watched it with great anticipation for liking it.  I love Jane Austen, have a Jane Austen related web site, and I am pretty easy to please when it comes to Jane movies.  But I really disliked it.  This past week I thought I would give it another try, and watched it again.  I still really really disliked it. I just think it was poorly portrayed. The Bennet family is made to look excessively poor, grimy and shabby, and not portrayed as the gentlemen's family that they were. Kitty and Lydia were just foolishly, cartoonishly ridiculous, to the point of absurdity. The ball scenes were frenetic and overly crowded, again to the point of absurdity. Keira Knightley's Elizabeth was not likable in any part of the movie - her portrayal was too modern. The entire pace of the movie was too fast - the dialogue was so fast to the point of not being able to understand it at times (and I am not old and I watch British period dramas frequently and so am used to the language). Mr. Bingley seemed a buffoon, which he is not. Mr. Darcy was just never appealing. Their eventually romance seemed implausible.  The whole thing just seemed forced. Jane Austen's subtle humor was never fairly portrayed.It seemed like they wanted give these characters a modern feel while keeping them in early 19th century setting, and it just didn't work. I'm all for modernizations and retelling of Pride and Prejudice, and am a HUGE fan of the Lizzie Bennet Diaries on YouTube.Of course, by far the best Pride and Prejudice portrayal is the Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth 1995 BBC version. Well worth the $4.99 on Amazon Instant Video.Episode 1
summary: I guess I'm one of the few that really dislikes this version

reviewText: This is a really engaging and quite authentic production of Austen's great work. There is less of the frothy romaticising of the time and much more of gritty determination to represent the period and the evidence of class division. Equally, Austen's great wit and simmering sarcasm are brought to life more vividly. I have been given to be a little harsh about the artisitic ability of Keira Knightly in the past, but here she utterly redeems herself and shows a level of talent that is confidant and appealing. She injects into Elizabeth Bennett, the fiesty and forthright nature, out of tune with the requirements of her time, that I believe Austen intended her to have. The relationship between Knightly and Pike (Sisters Elizabeth and Jane) is girlish, affectionate and charming. Brenda Blethyn is perfectly dotty and anxst ridden as Mrs Bennett is intended to be and Donald Sutherland is world weiry whilst dotishly  parental.The simmering romance is evident and heartfelt and for all that people have long adored Firth's Darcy, Macfadyen injects this awkward and snobbish, cold-fish with a sense of heartbreaking tenderness and vulnerability not before seen; and it is all the better for it.Dench is utterly and obnoxiuosly brilliant and the Grand and Judgemental de Borg. And the sets are magical and actual representations of great English homes of the period. Well worht the effort and thoroughly well done for it's quality of acting, sense of action and pathos and departure from the frothy nostalgia of so many classic novel, film versions.

reviewText: This movie is reason enough to contemplate burning the book.  Although Jane Austen's original work was not the best, this movie is the epitome of monotony.  Nothing interesting happens at all.  It is essentially one of the most generic and boring styles of cinema: a love story with no twists and no added elements of suspense or uncertainty.  Again, Hollywood fails to do anything more than reprint a book on screen and bore us all to death in the process.  Make no mistake:  the book itself had many flaws, and though considered a classic work of literature, it was incredibly slow-paced and left the reader searching frantically for adrenaline to keep his or her heart beating.  Nevertheless the movie falls into this trap in a far worse way than the book; by the end, you seriously wonder what happened to the last two hours of your life.  The conclusion is unfulfilling at best.  You know precisely what will happen from about twenty minutes in, and it never changes.  No surprises whatsoever.  Even by today's low standards for cinema, this is pathetic.  I honestly cannot see why anyone would want to see this movie, and I've been pondering the positive reviews on amazon.com for hours.  It is not nearly as good as everyone else believes and certainly not worth eight dollars.
summary: A Travesty for the Body, Mind, and Soul

reviewText: I've seen all the filmed versions of Pride & Prejudice, and found each one to be enjoyable in its own unique way.There is no reason to remake a film if it is going to be exactly like the one before, and with this latest version of  P&P;, director Joe Wright, who is quite a young man, was obviously unwilling to create just another clone. Instead he has chosen to shock us a little by his attention to realism in the settings and activities surrounding the characters - using social documentary, circa 1797, to emphasize the differences in social status of the family groups in the story.I particularly like the scene where the Bennet ladies visit Netherfield when Jane is sick.  They all sit on the sofa in their best, but dated "provincial" Georgian clothes, while Caroline Bingley is dressed in the height of fashion in an elegant high-waisted Empire gown.Life in an English country manor 200 years ago was far from palatial. Even Great Houses were dark and drafty and often dirty.  There was no indoor plumbing, electricity, washing machines, drycleaning, cooking ranges, refrigeration, vacuum cleaners, or central heating. Fireplaces smoked, floors creaked; roofs leaked; water and wood and coal was carried in; ashes and slops were carried out. Livestock was everywhere and flies followed them. There were not even any commercial soaps or cleaning materials - you had to make your own from caustic chemicals.  New furnishings, drapery and carpets were expensive, and hand-me-downs were valued, even if threadbare and faded.Austen mentions only 2 indoor servants at Longbourn - the cook and Hill, the maid of all work, and both would have worked long hours. The daughters would have had to make up the slack, although Mrs Bennet makes it clear cooking was beneath them.  Even the family's riding horses must do double duty on the farm. Life at Longbourn would not have been up to the standards of Rosings and Pemberley, which though they were palaces, would have suffered the same housekeeping difficulties as Longbourn -  but would have more servants to throw at the problems.Jane Austen devoted few words to descriptions of houses and housekeeping. She expected her readers would be familiar with life in various social milieus. We have been reading between the lines, and our reading has not always been accurate, if one is to judge from the disappointed comments of some viewers.This version will never replace the earlier versions, but it does add another point of view, as the film "Clueless" did for "Emma". Wright has taken some liberties with the characters, making Mrs Bennet more sympathetic.  I found the dialogue was rather mumbled, but,like most Janeites, I  know it  by heart so it didn't matter very much.  I expect the film's biggest audience will be Janeites who already know the story & appreciate a fresh look at it.  Just think of all those versions of Shakespeare's plays & no one has got tired of doing another after 400 years.

reviewText: As a fan of both the book and the 1995 BBC version, I have to say this was a wonderful effort by both the cast and director.The 1995 version is faithful to the novel, but then again, it had 5 hours to tell the story.Time restrictions on this film of course lead to the omission of various scenes and characters but the director gives you enough to understand the story fully.Visually, it's a beautiful piece of film. The sets were awe inspiring. And that sunset scene at the end--oh my, was so glorious.Macfadyen is simply breathtaking as Mr. Darcy. He is easy on the eyes. One thing I loved is that he seemed to really show, by way of his mannerisms, Mr. Darcy's awkwardness and insecurities. When he grabs Elizabeth's hand, that first instant of skin to skin contact, his reaction is heartwarming. In another instance, when he enters the room and surprises Elizabeth, the way he just played with his gloves was amazing and it really gave you insight as to what Mr. Darcy was feeling at the moment. Colin Firth was exceptional as Mr. Darcy but Macfadyen gave him a good run for his money.Kiera did a nice job as Elizabeth. A wonderful effort on her part.All in all, the film was a fine effort. I thoroughly enjoyed it and although I prefer the 1995 version (because of its wholeness and Mr. Colin Firth), the film is a visual stunner, and worth seeing.

reviewText: I am a Jane Austen freak. I love her novels.I am ALSO a HUGE fan of the Pride & Prejudice mini-series with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. It has to be one of the most watched sets of DVDs in my collection.That said, I was expecting to go into this movie and be disappointed. I mean, it was hard enough to adapt the novel into a nearly 6 hour mini series. How in the world would they get it down to 2 hours and 7 minutes? Would it be Jane Austen on speed?I must say, though I was not thoroughly pleased (though I expected I would not be), I was most certainly not disappointed either! :o) All the acting was well done. It was interesting to see different takes on the Bennett girls. After time, I adjust to Keira Knightley's portrayal of Elizabeth Bennett. McFadden wasn't broody enough in my opinion. He just seemed shy more than proud. I must give much credit to my enjoyment of the acting to Mr Bingley. He was PERFECT. :) Yadda yadda yadda. You'll all form your own opinions.My only qualms with the film was the beautiful shots of the country/Lizzie. They were too long! Beautiful, but too long. I think SO much character development/relationship development could have been helped if they would have taken a few less of those shots, and had another family scene. I really missed Lizzie and Jane's relationship. Wickham was nearly cut out! I missed the culture of the time! The lack of showing this really destroyed a lot of Jane Austen's disdain for the upper crust of society.So I'm rambling, but that's how I feel in a nutshell!
summary: Avid fans won't be too disappointed.

reviewText: The most recent rendering of Jane Austen's masterpiece "Pride and Prejudice" is not the A&E; version that I own and adore, but it stands well on its own.I'll admit, being a Colin Firth as Darcy fan, and a huge fan of the A&E; version, I was prepared to dislike this movie, and dislike it intensely.  While it was not as good as the A&E; version, I did enjoy the film.My biggest problems?  First, and perhaps most importantly, the length.  A&E; did a five hour masterpiece, with wonderful character interpretations, dialogue and a general overview of Austen's cultures and times.  This version, coming in at 2 hours, requires certain characters and plotlines to be abbreviated, or left out entirely.  Which leads to problem number two.  Lizzy's Uncle and Aunt Gardiner are barely represented here, although they play a huge role in the book (and the A&E; version).  Bingham's sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Hurst, have been axed.  Caroline Bingley has few scenes.  We never see her meeting up with Jane in London.  Mr. Collins and Charlotte have very few scenes. You are not left with the impression that Charlotte and Lizzy are good friends, but maybe just acquaintances.  Lady Catherine de Burgh (played wonderfully icy by Judi Dench)appears in perhaps two scenes.The Bennets themselves, with the exception of Mr. Bennet, are woefully underrepresented.  Despite the loveliness of the actress playing her, you don't get a sense of Jane's modesty, shyness and affection for Bingley.  You also don't get a sense of the close bond that Lizzy and Jane shared.  Mrs. Bennet in this version lacks the hysterics and dramatics that the A&E; Mrs. Bennet possessed - - to the detriment of this film, in my opinion.  Mary, Kitty and Lydia seemed to be simply secondary characters, at least until Lydia runs away with Wickham . . but even then, the viewer may not have the impression of what a huge lout Wickham is, nor how precocious Lydia was.  All in all, having to tell such a beloved love story, with so many characters, is a daunting task, but a very difficult one in two hours or less.  As a result, this version feels rushed - - there is no feeling that nearly a year has passed since Bingley has seen Jane, or since Darcy and Lizzy first met.Now, what is good about this version?  The two lead actors are wonderfully endearing.  No, Keira Knightly is not Jennifer Ehle and Matthew MacFadeyn is not Colin Firth.  But they are very sweet together and have definite chemistry.  When I heard that Knightley was cast as my favorite literary character, originally, I was horrified.  But I have to say that she does a very credible job.  Again, she plays Lizzy very differently than Ehle does, but it works in this film.  The scenery is absolutely beautiful and the music is absolutely perfect for a timeless love story.All in all, I enjoyed this film.  If I had to choose, I would take the A&E; version over this one - - just because Firth and Ehle are impossible to top, and the five hour mini-series was simply magnificent, in casting, direction, sets, etc.But for a 2 hour Jane Austen fix, this movie is worth a watch.
summary: Not the A&E/BBC version, but still worthy

reviewText: Pride and Prejudice is an old favorite of mine.  Austen has a knack for writing about relationships.  There is a fine subterranean stream of masked sexuality contrasting with the formal social necessities of her era that create a wonderful tension in her novels.  The director picked up on this element and created a wonderful movie.Pride and Prejudice was gorgeously and authentically filmed.  The period was pre-regency--in the early Napoleonic wars--one not so commonly portrayed. The men pose in outfits that evoke some of the portraits of Napoleon.  All of the locations are stunning making the most of ancient trees and beautiful mansions.The film portrayed the ramifications of what it meant to be the daughters of poor gentry in this era.  The girls simply must marry in order to survive.  Yet they were looked down upon for their aspirations to marry well.  Also, their lower social status made them prey to men who might exploit these women for sex.  In most cases marriages were simply financial transactions--merging of assets.Matt McFayden was the perfect choice to play the proud man who is humbled by his love for a woman impossible for him to marry because she is not in his social class.  When he decides that his love for her is so great he cannot be without her, his pride and a series of misunderstandings cause Lizzy (Keira Knightly) to reject him. McFayden and Knightly play the star-crossed lovers with the restrained intensity called for by the social manners of the time. In particular McFayden is devastating as the heart-broken lover.This movie succeeded visually, as a psychological portrait of a social era and most importantly as a great romance.
summary: Hot and sexy, in a mannered English drawing room style!

reviewText: No, really, and I've seen them all. Of course this is my learned opinion so read at your own risk. Keira Knightly - excellent. reviewText: Being fully aware of the backlash stating my take on the most beloved of the works of Miss Jane Austen I shall attempt to be as brief as possible, by purely stating my own opinion.First of all I will admit that this adaptation of the darling tale does speed through a bit faster than to be desired, but one must remember that this version was made for the cinema, and therefore does not have the advantage of the BBC mini series. On the other hand the fact that it is shorter in length makes it much more feasible for the hundreds of viewings I have endured blissfully.However in nearly every other category I prefer this rendition. I honestly find very little fault in absolutely anything in this movie. The principle actors portray each of their characters in the most beautiful, poetic manor. Particularly I adore Simon Woods as the nave Mr. Bingley, his eyes sparkle and I find myself believing every little word he speaks.Joe Wright did the most admirable job directing such a fantastic film, finding romance and tension in the smallest of actions between Elizabeth and Darcy. When Darcy offers his hand to help Elizabeth into the carriage, the moment is just breathtaking. Not to mention the cinematography and scenery are gorgeous scene after scene.Movie aside, the soundtrack encompasses some of the most beautiful music I could imagine; Most of the tracks by Jean-Yves Thibaudet are in high rotation on my itunes, my personal favorite being `Liz on top of the World.'.It's surreal. One of my most favorite, romantic, timeless films I have ever seen.
summary: What are Men Compared to Rocks and Mountains?

reviewText: I was surprised when this version of Jane Austen's masterpiece was released - after the magnificent BBC mini series, I really didn't think that anyone would try and match the unmatchable so soon.However, as this is supposed to be a review of this latest version of Pride And Prejudice I'd better get on with it. Keira Knightley is mesmerizing as Eliza Bennett and I look forward to seeing a lot more of her work in the future.I also loved Matthew McFayden as Mr Darcy,Brenda Blethyn as Mrs Bennett, and Rosamund Pike captured the very essence of Jane Bennett, the eldest of the Bennett daughters.Dame Judi Dench gave a good performance as the interfering Lady Catherine De Bourg but Donald Sutherland as Mr Bennet left me wondering at both his characterization - dirty unkempt hair and slovenly appearance - and how this portrayal in any way came even close to the witty,intelligent and amusing Mr Bennett of Jane Austens creation.At present, Director Joe Wright has teamed up again with Keira Knightley and Belinda Blethyn to make Atonement and I hope his ability to transfer a fine novel to the screen is more successful this time around.Pride and Predujice is so perfectly written, so precisely mapped out by Miss Austen, that any change is noticeable and the changes in story line are NEVER an improvement on the original.The wonder of classics like the books of Austen,the Bronte sisters, Thomas Hardy, George Elliot,is that they teach one about the lives of people in another century, the houses,the customs,the language, the fashion of the day and so forth.So efforts to update or "modernise" should be kept to a minimum.I enjoyed the latest P&P; version, but as a film, not as an adaptation of Jane Austens finest work.
summary: Keira Knightly - Captivating as Eliza Bennett.

reviewText: I resisted seeing this movie for a long time, thinking who needs another P&P;?  It's been done many times, and quite well (BBC miniseries and the Greer Garson, Laurence Olivier versions stand out).  Cynically, I thought this is just another Hollywood grab for some sure dollars.However, I found this version to be refreshing and inspired.  Many people have commented on the youthfulness of the characters, the transposition to more rural as opposed to drawing room settings, and the more unrestrained atmosphere, as opposed to the buttoned-up proto-Victorian image of versions past.However, what I liked about it, was that it had a very clear grasp of the central relationship between Darcy and Lizzy, from the first attractions of their mutual chemistry, to the unfolding and appreciation of their respective characters.  In other hands, the attraction between the two would have been unfathomable, particularly where the dialogue is harsh, but Keira Knightley does a great job conveying the conflict between her head and heart, and the scenes between the two lovers are charged with enough emotion to thrill the heart of any romantic.Because of the intense focus on the central relationship, the other characters sort of fade into the background, and I don't think Mr. or Mrs. Bennett are done as well as in some other versions.  However, Collins and "his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourg" are done very well, and the last interview between Lizzie and Lady Catherine is re-cast very well, and is more coherent.In other words, I think this wasn't just made to make a buck, but made from a sense of trying to draw out some of the themes and relationships and show the characters in a fresh light.I was enchanted.  This is definitely a buy.
summary: Not the same old Pride & Prejudice

reviewText: I took a date to see Pride and Prejudice, and I expected to sleep through the whole thing.  The girl I took was a huge Jane Austen fan, but I never was.  My parents love the A&E version, but I never could get through it.  I went in with the same expectation and was completely wrong.  Keira Knightly's performance is her best to date.  If she doesn't get at least an Oscar nomination, something is wrong.  The film is bright, cheerful, and funny.  The supporting cast is wonderful, but Rosamund Pike and Donald Sutherland stand out.  Guys, don't worry.  I usually hate chick flicks too, but this is one that guys could handle taking dates to.  So don't have too much pride or predjudice, judge it for youself.  And I will buy this one on DVD.

reviewText: I think not. Nor, is he in fact, dead. I loved his masterful portrayal of Darcy, as I have loved everything he does, including Love Actually, but it did not prevent me from devouring this gorgeous adaptation.To me, Knightley was a revelation, and this beautifully crafted adaptation is a showcase for her genuine versatility. When you can hold your own against a goddess of stage and screen such as Dame Judi Dench, you've got something going on. Likewise, in her beautiful interaction with a superb Donald Sutherland, when she is speaking to him about Darcy's marriage proposal. Both actors are just stunning.I love this version equally with the Colin Version, and everything from the cinematography to the casting, production and direction all conspire to make this movie a delight for the senses. Being a fan of solo piano, I also loved the soundtrack (Dario Marianelli), especially the exquisite cascading ripples of pieces such as Liz On Top Of The World.At the heart of this delicious interpretation is Austen's disturbing portrayal of the sheer madness of a blinkered patriarchal society in which females, even brilliant, beautiful and gifted females, could never inherit property. Brenda Blethyn's delightful performance as a mother anxious to get her divine daughters married off, is based on this shameful reality.Even though I had heard many good things about the Knightley Version, it actually exceeded my expectations by a quantum factor, and I cannot recommend this DVD highly enough.
summary: Colin Firth... rolling in his grave?

reviewText: I am not worthy of writing a review of this film, but I MUST try.It seems like only yesterday Codemaster Talon (my genius sister and fellow Amazon reviewer) and myself were sitting in a darkened theater watching previews before some film or other, and saw a fleeting glimpse of yet another Jane Austin inspired film. That was my initial reaction, "Oh no, not ANOTHER one...". And yet, within that short time I was intrigued. The acting looking competent, and the cinematography absolutely breath-taking. "I'll see it for the cinematography alone," I commented to my companion.Now I don't pretend to be half the Jane Austin fan that Codemaster Talon is. I don't pretend to be some kind of literary higher critic or the absolute authority on historical accuracy and proper period acting. I do however, know a good story when I see one. Pride and Prejudice as a story in all it's versions holds a very special place in my heart. You see at it's core it is the story of two very similar personality types who are monstrously incompatible on the surface, and perfect compliments deep down.Elizabeth Bennet is an introvert who acts the extrovert, a whimsical person who is practical deep down, a genius who cares more about her friends' happiness than impressing others, and wishes for true love more than riches. She's a young woman who uses her feelings to deal with the world but most treasures her intuition. Darcy is a person who has all his feelings buried deep down. He's an introvert who keeps to himself unless compelled to action. He's logical and analytical, but treasures his feelings above all. He's blunt with his feelings, because so few people understand them. He's arrogant and proud, but courageous, and noble. In short he's the exact opposite of Elizabeth in every way save one. They are both people who live in their own universe separate from the rest of the world. And they are both VERY stubborn and judgmental.I've seen the old version of this story with Sir Laurence Olivier as Darcy and Greer Garson as Elizabeth. I've seen the gold-standard A&E; version which caused such an uproar with it's amazing dialog and acting. I have never seen anything like this. Never before has the true heart and soul of Liz and Darcy been on display. Never before could I see clearly expressed WHY  they fell in love with each other. In fact, never before could I see a real sign that they HAD fallen in love with each other. Now I see it.A movie is more than just acting with some music and sound effects tossed in, captured through a hand-held camera (despite what Indy film buffs may have told you). A real movie uses the acting to further the dialog, the dialog to further the action, the music to further the moment captured by the lens. Everything pushes  to express feelings and emotions that grab a hold of you and don't let go. I mentioned that the preview for this movie intrigued me because of the cinematography, but I had NO IDEA what was yet to come.Painting with Color, Drawing with LightThe title of this movie appears in a ray of sunlight. The first few minutes take us inside of the Bennet house with a genius that reminded me of the camera-work of The Magnificent Ambersons' greatest shot. And it only gets better. This is not showy camera-work for it's own sake. Everything has a point in this movie. Those opening minutes told multiple stories at once. Those first time I saw this movie beginning made me think first of the  standing of the household (as the lived-in and somewhat decayed nature of the estate was quite apparent), then of the personality of the main character (carrying a book and inside her own world despite all the hustle and bustle around her), and then of the personality of everyone else inside the house, as each person's body language, voice and activity summarized their personality in a snapshot.As the film progressed I witnessed a country party quite unlike anything I've seen in a Jane Austin film before. The party was lively and ecstatic and looked like FUN. And when Darcy and his friend came to the party we could quite quickly see how everyone else was a country bumpkin compared to them (something that was never so clear to me before). More than that, again the use of camera angles and body language spoke beyond the dialog to hint at things unsaid. "Interesting," I thought. "This movie is going to be interesting." Then came the first scene where I honestly was mentally agasp with the question "How did they do that?". Liz and Jane are having a sister-to-sister conversation under the bed covers late at night and the perspective of the camera is the the arm of one sister, then it switches back to the other sister's perspective. "Where's the camera?", was all I could think. Not good camera use, GREAT.There were three moments in this film that  took my breath away (and while it was certainly impressive and added enormously to the picture, the dance between Darcy and Elizabeth where everyone else disappears {an effect executed marvelously here} is not one of them). The moments were these:The ProposalFirstly, Darcy's famous proposal. Normally portrayed somewhat arrogantly on Darcy's part, here it is played with passion, and we can see his heartache. Nay, we can FEEL his heartache. The whole scene happens in the rain, outdoors, with Liz and Darcy starting somewhat apart, and, as he proposes and she rejects him with more and more fury, they gradually get closer and closer until by the end of the scene their faces are nearly touching. I could FEEL the magnetism between the characters. I could SEE for the first time, that it was not HIM that she was rejecting (though she thought she was) but his ACTIONS. Despite her words, she was clearly drawn to him, absorbed in his personality. Though for so long she acted indifferent toward him, seemingly not caring, she was in fact almost obsessed with him. Yeah, I got all that from one scene.On top of the WorldOkay, this was it, the moment when I knew that I didn't just like this movie, I had fallen head-over-heels-in-love! While there are many splendid moments of wide-screen wide-angle shots (YES!), and some super-nice super-close-ups (the beauty is almost too much for my eyes!), this scene truly takes the cake. It starts with Lizzy in a carriage, the camera  on her eyes as sunlight and shadow dance across them. Then, the camera cuts to a STUNNING  shot of Elizabeth standing at the edge of a cliff with the wind blowing against her. The music swells and... GOODNESS. I'm glad I have ears and eyes and life within me to witness spectacles like this.Your Hands Are Cold.I've always loved Darcy as a character, for the same reason I loved Colonel Brandon in Sense and Sensibility. To me he's always been a hero, a great man just waiting for a chance to prove his strength and courage. This is perhaps the most powerful scene of the movie. After a terrible confrontation with the Lady Catherine, Lizzy gets up early in the cold morning and walks out into the hills. Just as the sun is coming up, who appears but Darcy, walking up with his jacket billowing in the wind like a hero's cape, sad, noble, and with depth of emotion to bring you to tears. It's like a hero coming back from a war. As he and Lizzy talk, they draw close together just as the sun is coming up between the two of them. That's what I live for. It's a moment that's so romantic and larger than life that it belongs alongside the greatest from Gone With the Wind and Casablanca. I don't know what else to say.The FilmWhat can I say about the acting of this film? For the first time in ages I forgot I was watching ACTORS and felt like I was watching a story unfold in front of me. I haven't felt this way since I was a kid. I forgot anyone was acting. For the most part, the characters in the film simply WERE. In other words, I smell Academy Awards.Knightley's Elizabeth is sharp, sensitive, sweet, and strong, a fully fleshed out acting job that simply makes us believe she IS the character. Matthew Macfadyen's Darcy is so sincere, so from the heart, that we cannot for one moment doubt his sincerity. He brings new depth to a new interpretation of a classic character. Rosamund Pike's Jane is simply overflowing with sweetness and good nature (and the scene of her leaving to pursue her love in the back of a carriage is feminine beauty personified). Even the so often portrayed as unbearably oily Mr. Collins gets a new spin as played by Tom Hollander. I actually felt SORRY for the guy a few times (trapped as he is in his own ridiculous world and never realizing how absolutely pathetic and silly he seems). Also wonderfully done are the Bennet parents played by Brenda Blethyn and Donald Sutherland. Mrs. Bennet comes across more as a misunderstood sweet parent than a hyper-annoying flibbertigibbet. And Mr. Bennet just has more emotional resonance than in any previous version I've ever seen. Just about everyone is perfectly played in this movie.The music is sparing, but used to great effect. Never overwhelming the action, but rather pushing it, the soundtrack is quite good (I have it). There are moments of supreme beauty to be heard, but on the whole the soundtrack is rather sparse (comes to little more than half an hour).Some reviewers on the Net said that this production was by-the-numbers. I can understand that...if you happen to be color-blind, tone-deaf, and wouldn't know a good script if it smacked you upside the head. This film deserves to sweep the Oscars in every category. So perfect is the camera-work ( I have seen nothing like it since the days of Ford, Cardiff and Kurosawa), the score (heart-breaking), the acting (I love ALL the characters), and the script (it reaches straight into your heart) that EVERYONE should enjoy this film. Like the story that inspired it, it is a perfect marriage of the Male and Female personalities combining the Epic feel and strength of a man's film with the delicacy, beauty, and wit of a woman's film. I had thought long ago that the two great miracles of film-making would be to make the ordinary seem Epic, or the Epic seem ordinary. This film makes the ordinary, the lives and loves of people, into something as Epic as the end of the world or the blazing of new frontiers. I for one shall never be the same. After seeing this film I look at the world in a different way, and perhaps always shall.If this movie has one major flaw it is this: it is FAR too short at 2 hours. This is simply too big a story with too many characters to tell in that short a time. As such a lot of things things had to be spelled-out, and entire scenes and characters got the chopping block. And another reason I wish it were longer: I enjoyed every moment of this film so much I never wanted it to end.  My first words at as the end credits rolled were something like "I can't wait for the director's cut." You could wait for it to come out on DVD, but then you'd have to buy a big-screen TV and a surround-sound system to experience it's full glory. And to see this one on pan-and-scan would be to cut it's head off with a guillotine. In short, THIS is the film that EVERYONE has been waiting for.I tried to write a review. I really did. Words failed me. Please see this film in the theater. Please.

reviewText: This is, in my opinion, a thoroughly satisfying rendition of the beloved novel -- or, at least, it's the film version that I prefer. The acting is outstanding, from bit parts right on through main characters; the settings evocative of place and period; the sets are visions of color, lighting, details that entrance and convince that this is authentic (or, at the very least, a "reality" that satisfies)! Revel in the beautifully chosen colors and luscious tints of walls, gowns/costumes (whether plain or dress formal) and then glory in the sweeping countryside shots...There are some memorable scenes in this one -- enjoy!

reviewText: Read the book, didn't like it, why would I like the movie? The story of a family whose English countryside home and property must pass to the next male heir, just rubs me the wrong way.  There are five daughters in the family, and the mother's goal is to get them all married off advantageously (in case her husband drops dead and they are all kicked out).  I don't remember all the chickens, pigs and goats being all around the house, nor the wash hung on the line. Of course none of the girls, mother or father had to do a lick of work, they had servants for that...the father thanked one of them once for serving the food.  One maid hums as she passes out the clean laundry, so we're supposed to infer that as servants, they were content with their lot in life.Kiera Knightly plays Lizzie Bennet, who is supposed to be not very attractive, but very intelligent and witty. This is not convincing.  Ms. Knightly displayed a disturbing habit of wrinkling her nose and baring her overlapping incisors at the camera at almost every opportunity. In fact, I think her teeth should have gotten second billing.The rest of the story is basically the same as the novel and all following Harlequin romance stories - distant man, girl can't stand him, learns more about him, falls in love (especially when she sees his house), he falls in love with her, oh happy happy joy joy. The mother gets to brag on daughters, keep house, keep servants. Absolutely no contribution to society is necessary. Get what you can, survival is everything.
summary: I Just Don't Like This Story

reviewText: It's so rare to find a satisfying romance at the movies that I nearly dissolved into raptures of delight to discover not one but two of them this weekend! On Friday I had the distinct pleasure of going to see the new theatrical version of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE with Keira Knightly and Matthew MacFadyen. To be honest, I was prepared to be disappointed. I had seen the rather murky looking trailer that made even the gorgeous Keira Knightly look washed-out and blotchy. Plus as we all know, every version of P & P must now be compared to that platinum standard of the 1995 BBC mini-series with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.But I found the new movie to be thoroughly delightful and exhilarating! At just a little over 2 hours long, it couldn't cover quite as much ground as the mini-series (Wickham and the two younger sisters had very minor roles), but it beautifully captured the romance and robust good humor of Austen's story. I was caught off guard by several laugh-out-loud moments.Keira Knightly embodied Elizabeth Bennet's intelligence and wit. (Her portrayal also reminded me a little of Jo March in LITTLE WOMEN.) One glimpse of her smile and you knew why Darcy's heart was captivated. MacFadyen as Mr. Darcy won me over in the moment when I realized his voice had the exact same timbre as Alan Rickman's. The murkier cinematography actually ended up making the movie seem more vital and historically accurate. The gritty images of daily life are contrasted with breathtaking shots of the English countryside, including one of Mr. Darcy striding out of the mist that almost rivals Colin Firth's rising up out of Pemberly's pond on the female gasp of appreciation scale. (Yes, this is an actual scientific device. I have one in my office.)(Originally published on the website of author Teresa Medeiros[...])

That to me is as much success as a romance story can ever hope to achieve, so 5 stars.

reviewText: ****Aah, Jane Austen. The "Harry Potter" of the independent theater chains. Always reliable to pack the theaters. And you can count on a new film based on one of her books every few years.Mrs. Bennet (Brenda Blethyn) is in a state, her family of five daughters is living on borrowed time. She and her husband Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland) live on their current estate as the guests of family members, and it has seen better days. With five growing daughters, she feels it imperative to begin marrying them off, hopefully to rich suitors who can then help provide for Mr. and Mrs. Bennet and the unwed daughters. When word arrives that a nearby estate has been rented by Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods), a rich man from London, she becomes anxious that he meet her eldest daughter, Jane (Rosamunde Pike), scheming for them to spend every available moment together. At the local ball, Jane meets Mr. Bingley and Elizabeth (Keira Knightley), the second oldest of the Bennet children, meets Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen), Mr. Bingley's friend and guest. Just as Jane and Bingley seem to be headed to the altar, Mr. Bingley leaves the estate causing Jane to become distraught. Elizabeth learns that Darcy may have been responsible and her hatred grows. Yet, every time they meet, Elizabeth finds herself more and more attracted to Darcy. But is the feeling mutual?Just when it seems another film based on a Jane Austen book, especially one already made into a film or miniseries at least six times, not counting the numerous other takes on the same material ("Bride and Prejudice", a recent example), could be excessive, this version of "Pride" pushes the envelope, offering something new.One of the best things this film does is cast more authentic looking people in the lead roles. From Knightley on down, all of the actors have a rougher appearance, which seems entirely appropriate for the time. Some previous film adaptations of Austen's work have cast the most beautiful American (Aaaah- Gwyneth Paltrow - choo!) or British actors in the roles. Every time they appeared on screen, it looked like they just walked out of their make-up trailer. Sure, they looked beautiful, but it isn't believable. "Pride" strives for and attains a more accurate depiction.Keira Knightley is very pretty, but she isn't glamorous. Too skinny, which may be the one aspect of her that doesn't fit the period, she otherwise seems like a pretty girl. Her features are not perfect and this helps her seem to be a natural fit for the English countryside. Also, there are many scenes in which she has just come in from a walk, or the girls are laying about reading books, etc., and they don't appear perfectly groomed; hair may be out of place or there may be mud on the hem of their skirt. It works. In one scene, Dame Judi Dench arrives at the Bennet home. Irate, her hair is not perfect, because she has just arrived on horseback. Matthew McFadyen is also very handsome, but he isn't movie star handsome. He isn't as good looking as Colin Firth or Hugh Grant and it seems more appropriate for the role, the setting and the time.Director Joe Wright also does some interesting things with the camera, which may seem strange or obtrusive on paper, but actually make the experience of watching the film more interesting and enjoyable. In one scene, the camera follows Mrs. Bennet through a ball hosted by Mr. Bingley. She passes certain people throughout the filled rooms. When the camera spots one of the Bennet girls, it stops briefly, allowing us to hear their conversation. After we have heard what we need, it picks up and follows another character, past another conversation. Soon, the camera spots Mrs. Bennet again as she finally reaches the outdoor patio for some fresh air. In another, the camera roves across the windows in the Bennet home picking up pieces of conversation in each of the bedrooms, starting with Mr. and Mrs. Bennet. This gives us the feeling we are watching a book come to life, as though we are turning the pages as we read. It is an effective technique, aiding the look and feel of the film.All of the performances in the film are very good. Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen are very believable as the unrequited lovers. Knightley conveys Elizabeth's intelligence, pride and passion, at turns, throughout the film. She is low key, but very interesting. When she initially meets Darcy, she claims her hatred for him and his attitude. Later, as she tells her father she really loves him, he doesn't understand, yet we do. Matthew MacFadyen conveys Darcy's boredom, growing attraction and passion as well. There are more than a few instances when their attraction to one another is palpable, yet because of their misunderstandings, or misconceptions about one another, are unable to act. It seems as though they take shifts; in one scene Elizabeth is in love with him. In others, he loves her. Throughout, reciprocation is prevented by an outside influence of some sort. The final scene is also very romantic.All of the supporting characters are equally believable. Brenda Blethyn is a little over the top, but it works to see her running around, insinuating her daughters into the lives of every eligible bachelor within ten miles. Donald Sutherland is great as the father who is much quieter than his wife, yet he exudes a quiet admiration for his partner. He is also the more level headed member of the family providing calm and serenity to his somewhat overbearing wife. Judi Dench is also memorable as a member of the aristocracy who tries to control the lives of some of the people involved.I don't think we can ask for more in a film adaptation of a book; the characters, their persona, the setting and the feel of the period are all correct creating an engrossing film worthy of any book.
summary: Yet Another Jane Austen Film?... Oh, Yes!

reviewText: The 1995 version of this movie with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehrle was the most beautiful production, filmed b ythe BBC and shown on the A&E; channel. The scenery was luscious, the acting was convincing, and the period of the drama seemed more authentic than this version. Also the cinamentographer had breathtaking views. Also, this 1995 version is light, breezy, and easy comedic drama. I believe this is the movie catapulted Colin Firth's career.  For me, he will always be "the" Mr. Darcy.Now, regarding this 2005 remake, for the film has been remade many times, it was a very drab. I love Keira Knightly, and I thought Brenda Bleven played her part well; however, Allison Steadman, who played the mother in the 1995 version, was very irritating but funny too. I didn't like Donald Sutherland portrayal as the father. To me, he seemed somewhat aloof as the father. Of all the sisters, Jena Malone, who portrayed Lydia, was the most miscast as was the actor who played Mr. Collins. If you get the 1995 version, watch how David Bammer who played this role just makes you laugh at his portrayal of this character. In my opinion, the main fault of this movie, along with the casting, should not have been squeezed into two hours. The 1995 version, on two discs, was just over 5 hours.Andrew Davies, the British screenwriter, really caught the nuance of Jane Austin's book. I'm sure this is the movie that help catapult Colin Firth's film career. In my opinion, he's never had a better role even although he's gone on to have been nominated as Best Actor for "A Single Man", then later won the Oscar for his role in "The King's Speech."  So, please, please see the 1995 A&E; version with Colin Firth, please see it. It is a wonderfully made.

reviewerName: T. Noever "Author of the TETHYS series"
reviewText: First of all, I enjoyed this version; I really did. What it got right is a more distinct sense of the darker and chaotic side of Jane Austen's worlds. There's a lot of melancholy here, which wasn't rendered in the preceding TV series. The Brits--though this time contaminated by French input, which didn't help at all; it seldom does-can do Austen very well indeed when they put their midns to it. The BBC version of Emma with Kate Beckinsale was so much superior to the boring Paltrow cinema version.Where does this latest production of P&P; fail?The first problem coming to mind is the script. Adaptation is an art all of its own, and while the TV series had time to plot out most of the significant narrative strands of the novel, two hours of film doesn't. Purely from a scripting point of view, significant characterizations--'significant' in the sense that they contributed to the explication and bringing-to-live of the central characters--were far too 'pro forma', almost as if they were thrown in because the writer felt that they needed to. The result was that many of them had no function at all, and cluttered up the action and diffused the narrative focus.The second problem had to do with direction. The first half, with the aid of the muddled script, was confusing, unconvincing and occasionally annoying. I loved the deconstruction of the decorous superficiality that adhered to the TV series, and the occasionally chaotic social occasions; but in the end it got too much, and the interactions of the main characters were lost, instead of, as the director presumably intended, contextualized. Also, the sound was awful. The deliberate toning-down and made-hard-to-hear-above-the-din of individual conversations may have had an element of realism, but the strain of the listener, having to work out just exactly what was being said, didn't help one's becoming engrossed in the tale. The vacuous sisters and mother and their hysterical carry-ons also became annoying and were overdone and for too long.Third problem: Keira Knightley. She's a cool actress, who fits perfectly into King Arthur, Pirates of the Caribbean, Love Actually--but here she was very much miscast. If the producers had had any guts they would have cast the incomparable Rosamund Pike in that role, instead of wasting her in the nearly-invisible part of Jane Bennett. Rosamund was the saving grace among the women of Die Another Day, and here, too, she basically stole the show without even trying hard whenever she appeared, whether she said or did much or, as was the case for the most time, not. Keira, by contrast, needs to act-by-effort since she doesn't as yet have enough depth of personality. Too much 'star' and not enough 'character'; quite unsuitable for this part. She battled her way through it valiantly, and I admire her for that, but it just wasn't 'right' for her. The mis-casting was rivaled only by the casting of Katie Holmes in Batman Begins.Fourth problem: just about all the male characters, except for Donald Sutherland, who can do no wrong. That the film should fade out with a shot of him was an unexpected stroke of genius. I wonder if it was scripted that way or a directorial decision. (I never saw the alternate ending, which I probably would have loathed; so let's go with this one and pretend that the other never was).Having said all these basically negative things, I'd like to finish on a positive note, which is that in the second half, when the 'busy-ness' started to abate, the film actually acquired depth and became quite touching. The final scene between Elizabeth and her father was the crown, and if an ending is what makes a movie, it makes me forgive many other mistakes.But just imagine if, instead of Keira Knightley it had Rosamunde Pike who had been doing that scene with Sutherland. It would have been near-perfection.It was meant to be FOUR stars (I entered five by mistake!) and that solely because of the second half and a great attempt to take the saccharine edge off the movie-incarnations of Austen's novels.Till Noever, owlglass.com, Author: KEAEN, CONTINUITY SLIP, SELADIENNA

reviewText: We greatly enjoyed seeing the new adaptation of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice. Jane Austen's stories are rich romances, featuring strong and spirited women who seem like they won't get the man they deserve, and the men are often not what they seem at first blush (both good and bad), but character always triumphs over class and money in her endings. In this story, protagonists Lizzie Bennett and Mr. Darcy spar engagingly like Beatrice and Benedick until the inevitable reconciliation. Keira Knightly is perfectly cast as the spirited Lizzie, and Matthew MacFadyen is marvelous as the brooding and taciturn Darcy. The story has been very nicely adapted to the screen by big screen newbies director Joe Wright and writer Deborah Moggach (though rumor has it that Emma Thompson had some hand in the dialogue; she is credited on the film with "special thanks"), in a sensitive handling that focuses on the romance and the character judgments (and mistakes) that people can make. Beautiful shots of English countryside, together with some very subjective camerawork contribute to the story. (One memorable scene: when Lizzie and Mr. Darcy are dancing at a crowded ball, and for a moment we see the scene as Lizzie does, as if they are the only two in the room, providing a nice depth of feeling in contrast to her seemingly aloof repartee.) The cast are all excellent, but especially notable are Donald Sutherland as the loving father Mr. Bennett (who truly wants his daughter to marry for love), Tom Hollander as the mousy and obsequious Mr. Collins, and of course Judi Dench as the imperious Lady Catherine de Bourg. The costumes, settings, and even the blocking (all that courtly bowing) perfectly recreate the texture of the period. The superb 1995 adaptation of Sense and Sensibility was a hard act to follow, but Pride and Prejudice lived up to our great expectations.

reviewText: Okay, I am a rabid Frith and BBC fan of the miniseries, but I was very impressed with this adaption and found it refershing in it's grounded, youthful take on the story.For starters, there is a very grounded nature to the presentation of the story. Some Austenites got their knickers into a twist because they thought it made the family and their circumstances too drab looking. But I loved it! The Meryton Assembly basically sets the stage for this grounded approach-the dancing looks a little heavy footed, the girls look sweaty, and you can't help but think that someone needs to open a window cause it looks awfully sweaty! But at the same time,it made the story come alive, like you were a fly on the wall, peeking in on Lizzy and Darcy and the rest of the gang.Lastly, I loved the youthful take on the story. I LOVE Firth and Ehle as the '95 leads. They had this chemistry and sensual tension that was electric! But their take was definitely from a mature standpoint-like the way I'd act now as a 33 year old woman. Whereas Macfadyen and Knightley? Theirs is a more youthful, innocent, first love take that I just took to. Great chemistry, Lizzy's a little less cocksure, Darcy's a bit more unbalanced by this attraction, and it felt right in terms of age and stage of development with the actual characters in the book.Great adaption, brisk storytelling, and a wonderfully irreverent tone by a fun director who knew it was a good idea to knock the pedestal off from under our Lizzy and Darcy, and let them be seen in a more grounded light. And ps-I thought Macfadyen, even though he doesn't have that big of a part, was a great Darcy!
summary: I'm a Firth/BBC fan, and I still loved it!

reviewText: With the Colin Firth-Jennifer Ehle BBC version still fresh and available, why anyone thought that making an abridged theatrical version with anachronisms and insipid acting is beyond me. It's illiterate to confuse the srong-willed and unconventional Austen character of Elizabeth Bennet with a modern-day liberated feminist, which she was not and could not have been. The BBC version understood that; this version was silly and superficial, not to mention that there was no chemistry at all between the leading characters. The idea of Mr and Mrs Bennet as a loving couple is completely contrary to the original story. There was no presentation of the absolute necessity for a young woman with little money to have to marry well, and many other essentially interesting plot points were eliminated.  This Mr Darcy isn't haughty and rude, we're supposed to feel sorry for him because he's shy?  Films are different from novels, but if you're going to change the essentials of the story, you might as well update it entirely to the present day, and call it something else, but not Jane Austen's.
summary: Well, I suppose a little Austen is better than none.  Maybe not.

reviewText: I admit it, all right, I liked this movie more than I expected to.  When I first heard that they were making a new version of Pride and Prejudice, I was excited.  Then when I heard that Keira Knightley was playing Elizabeth, I was put out.  Understand, please, that while Knightley is just fine as a pirate-movie chick, I do not believe she has the acting props or even appreciation of the character she is playing (don't take it to heart, Elizabeth Bennett is, you know, the most complex and thoroughly likeable, believable female character in literature.).  She was ok, a little better than I thought she would be, but I did not recognise Lizzy Bennett in her.  Matthew MacFayden I liked more the second time through, but really thought basically the same of him as of Keira Knightley, that he was more a pretty face to put on the screen than a serious competitor for the "perfect" Mr. Darcy.Perhaps my favorite part of the movie was Jane Bennett, who is played very well by an actress whose name I don't know, but who loks and acts the part sublimely.  Sometimes it's hard to like Jane in the book, because she's just too perfect, but she makes you realize why it is that everyone likes Jane, and it was a joy to watch her performance.As for the soundtrack, it was very pretty, but I kept on thinking to myself, "if you're going to sound exactly like Chopin, why not just use Chopin?  He's dead, he's not going to care."Anyway, it was a very enjoyable movie, I went to see it twice and liked it both times, but when you're dealing with a classic like P and P, I think a little more care would be in order.  I have certainly seen worse ruination worked on a book in a screen version however, so some credit goes to the director for restraining himself as much as he did.
summary: Lovely as a movie, ok as an interpretation of the book

reviewText: DO we need another `Pride and Prejudice'? When we have already the excellent 1995 BBC TV mini-series? It depends solely on this - Elizabeth Bennet and Darcy. Without the chemistry between these endearingly headstrong characters, there is no point in making a new film, no matter how much money you spend on the sets and the costumes.The newest version of Jane Austen classic (`Pride & Prejudice') will be met with skepticism, but as far as Keira Knightley's portrait of this feisty heroine goes, it is a perfect success. Forget her terribly miscast role in `Domino,' and enjoy the film's spirited heroine who learns a thing or two about romance in the late 18th century England.Compared with her, Matthew Macfadyen who plays the laconic Mr. Darcy is less advantageous from the first. We have seen impeccable portrait from Colin Firth (and another impeccable one from Laurence Olivier), and who can forget them? Surprisingly, Macfadyen's Darcy turns out a convincing one, the aristocratic image of a person with something repressed deep inside. Unfortunately, he is not allowed to do much in this running time.[MODERN TOUCH ALL AROUND] I personally do not find the modernized dialogues exchanged between the characters so irritating as some viewers say. I know the film focuses the original book's romantic side, and gives less attention to the class structure of the Regency Britain. But if you have to make a 2-hour film, something must go. If romance must go, then ... what is the point of making this film anyway?But I thought first-time director Joe Wright did some missteps during those two hours. He uses too much showy camera works (there is a long one-take sequence in which the camera glides on the dancing floor) while more orthodox way of shooting the scenes are more effective. As to the portraits of the Bennet Family, some might find the eldest sister Jane (Rosamund Pike) is less impressive than she should be, and I for one thought Donald Sutherland, amusing as he is, might be too old for the role of Mr. Bennet.I know `Pride & Prejudice' should not be compared unfavorably with the previous versions though I was, and am, tempted to do so. Still I heartily enjoyed watching this beautifully-shot, well-acted film, and Ms. Knightley's Elizabeth is genuinely lovely and vivid.
summary: As Mr. Collins Says, This Is a "Very Agreeable Alternative": Pleasant Austen Adaptation with Keira Knightley's Vivid Portrait

reviewText: I never saw this movie at the theater, but I purchased a full screen DVD version and absolutely love this movie. I have watched it countless times. Now I realize how lucky I was to get the full screen version. Recently, I borrowed a copy of the widescreen version from my local library just to see how much I was missing. For some reason, though, I didn't enjoy the widescreen version like I did the full screen version. I then used two computers to run both versions at once, cued at the same time, on side by side monitors and then it became glaringly obvious that the widescreen bars were cutting off immense amounts of important parts of the picture. Yes, the widescreen gives the wider shot, but most of composition of the focus of the scenes is not widescreen in nature, so you're not gaining a lot of important imagery from the widescreen format, but you are losing A LOT from the top and bottom that you get with the full screen format. This really surprised me. I've always assumed that widescreen versions were the full picture shown at the theaters. If the widescreen DVD version is the version shown on the big screen at the theater, then the theater audience missed a tremendous amount of the pleasure of watching this film. I have a hard time believing that this could be the case. THERE IS SO MUCH MORE VISUAL PLEASURE WITH THE FULLSCREEN VERSION. For instance, in the scene at Netherfield where Lydia asks Bingley to host a ball, in the shot of Bingley, Darcy, and Caroline, in the widescreen version, Caroline is cut off at the stomach by the lower bar, while on the fullscreen version of the same shot, you see her near fully sitting on the couch in a way that is very expressive for the scene. Frankly, I pity those who have only seen this movie on the widescreen DVD. What a great shame! How can this be? They don't know what they're missing and their appreciation of this film might be greatly improved by watching the fullscreen version.

reviewText: ...and at first, it WAS handsome enough to tempt me...i even bought the DVD.Now I ask myself, "why?" I've watched it only once. I really can't stand it, sorry to its avid fans. But, when one has watched Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth and a 6-hour, faithful-to-the-book adaptation, this really pales in comparison. A LOT. I really don't know what they were thinking when they cast Keira Knightley as Elizabeth. Instead of being a spirited young woman, she seems to be an egoistic teenager who can't keep her mouth to herself.Matthew McFadyen as Darcy was alright, but I agree he was rather wooden- Colin Firth spoke with his eyes, and through this we saw every unshaped thought and desire of his. It really disappointed me how so much of the book was cut (although more could not be expected from a movie), and the unfaithfulness to Austen's time period was simply shocking. When Jane was sick, Mr Bingley should NOT have walked in to see her! It was highly inappropriate and although I sound like a pedant, such small details ought to be considered in making the movie more memorable. Mr Bingley looked like a lovesick teenager, which was irksome too. *Sigh* maybe I expected too much...but is it wrong, when high-quality, endearing literature is in the mix?In its favor; the music and scenery. Both were exquisite, and (to others) patched up the movie's faults. Sorry to sound so harsh, but that's the way I felt.
summary: It was JUST tolerable, I suppose...

reviewText: I liked Matthew McFadden very much as Mr. Darcy.  Though stiff and aloof, he seemed to almost quake with sublimated passion.  It made me think of the many times in personal relationships that you try to convey your feelings--only to end up completely misunderstood!  I also enjoyed Donald Sutherland as Elizabeth Bennett's good-natured but concerned father.My favorite scene was the last--where Mr. Bennett speaks with Elizabeth in his study as he tries to understand how her feelings for Mr. Darcy were able to change so dramatically.  I was very moved but their interaction in this scene--and the joy that came with the understanding of how truly she now loved Mr. Darcy!
summary: An aloof Mr. Darcy's sublimated passion and an affable but concerned Mr. Bennett

reviewText: This was a great movie and relatively faithful adaptation of the book. I just finished re-reading Pride & Prejudice about a week ago and wanted to watch the film, so I rented this and absolutely adored it. It is always tough to make a great book into a movie, but they did a great job with this one: they stayed relatively close to the original, simplifying a few plot lines to keep the story concise and focused. People who have read the book will know there is a lot more to Wickham's story, but you can definitely see why they would limit his time.I think the movie did a fantastic job of portraying the Charlotte/Collins relationship, which in turn highlights the really miserable life options women had in this time frame. As Charlotte says, "I am 27 years old. I am already a burden on my family..."Costume, hair and makeup were all excellent in this film. Casting was wonderful. Cinematography, fantastic.There was so much to like about this movie that renting it just wasn't enough. I want to have a copy for my collection so I can watch it again and again.I have a total book-characer crush on Mr. Darcy, and Keira Knightley did a wonderful job of showing just why Mr. Darcy would fall in love with her. Not only is she beautiful in a very natural way, she is sassy and she doesn't take any garbage from anyone, which was an extremely unusual trait in any woman of her time.Mrs. Bennett was just as fabulously inappropriate as she was in the book.My one disappointment with the movie is that they don't include any of the information that Jane Austen shared at the end of the book about how everyone's lives turned out later on--ie, what is life like for Lydia, Mary, Kitty and everyone else in the family five years down the road. I also thought they could have spent a bit more time highlighting the extremely awkward experience that Lydia's homecoming should have been. It is difficult, with our modern perspective, to really appreciate how just how completely inappropriate Lydia's behavior was.Still, one of the best great-book-to-movie adaptations I've seen.
summary: I rented it, now I'm going to buy the DVD

reviewText: I bought both versions at the same time the Firth 1995 and the above. Which to watch first was my initial dilemma. I decided on the above shorter version first and it was the right decision after having now watched watched both versions. Unlike any devout P&P; fan and not having seen either versions before, I at least can watch it for what it is without any pre-conceived notions. It wasnt long into watching this version which I will call the Knightley version, that I noticed a problem with the sound. I couldnt work out if it was me, the player or the transfer. Five to ten minutes in and I said to myself I cant the heck make out what theyre talking about. Dialogue was drowned out by over-powering background music and ran so fast. I had no choice but to start it again and put the subtitles on which as pointed out by another reviewer were often 3 liners and placed which was a nuisance. For that alone I had to drop 1 star when I would have awarded it 5 stars.Sure there was 'Poetic License' taken in this Knightley version. Like theyre manor was more like a farmhouse and very rough and hardly an upper middle to high class. Donald Sutherland though a great actor imho didnt suit his part, he hardly resembled the English Gentleman of his time, more like Colonial America civil war period. These things aside I found this version to be more dynamic then the Firth version. This version gave more goose bumps, lumps in throat and emotional tears. Knightley was perfect in her role she was more dynamic and head strong then in previous version. What you didnt see in this 2 hr.version I saw in the Firth version to fill in the gaps. Which is why I decided on the right version to start off my viewing. So all in all, dont miss this version, it was beautiful even with some of its flaws. It is as I say far more dynamic then the previous Firth version. I also preferred Darcy in this version.UPDATE:Well after seeing the 5 hr. Firth version I could not resist in watching this Knightley version yet once again. It was as moving as the first time I watched it. Only this time I added to my title review the words 'Magical and Etherial' for it truly is as such. Furthermore re the sound short comings. I viewed it this time without the annoying subtitles and came to the conclusion that whilst the production starts almost with a ball which drowned the dialogue I thereafter was able to go along with the dialogue as I say without the subtitles and was better off for it. One still may miss some dialogue as it is still an imperfect sound, but better to take in all the splendour then concentrate on reading every word of the subtitle. My main gripe is that this production should have been longer with at least 3 hours. Especially missing is a wedding scene in its finale and makes ruse with dialogue depicting post marriage. Nevertheless truly magical and NOT to be missed.If you found this review helpful at all please vote on it. Thanks. Pleasant viewing.
