reviewText: Jane Austen affected a sea change in the novel in the early 1800s. Before that time the novel was limited to rather farfetched adventure stories like Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe. In the early 19th century, writing about everyday events was quite out of the ordinary, and Jane was the first to successfully portray the behind the scenes workings of the ladies and gentlemen of the English countryside.Watching a new adaptation of a Jane Austen novel is like seeing Shakespeare's Hamlet, there are no surprises in the final outcome. Rather the entertainment comes in the particular adaptation, actor's skills, and production qualities. Austen's Pride & Prejudice is one of her most popular novels, and each time it has found it's way onto the big screen and into DVD it's created a lot of passion for and against the adaptation.Universal's production has had a number of disappointed viewers as evidenced by many an online review. This disappointment typically seems to stem with having something to do with the casting decisions and the perceived lack of chemistry between the principal players. Conversely, some felt there was too much chemistry, or not enough propriety in the manner in which the Bennet's conducted themselves. Or that the Bennet's were incorrectly shown to be struggling financially and therefore didn't live or dress up to the idealized version of English gentility.To the chemistry of the actors, I believe the casting in Universal's version was excellent. Matthew Macfadyen perfectly portrayed the aloof, shy, yet emotionally caring Mr. Darcy. Keira Knightley is a surprise in this role, for she is able to capture the strong-willed, hastily opinionated and yet free spirited Elizabeth Bennet quite well. But more importantly, this adaptation develops the full picture of the Bennet Family, with all five Bennet girls, with their individual personalities vying for the best dress, or introduction. Both Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennet, and Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet are superb in their timing, and comedic needling of one another. Judi Dench as the controlling Lady Catherine de Bourg, is pleasingly condescending wicked.Screenwriter Deborah Moggach portrayed the Bennet family in a very real and grounded environment. While she may have packaged Austen's novel in a less glamorous light than is typical; she was able to reflect the troubling circumstances people of that time had to deal with.  After all, the financial fix and worry of having five girls with no inheritance in 18th century England was the very point of view and experience that Jane wrote from.Between Director Wright and screenwriter Moggach, this version of Pride & Prejudice is deeply thought-provoking, and portrays the ups and down, moral questions, dilemmas, and hardships of being in society in the 18th century.
summary: Full Picture of the Bennet Family

reviewText: While PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is admittedly gorgeous on almost every visual level, a weak script and strange interpretations by both director and actors mar this otherwise enjoyable film. Joe Wright directs this adaptation of the Jane Austin classic that pairs a country girl lacking looks but loaded with prejudice - played by Keira Knightley - with a city gentleman short on personality but full of pride - played by Matthew Macfadyen. While Wright is true to the period as far as look, he is utterly clueless as far as the manners and customs of the people.So many things that happened left me scratching my head. For example, would the Bennet family really have left their laundry hanging on the line at the beginning of a rainstorm while they stood at the window watching? This may say something about the impracticality of the Bennets; but the way it was handled, it says more about the naivete of the director. Also, people walking in and out of other people's houses and bedrooms unannounced; the grandest lady of the county, Lady Catherine, dropping by unescorted in the middle of the night - and sunburned, no less; a gentleman showing up at dawn to propose, and on foot; everyone getting up from a meal so two people could talk instead of sending them into the parlor: people were more formal and considerate than that in the late 1700's and early 1800's. These types of faux pas break down the credibility of the film and make it less than it could have been.My biggest problem was with the two stars. While Keira Knightly was winsome enough as Elizabeth Bennet, her mischievous smile reminded me of a cat or rat. And since she smiles a lot in the film, I had a hard time warming up to her. Most disappointing, though, was Matthew Macfadyen's downright wooden portrayal of Mr. Darcy. I do believe there is a way to play a character lacking personality without becoming a moribund oaf. Neither actor is particularly attractive in this production, and their odd expressions and mannerisms make them even less so. And their lack of chemistry - even though their relationship is supposed to be alienating and strained - is almost painful. Again, there is a way for two people to act like they dislike each other and still show the telltale signs of a growing attraction. When their love for each other is finally revealed, it seems very unlikely. It certainly isn't emotionally explosive the way the revelation of love between Edward and Elinor in SENSE AND SENSIBILITY was. The supporting cast members give far more interesting performances than the stars, and, in most cases, outshine them.The most redeeming aspect of this film is visual, especially the cinematography, which is stunning. There is one tracking shot at the party which is very clever, and makes us feel we are part of it. It begins with Mr. Bennet closing the keyboard to the piano on Mary who had been indiscreetly singing away, continues through the various rooms and conversations, and ends with Mr. Bennet and Mary making up, with a final tag of Elizabeth outside by herself. The entire shot lasts 3 minutes - it seems longer - and is masterful. Another noteworthy shot - less clever because of its self-consciousness - is one of Elizabeth on a swing in the barn, and we are spinning with her, watching the different scenes outside the barn change as they go flying past. While the technique is interesting, it is disruptive, because we are no longer lost in the story, but have suddenly become aware of the camera and what it is doing - an unforgivable sin in cinematography. Other shots of the sumptuous interiors and breathtaking landscapes are wonderful.Overall, this is a fun and enjoyable film, if you can get past the disconcerting anachronisms. It doesn't rank with Ang Lee and Emma Thompson's SENSE AND SENSIBILITY, which had a far better script, far better acting and very few if any anachronisms. But it is good for what it is: a visual feast.Waitsel Smith
summary: GORGEOUSLY MOUNTED, BUT LACKING THE DRAMATIC DEPTH OF SENSE AND SENSIBILITY

reviewText: I guess I'm in the minority among reviewers, but I'll stick with my opinion that this is a travesty of Austen's matchless novel.  (I'd give it no stars if the system allowed.)  Virtually every production detail -- the costumes, the hair styles, the number of people at the balls, failure to show Darcy's attraction to Lizzy from the first, behavior of individual characters (Bingley's entering Jane's room in the night, Lady Catherine's pounding on the door for a night time visit), the ludicrous sculpture gallery at Pemberley etc. etc. -- is wrong.  The abilities of such actors as Judi Dench and Donald Sutherland are wasted by a script that essentially gives them nothing worthwhile to do.  They are reduced to being little more than set decoration.  A single feature film cannot include everything in the novel, of course (the much praised 1995 BBC production left things out, too), but a better script would more truly reflect the original, and none of the production details listed can be explained as necessary because of the limitations of adaptation.  Even the old Greer Garson-Laurence Olivier film, which is pretty bad, is a better adaptation than this one.  If you want "Pride and Prejudice" in video form, get either of the BBC adaptations for a version far closer to what Austen wrote.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was very prepared to like this film. I wanted to like it. I'd been warned about the liberties it took.  I'd already heard that it had played havoc with Austen's language, pacing and intent.  I'd heard about the pigs, the period inappropriate behavior of the characters, the idiosyncratic scenes such as the midnight arrival of the great Dragon Lady, the bursting into ladies rooms, the list is endless.  I was prepared for all these absurdities, but had also heard that it was cinematically lovely, took chances and the characters were age appropriate. Yet still I was appalled by the reality.In all fairness we've been spoilt by the last 1995 tremendous miniseries adaptation by the BBC. And a 2 hour movie by its very nature cannot do justice to Austen's matchless prose and wit. But it was horrifying to watch an Austen film stripped of subtlety, wit, pace, delicate but biting social observation (there was nothing hinted at here, it's thrown in your face like slop at a pig!) and almost completely denuded of that sublime Austen language.It's difficult to say at whose feet lies the blame for the terrible acting choices, the horrible editing, the nonsensical exposition. Even the music, which at times I enjoyed as it was very reminiscent of Chopin/Beethoven/Mozart is almost too wall to wall and syrupy and turns Austen into mush.I am making a mad dash for my 1995 BBC version to cleanse my palate and am only thankful that I only rented this version.

reviewText: I watched both the 2005 film and the 1995 A&E; version close together in time; both are wonderful - the film manages to achieve almost the same effect in just under half the time. Both are respectful of Austen's novel.The new film version is very very fine. The biggest difference between the two is the space allowed to develop various aspects of character and plot (i.e., in the `95 TV series we see the developments from Lizzie's AND Darcy's points of view, we see them in flashback, sometimes multiple times). But the new film version does an excellent job of conveying the book, even if some scenes must necessarily be omitted. The flashbacks of the A&E; version are an easy way of telegraphing a character's second thoughts, but a really good actor can convey doubt and complexity without this assistance.The hardest character for an actor to portray in Austen's novel is Mr. Darcy. Is he a prideful and arrogant aristocrat who changes -- that is, is he a bad character who grows, develops, and becomes good? Or is he a good character who, from the outset, is at least partly misunderstood? There is evidence to support both interpretations. As we learn, all his family, including his servants, who have known him for his whole life admire his integrity and his kindness. But he certainly gives Elizabeth Bennet reason from the outset to find him cold, distant, and even snobbish. However terrific Colin Firth is in the A&E; version, his representation of the character comes down pretty strongly for change and growth, while Matthew MacFadyen, the hero of the recent film and the sweetest Mr. Darcy you would ever want to meet, keeps the question open. His reserve at the beginning could easily be chalked up to shyness. Both Darcies have much to recommend them. Even though Firth leaves more of the impression of confidence and sharpness that I got from Austen's novel, I think I actually prefer the sweetness of MacFadyen, who does a better job of convincing us that he actually finds Elizabeth attractive from the beginning.I'm not a fan of the actress who plays Elizabeth in the 2005 film -- Keira Knightley (her name rhymes with sprightly, only too conveniently) -- but she does credit, in her odd and energetic way, to Lizzie Bennet, and Donald Sutherland makes a surprisingly good Mr. Bennet (though perhaps not quite so true to the book as Benjamin Whitrow in the A&E; version). As much as I admire Brenda Blethyn in other films she is not great here; she is nothing to the earlier BBC Bennet mother Alison Steadman, who more perfectly captures the mother's hysterics. And I don't think Judi Dench is well cast as Lady Catherine de Bourgh (in the movie); she is just too regal and admirable in her own right; Lady Catherine needs a certain reptilian quality, which Barbara Leigh-Hunt in the A&E; production manages very capably. Also, I must admit that Tom Hollander's Mr. Collins in the 2005 does not hold a candle to the simpering skin-crawling performance of David Bamber in the BBC version of that part. Despite these quibbles, however, the makers of this film had their wits about them. Most importantly, they were not afraid of emotion. Both versions end with a very satisfying and un-Austenlike kiss.The music in this film is lush and engaging; the landscape, notwithwithstanding the opinion of other reviewers, captures the constrained circumstances of the Bennets while remaining appropriately Anglophilic in its attachment to the British countryside and country houses. In short, this new movie manages to convey the essence of the book nearly as well and just as movingly as the excellent A&E; series, which is twice as long.

reviewText: "Pride and Prejudice," Joe Wright's adaptation of the Jane Austen classic, is peculiarly radient in that these sort of adaptations (for instance, the same novel's '95 television miniseries) are always done with an air of leisure, which is, unless handled well, simply another word for intense boredom; not to say director Wright cheapens the novel in any way. In fact, his luminosity only deepens what societal subtext there is, exciting and intriguing the senses with every frame. We can all from here on out exhale with relief at the thought of a period piece that does not meander but instead distills a piece of art to its exuberant soul while also providing an expansive emphasis on society, in this case Victorian-era Britain. Never are the bounds of marriage forgotten, or the lack of money, or the ridiculousness of romanticism in the context of Austen society (Charlotte, heroin Elizabeth Bennet's good friend, at some point says "I can't afford to be romantic" when defending her marriage to the sycophant Mr. Collins, a line that is all the more poignant coming from the fantastic Claudie Blakley).Perhaps what most distinguishes this version of the well-known tale of the Bennet sisters is the casting. I wholeheartedly call it perfect, with each daughter containg their aesthetic qualities and personality quirks as described in the novel. As with most British costume dramas, the supporting cast is pitch-perfect throughout, including Brenda Blethyn and Donald Sutherland as Mr. and Mrs. Bennet. Matthew McFayden plays Darcy convincingly, which is important considering the emotional arc he's called the portray. The biggest surprise, however, is most certainly Keira Knightly, who I expected to be nothing short of a mess but instead gives off the sharp, modest beauty inherent in Elizabeth Bennet.In my recent essay on the novel "Pride and Prejudice" for AP Literature, I concluded in saying that above all Austen makes the point "that all people deserve to love and deserve to be satisfied with who they are and who they grow to be." Joe Wright's largest accomplishment is making me believe said message all over again. Even if the accomplishment is rather minor in terms of cinema (though major when considering that it's a debut), it compells on every level, a quality in film that's been missing for most of the year.

reviewText: In watching this version of Jane Austen's classic novel of love, marriage, and class distinctions of Regency England, all I could think of was that, while pleasing to the eye, Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen were less playing Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Bennet than versions of Heathcliff and Catherine in Emily Bronte's "Wuthering Heights".Knightley's Elizabeth struck me as self important, dramatic, and smug rather than intelligent and full of life. Why was she always snarling, smiling, or generally baring her teeth? MacFadyen's Darcy, rather than proud, alternating between shyness and simply looking like he wanted to cry. Where was the pomposity? The disdain for others around him? I saw none of that.This is not even touching the appalling additions of such things as pigs in the living room and the generally unkempt appearance of the Bennets and their living situation. Mr. Bennet was a bookkeeper, a gentleman. The book states that the Bennets were "not too poor" and still managed to appear well mannered and well groomed despite the lack of funds. So the dirt and the farm animals were unneeded and had no point relevant to the "Pride and Prejudice" I have read. If they were that poor, what would be the point of the fuss made over Lizzie getting her skirt inches in mud on the way to visit Jane? There'd be nothing to remark on, because it would be the norm. And it is not.But back to "Pride and Prejudice" meets "Wuthering Heights". I get the idea was likely to appeal to the greater masses. But the Harlequinesque declarations and outright lack of propriety shown in the film - the flowing hair, the over the top emotion, the schmaltz - is counterproductive to the novel. I could buy the sap in "Wuthering Heights" because Heathcliff and Catherine were both so dramatic on their own that their romance and doom were highlighted by such actions. Mr. Darcy and Lizzie were more circumspect. No less passionate, but their passion lay in their mannerisms and their verbal sparring, not walking around in bare feet, nightgowns, or half-done shirts. No, no, no. Leave that to Emily Bronte, not Jane Austen.As for the rest, no way would single men visit sick single women when they are alone. Reputation, as was one point of the novel, meant everything. Such an action would be scandalous back in the day. A woman would NOT be seen with her hair down. Lizzie would not giggle endlessly and lick her fingers and act as silly as Lydia. No way would Mr. Darcy EVER deliver that letter in the way he did. And the first proposal: the book mentioned Charlotte's parlor. It should have been left at that. The rain was, again, more dramatic, but it did not fit for these characters, especially not at that juncture of their acquaintance. And no way would Lady Catherine go to Longbourn in the dead of night to have it out with Lizzie over her intentions for her nephew. It's all wrong.I am glad for those who enjoy this version, but if the filmmaker wanted over the top romance, he should have left Jane Austen alone and gone with the more lushly romantic aforementioned Emily Bronte. The Bronte-ization of "Pride and Prejudice" left me cold and diluted Jane Austen's observations about love, marriage, society, and money and turned the story into just another romance flick. Give me the A&E; miniseries, please.
summary: Pride and Prejudice is not Wuthering Heights!

reviewText: I'm an avid book reader so I know anytime a book I love is made into a movie, I will probably dislike some portion of it. You can never get everything from a book into a movie & books leave room for imagination. The reader will form a vision of the character in their minds, so when a fan of a writer or a particular novel finds the actor didn't fit that vision, they are unhappy. So I don't doubt that avid Austen readers will find problems with the movie.Looking at it purely from a movie objective. I loved it. I thought it was well acted and written. It very much reminded me of "Sense & Sensibility", which I also loved. I was fortunate, I guess you could say, that I have never read "Pride & Prejudice" so I was left in suspense as to whether Mr. Darcy & Elizabeth would ever be together. This certainly added to my pleasure of the movie. The movie allowed me to get to know all the characters. It definately drew out the romantic dreamer in me and I was crying at the end. I plan to read the book now, and I am sure I will have some opinions as to how the book compares to the movie, but for those that just love a good romantic movie.... watch it!

reviewText: I first read this book in college and loved it, so I have seen all the versions from the silly Lawrence Olivier version to now. My favorite still remains the 1995 Colin Firth version, but this one is also a keeper. Kiera Knightley is wonderful as she has been so far in everything she has played. The scenery alone is well worth the price of the DVD. The settings give you a real flavor of the time - early 1800's - and the muddy way that people lived. No wonder the upper class were revolted by country manners - with a pig that size in the house? Brenda Blethyn does a wonderful job as Mrs. Bennett, as do the four sisters. But, for those of us who know the book by heart, this version is a disappointment. I miss many of the lines I love - they are either missing or thrown away in a mumble. The hair stylist should have done more research as should the writer - I agree that the 'faux pas' - Elizabeth running around in her nightgown - Darcy waltzing into the Collins' whenever he feels like it - are GLARING. It disrupts the reality for those of us who know the manners of that time better. But the real problem with it is Darcy - Darcy has to be cold and haughty, warm and shy, and sexy. MacFayden does angry and appalled, and little else. The director said that he did not want to cast someone too handsome and he certainly has followed through on that. MacFayden could have been cast as one of the farm hands much more easily. Love stories have to be believable - you have to believe that someone as great as Kiera Knightley is going to fall for the guy. With Orlando Bloom this works. But not here - such a shame. Lastly, although I like Donald Sutherland, he plays Mr. Bennett as though he on the edge of senility - Mr. Bennett has a lot of great lines in this story but I'm not surprised that other viewers didn't value them because Sutherland threw them away if he got to say them at all. Read the book, it's funnier.
summary: great scenery, but jane austen is funnier

reviewText: While I am a huge fan and appreciate the quality and content of many BBC productions, this movie is quite possibly the greatest romantic film ever made.  Even though Jane Austin purists may think it is subpar, I advise taking it for its own qualities and strengths.  This rendition of Pride and Prejudice is simply a masterpiece!  Kiera Knightley should have won best actress and this film should have won best film of the year.  The acting by the two leads is exceptional, the musical score is moving, the choreography is beautiful, the storyline terrific, the humor is engaging, and the romance inspiring.  This film holds you in its grip and does not let go.  It is a movie to watch over and over again.  Joe Wright did an outstanding job directing.  (This is far superior to the movie Atonement, by the way).  If you are truly a romantic at heart you cannot miss this movie or deny its intensity.

reviewText: I was skeptical in the beginning, then I read the great reviews as well as some first hand accounts of how good this movie was and I had to see it. In fact, I was pretty excited about it.As we started watching the movie, we were like, "Why can't we understand what they're saying." The first half-hour seemed muffled, then they spoke more clearly.On the movie, I thought it was just OK. This version didn't need to be made. A much better version exists out there and that's the 1995 A&E; version. Too many scenes were shortened to accommodate for time and I think it hurt the movie. I don't think there was chemistry between Lizzy and Mr. Darcy. Lydia's character should have been expanded on as well as Mrs. Bennet to understand these characters. Mr. Wickham was barely there and you don't know how terrible his unless you've read the book. By the other characters telling us his story doesn't help us loathe him the way we should. I could go on but there isn't enough space.On the positive side: the Cinematography was very good and the ending, though completely fabricated, gave it a nice ending, hence the two stars given.

reviewText: I watched this 2005 adaptation of Pride and Prejudice some years ago and then forgot all about it. I guess I wasn't really paying attention to it, and decided to give it another go last night. Now, I am an ardent fan of the BBC adaptation starring Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy and Jennifer Ehle as Elizabeth Bennet,Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996), and the other adaptation I have a fondness for is the one starring David Rintoul as Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Garvie as Elizabeth Bennet,Pride and Prejudice (BBC, 1980). Both are faithful adaptations of the novel and I've worn out my DVDs watching them over and over whenever I have the time.This 2005 adaptation is a film version, so it is predictably an abridged version. It stars Keira Knightley (who does well in period dramas, e.g.The Duchess, andAtonement (Widescreen Edition)) as Elizabeth Bennet, and Matthew McFadyen as Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy. Long-suffering Mr. Bennet is played by Donald Sutherland, and Mrs. Bennet is played by Brenda Blethyn. The other daughters are played by Rosamund Pike (Jane), Jena Malone (Lydia), Carey Mulligan (Kitty), and Talulah Riley (Mary). Elizabeth's best friend, Charlotte Lucas is played by Claudie Blakley (who went on to do an amazing job as Emma Timmins in the beloved BBC series Lark Rise and Candleford.So how does this film version measure up to the full-length BBC series? There is truly no comparison. Many liberties have been taken with the storyline such that the essence of the story is there, but many of the finer nuances of Austen's writing and social commentary is quite lost in translation. Both Knightley and McFadyen deliver credible performances, though Knightley's giggly and bewildered looks do tend to get a tad tiresome after awhile. Mr. and Mrs. Bennet are sufficiently adequate in their roles, but the actors portraying them fail to capture the true essence of these two ridiculous characters, especially in Mrs. Bennet's case. Jena Malone also fails to convince as the flirty, silly, and impulsive Lydia Bennet (she really can't compare to Julia Sawalha's infuriatingly convincing performance in the 1996 BBC adaptation). The actor portraying Mr. Collins delivered a tepid performance. Luckily his counterpart in the movie, Charlotte Lucas nee Collins as played by Blakley, is compelling. Lady Catherine de Bourgh, the snobbish wannabe mother-in-law to Darcy, is well-played by Dame Judi Dench (who never fails to deliver in any of her roles).Despite these flaws and the liberties taken with the plot, I did like this adaptation because of several things. The two leads beguile viewers with their strong chemistry. There's a sexual tension between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy that practically simmers on-screen and draws viewers in. The love-hate relationship and longing that is so evident is credibly portrayed by the two leads, each look, gesture, etc. The cinematography is breathtaking. When I first saw Pemberley in this movie, it just about took my breath away (though the Pemberley featured in the 1996 BBC adaptation will always be my favorite). My favorite outdoors scene in this movie was of Elizabeth standing on the cliffs with the haunting music playing the background...it was just transcendent! Then there's the amazing score. The music is so perfect for this period drama, and Dawn is one of my favorites. The music is memorable and can very well be a classic, just as the score to the 1996 BBC adaptation is.All in all, I was glad I watched this again, and will add this adaptation to my Pride and Prejudice collection.
summary: 3.5* - Many liberties taken here, but the chemistry between the leads sizzles!

reviewText: Okay, here's the deal: if you have read Pride and Prejudice and loved it, do NOT watch this movie unless you want to go on an unrewarding emotional journey: first you will hoot laughing, and then cry in despair,  and then become angry and hurl insults (and possibly rotten garbage) at your dvd player. If you are not a reader and are not a fan of Jane Austen, then you might find this somewhat amusing. I guess. I wouldn't know because I was so outraged by this "adaptation." I like to think of it more as an abomination, because that's what it is. The costumes are awful, the writer's and actors' interpretations of the characters is dreadful, and the whole thing is a hideous mess of a movie.Keira Knightley is fine in movies like "Bend it Like Beckham" and "Pirates," but she cannot carry a true period drama. (By the way, is anyone else distracted by her mouth? It is CONSTANTLY open -- watch for it in "Pirates" as well). Darcy, Bingley, and the Bennett parents barely resemble the characters as Austen wrote them, and Wickham is hardly present! There is NO chemistry between Lizzie and Darcy either. Ugh, the whole thing is just terrible.Do yourself a favor and watch (or re-watch) the A&E; BBC version with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth. Okay, so they made up the scene with Darcy at the pond, but it's a pardonable (and saucy) addition to an otherwise extremely faithful and beautiful rendition of Pride and Prejudice. If you haven't seen the BBC version, by all means skip the Keira Knightley debacle and go straight to the real thing!
